Title: Shrines of Gaiety
Subtitle: A Novel
Summary: London, 1926: a city buzzing with postwar glamour, jazz-soaked nightclubs, and seedy undercurrents of crime and corruption. At the center is Nellie Coker, a ruthless club owner determined to secure a glittering future for her children. Yet ambition and decadence breed enemies, and the Coker empire is shadowed by betrayal, law enforcement, and rival power players. Shrines of Gaiety paints a vivid portrait of an era teetering between gaiety and ruin.
Refined_Long_Summary:
London, 1926. In a country still reeling from the Great War, the city pulses with delirious new nightlife. In Soho's glittering clubs, aristocrats mingle with starlets, foreign dignitaries with gangsters, and girls sell dances for a shilling.

Ruling this intoxicating world is Nellie Coker, ruthless queen of the night who's fiercely ambitious for her six children—including her enigmatic eldest, Niven, whose character was forged in the crucible of the Somme. But success breeds enemies, and Nellie's empire faces threats from all sides.

Beneath Soho's dazzling gaiety lurks a dark underbelly where it's all too easy to become lost. With her signature Dickensian flair, Kate Atkinson opens a window into this vanished world. Slyly funny, brilliantly observant, and ingeniously plotted, Shrines of Gaiety showcases the talents that have made Atkinson one of our most celebrated writers.

Title: Book of Lives
Subtitle: A Memoir of Sorts
Refined_Long_Summary:
Raised by scientifically minded parents, Margaret Atwood spent most of each year in the wild forests of northern Quebec—a vast playground for her entomologist father and independent, resourceful mother. It was an unfettered and nomadic childhood, sometimes isolated but also thrilling and beautiful.

From this unconventional start, Atwood unfolds the story of her life, linking key moments to the books that have shaped our literary landscape. She traces the cruel school year that would become Cat's Eye and the unease of 1980s Berlin, where she began The Handmaid's Tale.

In pages alive with the natural world, reading and books, major political turning points, and her lifelong love for writer Graeme Gibson, we meet poets, bears, Hollywood stars, and larger-than-life characters straight from an Atwood novel. As she explores her past, Atwood reveals the connections between real life and art—and the workings of one of our greatest literary imaginations.
Refined_Short_Summary: The literary icon behind The Handmaid's Tale reflects on her unconventional childhood in the Quebec wilderness and the experiences that shaped her groundbreaking novels. Essential reading for anyone curious about the mind behind dystopian masterpieces.
Refined_Bio: Margaret Atwood is the author of more than fifty books of fiction, poetry, and critical essays. Her novels include Cat's Eye, The Robber Bride, Alias Grace, The Blind Assassin, and the MaddAddam trilogy. Her 1985 classic, The Handmaid's Tale, was followed in 2019 by The Testaments, which won the Booker Prize. She has won numerous awards, including the PEN America Lifetime Achievement Award and was made a member of the Order of the Companions of Honour for services to literature. She lives in Toronto.
Formatted_Quotes:
"Luminous prose, a palpable lust for life, and an invaluable glimpse into the mind of a literary giant make this a must-read."

—Publishers Weekly

"Engaging, wise, and marvelously witty—illuminating both the craft of writing and the art of living."

—Kirkus Reviews

"Atwood's long-awaited memoir covers her arc to becoming one of the leading voices of modern literature."

—New York Magazine

Title: Sunset Park
Subtitle: A Novel
Summary: During the aftermath of the 2008 financial crisis, a group of young squatters in Brooklyn builds a fragile community inside an abandoned house. Among them is Miles Heller, a haunted young man fleeing his past. Against a backdrop of economic collapse and personal reinvention, Paul Auster crafts a moving meditation on love, loss, and the struggle to find meaning in uncertain times.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Sunset Park follows an unforgettable cast of characters brought together during the dark months of the 2008 economic collapse. At the center is Miles Heller, an enigmatic young man working as a trash-out specialist in Florida, obsessively photographing abandoned objects left behind by evicted families.

Miles eventually finds his way to a group of young people squatting in a Brooklyn apartment, where they've created their own fragile community amid the ruins. Their world intersects with the Hospital for Broken Things, which specializes in repairing artifacts of a vanished world, and touches the lives of a celebrated actress preparing for her Broadway return and an independent publisher desperately trying to save both his business and his marriage.

Auster weaves these elements together in an immensely moving meditation on contemporary America and its ghosts, exploring how people forge connections and meaning in the aftermath of personal and economic devastation.
Refined_Short_Summary: Young squatters create a makeshift family in an abandoned Brooklyn house during the 2008 financial crisis. Auster captures the fragile hope and resilience of a generation rebuilding from the ruins.
Refined_Bio: Paul Auster (1947–2024) was the bestselling author of 4 3 2 1, Sunset Park, The Book of Illusions, Moon Palace, and The New York Trilogy, among many other works. In 2006, he was awarded the Prince of Asturias Prize for Literature. His other honors included the Prix Médicis étranger for Leviathan, the Independent Spirit Award for the screenplay of Smoke, the Los Angeles Times Book Prize for Burning Boy, and the Carlos Fuentes Prize for his body of work. His most recent novel, 4 3 2 1, was shortlisted for the Man Booker Prize. He was a member of the American Academy of Arts and Letters and a Commandeur de l'Ordre des Arts et des Lettres.
Formatted_Quotes:
"With a plot that encompasses war in the Middle East, economic recession and the perils of the publishing industry, a contemporary vitality distinguishes the latest from the veteran author…. Sure to please Auster fans and likely to attract new readers as well."

—Kirkus

"Passionately literary… every element is saturated with implication as each wounded, questing character's story illuminates our tragic flaws and profound need for connection, coherence, and beauty. In a time of daunting crises and change, Auster reminds us of lasting things, of love, art, and 'the miraculous strangeness of being alive.'"

—Donna Seaman, Booklist

"Auster deftly balances minute details that evoke New York City, post-financial meltdown, with marvelously drawn characters bruised but unbowed by life's vicissitudes. He has an impressive array of literary nominations to his credit, but this should be the novel that brings him a broader readership."

—Sally Bissell, Library Journal

Long_Summary:
Sunset Park follows the hopes and fears of a cast of unforgettable characters brought together by the mysterious Miles Heller during the dark months of the 2008 economic collapse.

An enigmatic young man employed as a trash-out worker in southern Florida obsessively photographing thousands of abandoned objects left behind by the evicted families.

A group of young people squatting in an apartment in Sunset Park, Brooklyn.

The Hospital for Broken Things, which specializes in repairing the artifacts of a vanished world.

William Wyler's 1946 classic The Best Years of Our Lives.

A celebrated actress preparing to return to Broadway.

An independent publisher desperately trying to save his business and his marriage.

These are just some of the elements Auster magically weaves together in this immensely moving novel about contemporary America and its ghosts.

Title: The Last Animal
Subtitle: A Novel
Summary: When a scientist mother and her two daughters stumble upon a chance to bring back the woolly mammoth, their lives spiral into an adventure that blurs boundaries between grief, discovery, and family resilience. The Last Animal is a heartfelt, witty novel about the wonders of science and the enduring strength of human connection.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Teenage sisters Eve and Vera never imagined their summer vacation would be spent in the Arctic, tagging along on their mother's scientific expedition. But there's a lot about their lives lately that hasn't been going as planned, and their single mother might not be so happy either.

Now in Siberia with a bunch of serious biologists, Eve and Vera are just bored enough to cause trouble. Fooling around in the permafrost, they accidentally discover a perfectly preserved, four-thousand-year-old baby mammoth, and things finally start to get interesting.

The discovery sets off a surprising chain of events, leading mother and daughters to go rogue, pinging from the slopes of Siberia to the shores of Iceland to an exotic animal farm in Italy. What follows is a wild journey that explores the possibilities and perils of human imagination on a changing planet, what it's like to be a woman in a field dominated by men, and how a wondrous discovery can best be enjoyed with family—even teenagers.
Refined_Short_Summary: Two bored teenagers accidentally discover a perfectly preserved baby mammoth in Siberia, launching their scientist mother and them on a globe-hopping adventure that could change everything. A witty, heartwarming story perfect for fans of Tomorrow and Tomorrow and Tomorrow.
Refined_Bio: Ramona Ausubel is the author of two novels and two story collections, including Awayland and Sons and Daughters of Ease and Plenty. Winner of the PEN Center USA Literary Award for Fiction and the VCU Cabell First Novelist Award, she has been long-listed for the Story Prize. Her work has appeared in The New Yorker, The New York Times, and NPR's Selected Shorts.
Formatted_Quotes:
"I know it's hard to imagine, but The Last Animal by Ramona Ausubel, is like a sweeter, more poignant version of 'Jurassic Park. . .' This shaggy elephant story is as much about surviving family grief as it is about living in a world doomed by climate change. And yet, The Last Animal takes flight with all the improbable buoyancy of a pterodactyl."

—Ron Charles, CBS

"Every family, after all, goes extinct eventually. The paradox that this novel confronts with such tender sympathy and humor is how to love the time we have left."

—The Washington Post

"This extraordinary story hops the globe, combining wild adventures aimed at reversing climate change with a fullhearted portrait of sisterhood, family and the ways we process grief. Charming, wry and original."

—People
Short_Summary: When a scientist mother and her two daughters stumble upon a chance to bring back the woolly mammoth, their lives spiral into an adventure that blurs boundaries between grief, discovery, and family resilience. The Last Animal is a heartfelt, witty novel about the wonders of science and the enduring strength of human connection.

Now in Siberia with a bunch of serious biologists, Eve and Vera are just bored enough to cause trouble. The discovery sets off a surprising chain of events, leading mother and daughters to go rogue, pinging from the slopes of Siberia to the shores of Iceland to an exotic animal farm in Italy, and resulting in the birth of a creature that could change the world—or at least this family.

The Last Animal takes readers on a wild, entertaining, and refreshingly different kind of journey, one that explores the possibilities and perils of the human imagination on a changing planet, what it’s like to be a woman in a field dominated by men, and how a wondrous discovery can best be enjoyed with family. Even teenagers.

Title: Strangers to Ourselves
Subtitle: Unsettled Minds and the Stories That Make Us
Summary: Through intimate case studies and her own history, Aviv probes the narratives people use to make sense of mental illness, challenging the boundaries between sickness and selfhood.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Strangers to Ourselves poses fundamental questions about how we understand ourselves in periods of crisis and distress. Drawing on deep, original reporting as well as unpublished journals and memoirs, Rachel Aviv writes about people who have come up against the limits of psychiatric explanations for who they are.

She follows an Indian woman celebrated as a saint who lives in healing temples in Kerala; an incarcerated mother vying for her children's forgiveness after recovering from psychosis; a man who devotes his life to seeking revenge upon his psychoanalysts; and an affluent young woman who, after a decade of defining herself through her diagnosis, decides to go off her meds because she doesn't know who she is without them.

Animated by profound empathy, Aviv's exploration is refracted through her own account of living in a hospital ward at age six and meeting a fellow patient with whom her life runs parallel—until it no longer does. Aviv asks how the stories we tell about mental disorders shape their course in our lives and our identities. Challenging how we understand and talk about illness, her account is a testament to the porousness and resilience of the mind.
Refined_Short_Summary: When psychiatric explanations fall short, who are we really? This deeply empathetic exploration follows people navigating mental illness across cultures and circumstances. Perfect for readers moved by Susanna Kaysen's Girl, Interrupted.
Refined_Bio: Rachel Aviv is a staff writer at The New Yorker, where she writes about medicine, education, and criminal justice. In 2022, she won a National Magazine Award for Profile Writing. A 2019 national fellow at New America, she received a Whiting Creative Nonfiction Grant to support her work on this book. She lives in Brooklyn.
Formatted_Quotes:
"In this penetrating, landmark book, Rachel Aviv investigates what she calls the 'psychic hinterlands,' drawing on her customary vivid reporting and her own extraordinary personal story to pose unsettling questions about the ways in which we reckon with mental illness by categorizing it, diagnosing it, giving it a name. Threading together the intimate and emotionally shattering stories of a series of very different people who have struggled to live with and to understand their own psychological afflictions, Aviv has created an arresting work of profound empathy and insight."

―Patrick Radden Keefe, author of Say Nothing and Empire of Pain

"Intimate and revelatory . . . attuned to subtlety and complexity . . . This isn't an anti-psychiatry book― Aviv is too aware of the specifics of any situation to succumb to anything so sweeping and polemical . . . a book-length demonstration of Aviv's extraordinary ability to hold space for the 'uncertainty, mysteries and doubts' of others."

―Jennifer Szalai, New York Times

"Aviv writes with an unpredictable mixture of intimacy and distance, exploring how psychiatric language often alters what it names. She has assembled a remarkable archive of unpublished materials―memoirs, poems, journals (including her own)―that offers a visceral counterpoint to the official languages of institutions and expertise. I admire her rigor and eloquence but also her restraint―she makes vivid experiences we can't explain."

―Ben Lerner, author of The Topeka School

Title: Dayswork
Subtitle: A Novel
Summary: Blending biography, essay, and fiction, Dayswork traces a writer’s fascination with Herman Melville through the lens of pandemic life. It’s a meditation on marriage, literature, and the strange interplay between daily life and art.
Refined_Long_Summary:
During the endless days of the pandemic, a woman spends her time sorting fact from fiction in the life and work of Herman Melville. As she delves into Melville's impulsive purchase of a Massachusetts farmhouse, his fevered revision of Moby-Dick there, his intense friendship with neighbor Nathaniel Hawthorne, and his troubled marriage to Elizabeth Shaw, she becomes increasingly obsessed by what his devotion to his art reveals about cost, worth, and debt.

Her preoccupation deepens and expands, extending outward to an orbiting cast of Melvillean questers and fanatics, as well as to biographers and writers—among them Elizabeth Hardwick and Robert Lowell—whose lives resonate with Melville's. As she pulls these distant figures close, her quarantine quest ultimately becomes a midlife reckoning with her own marriage and ambition.

Absorbing, charming, and intimate, Dayswork considers the blurry lines between life and literature, the slippage between what happens and what gets recorded, and the ways we locate ourselves in the lives of others.
Refined_Short_Summary: During pandemic isolation, a woman's deep dive into Herman Melville's life becomes an unexpected reckoning with her own marriage and artistic ambitions. Literary fiction lovers and anyone fascinated by creative obsession will be captivated.
Refined_Bio: Chris Bachelder is the author of four novels, including National Book Award finalist The Throwback Special. He lives in Cincinnati, Ohio. Jennifer Habel is the author of the poetry collections Good Reason and The Book of Jane, which won the Iowa Poetry Prize. She lives in Cincinnati, Ohio.
Formatted_Quotes:
"A love letter to literature."

—Alexander Chee, author of How to Write an Autobiographical Novel

"Dayswork is a wonder. I cannot think of another book, another reading experience, entirely like this one. It is suffused with the pleasures of reading, of immersion, of companionship in all its forms."

—Katie Kitamura, author of Intimacies

"I was equally charmed and fascinated by Dayswork, this slender but capacious book about marriage and solitude, about Melville and Hawthorne, about literature and obsession and whether they might not be the same thing. Wry, intimate, and wholly original, the novel surprised me and edified me with every page I eagerly turned."

—Jess Walter, author of Beautiful Ruins

Title: The Sense of an Ending
Summary: Tony Webster, an ordinary man, reflects on his youth, his first love, and a past that resurfaces decades later with unexpected consequences. Quietly devastating, The Sense of an Ending is a meditation on memory, regret, and the stories we tell ourselves.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Tony Webster thought he'd left his past behind. Now in his sixties, settled into the comfortable rhythms of retirement and an amicable divorce, he's built a quiet life far removed from the intensity of his youth. But when he receives a mysterious legacy, Tony is forced to confront memories he'd buried and friendships he'd rather forget.

As he revisits his school days and first love, Tony discovers that his recollections may not be as reliable as he believed. The return of figures from his past—one tragically from beyond the grave—unravels the careful story he's told himself about who he is and what really happened all those years ago.

With devastating precision, Barnes crafts a psychological puzzle that forces both Tony and readers to question the nature of memory itself. What we remember, what we choose to forget, and how we reconstruct our histories to live with ourselves become the driving forces of this quietly explosive novel that demands to be read in one sitting.
Refined_Short_Summary: When a mysterious inheritance forces Tony Webster to revisit his past, he discovers his memories aren't as reliable as he thought. This quietly devastating exploration of regret and self-deception will appeal to readers who loved Kazuo Ishiguro's haunting examinations of memory.
Refined_Bio: Julian Barnes is the author of twenty-five books and recipient of the Man Booker Prize, Somerset Maugham Award, E. M. Forster Award from the American Academy of Arts and Letters, Prix Médicis and Prix Femina in France, and the Jerusalem Prize. In 2017 he was awarded the Légion d'honneur. His work has been translated into more than forty languages. He lives in London.

"Dense with philosophical ideas . . . it manages to create genuine suspense as a sort of psychological detective story . . . Unpeeling the onion layers of the hero's life while showing how [he] has sliced and diced his past in order to create a self he can live with."

—Michiko Kakutani, The New York Times

"An elegantly composed, quietly devastating tale about memory, aging, time and remorse. . . . Offers somber insights into life's losses, mistakes and disappointments in a piercing, thought provoking narrative. Bleak as this may sound, the key word here—the note of encouragement—is 'insights.' And this beautiful book is full of them."

—NPR

"With his characteristic grace and skill, Barnes manages to turn this cat-and-mouse game into something genuinely suspenseful."

—The Washington Post
Short_Summary: Tony Webster, an ordinary man, reflects on his youth, his first love, and a past that resurfaces decades later with unexpected consequences. Quietly devastating, The Sense of an Ending is a meditation on memory, regret, and the stories we tell ourselves.
Long_Summary:
This intense new novel follows a middle-aged man as he contends with a past he has never much thought about—until his closest childhood friends return with a vengeance, one of them from the grave, another maddeningly present. Tony Webster thought he’d left all this behind as he built a life for himself, and by now his marriage and family and career have fallen into an amicable divorce and retirement. But he is then presented with a mysterious legacy that obliges him to reconsider a variety of things he thought he’d understood all along, and to revise his estimation of his own nature and place in the world.

A novel so compelling that it begs to be read in a single sitting, with stunning psychological and emotional depth and sophistication, The Sense of an Ending is a brilliant new chapter in Julian Barnes’s oeuvre.

Title: Old God's Time
Subtitle: A Novel
Summary: Retired policeman Tom Kettle seeks quiet in a remote coastal home, but the past—personal grief and old investigations—refuses to leave him in peace. Old God’s Time is a lyrical, haunting story about trauma, memory, and the long shadow of violence.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Recently retired policeman Tom Kettle is settling into the quiet of his new home, a lean-to annexed to a Victorian castle overlooking the Irish Sea. For months he has barely seen a soul, catching only glimpses of his eccentric landlord and a nervous young mother who has moved in next door.

Occasionally, fond memories return of his family: his beloved wife June and their two children, Winnie and Joe. But when two former colleagues turn up at his door with questions about a decades-old case—one which Tom never quite came to terms with—he finds himself pulled into the darkest currents of his past.

A beautiful, haunting novel in which nothing is quite as it seems, Old God's Time explores what we live through, what we live with, and what may survive of us.
Refined_Short_Summary: When a retired Irish policeman's peaceful solitude is shattered by questions about an old case, buried secrets threaten to unravel everything. Literary fiction fans who loved The Midnight Library's exploration of memory and regret will be captivated.
Refined_Bio: Sebastian Barry was born in Dublin in 1955. He is the author of eight previous novels and numerous plays. He is the first novelist to twice win the Costa Book of the Year award, for Days Without End and The Secret Scripture, has twice been shortlisted for the Booker Prize, for A Long Long Way and The Secret Scripture, and has twice been longlisted for Days Without End and On Canaan's Side. He was the Laureate for Irish Fiction from 2018–2021, and lives in County Wicklow, Ireland.
Formatted_Quotes:
"Few contemporary writers have done more with the natural resource of Irish English, or with the buried tensions at the heart of Irish identity, than [Barry] . . . A writer of almost Joycean amplitude, Barry never segregates the comic and the tragic . . . What's striking about Old God's Time is the scrupulous realism that Barry brings to his outlandish premise—and his guileful refusal ever to clarify what kind of novel we are reading . . . Barry's [prose is] casually exquisite."

—Giles Harvey, The New Yorker

"Marvelous . . . Barry reaches deep into the messenger bag of mystery fiction and turns the whole business inside out to show the soft suede of its lining and the loosening stitches of the seams . . . The story plays out in ways that repeatedly surprise, but its twists and turns are less important than its steady emotional beats, which elegantly braid the long work of mourning to the mere fact of love. As always, Barry is a prose stylist of near-miraculous skill, turning out crystalline sentence after crystalline sentence without ever leaving or betraying his protagonist's perspective. His is an aphoristic imagination, and almost every chapter ends with a revelatory pirouette."

—The Washington Post

"Few can write like Sebastian Barry, there is a real thrill as each sentence unfolds. Old God's Time is a portrait of a good man facing the failings of his past. It is wonderfully alive because Barry is so attuned to the human condition, to the poetry in ordinary lives. Full of love and grief and heartache, this is an unforgettable novel from one of our finest writers."

—Douglas Stuart, author of Shuggie Bain & Young Mungo

Title: Ducks
Subtitle: Two Years in the Oil Sands
Summary: A searing graphic memoir of two years in Alberta’s oil sands: danger, loneliness, and the calculus women make to get by. Beaton’s wit and candor turn industrial boomtown life into an unforgettable reckoning.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Before there was Kate Beaton, New York Times bestselling cartoonist of Hark! A Vagrant, there was Katie Beaton from Cape Breton—specifically Mabou, a tight-knit seaside community where lobster is as abundant as beaches, fiddles, and Gaelic folk songs.

With the singular goal of paying off her student loans, Katie heads west to Alberta's oil rush, joining the long tradition of East Coasters seeking work when they can't find it in the homeland they love. In the oil sands, Katie encounters harsh realities where trauma is everyday occurrence yet never discussed.

Beaton's natural cartooning prowess shines as she draws colossal machinery and mammoth vehicles against a sublime Albertan backdrop of wildlife, northern lights, and boreal forest. Her first full-length graphic narrative tells an untold story of Canada: a country that prides itself on egalitarian values and natural beauty while simultaneously exploiting both the riches of its land and the humanity of its people.
Refined_Short_Summary: When student debt drives Katie Beaton to Alberta's oil fields, she discovers a brutal world of isolation and survival. This raw graphic memoir exposes the human cost of Canada's resource economy with devastating honesty.
Refined_Bio: Kate Beaton is a cartoonist from Mabou, Unama'ki-Cape Breton and New York Times bestselling author of Ducks: Two Years in the Oilsands, Hark! A Vagrant, Step Aside, Pops, and picture books The Princess and the Pony and King Baby. She executive produced Pinecone & Pony for AppleTV+. Her work has won multiple Eisner, Doug Wright, Harvey and Ignatz awards. Ducks won Canada Reads 2023, was chosen as one of Barack Obama's favorite books of 2022, and landed on best-of-year lists from Time, The New Yorker, The Washington Post, and the New York Times.
Formatted_Quotes:
"An exceptionally beautiful book about loneliness, labor, and survival. Beaton is a thoughtful guide through a complex landscape of class and gender, and these pages ache with grief and grace."

—Carmen Maria Machado, author of In the Dream House

"A masterpiece, a heartbreak, a nightlight shining in the dark."

—Patricia Lockwood, author of No One Is Talking About This

"Ducks is both a coming-of-age narrative and a skillful, subtle commentary on class, misogyny, and the human costs of environmental extraction. From the oil fields to the hallways of worker housing, Kate Beaton's comics are rich with quiet revelations, intimate details, and a deadpan, devastating sense of humor. A generous and illuminating book; I suspect it will stay on my mind for a very long time."

—Anna Wiener, author of Uncanny Valley
Short_Summary: A searing graphic memoir of two years in Alberta’s oil sands: danger, loneliness, and the calculus women make to get by. Beaton’s wit and candor turn industrial boomtown life into an unforgettable reckoning.
Long_Summary:
Before there was Kate Beaton, New York Times bestselling cartoonist of Hark! A Vagrant, there was Katie Beaton of the Cape Breton Beaton, specifically Mabou, a tight-knit seaside community where the lobster is as abundant as beaches, fiddles, and Gaelic folk songs. With the singular goal of paying off her student loans, Katie heads out west to take advantage of Alberta’s oil rush—part of the long tradition of East Coasters who seek gainful employment elsewhere when they can’t find it in the homeland they love so much. Katie encounters the harsh reality of life in the oil sands, where trauma is an everyday occurrence yet is never discussed.

Beaton’s natural cartooning prowess is on full display as she draws colossal machinery and mammoth vehicles set against a sublime Albertan backdrop of wildlife, northern lights, and boreal forest. Her first full length graphic narrative, Ducks: Two Years in the Oil Sands is an untold story of Canada: a country that prides itself on its egalitarian ethos and natural beauty while simultaneously exploiting both the riches of its land and the humanity of its people.

Title: The Sellout
Subtitle: A Novel
Summary: A biting satire of race and politics in America, The Sellout follows a Black man in Los Angeles who reinstitutes segregation and slavery as social experiments. Outrageous, darkly funny, and razor-sharp, it skewers hypocrisy and questions cultural taboos.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Born in the "agrarian ghetto" of Dickens on the southern outskirts of Los Angeles, our narrator has resigned himself to a lower-middle-class fate: dying in the same bedroom where he grew up, staring at earthquake cracks in the ceiling. Raised by a single father—a controversial sociologist—he spent his childhood as a subject in racially charged psychological studies, promised that his father's work would become a lucrative memoir.

When his father is killed in a police shoot-out, he discovers the memoir never existed. All that remains is the bill for a drive-thru funeral.

Fueled by this betrayal and his hometown's decay, the narrator discovers an even greater insult: Dickens has been literally erased from the map to save California embarrassment. Enlisting help from the town's most famous resident—Hominy Jenkins, the last surviving Little Rascal—he launches the most outrageous plan imaginable: reinstating slavery and segregating the local high school.

This audacious scheme lands him before the Supreme Court in Paul Beatty's brilliant satire that skewers the Constitution, urban life, civil rights, father-son relationships, and the holy grail of racial equality.
Refined_Short_Summary: When his California hometown gets erased from the map, a man decides to put it back by reinstating slavery and segregating the high school. This satirical masterpiece tackles race in America with the sharp wit of Dave Chappelle meets the literary brilliance of Invisible Man.
Refined_Bio: Paul Beatty is the author of four novels—The Sellout, Slumberland, Tuff, and The White Boy Shuffle—and two books of poetry: Big Bank Take Little Bank and Joker, Joker, Deuce. He is the editor of Hokum: An Anthology of African-American Humor. He lives in New York City.
Formatted_Quotes:
"The first 100 pages of [Paul Beatty's] new novel, The Sellout, are the most caustic and the most badass first 100 pages of an American novel I've read in at least a decade."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

"The Sellout isn't just one of the most hilarious American novels in years, it also might be the first truly great satirical novel of the century . . . [It] is a comic masterpiece, but it's much more than just that-it's one of the smartest and most honest reflections on race and identity in America in a very long time."

—Michael Schaub, NPR

"[The Sellout] is among the most important and difficult American novels written in the 21st century . . . It is a bruising novel that readers will likely never forget."

—Kiese Laymon, Los Angeles Times
Short_Summary: A biting satire about a young man's isolated upbringing and the race trial that sends him to the Supreme Court
Long_Summary:
Born in the "agrarian ghetto" of Dickens—on the southern outskirts of Los Angeles—the narrator of The Sellout resigns himself to the fate of lower-middle-class Californians: "I'd die in the same bedroom I'd grown up in, looking up at the cracks in the stucco ceiling that've been there since the '68 quake." Raised by a single father, a controversial sociologist, he spent his childhood as the subject in racially charged psychological studies. He is told that his father's work will lead to a memoir that will solve their financial woes. But when his father is killed in a police shoot-out, he realizes there never was a memoir. All that's left is the bill for a drive-thru funeral.
Fueled by this deceit and the general disrepair of his hometown, the narrator sets out to right another wrong: Dickens has literally been removed from the map to save California further embarrassment. Enlisting the help of the town's most famous resident—the last surviving Little Rascal, Hominy Jenkins—he initiates the most outrageous action conceivable: reinstating slavery and segregating the local high school, which lands him in front of the Supreme Court.
Paul Beatty's The Sellout showcases a comic genius at the top of his game. It challenges the sacred tenets of the U.S. Constitution, urban life, the civil rights movement, the father-son relationship, and the holy grail of racial equality—the black Chinese restaurant.

Title: Are You My Mother?
Subtitle: A Comic Drama
Summary: A searching, layered graphic memoir of Bechdel’s relationship with her mother, weaving psychoanalysis, literature, and family history into a moving meditation on love and creativity.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Following her groundbreaking Fun Home, Alison Bechdel turns her artistic lens toward an even more complex relationship: her mother. This brilliant graphic memoir explores a woman who was a voracious reader, music lover, and passionate amateur actor—but also someone trapped in an unhappy marriage to a closeted man, whose own artistic dreams simmered beneath the surface.

When Bechdel was seven, her mother stopped touching or kissing her goodnight forever, creating a gulf that would define their relationship. With her signature blend of humor and heartbreak, Bechdel embarks on a quest to understand this distance between them.

Her search weaves through fascinating territory: the work of psychoanalyst Donald Winnicott, an illuminating Dr. Seuss illustration, and Bechdel's own adult relationships. This richly layered investigation ultimately leads back to her mother and toward a fragile, real-time truce that will resonate with anyone who has navigated the complex terrain of loving a gifted but distant parent.
Refined_Short_Summary: Bechdel follows up her masterpiece Fun Home with an equally stunning exploration of her relationship with her artistically gifted but emotionally distant mother. Perfect for readers who loved Crying in H Mart's family complexity.
Refined_Bio: Alison Bechdel's cult following for her comic strip Dykes to Watch Out For expanded wildly with her family memoirs, including the New York Times bestselling Fun Home, adapted into a Tony Award–winning musical, and Are You My Mother? Her recent work The Secret to Superman Strength was named a New York Times Best Graphic Novel of 2021. Bechdel is a MacArthur Fellow among many other honors.
Short_Summary: From the best-selling author of Fun Home, Time magazine’s No. 1 Book of the Year, a brilliantly told graphic memoir of Alison Bechdel becoming the artist her mother wanted to be.
Long_Summary: Alison Bechdel’s Fun Home was a pop culture and literary phenomenon. Now, a second thrilling tale of filial sleuthery, this time about her mother: voracious reader, music lover, passionate amateur actor. Also a woman, unhappily married to a closeted gay man, whose artistic aspirations simmered under the surface of Bechdel's childhood . . . and who stopped touching or kissing her daughter good night, forever, when she was seven. Poignantly, hilariously, Bechdel embarks on a quest for answers concerning the mother-daughter gulf. It's a richly layered search that leads readers from the fascinating life and work of the iconic twentieth-century psychoanalyst Donald Winnicott, to one explosively illuminating Dr. Seuss illustration, to Bechdel’s own (serially monogamous) adult love life. And, finally, back to Mother—to a truce, fragile and real-time, that will move and astonish all adult children of gifted mothers.
Copy_Bio: Alison Bechdel’s cult following for her early comic strip Dykes to Watch Out For expanded wildly for her family memoirs, the New York Times bestselling and Time magazine #1 Book of the Year graphic memoir Fun Home, adapted into a Tony Award–winning musical, and Are You My Mother? Most recently, The Secret to Superman Strength was named a New York Times Best Graphic Novel of 2021. Bechdel has been named a MacArthur Fellow, among many other honors.
Copy_Quotes:
"Sad, funny, sprawling graphic memoir...An intensely personal, specific story, but Bechdel's imaginative narrative techniques make it easily as compelling as any fiction...Its stylistic flexibility accomodates more layers than any straight documentary or prose memoir could support...This work is her link in the long chain connecting her foremothers and their daughters and all of the other women who shaped her."—The Atlantic

"...Magnificent... Whatever issues Bechdel has with her mother, one always has the sense that she likes her as much as she loves her. That affection — and the real sense one gets of her mother reading these pages, running her finger over the tenderly drawn panels of their history — gives this book an urgency and an intimacy that Fun Home, in retrospect, lacked... Bechdel's triumph is not just that she's emerged from her tunnel, with weary but clear eyes, but that she's brought her mother with her. Grade: A"—Entertainment Weekly

"...Are You My Mother is as complicated, brainy, inventive and satisfying as the finest prose memoirs...The tragedy and comedy are so entwined, so gloriously balanced, the reader can't help being fascinated. The book delivers lightening bolts of revelation...I haven't encountered a book about being an artist, or about the punishing entanglements of mothers and daughters, as engaging, profound or original as this one in a long time. In fact, the book made such a deep impression on me that after reading it I walked around for days seeing little bits and snatches of my life as Alison Bechdel drawings."—The New York Times
Awards_&_Accolades: Named — Time Magazine Top 10 Book of the Year (2012)
Contributor_Bio_(Raw_from_PDF): Alison Bechdel is a cartoonist and MacArthur Fellow, author of the acclaimed graphic memoir Fun Home and creator of the long-running comic strip Dykes to Watch Out For.

Title: The Talk
BISAC_Category_Description: Comics & Graphic Novels / Nonfiction / Biography & Memoir
Summary: A powerful graphic memoir exploring the personal and political weight of ‘the Talk’ Black parents give their children, blending autobiography with commentary on race and America.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Darrin Bell was six years old when his mother told him he couldn't play with a white friend's realistic water gun. She explained that police tend to see little Black boys as older and less innocent than they really are, making him far more likely to be shot than his friend.

Bell examines how "the talk" has shaped nearly every moment of his life into adulthood and fatherhood. Through evocative original illustrations, this graphic memoir chronicles his painful awakening to being regarded as dangerous by white teachers, neighbors, and strangers—and his growing awareness of his own mortality.

Drawing attention to the brutal murders of Trayvon Martin, Eric Garner, George Floyd, and Breonna Taylor, Bell weaves his personal story with his award-winning editorial cartoons. The narrative builds to a moment of reckoning when nationwide protests erupted and Bell faced giving "the talk" to his own six-year-old son.
Refined_Short_Summary: Through stunning illustrations and raw honesty, Pulitzer Prize-winning cartoonist Darrin Bell chronicles how "the talk" about police violence shaped his entire life. Essential reading for anyone moved by works like Between the World and Me.
Refined_Bio: Darrin Bell is a Pulitzer Prize-winning cartoonist and recipient of the 2016 Berryman Award for Editorial Cartooning, 2015 RFK Award for Editorial Cartooning, and UC Berkeley's 2015 Daily Californian Alumni of the Year Award. He cocreated the comic strip Rudy Park and launched Candorville, syndicated by Washington Post Writers Group. His editorial cartoons are syndicated by King Features, and he's a contributing cartoonist for the New Yorker. He lives in California with his wife and four children.
Formatted_Quotes:
"A Pulitzer Prize-winning cartoonist draws on his childhood in Los Angeles to explore racism on a deeply personal level. There's a poignancy, too, in the cyclical nature of the story: Bell, now a father, is wrestling with the same questions his own parents face."

—The New York Times

"A stunning account of a young Black man navigating his way through Los Angeles and Berkeley in the 1980s and '90s, into life as a successful professional and father. The illustrations, fluctuating from the whimsically cartoonish to the painterly, are as multi-tiered and engrossing as Bell's narrative voice. Like Alison Bechdel's Fun Home and Marjane Satrapi's Persepolis, this epic portrait of an artist is destined for iconic status."

—NPR

"A beautifully drawn book, rich with insight, humor, and hard-won knowledge."

—Kirkus
Short_Summary: A powerful graphic memoir exploring the personal and political weight of ‘the Talk’ Black parents give their children, blending autobiography with commentary on race and America.
Long_Summary:
Darrin Bell was six years old when his mother told him he couldn’t play with a white friend’s realistic water gun. “She told me I’m a lot more likely to be shot by police than my friend was if they saw me with it, because police tend to think little Black boys—even light-skinned ones—are older than they really are, and less innocent than they really are.”

Bell examines how “the talk” has shaped nearly every moment of his life into adulthood and fatherhood. Through evocative original illustrations, The Talk is a meditation on this coming-of-age—as Bell becomes painfully aware of being regarded as dangerous by white teachers, neighbors, and strangers, and thus of his mortality. Drawing attention to the brutal murders of African Americans like Trayvon Martin and Eric Garner, and showcasing his award-winning cartoons along the way, Bell takes us up to the very moment of reckoning when people took to the streets protesting the murders of George Floyd and Breonna Taylor and when he must have “the talk” with a six-year-old son of his own.
Copy_Bio: Darrin Bell, recipient of the 2016 Berryman Award for Editorial Cartooning, the 2015 RFK Award for Editorial Cartooning, and UC Berkeley’s 2015 Daily Californian Alumni of the Year Award, began his career in 1995 at the age of twenty. While serving as the Daily Californian’s staff cartoonist, he began freelancing for the Opinion pages of the Los Angeles Times, San Francisco Chronicle, and Oakland Tribune. In 1997, he cocreated the comic strip Rudy Park and self-syndicated it to technology magazines. United Media launched it into newspapers in 2001. In 2003, Darrin launched his other comic strip, Candorville, in newspapers via the Washington Post Writers Group (WPWG), which also began syndicating his editorial cartoons in 2013. While WPWG still syndicates Candorville and Rudy Park, Darrin moved his editorial cartoons to King Features Syndicate in late 2018. He’s also a contributing cartoonist for the New Yorker. Darrin lives with his wife and four children in California.
Copy_Quotes:
“A Pulitzer Prize-winning cartoonist draws on his childhood in Los Angeles to explore racism on a deeply personal level. There’s a poignancy, too, in the cyclical nature of the story: Bell, now a father, is wrestling with the same questions his own parents face.“—The New York Times

“A stunning account of a young Black man navigating his way through Los Angeles and Berkeley in the 1980s and '90s, into life as a successful professional and father. The illustrations, fluctuating from the whimsically cartoonish to the painterly, are as multi-tiered and engrossing as Bell's narrative voice. Like Alison Bechdel's Fun Home and Marjane Satrapi's Persepolis, this epic portrait of an artist is destined for iconic status.“—NPR

“A beautifully drawn book, rich with insight, humor, and hard-won knowledge.“—Kirkus

Title: The Vanishing Half
Subtitle: A GMA Book Club Pick (A Novel)
Summary: Twin sisters in a small Black Southern community choose radically different lives: one passes as white, the other stays rooted in her origins. The Vanishing Half explores identity, family, and the costs of secrets across generations.
Refined_Long_Summary:
The Vignes twin sisters will always be identical. But after growing up together in a small, southern Black community and running away at age sixteen, their adult lives couldn't be more different. Many years later, one sister lives with her Black daughter in the same southern town she once tried to escape. The other secretly passes for white, and her white husband knows nothing of her past.

Still, even separated by so many miles and just as many lies, the fates of the twins remain intertwined. What will happen to the next generation, when their own daughters' storylines intersect?

Weaving together multiple strands and generations of this family, from the Deep South to California, from the 1950s to the 1990s, Brit Bennett produces a story that is at once a riveting, emotional family saga and a brilliant exploration of the American history of passing. Looking well beyond issues of race, The Vanishing Half considers the lasting influence of the past as it shapes a person's decisions, desires, and expectations.
Refined_Short_Summary: Twin sisters choose radically different paths when one decides to pass for white while the other embraces her Black identity. This multigenerational saga explores identity, family secrets, and the weight of the past with the emotional depth of Beloved.
Refined_Bio: Born and raised in Southern California, Brit Bennett graduated from Stanford University and earned her MFA in fiction at the University of Michigan. Her debut novel, The Mothers, was a New York Times bestseller and finalist for both the NBCC John Leonard First Novel Prize and the PEN/Robert W. Bingham Prize for Debut Fiction. The Vanishing Half was an instant #1 New York Times bestseller, longlisted for the National Book Award, and a Women's Prize finalist. Bennett has been named a National Book Foundation 5 Under 35 honoree and one of Time's Next 100 Influential People.
Formatted_Quotes:
"[Bennett's] second [book], The Vanishing Half, more than lives up to her early promise. . . more expansive yet also deeper, a multi-generational family saga that tackles prickly issues of racial identity and bigotry and conveys the corrosive effects of secrets and dissembling. It's also a great read that will transport you out of your current circumstances, whatever they are. . . Like The Mothers, this novel keeps you turning pages not just to find out what happens."

—NPR

"Bennett's gorgeously written second novel, an ambitious meditation on race and identity, considers the divergent fates of twin sisters, born in the Jim Crow South, after one decides to pass for white. Bennett balances the literary demands of dynamic characterization with the historical and social realities of her subject matter."

—The New York Times

"Assured and magnetic. . .Bennett is deeply engaged in the unknowability of other people and the scourge of colorism…calls up Toni Morrison's The Bluest Eye, the book's 50-year-old antecedent. . . .  [a] rich, sharp story about the way identity is formed."

—Kirkus
Short_Summary: From The New York Times-bestselling author of The Mothers, a stunning new novel about twin sisters, inseparable as children, who ultimately choose to live in two very different worlds, one black and one white.
Long_Summary:
The Vignes twin sisters will always be identical. But after growing up together in a small, southern black community and running away at age sixteen, it's not just the shape of their daily lives that is different as adults, it's everything: their families, their communities, their racial identities. Many years later, one sister lives with her black daughter in the same southern town she once tried to escape. The other secretly passes for white, and her white husband knows nothing of her past. Still, even separated by so many miles and just as many lies, the fates of the twins remain intertwined. What will happen to the next generation, when their own daughters' storylines intersect?

Weaving together multiple strands and generations of this family, from the Deep South to California, from the 1950s to the 1990s, Brit Bennett produces a story that is at once a riveting, emotional family story and a brilliant exploration of the American history of passing. Looking well beyond issues of race, The Vanishing Half considers the lasting influence of the past as it shapes a person's decisions, desires, and expectations, and explores some of the multiple reasons and realms in which people sometimes feel pulled to live as something other than their origins.

Title: A Manual for Cleaning Women
Subtitle: Selected Stories
Summary: This posthumous collection gathers 43 short stories of working-class women, addiction, motherhood, and survival. Berlin’s voice is raw, compassionate, and darkly funny, revealing beauty in ordinary struggles.
Refined_Long_Summary:
A Manual for Cleaning Women compiles the best work of legendary short-story writer Lucia Berlin. With the grit of Raymond Carver, the humor of Grace Paley, and a blend of wit and melancholy all her own, Berlin crafts miracles from the everyday.

She uncovers moments of grace in the Laundromats and halfway houses of the American Southwest, in the homes of the Bay Area upper class, among switchboard operators and struggling mothers, hitchhikers and bad Christians. These stories pulse with the authentic voices of hard-living women navigating life's complications with clear-eyed humor and resilience.

Readers will revel in this remarkable collection from a master of the form and wonder how they'd ever overlooked her in the first place.
Refined_Short_Summary: Hard-living women navigate life's complications with wit and resilience in these masterful stories. Think Grace Paley meets Raymond Carver—gritty, funny, and deeply human. A rediscovered American classic.
Refined_Bio: Lucia Berlin (1936-2004) worked brilliantly but sporadically throughout the 1960s, 1970s, and 1980s. Her stories draw from her childhood in Western mining towns, glamorous teenage years in Santiago, Chile, three failed marriages, struggles with alcoholism, and various jobs supporting her writing and four sons. Sober by the 1990s, she became associate professor at University of Colorado Boulder in 1994. She died in 2004 in Marina del Rey.
Formatted_Quotes:
"In A Manual for Cleaning Women we witness the emergence of an important American writer, one who was mostly overlooked in her time. Ms. Berlin's stories make you marvel at the contingencies of our existence. She is the real deal. Her stories swoop low over towns and moods and minds."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

"A posthumous collection of stories, almost uniformly narrated by hard-living women, that makes a case for the author as a major talent . . . The prevailing sensibility of this book, collecting 43 of the 76 stories Berlin published, is cleareyed and even comic in the face of life hitting the skids. The title story, for instance, balances wry commentary about housecleaning work ('never make friends with cats') and deadpan observation ('I clean their coke mirror with Windex') with a sad, thrumming back story."

—Kirkus

"[Lucia Berlin] may just be the best writer you've never heard of . . . Imagine a less urban Grace Paley, with a similar talent for turning the net of resentments and affections among family members into stories that carry more weight than their casual, conversational tone might initially suggest . . . Berlin's offbeat humor, get-on-with-it realism, and ability to layer details that echo across stories and decades give her book a tremendous staying power."

—Publishers Weekly
Short_Summary: Stories from a lost American classic "in the same arena as Alice Munro" (Lydia Davis)

A Manual for Cleaning Women compiles the best work of the legendary short-story writer Lucia Berlin. Her stories are inspired by her early childhood in various Western mining towns; her glamorous teenage years in Santiago, Chile; three failed marriages; a lifelong problem with alcoholism; her years spent in Berkeley, New Mexico, and Mexico City; and the various jobs she later held to support her writing and her four sons. Sober and writing steadily by the 1990s, she took a visiting writer's post at the University of Colorado Boulder in 1994 and was soon promoted to associate professor. In 2001, in failing health, she moved to Southern California to be near her sons. She died in 2004 in Marina del Rey.

Title: Black Is the Body
Subtitle: Stories from My Grandmother's Time, My Mother's Time, and Mine
Summary: A deeply personal essay collection that traces race, family, and belonging across generations, blending Bernard’s own life with broader American histories.
Refined_Long_Summary:
In these twelve deeply personal, interconnected essays, Emily Bernard explores the complex realities of race, identity, and belonging in America. She details growing up Black in the South with a family name inherited from a white man, surviving a random stabbing at a New Haven coffee shop, and navigating the challenges of marrying a white man from the North and bringing him home to her family.

Bernard also writes about adopting two children from Ethiopia and living as one of the few Black faculty members in a primarily white New England college town. Each essay becomes a journey of discovery, seeking new ways to talk honestly about race and tell the truth as she has lived it. Her experiences span generations and geographies, weaving together personal narrative with broader American histories to create a powerful meditation on what it means to be Black in America today.
Refined_Short_Summary: Twelve interconnected essays explore race, identity, and belonging through one woman's journey from the South to New England. Perfect for readers who found power in Kiese Laymon's Heavy or Roxane Gay's Hunger.
Refined_Bio: Emily Bernard was born and raised in Nashville, Tennessee, and received her PhD in American Studies from Yale University. She has received grants from the Ford Foundation and NEH, plus a W.E.B. Du Bois Resident Fellowship at Harvard University. Her essays appear in The American Scholar, Best American Essays, and Best African American Essays. She is the Julian Lindsay Green and Gold Professor of English at the University of Vermont.
Formatted_Quotes:
"My very favorite book that I have read so far this year…It's really life changing. If you get no other book this year, get Black Is the Body by Emily Bernard."

—Ann Patchett, author of Tom Lake, The Dutch House, Commonwealth & State of Wonder

"Of the 12 essays here, there's not one that even comes close to being forgettable. Bernard's language is fresh, poetically compact, and often witty ... Bernard proves herself to be a revelatory storyteller of race in America who can hold her own with some of those great writers she teaches."

—Maureen Corrigan, NPR

"Contemplative and compassionate ... Bernard's voice is personable yet incisive in exploring the lived reality of race ... [Her] wisdom and compassion radiate throughout this collection."

—Publishers Weekly

Each of these essays sets out to discover a new way of talking about race and of telling the truth as the author has lived it.

Title: Beautyland
Subtitle: A Novel
Summary: Adina Giorno, born in Philadelphia in 1974, receives strange messages from space hinting she may not be entirely human. Beautyland traces her extraordinary life from girlhood through adulthood in a heartfelt, imaginative exploration of belonging, identity, and cosmic wonder.
Refined_Long_Summary:
At the moment Voyager 1 launches into space carrying its golden record, a baby with unusual perception is born to a single mother in Philadelphia. Adina Giorno is tiny and jaundiced, but she reaches for warmth and light, recognizing from childhood that she's different—she possesses knowledge of a faraway planet.

The arrival of a fax machine enables her to contact her extraterrestrial relatives, beings who have sent her to report on the oddities of Earthlings. For years, as she moves through the world and makes a life among humans, she dispatches transmissions on the terrors and surprising joys of their existence.

Then, at a precarious moment, a beloved friend urges Adina to share her messages with the world. Is there a chance she's not alone? Beautyland is a startling novel about the fragility and resilience of life on Earth and beyond—a remarkable evocation of feeling like an exile at home.
Refined_Short_Summary: When an alien soul is born into human form, she begins sending reports about Earth back home via fax machine. This tender, funny exploration of belonging will resonate with anyone who's ever felt like an outsider.
Refined_Bio: Marie-Helene Bertino is the author of Parakeet, 2 A.M. at The Cat's Pajamas, and Safe as Houses. She was the 2017 Frank O'Connor International Short Story Fellow and has received the O. Henry Prize, Pushcart Prize, Iowa Short Fiction Award, and fellowships from MacDowell, Sewanee, and NYC's Center for Fiction. Her work has been featured twice on NPR's Selected Shorts. She teaches at NYU and Yale and lives in Brooklyn.
Formatted_Quotes:
"[A] remarkable funny-sad novel . . . Astonishing."

—Alexandra Jacobs, The New York Times

"This book is endlessly surprising on the sentence level, but also as a story, and also in its tenderness. We might all need the unexpected love and perspective of a child alien at this point in human history. Beautyland is beautiful and hilarious and transcendent. It honestly feels like a message from another planet. Marie-Helene Bertino is an otherworldly talent."

—Tommy Orange, author of There, There

"Marie-Helene Bertino's delicious, uncanny vision throughout Beautyland makes everything feel brand-new. The chapters are so propulsive one doesn't even fully notice the way she's subtly deconstructing the world. One page swiftly returns ubiquity to wonder, while the next reminds us that cruelty is a choice, that nothing is inevitable but death. It's impossible for a book to feel this fun and this urgent. Beautyland is a miracle. I'll be rereading it forever."

—Kaveh Akbar, author of Martyr!
Short_Summary: A wise, tender novel about a woman who doesn’t feel at home on Earth, by the acclaimed author of Parakeet.
Long_Summary:
At the moment when Voyager 1 is launched into space carrying its famous golden record, a baby of unusual perception is born to a single mother in Philadelphia. Adina Giorno is tiny and jaundiced, but she reaches for warmth and light. As a child, she recognizes that she is different: She possesses knowledge of a faraway planet. The arrival of a fax machine enables her to contact her extraterrestrial relatives, beings who have sent her to report on the oddities of Earthlings.

For years, as she moves through the world and makes a life for herself among humans, she dispatches transmissions on the terrors and surprising joys of their existence. Then, at a precarious moment, a beloved friend urges Adina to share her messages with the world. Is there a chance she is not alone?

Marie-Helene Bertino’s Beautyland is a novel of startling originality about the fragility and resilience of life on our Earth and in our universe. It is a remarkable evocation of the feeling of being in exile at home, and it introduces a gentle, unforgettable alien for our times.

Title: On Immunity
Subtitle: An Inoculation
Summary: In this probing blend of cultural history, science, and memoir, Biss explores the metaphors and fears around vaccination, revealing how ideas of purity, immunity, and community intersect.
Refined_Long_Summary:
When Eula Biss becomes a new mother, she confronts a chronic condition of modern parenthood: fear. Fear of the government, the medical establishment, and what lurks in her child's air, food, mattress, medicine, and vaccines. She discovers you cannot immunize your child—or yourself—from the world.

In this bold investigation, Biss explores the metaphors and myths surrounding immunity and what they mean for both individual and social bodies. As vaccine fears swirl around her, she researches what they mean for her own child, her community, and the world. She weaves conversations with other mothers into meditations on Voltaire's Candide, Bram Stoker's Dracula, Rachel Carson's Silent Spring, and Susan Sontag's AIDS and Its Metaphors.

On Immunity becomes a moving account of our interconnectedness—how our bodies and fates are inextricably linked, and how the choices we make about health ripple far beyond ourselves.
Refined_Short_Summary: When motherhood brings vaccine anxiety, Biss dives deep into our cultural fears around immunity and health. Blending personal narrative with literary analysis, she examines why we're so afraid and what our choices mean for everyone.
Refined_Bio: Eula Biss is the author of four books, including the New York Times bestseller On Immunity: An Inoculation, named one of the 10 Best Books of 2014 by The New York Times Book Review, and Notes from No Man's Land: American Essays, which won the National Book Critics Circle Award for criticism. Her work has appeared in Harper's Magazine, The New York Times, and The Believer, supported by NEA Literature, Howard Foundation, and Guggenheim fellowships.
Formatted_Quotes:
"On Immunity casts a spell...There's drama in watching this smart writer feel her way through this material. She's a poet, an essayist, and a class spy. She digs honestly into her own psyche and into those of 'people like me, ' and she reveals herself as believer and apostate, moth and flame."

—The New York Times

"Biss, while making an unimpeachable case for childhood vaccination, delves into the metaphors that accompany notions of purity and invasion and recounts the medical history of vaccine development. It's a touching personal story that seeks to understand why the antivax crowd exists and why it's such a well-meaning, if misguided, movement."

—Publishers Weekly

"Biss ably tracks the progress of immunization...Biss also administers a thoughtful, withering critique to more recent fears of vaccines--the toxins they carry, from mercury to formaldehyde, and accusations of their role in causing autism. The author keeps the debate lively and surprising...but arrives at a clear point of view: Vaccinate. Brightly informative, giving readers a sturdy platform from which to conduct their own research and take personal responsibility."

—Kirkus
Short_Summary: Why do we fear vaccines? A provocative examination by Eula Biss, the author of Notes from No Man's Land, winner of the National Book Critics Circle Award
Long_Summary:
Upon becoming a new mother, Eula Biss addresses a chronic condition of fear-fear of the government, the medical establishment, and what is in your child's air, food, mattress, medicine, and vaccines. She finds that you cannot immunize your child, or yourself, from the world.
In this bold, fascinating book, Biss investigates the metaphors and myths surrounding our conception of immunity and its implications for the individual and the social body. As she hears more and more fears about vaccines, Biss researches what they mean for her own child, her immediate community, America, and the world, both historically and in the present moment. She extends a conversation with other mothers to meditations on Voltaire's Candide, Bram Stoker's Dracula, Rachel Carson's Silent Spring, Susan Sontag's AIDS and Its Metaphors, and beyond. On Immunity is a moving account of how we are all interconnected-our bodies and our fates.

Title: The Rediscovery of America
Subtitle: Native Peoples and the Unmaking of U.S. History
Summary: Blackhawk reframes U.S. history by placing Native peoples at its center, showing how Indigenous nations shaped the country from its founding onward.
Refined_Long_Summary:
The most enduring feature of U.S. history is the presence of Native Americans, yet most histories have focused on Europeans and their descendants. This long neglect is changing as a new generation of scholars insists that any full account of America must address the struggle, survival, and resurgence of Indigenous nations.

In this transformative synthesis, Ned Blackhawk interweaves five centuries of Native and non-Native histories to show how Native peoples have shaped the nation at every turn. He demonstrates that European colonization in the 1600s was never predetermined; that Native nations influenced England's crisis of empire; that the first shots of the American Revolution were prompted by Indian affairs; that California Indians were among the first casualties of the Civil War; and that twentieth-century activists refashioned American law and policy.

Blackhawk's retelling acknowledges the enduring power, agency, and survival of Indigenous peoples, offering a truer account of the United States and revealing anew the varied meanings of America.
Refined_Short_Summary: Five centuries of American history finally told right, centering Indigenous voices that shaped every major moment. This groundbreaking synthesis will transform how you understand the country's past and present.
Refined_Bio: Ned Blackhawk (Western Shoshone) is the Howard R. Lamar Professor of History and American Studies at Yale University, where he coordinates the Yale Group for the Study of Native America. He is the author of Violence over the Land: Indians and Empires in the Early American West and lives in New Haven, CT.
Formatted_Quotes:
"Blackhawk demonstrates how inextricably linked Indigenous history is with all aspects of American life and politics in this expansive survey, which teases out the deep connection between the aims and attitudes of the developing nation and its dealings with Native peoples. Reorienting the history of America as foremost that of an Indigenous colony, Blackhawk calls for a fundamental change of perspective."

—Publishers Weekly

"Even as the telling of American history has become more complex and nuanced, Native Americans tend to be absent. Blackhawk, a professor at Yale, confronts that absence in this sweeping account of how Native Americans shaped the country legally, politically, and culturally."

—The Washington Post

"A thoughtful, innovative, and provocative book. . . . The legends about the founding and growth of the United States have been promulgated so often and so widely that Blackhawk's conception of American history is long overdue. It is, more than any other attempt at re-interpreting our national story, US history turned upside down."

—David Shribman, Boston Globe
Short_Summary: A sweeping and overdue retelling of U.S. history that recognizes that Native Americans are essential to understanding the evolution of modern America.
Long_Summary: The most enduring feature of U.S. history is the presence of Native Americans, yet most histories have focused on Europeans and their descendants. This long neglect is changing as a new generation of scholars insists that any full account of America must address the struggle, survival, and resurgence of Indigenous nations. In this transformative synthesis, Ned Blackhawk interweaves five centuries of Native and non-Native histories—from Spanish colonial exploration to the rise of Native self-determination in the twentieth century—to show how Native peoples have shaped the nation at every turn. He demonstrates that European colonization in the 1600s was never a predetermined success; that Native nations influenced England’s crisis of empire; that the first shots of the American Revolution were prompted by Indian affairs; that California Indians, targeted by militias, were among the first casualties of the Civil War; that the Union victory forever recalibrated Native communities across the West; and that twentieth-century activists refashioned American law and policy. Blackhawk’s retelling of U.S. history acknowledges the enduring power, agency, and survival of Indigenous peoples, offering a truer account of the United States and revealing anew the varied meanings of America.
Copy_Bio: Ned Blackhawk (Western Shoshone) is the Howard R. Lamar Professor of History and American Studies at Yale University, where he is the faculty coordinator for the Yale Group for the Study of Native America. He is the author of Violence over the Land: Indians and Empires in the Early American West. He lives in New Haven, CT.
Copy_Quotes:
“Blackhawk demonstrates how inextricably linked Indigenous history is with all aspects of American life and politics in this expansive survey, which teases out the deep connection between the aims and attitudes of the developing nation and its dealings with Native peoples. Reorienting the history of America as foremost that of an Indigenous colony, Blackhawk calls for a fundamental change of perspective.”—Publishers Weekly

“Even as the telling of American history has become more complex and nuanced, Native Americans tend to be absent. Blackhawk, a professor at Yale, confronts that absence in this sweeping account of how Native Americans shaped the country legally, politically, and culturally.”—The Washington Post

Title: Frederick Douglass
Subtitle: Prophet of Freedom
Summary: A sweeping biography of the great abolitionist, tracing Douglass’s life from enslavement to international fame as an orator, activist, and writer.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Frederick Douglass (1818–1895) escaped slavery in Baltimore as a young man, armed with literacy secretly taught by his owner's wife. He would become one of America's most powerful literary voices, his very existence challenging everything slave owners claimed about Black humanity.

Initially mentored by William Lloyd Garrison, Douglass transformed his personal story into a weapon against slavery. By the Civil War, he had become the nation's most celebrated orator, traveling widely to bear witness to slavery's brutality. His voice—both written and spoken—made him a fierce critic of America and a radical patriot simultaneously.

After the war, though he sometimes clashed politically with younger African Americans, Douglass never abandoned the Republican party or the fight for Black civil rights. David Blight's biography draws on newly discovered private collections and recently found issues of Douglass's newspapers to reveal intimate details of his two marriages and complex family life. This definitive portrait captures both the public giant and the deeply human man behind one of the nineteenth century's most important American voices.
Refined_Short_Summary: The definitive biography of Frederick Douglass, who escaped slavery to become America's greatest 19th-century orator and a towering abolitionist. Perfect for readers who loved The Warmth of Other Suns or Stamped from the Beginning.
Refined_Bio: David W. Blight is Sterling Professor of History and Director of the Gilder Lehrman Center for the Study of Slavery, Resistance, and Abolition at Yale University. He's authored or edited a dozen books, including American Oracle: The Civil War in the Civil Rights Era, Race and Reunion: The Civil War in American Memory, and annotated editions of Douglass's first two autobiographies. His work has earned the Bancroft Prize, Abraham Lincoln Prize, and Frederick Douglass Prize.
Formatted_Quotes:
"The first major biography of Douglass in nearly three decades. . . . Blight isn't looking to overturn our understanding of Douglass, whose courage and achievements were unequivocal, but to complicate it — a measure by which this ambitious and empathetic biography resoundingly succeeds."

—Jennifer Szalai, The New York Times

"Extraordinary. . . . In Blight's pages, [Douglass's] voice again rings out loud and clear, melancholy and triumphant — still prophesying, still agitating, still calling us to action."

—Adam Goodheart, The Washington Post

"Frederick Douglass: Prophet of Freedom is a triumph—elegantly written, with much new material about one of the most famous and important men in modern history. David Blight has created a vibrant and convincing portrait of a towering figure who was also, Blight says, 'thoroughly and beautifully human.' A great American gets the stellar biography he deserves from one our country's greatest historians."

—Annette Gordon-Reed, Pulitzer Prize-winning author of The Hemingses of Monticello: An American Family & On Juneteenth
Short_Summary: “Extraordinary…a great American biography” (The New Yorker) of the most important African American of the 19th century: Frederick Douglass, the escaped slave who became the greatest orator of his day and one of the leading abolitionists and writers of the era.
Long_Summary:
As a young man Frederick Douglass (1818–1895) escaped from slavery in Baltimore, Maryland. He was fortunate to have been taught to read by his slave owner mistress, and he would go on to become one of the major literary figures of his time. His very existence gave the lie to slave owners: with dignity and great intelligence he bore witness to the brutality of slavery.

Initially mentored by William Lloyd Garrison, Douglass spoke widely, using his own story to condemn slavery. By the Civil War, Douglass had become the most famed and widely travelled orator in the nation. In his unique and eloquent voice, written and spoken, Douglass was a fierce critic of the United States as well as a radical patriot. After the war he sometimes argued politically with younger African Americans, but he never forsook either the Republican party or the cause of black civil and political rights.

In this “cinematic and deeply engaging” (The New York Times Book Review) biography, David Blight has drawn on new information held in a private collection that few other historian have consulted, as well as recently discovered issues of Douglass’s newspapers. “Absorbing and even moving…a brilliant book that speaks to our own time as well as Douglass’s” (The Wall Street Journal), Blight’s biography tells the fascinating story of Douglass’s two marriages and his complex extended family. “David Blight has written the definitive biography of Frederick Douglass…a powerful portrait of one of the most important American voices of the nineteenth century” (The Boston Globe).
Copy_Bio: David W. Blight is the Sterling Professor of History and Director of the Gilder Lehrman Center for the Study of Slavery, Resistance, and Abolition at Yale University. He is the author or editor of a dozen books, including American Oracle: The Civil War in the Civil Rights Era; and Race and Reunion: The Civil War in American Memory; and annotated editions of Douglass’s first two autobiographies. He has worked on Douglass much of his professional life, and been awarded the Bancroft Prize, the Abraham Lincoln Prize, and the Frederick Douglass Prize, among others.
Copy_Quotes:
“The first major biography of Douglass in nearly three decades. . . . Blight isn’t looking to overturn our understanding of Douglass, whose courage and achievements were unequivocal, but to complicate it — a measure by which this ambitious and empathetic biography resoundingly succeeds.”—Jennifer Szalai, The New York Times

“Extraordinary. . . . In Blight’s pages, [Douglass’s] voice again rings out loud and clear, melancholy and triumphant — still prophesying, still agitating, still calling us to action.”—Adam Goodheart, The Washington Post

“Frederick Douglass: Prophet of Freedom is a triumph—elegantly written, with much new material about one of the most famous and important men in modern history. David Blight has created a vibrant and convincing portrait of a towering figure who was also, Blight says, ‘thoroughly and beautifully human.’ A great American gets the stellar biography he deserves from one our country’s greatest historians.”—Annette Gordon-Reed, Pulitzer Prize-winning author of The Hemingses of Monticello: An American Family & On Juneteenth
