Title: Kansas City Lightning
Subtitle: The Rise and Times of Charlie Parker
Summary: A vibrant portrait of jazz legend Charlie Parker’s early years, tracing his genius, struggles, and the cultural forces that shaped modern music.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Charlie "Yardbird" Parker lived one of the most dramatic and tragic lives in American music. From his breakthrough as a Kansas City prodigy in the late 1930s to his death at just thirty-five, Parker revolutionized jazz with the creation of bebop, even as drug addiction shadowed his career and cut it short.

Since then, Parker has become legend—immortalized in bootlegs, in the graffiti "Bird Lives!", in festivals and radio tributes, and on screen in Clint Eastwood's Bird. Yet his full story has rarely been told.

In this first volume of a projected two-part biography, Stanley Crouch draws on decades of research and interviews to uncover the real Parker: the gifted teenager shaped by Depression-era Kansas City, the apprentice absorbing lessons from Lester Young and Count Basie, and the young man torn between music, drugs, his domineering mother, and his teenage bride. With the authority of a jazz scholar and the storytelling skill of a novelist, Crouch brings Parker vividly to life.
Refined_Short_Summary: Stanley Crouch delivers the definitive portrait of Charlie Parker's early years in this groundbreaking biography. Jazz fans and music lovers will be captivated by this intimate look at the genius who revolutionized American music.
Refined_Bio: Stanley Crouch was twice nominated for the National Book Critics Circle Award for Notes of a Hanging Judge and The All-American Skin Game. His other books include Always in Pursuit, The Artificial White Man, and the acclaimed novel Don't the Moon Look Lonesome. He served as artistic consultant for jazz programming at Lincoln Center, was president of the Louis Armstrong Educational Foundation, and was a member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. He died in 2020 at age 74.
Formatted_Quotes:
"A tour de force that is the print equivalent of a long, bravura jazz performance. . . . Crouch has given us a bone-deep understanding of Parker's music and the world that produced it. In his pages, Bird still lives."

—The Washington Post

"It is from Mr. Crouch, a novelist as well as a critic and essayist, that we come to see Charlie Parker in the context of his time and place in America. . . . One comes away from Mr. Crouch's book wanting more."

—The Wall Street Journal

"A book about a jazz hero written in a heroic style. . . a bebop Beowulf."

—The New York Times
Short_Summary: The first installment of Stanley Crouch’s long-awaited life of Charlie Parker—an intimate, groundbreaking portrait of the genius as a young man.
Long_Summary:
Charlie “Yardbird” Parker lived one of the most dramatic, triumphant, and tragic lives in American music. From his breakthrough as a Kansas City prodigy in the late 1930s to his death in 1955 at just thirty-five, Parker revolutionized jazz with the creation of bebop, even as drug addiction shadowed his career and cut it short.

Since then, Parker has become legend—immortalized in bootlegs and reissues, in the graffiti “Bird Lives!”, in annual festivals and daily radio tributes, and on screen in Clint Eastwood’s Bird. Yet his full story has rarely been told—until Kansas City Lightning.

In this first volume of a projected two-part biography, Stanley Crouch—one of America’s foremost writers on jazz and culture—draws on decades of research and interviews to uncover the real Parker: the gifted teenager shaped by Depression-era Kansas City, the apprentice absorbing lessons from Lester Young, Buster Smith, and Count Basie, and the young man torn between music, drugs, his domineering mother, and his teenage bride Rebecca Ruffin.

With the authority of a jazz scholar, the insight of a cultural critic, and the storytelling skill of a novelist, Crouch brings Parker vividly, urgently to life.
Copy_Bio: Stanley Crouch was twice nominated for the National Book Critics Circle Award, for his essay collections Notes of a Hanging Judge and The All-American Skin Game. His other books include Always in Pursuit, The Artificial White Man, and the acclaimed novel Don't the Moon Look Lonesome. He served on and off as the artistic consultant for jazz programming at Lincoln Center, was the president of the Louis Armstrong Educational Foundation, and was a member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. He died in 2020 at the age of 74.
Copy_Quotes:
“A tour de force that is the print equivalent of a long, bravura jazz performance. . . . Crouch has given us a bone-deep understanding of Parker’s music and the world that produced it. In his pages, Bird still lives.”—The Washington Post

“It is from Mr. Crouch, a novelist as well as a critic and essayist, that we come to see Charlie Parker in the context of his time and place in America. . . . One comes away from Mr. Crouch’s book wanting more.”—The Wall Street Journal

“A book about a jazz hero written in a heroic style. . . a bebop Beowulf.”—The New York Times

Title: Day
Subtitle: A Novel
Summary: Set across three Aprils—2019, 2020, and 2021—Day traces one Brooklyn family’s shifting dynamics through love, loss, and the pandemic’s upheaval. Cunningham’s luminous prose captures the fleeting nature of time and the enduring need for connection.
Refined_Long_Summary:
April 5, 2019: In a cozy Brooklyn brownstone, domestic bliss is cracking at the seams. Dan and Isabel's troubled marriage grows more complicated by their shared affection for Isabel's younger brother, Robbie—the wayward soul still living in their attic loft. When Robbie, nursing a recent breakup through his glamorous online avatar, is forced to move out, the family threatens to fracture. Ten-year-old Nathan takes his first uncertain steps toward independence, while five-year-old Violet tries not to notice her parents' growing distance.

April 5, 2020: Lockdown transforms their home into a prison. Violet obsesses over keeping windows closed and her family safe, while Nathan pushes against her rules. Isabel and Dan communicate in veiled jabs and frustrated sighs. Beloved Robbie remains stranded in an Iceland mountain cabin with only his thoughts and secret Instagram life for company.

April 5, 2021: Emerging from crisis, the family confronts a transformed reality—reckoning with what they've learned, lost, and how they might continue.

From Pulitzer Prize winner Michael Cunningham comes a searing meditation on love, loss, and family's struggles—the delicate art of living together and apart.
Refined_Short_Summary: When a Brooklyn family faces upheaval spanning three pivotal years, they must navigate love, loss, and the complexities of staying connected. Perfect for readers who were moved by The Midnight Library's exploration of life's possibilities.
Refined_Bio: Michael Cunningham is the author of seven novels, including The Snow Queen, A Home at the End of the World, Flesh and Blood, The Hours (winner of the PEN/Faulkner Award and the Pulitzer Prize), Specimen Days, and By Nightfall, as well as Land's End: A Walk in Provincetown. He is currently a senior lecturer at Yale University and lives in New York.
Formatted_Quotes:
"Along with George Eliot, Michael Cunningham belongs in that rare group of novelists who hold the world close, with apparently infinite respect, compassion, and tenderness, all while describing the world and its inhabitants unsparingly. Day is a portrait of the life of a family, preceding, during, and immediately after the pandemic, rendered in fragments, almost as if assembling forensic evidence, not of a crime but of quiet tragedies and quiet, heroic endurance. There's deep recognition here, bordering on revelation."

—Tony Kushner

"Michael Cunningham, the perennial master of rendering the quotidian with a profound and deeply considered eye for human frailty, returns with a book that exemplifies the hallmarks of his style: lush, erudite, voracious in its seeking. Like a true poet, he remakes the world in his descriptions, freshened with care and compassion and tinged with the radiant heat of grief. What a quietly stunning achievement."

—Ocean Vuong, author of On Earth We Are Briefly Gorgeous

"Michael Cunningham writes such eloquent, seductive sentences that we have to keep reminding ourselves to step back and pay attention to his appealing, dimensional characters and to his generous vision of childhood and adulthood, of work and love, of the pleasures and griefs of family life, and of all the rich complexities of being human."

—Francine Prose
Short_Summary: As the world changes around them, a family weathers the storms of growing up, growing older, falling in and out of love, losing the things that are most precious—and learning to go on—from the Pulitzer Prize–winning author of The Hours
Long_Summary:
April 5, 2019: In a cozy brownstone in Brooklyn, the veneer of domestic bliss is beginning to crack. Dan and Isabel, troubled husband and wife, are both a little bit in love with Isabel’s younger brother, Robbie. Robbie, wayward soul of the family, who still lives in the attic loft; Robbie, who, trying to get over his most recent boyfriend, has created a glamorous avatar online; Robbie, who now has to move out of the house—and whose departure threatens to break the family apart. Meanwhile Nathan, age ten, is taking his first uncertain steps toward independence, while Violet, five, does her best not to notice the growing rift between her parents.

April 5, 2020: As the world goes into lockdown, the brownstone is feeling more like a prison. Violet is terrified of leaving the windows open, obsessed with keeping her family safe, while Nathan attempts to skirt her rules. Isabel and Dan communicate mostly in veiled jabs and frustrated sighs. And beloved Robbie is stranded in Iceland, alone in a mountain cabin with nothing but his thoughts—and his secret Instagram life—for company.

April 5, 2021: Emerging from the worst of the crisis, the family reckons with a new, very different reality—with what they’ve learned, what they’ve lost, and how they might go on.

From the brilliant mind of Pulitzer Prize winner Michael Cunningham, Day is a searing, exquisitely crafted meditation on love and loss and the struggles and limitations of family life—how to live together and apart.

Title: Second Place
Subtitle: A Novel
Summary: A woman invites a famous painter to stay at her remote property, hoping for inspiration but instead confronting tensions of art, power, and gender. Inspired by a real-life memoir, Second Place is a taut, provocative meditation on creativity and desire.
Refined_Long_Summary:
A woman living in a remote coastal region invites a celebrated artist to visit, convinced his artistic vision will unlock the mysteries of her life and surroundings. What unfolds is a tense psychological drama that examines the collision between his provocative presence and her carefully constructed world.

Cusk masterfully dissects the power dynamics at play—exploring themes of female fate and male privilege while mapping the complex geometries of human relationships. As the visit progresses, both characters are forced to confront fundamental questions about how we live morally when our internal desires clash with external realities.

At its heart, this is a meditation on art's dual nature: its capacity to both illuminate and devastate. Through precise, unflinching prose, Cusk creates a story that affirms the resilience of the human spirit while refusing to look away from our deepest struggles and contradictions.
Refined_Short_Summary: When a woman invites a famous artist to her remote home, expecting revelation, she gets something far more unsettling. Cusk delivers a psychologically complex fable about art, power, and human nature that fans of Sally Rooney's intricate character studies will find irresistible.
Refined_Bio: Rachel Cusk is the author of Second Place, the acclaimed Outline trilogy, memoirs A Life's Work and Aftermath, and several other works of fiction and nonfiction. A Guggenheim Fellow, she lives in Paris.
Formatted_Quotes:
"Cusk is at her best when she works in diversions, as she does with the deceptive simplicity of Second Place. The novel is skillfully meandering, offering consistent flashes of insight while traversing a great deal of intellectual terrain. The drama is tight and the action straightforward, but when it comes to the beguiling complexity of human nature, the wisdom offered here is significant."

—Quill & Quire

"Cusk, as always, is brilliant at the subtleties of human dynamics, which here are as ever-changing as the landscape against which they're set."

—Toronto Star

"Cusk is as brilliant as ever at revealing the tumult that occurs when people with varying strengths of personal will come into close contact with each other. Second Place is the kind of book that requires re-reading, but also rewards it."

—Globe and Mail
Short_Summary: From the author of the Outline trilogy, a fable of human destiny and decline, enacted in a closed system of intimate, fractured relationships
Long_Summary: A woman invites a famed artist to visit the remote coastal region where she lives, in the belief that his vision will penetrate the mystery of her life and landscape. His provocative presence provides the frame for a study of female fate and male privilege, of the geometries of human relationships, and of the struggle to live morally in the intersecting spaces of our internal and external worlds. With its examination of the possibility that art can both save and destroy us, Second Place is deeply affirming of the human soul, while grappling with its darkest demons.

Title: Outline
Subtitle: A Novel
Summary: A writer travels to Athens to teach a writing course. Instead of telling her own story, she listens as others reveal theirs. Spare yet layered, Outline is a meditation on identity, perception, and the act of storytelling.
Refined_Long_Summary:
A woman sits next to a stranger on a plane to Athens. They talk—about destinations, careers, families. Grievances surface, tragedies unfold, relationships dissected. An unexpected intimacy emerges between two people contrasting their own fictions about their lives.

Rachel Cusk's Outline unfolds through ten conversations. Spare and luminous, it follows a novelist teaching creative writing during one oppressively hot Athenian summer. She guides students through storytelling exercises, dines with visiting writers, swims in the Ionian Sea with her fellow passenger. Everyone she encounters speaks openly about themselves—fantasies, anxieties, theories, regrets, longings. Through these revelations, a portrait of the narrator emerges by contrast: a woman learning to face profound loss.

Outline examines what's hardest to articulate. It captures the rhythms of conversation, investigates why people tell stories, and questions whether they can ever do so honestly. In the process, it reveals the deepest impulses behind fiction writing itself.
Refined_Short_Summary: Through ten conversations in sweltering Athens, a writing teacher listens as strangers reveal their deepest selves, while her own story emerges through absence and silence. Perfect for readers who loved the introspective brilliance of My Education by Susan Choi.
Refined_Bio: Rachel Cusk is the author of Second Place, the Outline trilogy, the memoirs A Life's Work and Aftermath, and several other works of fiction and nonfiction. She is a Guggenheim Fellow and lives in Paris.
Formatted_Quotes:
"Rachel Cusk's Outline is full of baking light and quiet melancholy and bodies brushing past one another in the heat; it's a subtle and utterly engrossing exploration of the ways we make ourselves known to one another--in stories and anecdotes, through seductions and disputes--and yet remain opaque; how we sketch ourselves as outlines and find these outlines interrogated. Its conversations echo each other deftly, their acute insights gracefully pulling apart the seams of its carefully composed characters to show glimpses of much messier selves within: a series of searing psychic X-rays bleached by coastal light."

—Leslie Jamison, author of The Empathy Exams

"Like the Higgs boson, which appears only when bombarded by electrons, Rachel Cusk's nearly nameless narrator flickers into visibility only through her encounters with a series of amazingly eloquent and fascinating interlocutors. Writing at the highest level and with the greatest technical restraint, Cusk manages to describe the painful realities of women's lives by a process of erasure that is itself responsible for that suffering. This is a novel where form and content meld so perfectly as to collapse into each other. I am so much the better for having read it. As if someone finally told me the truth by telling me everything, and nothing."

—Jeffrey Eugenides, author of The Marriage Plot

"Outline, in the most seemingly effortless way imaginable, winds up being completely captivating: the conversations are autobiographies in miniature, with all the holes, lies and self-deceptions lurking in that wily form . . . As you'd expect in a novel so obsessed with language, Cusk's own writing is a pleasure to read -- unfailingly precise and surprising . . . The ultimate and undeniably cerebral pleasure of Outline is it nudges you into being a more attentive reader and listener, more alert to the cracks in sentences and the messier realities that words can only try to contain."

—Maureen Corrigan, NPR
Short_Summary: A writer travels to Athens to teach a writing course. Instead of telling her own story, she listens as others reveal theirs. Spare yet layered, Outline is a meditation on identity, perception, and the act of storytelling.
Long_Summary:
A man and a woman are seated next to each other on a plane. They get to talking—about their destination, their careers, their families. Grievances are aired, family tragedies discussed, marriages and divorces analyzed. An intimacy is established as two strangers contrast their own fictions about their lives.
Rachel Cusk's Outline is a novel in ten conversations. Spare and stark, it follows a novelist teaching a course in creative writing during one oppressively hot summer in Athens. She leads her students in storytelling exercises. She meets other visiting writers for dinner. She goes swimming in the Ionian Sea with her neighbor from the plane. The people she encounters speak volubly about themselves: their fantasies, anxieties, pet theories, regrets, and longings. And through these disclosures, a portrait of the narrator is drawn by contrast, a portrait of a woman learning to face a great loss.
Outline takes a hard look at the things that are hardest to speak about. It brilliantly captures conversations, investigates people's motivations for storytelling, and questions their ability to ever do so honestly or unselfishly. In doing so it bares the deepest impulses behind the craft of fiction writing. This is Rachel Cusk's finest work yet, and one of the most startling, brilliant, original novels of recent years.

Title: The Catch
Subtitle: A Novel
Refined_Long_Summary:
Twin sisters Clara and Dempsey have always struggled to relate, their bond severed after their mother vanished into the Thames. Adopted into different families as infants, Clara grew up with a successful upper-class couple while Dempsey was raised by a sullen city councilor. In adulthood, they're content to remain estranged—until Clara spots a woman on London's streets who looks exactly like their mother.

The catch: this version of Serene hasn't aged a day and has lived a childless life, seemingly the very existence she might have had if the girls were never born.

Clara, a celebrity author with a taste for excessive drinking and one-night stands, eagerly welcomes the confident Serene into her home. But reclusive Dempsey, who makes a modest living doing data entry from her apartment, suspects this woman is running an elaborate con. As the sisters clash over this mysterious stranger who burrows deeper into their lives, they hurtle toward a confrontation that threatens everything, forcing them to finally face their past together.

In her stunning fiction debut, Yrsa Daley-Ward creates a kaleidoscopic exploration of daughterhood and maternal longing, examining the sacrifices women make for self-actualization.
Refined_Short_Summary: When estranged twin sisters spot a woman who looks exactly like the mother who abandoned them—except she hasn't aged and lived a childless life—their conflicting reactions threaten to destroy them both. A mind-bending family drama perfect for fans of Brit Bennett.
Refined_Bio: Yrsa Daley-Ward is a poet, writer, and actress. She's the author of The How, bone, and The Terrible, for which she won the PEN Ackerley Prize. She lives in Los Angeles.
Formatted_Quotes:
"[Daley-Ward] has a knack for getting directly to a story's heat-point, and once there, to distill the emotions within it down to a line or two."

—Hanif Abdurraqib, Atlantic

"Yrsa's work is like holding the truth in your hands. It sweats and breathes before you. A glorious living thing."

—Florence Welch, Florence + the Machine

"Poet Daley-Ward (Bone) makes her fiction debut with an engrossing and off-kilter tale of twin sisters and their mother, a Black woman who left them when they were infants. The dreamy novel is propelled by searching questions about how to be a mother and how to find fulfillment. It's a singular family drama."

—Publishers Weekly
Short_Summary: The inaugural novel in the Well-Read Black Girl Books series, The Catch is a darkly whimsical tale of women daring to live and create with impunity.
Long_Summary:
Twin sisters Clara and Dempsey have always struggled to relate, their familial bond severed after their mother vanished into the Thames. As infants they were adopted into different families, Clara sent to live with a successful, upper-class couple, and Dempsey with a sullen, unaffectionate city councilor. In adulthood, they are content to be all but estranged, until Clara sees a woman who looks exactly like their mother on the streets of London. The catch: this version of Serene, aged not a day, has enjoyed a childless life—the very life, it seems, she might have had if the girls had never been born.

As with most things, Clara and Dempsey cannot see eye to eye on the confounding appearance of this woman. Clara, a celebrity author with a penchant for excessive drinking and one-night stands, is all too willing to welcome the confident and temperamental Serene into her home. But cloistered Dempsey, who makes a modest living doing menial data entry work from the confines of her apartment, is dubious of the whole situation, believing this all to be the insidious ruse of a con woman. Clashing over this stranger who burrows deeper and deeper into their lives, the sisters hurtle toward an altercation that threatens their very existence, forcing them to finally confront their pasts—together.

In her riveting first foray into fiction, Yrsa Daley-Ward conjures a kaleidoscopic multiverse of daughterhood and mother-want, exploring the sacrifices that women must make for self-actualization. The result is a marvel of a debut novel that boldly asks, “How can it ever, ever be a crime to choose yourself?”

Title: Raising Hare
Subtitle: A Memoir
Refined_Long_Summary:
Imagine bottle-feeding a baby hare that drums on your duvet cover for attention, runs to you when called from the fields, and gives birth to leverets in your study. For political advisor Chloe Dalton, spending lockdown in the English countryside far from her busy London life, this became her extraordinary reality.

In February 2021, Dalton discovers a newborn leveret that had been chased by a dog. Fearing for its life, she brings it home, only to learn how nearly impossible it is to rear a wild hare—most perish in captivity from shock or starvation. Through trial and error, she learns to feed and care for the leveret, intending to return it to the wild.

Instead, it becomes her constant companion, wandering fields and woods at night before returning to her house by day. Though Dalton knows the hare faces threats from foxes, stoats, feral cats, and raptors, she never restricts it to the house. Each departure means she may never see it again, yet she understands that confinement would be its own kind of death.

Raising Hare chronicles their remarkable journey while exploring hare behavior, biology, and their place in art, literature, and folklore—a reminder that life's most beautiful experiences often arise when we least expect them.
Refined_Short_Summary: When political advisor Chloe Dalton rescues an abandoned baby hare during lockdown, she never expects it to become her constant companion. This extraordinary memoir of their unlikely friendship will captivate anyone who loved The Midnight Library's themes of connection and purpose.
Refined_Bio: Chloe Dalton is a writer, political adviser, and foreign policy specialist who spent over a decade working in the UK Parliament and the Foreign and Commonwealth Office. She has advised and written for numerous prominent figures, dividing her time between London and the English countryside. Raising Hare is her first book.
Formatted_Quotes:
"An astounding debut memoir in which Dalton shows how a serene and long-misunderstood creature opened her eyes in many ways. It just might do the same for readers. . . . Soulful and gracefully written."

—Kirkus

"This book tells a story of true friendship with great respect . . . If you love animals, this book is incredibly beautiful and moving and helped me see nature differently. I think it's the best non-fiction book of the year."

—Elizabeth Gilbert

"Dalton's clear, measured prose and Denise Nestor's delicate drawings provide . . . a bit of solace in a world that has now returned to an even more frenetic state. In Raising Hare, nature, indeed, takes its course."

—The New York Times
Short_Summary: A moving and fascinating meditation on freedom, trust, loss, and our relationship with the natural world, explored through the story of one woman’s unlikely friendship with a wild hare.
Long_Summary:
Imagine you could hold a baby hare and bottle-feed it. Imagine that it lived under your roof and lolloped around your bedroom at night, drumming on the duvet cover when it wanted your attention. Imagine that, over two years later, it still ran in from the fields when you called it and slept in your house for hours on end and gave birth to leverets in your study. For political advisor and speechwriter Chloe Dalton, who spent lockdown deep in the English countryside, far away from her usual busy London life, this became her unexpected reality.

In February 2021, Dalton stumbles upon a newborn hare—a leveret—that had been chased by a dog. Fearing for its life, she brings it home, only to discover how impossible it is to rear a wild hare, most of whom perish in captivity from either shock or starvation. Through trial and error, she learns to feed and care for the leveret with every intention of returning it to the wilderness. Instead, it becomes her constant companion, wandering the fields and woods at night and returning to Dalton’s house by day. Though Dalton feared that the hare would be preyed upon by foxes, stoats, feral cats, raptors, and even people, she never tried to restrict it to the house. Each time the hare leaves, Chloe knows she may never see it again. Yet she also understands that to confine it would be its own kind of death.

Raising Hare chronicles their journey together, while also taking a deep dive into the lives and nature of hares, and the way they have been viewed historically in art, literature, and folklore. We witness first-hand the joy at this extraordinary relationship between human and animal, which serves as a reminder that the best things, and most beautiful experiences, arise when we least expect them.

She spent over a decade working in the UK Parliament and the Foreign and Commonwealth Office and has advised, and written for and with, numerous prominent figures. She divides her time between London and her home in the English countryside. Raising Hare is her first book.

Title: Fellowship Point
Subtitle: A Novel
Summary: Two lifelong friends, Agnes and Polly, face the prospect of legacy, land preservation, and family entanglements in coastal Maine. Spanning generations, Fellowship Point is a rich, sweeping novel about friendship, feminism, and the ties that endure.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Celebrated children's book author Agnes Lee is determined to secure her legacy—to complete what she knows will be the final volume of her pseudonymously written Franklin Square novels, and even more consuming, to permanently protect the peninsula of majestic coast in Maine known as Fellowship Point. To donate the land to a trust, Agnes must convince shareholders to dissolve a generations-old partnership. And one of those shareholders is her best friend, Polly.

Polly Wister has led a different kind of life than Agnes: that of a well-off married woman with children, defined by her devotion to her husband, a philosophy professor with an inflated sense of stature. She strives to create beauty and harmony in her home, friendships, and family. But Polly soon finds her loyalties torn between her best friend's wishes and her three sons' demands—forcing her to confront what she actually wants for herself.

Agnes's carefully laid plans become even more complicated when an enterprising young book editor named Maud Silver arrives, determined to convince Agnes to write her memoirs. Despite Agnes's resistance, long-buried memories and secrets begin surfacing with far-reaching consequences for everyone involved.
Refined_Short_Summary: Eighty years of friendship, family secrets, and one pristine Maine coastline that could change everything. When lifelong friends Agnes and Polly face off over land that's been in their families for generations, loyalties fracture and buried truths emerge. Big Little Lies fans will love the intricate family dynamics.
Refined_Bio: Alice Elliott Dark is the author of the novels Fellowship Point and Think of England, plus two short story collections, In the Gloaming and Naked to the Waist. Her work has appeared in The New Yorker, Harper's, The New York Times, Best American Short Stories, and O. Henry: Prize Stories. Her award-winning story "In the Gloaming" was made into two films and chosen for Best American Stories of the Century. A National Endowment for the Arts Fellowship recipient, she's an associate professor at Rutgers-Newark in the MFA program.

—Leah Greenblatt, Entertainment Weekly

"A sweeping story of lifelong best friends...you will surely want to read this book. Elegantly structured, beautifully written, and altogether diverting, with a powerful message about land ownership in America."

—Kirkus

"Enthralling, masterfully written . . . Fellowship Point is a novel rich with social and psychological insights, both earnest and sly, big ideas grounded in individual emotions, a portrait of a tightly knit community made up of artfully drawn, individual souls."

—Kate Christensen, The New York Times
Short_Summary: “A magnificent storytelling feat” (The Boston Globe) story of lifelong friendship between two very different “superbly depicted” (The Wall Street Journal) women with shared histories, divisive loyalties, hidden sorrows, and eighty years of summers on a pristine point of land on the coast of Maine, set across the arc of the 20th century.
Long_Summary:
Celebrated children’s book author Agnes Lee is determined to secure her legacy—to complete what she knows will be the final volume of her pseudonymously written Franklin Square novels; and even more consuming, to permanently protect the peninsula of majestic coast in Maine known as Fellowship Point. To donate the land to a trust, Agnes must convince shareholders to dissolve a generations-old partnership. And one of those shareholders is her best friend, Polly.

Polly Wister has led a different kind of life than Agnes: that of a well-off married woman with children, defined by her devotion to her husband, a philosophy professor with an inflated sense of stature. She strives to create beauty and harmony in her home, in her friendships, and in her family. Polly soon finds her loyalties torn between the wishes of her best friend and the wishes of her three sons—but what is it that Polly wants herself?

Agnes’s designs are further muddied when an enterprising young book editor named Maud Silver sets out to convince Agnes to write her memoirs. Agnes’s resistance cannot prevent long-buried memories and secrets from coming to light with far-reaching repercussions for all.

“An ambitious and satisfying tale” (The Washington Post), Fellowship Point reads like a 19th-century epic, but it is entirely contemporary in its “reflections on aging, writing, stewardship, legacies, independence, and responsibility. At its heart, Fellowship Point is about caring for the places and people we love...This magnificent novel affirms that change and growth are possible at any age” (The Christian Science Monitor).

Title: Clear
Subtitle: A Novel
Summary: In 1840s Scotland, a minister is sent to evict the last inhabitant of a remote island. Instead, he forms a fragile bond with the man he came to displace. Clear is a spare, lyrical novel about language, exile, and connection.
Refined_Long_Summary:
John, an impoverished Scottish minister, accepts a job evicting the last remaining occupant of a remote island north of Scotland—Ivar, who has lived alone for decades with only animals and the sea for company. Despite his wife Mary's serious misgivings, John sets off for the island, setting in motion events neither could have predicted.

Shortly after arriving, John falls down a cliff and is found unconscious and badly injured by the very man he came to evict. Ivar takes him home and tends to his wounds, and a surprising bond develops between these two unlikely companions. John begins learning Ivar's language while Ivar sees himself reflected through another person's eyes for the first time in decades.

Set during the final stages of the Scottish Clearances—a brutal 19th-century period that saw rural communities forcibly driven from their land—this singular novel explores what binds us together across insurmountable differences. Moving and unpredictable, Clear examines how history shapes our deepest convictions and how the human spirit endures against all odds.
Refined_Short_Summary: When a Scottish minister arrives to evict the last inhabitant of a remote island, an accident changes everything. This spare, powerful novel about language and unlikely connection will appeal to readers who loved the intimate storytelling of Hamnet.
Refined_Bio: Carys Davies is the author of the novels West, shortlisted for the Rathbones Folio Prize and winner of Wales Book of the Year, and The Mission House, The Sunday Times 2020 Novel of the Year. Her collection The Redemption of Galen Pike won the Frank O'Connor International Short Story Award and the Jerwood Fiction Uncovered Prize. She has received the Royal Society of Literature's V.S. Pritchett Prize, the Society of Authors' Olive Cook Award, and a Cullman Fellowship at the New York Public Library. Born in Wales, she lived in New York and Chicago before settling in Edinburgh.
Formatted_Quotes:
"The sheer beauty of Clear—with its perfect sentences, its austere tenderness, and its quiet sense of disquiet—feels timeless ... A poignant, profound depiction of both solitude and connection. Carys Davies has written a masterful, discreetly sublime book."

—Hernan Diaz, Pulitzer Prize-winning author of Trust and In the Distance

"This intriguing and inventive story escorts the reader to an unexpectedly joyous ending that hints at our contemporary interest in new ideas of what a family might be. The writing style is one of clarity and reserved sensibility punctuated with an end-game needle jab. Not to be missed."

—Annie Proulx, author of Barkskins

"Clear is a compact, taut and brilliant novel with an ingenious premise: one man is sent to evict another from his land, but suddenly requires the second man's aid. Everything gets more complicated from there. The book is about belonging, a dying language, secrets, and a pistol in a box. I loved every page."

—Anthony Doerr, author of All the Light We Cannot See and Cloud Cuckoo Land

Moving and unpredictable, “a love letter to the scorching power of language” (The Guardian), Clear is “a jewel of a novel” (The Washington Post)—a profound and unforgettable read.

Title: Soldiers and Kings
Subtitle: Survival and Hope in the World of Human Smuggling
Summary: Through gripping fieldwork and harrowing stories, De León examines the human smuggling economy, exposing the dangers, desperation, and resilience of those navigating migration routes.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Political instability, poverty, climate change, and the demand for cheap labor all fuel clandestine movement across borders. As those borders harden, the need for smugglers who guide migrants increases every year. Yet the real lives of these smugglers—or coyotes, as they're known by the migrants who hire them—are only reported from a distance, using tired stereotypes that paint them as violent warlords.

To understand this essential yet illegal billion-dollar global industry, internationally recognized anthropologist Jason De León embedded with smugglers moving migrants across Mexico over seven years. The result is SOLDIERS AND KINGS: the first in-depth, character-driven look at human smuggling.

This heart-wrenching narrative revolves around one coyote who falls in love and tries to leave smuggling behind. De León chronicles the lives of low-level foot soldiers breaking into the game and morally conflicted gang leaders who oversee ragtag crews along the migrant trail. More than a groundbreaking glimpse into a difficult-to-access world, this is a masterpiece of narrative nonfiction.
Refined_Short_Summary: MacArthur Fellow Jason De León spent seven years embedded with human smugglers across Mexico, delivering the first intimate portrait of this billion-dollar underground world. This character-driven narrative follows coyotes trying to survive and escape the dangerous trade that defines their lives.
Refined_Bio: Jason De León is professor of Anthropology and Chicana/o Studies and director of the Cotsen Institute of Archaeology at UCLA. He's executive director of the Undocumented Migration Project and a 2017 MacArthur Foundation Fellow. His previous book, The Land of Open Graves: Living and Dying on the Migrant Trail, won multiple awards.
Formatted_Quotes:
"This is a real one. A work of extraordinary reportage and compassion, Soldiers and Kings takes us deep inside the lives of smugglers guiding desperate migrants across Latin America. One breathtaking scene follows another, rendered in vibrant, unsparing prose documenting grinding poverty and violence, but also young love and redemption. It will shock you, move you, and leave you changed."

—Matthew Desmond, Pulitzer Prize-winning and New York Times bestselling author of Evicted and Poverty, by America

"A harrowing account of the work of human smugglers in bringing aspirational immigrants to America's southern border...[and] an exemplary ethnography of central importance to any discussion of immigration policy or reform."

—Kirkus

"A rare inside look at human smuggling on the border . . . Smuggling, [De León] says, 'is not the problem.' But as his own book memorably recounts, in a world with no shortage of problems, it's nevertheless one of them."

—The New York Times
Short_Summary: An intense, intimate and first-of-its-kind look at the world of human smuggling in Latin America, by a MacArthur "genius" grant winner and anthropologist with unprecedented access
Long_Summary:
Political instability, poverty, climate change, and the insatiable appetite for cheap labor all fuel clandestine movement across borders. As those borders harden, the demand for smugglers who aid migrants across them increases every year. Yet the real lives and work of smugglers—or coyotes, or guides, as they are often known by the migrants who hire their services—are only ever reported on from a distance, using tired tropes and stereotypes, often depicted as boogie men and violent warlords. In an effort to better understand this essential yet extralegal billion dollar global industry, internationally recognized anthropologist and expert Jason De León embedded with a group of smugglers moving migrants across Mexico over the course of seven years.

The result of this unique and extraordinary access is SOLDIERS AND KINGS: the first ever in-depth, character-driven look at human smuggling. It is a heart-wrenching and intimate narrative that revolves around the life and death of one coyote who falls in love and tries to leave smuggling behind. In a powerful, original voice, De León expertly chronicles the lives of low-level foot soldiers breaking into the smuggling game, and morally conflicted gang leaders who oversee rag-tag crews of guides and informants along the migrant trail. SOLDIERS AND KINGS is not only a ground-breaking up-close glimpse of a difficult-to-access world, it is a masterpiece of narrative nonfiction.
Copy_Bio: Jason De León is professor of Anthropology and Chicana/o Studies and director of the Cotsen Institute of Archaeology at the University of California, Los Angeles. He is also executive director of the Undocumented Migration Project, a 501(c)(3) research, arts, and education collective that seeks to raise awareness about migration issues globally. He is a 2017 MacArthur Foundation Fellow and author of the award-winning book The Land of Open Graves: Living and Dying on the Migrant Trail.

One breathtaking scene follows another, rendered in vibrant, unsparing prose documenting grinding poverty and violence, but also young love and redemption. It will shock you, move you, and leave you changed.”—Matthew Desmond, Pulitzer Prize-winning and New York Times bestselling author of Evicted and Poverty, by America

“A harrowing account of the work of human smugglers in bringing aspirational immigrants to America’s southern border...[and] an exemplary ethnography of central importance to any discussion of immigration policy or reform.”—Kirkus

“A rare inside look at human smuggling on the border . . . Smuggling, [De León] says, ‘is not the problem.’ But as his own book memorably recounts, in a world with no shortage of problems, it’s nevertheless one of them.”—The New York Times

Title: Wave
Summary: A devastating memoir of loss and survival, Deraniyagala recounts the 2004 tsunami that claimed her family and her struggle to live after unimaginable grief.
Refined_Long_Summary:
On December 26, 2004, Sonali Deraniyagala was vacationing with her family on Sri Lanka's southern coast when the tsunami hit. She survived. Her parents, husband, and two young sons did not.

In this unflinchingly honest memoir, Deraniyagala chronicles her journey through unimaginable grief. She captures those first horrifying moments of loss and the brutal months that followed, when she fought against a reality too devastating to accept yet impossible to deny.

Slowly, over the years, she begins the delicate work of remembering. Her memories take us through the rich life she's mourning—from her family's London home to her children's births, from meeting her English husband at Cambridge to her childhood in Colombo. Throughout, she navigates the impossible balance between honoring her lost family's memory and finding a way to continue living.

This is a searingly beautiful account of survival, written with remarkable poise and without sentimentality. Deraniyagala shows us how memory can be both unbearably painful and essential for healing.
Refined_Short_Summary: When the 2004 tsunami claimed her entire family, economist Sonali Deraniyagala faced an unthinkable choice: how to keep living. Her unflinching memoir traces the brutal journey from survival to acceptance.
Refined_Bio: Sonali Deraniyagala teaches in the Department of Economics at SOAS, University of London. Her books include Wave (2013), an acclaimed memoir of her experiences during and after the 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami.
Short_Summary: A devastating memoir of loss and survival, Deraniyagala recounts the 2004 tsunami that claimed her family and her struggle to live after unimaginable grief.
Long_Summary: On the morning of December 26, 2004, on the southern coast of Sri Lanka, Sonali Deraniyagala lost her parents, her husband, and her two young sons in the tsunami she miraculously survived. In this brave and searingly frank memoir, she describes those first horrifying moments and her long journey since. She has written an engrossing, unsentimental, beautifully poised account: as she struggles through the first months following the tragedy, furiously clenched against a reality that she cannot face and cannot deny; and then, over the ensuing years, as she emerges reluctantly, slowly allowing her memory to take her back through the rich and joyous life she’s mourning, from her family’s home in London, to the birth of her children, to the year she met her English husband at Cambridge, to her childhood in Colombo; all the while learning the difficult balance between the almost unbearable reminders of her loss and the need to keep her family, somehow, still alive within her.
Copy_Bio: Sonali Deraniyagala teaches in the Department of Economics at SOAS, University of London. Her books include Wave (2013), an acclaimed memoir of her experiences during and after the 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami.
Copy_Quotes:
“Courageous, truthful and, above all, generous . . . What amazed me most about the book is what good company it is. Deraniyagala is accepting and tender in her record of grief . . . Wave is in fact full of persisting life.”—Globe & Mail

“A devastating but ultimately redemptive memoir . . . The craft and control reflect an exceptional literary command . . . Excellent. Reading Deraniyagala’s account proves almost as cathartic as writing it must have been.”—Kirkus

“Deraniyagala has written a book teaming with beautiful ruminations on the bittersweetness of memory and the precariousness of life.”—Publishers Weekly
Awards_&_Accolades:
Winner — PEN/Ackerley Prize (2014)
Named — The New York Times 10 Best Books (2013)

Title_Subtitle: The Loneliness of Sonia and Sunny
Title: The Loneliness of Sonia and Sunny
Subtitle: A Novel
Refined_Long_Summary:
When Sonia and Sunny first glimpse each other on an overnight train, they are immediately captivated—yet also embarrassed by their grandparents' clumsy matchmaking attempts that had once driven them apart.

Sonia, an aspiring novelist fresh from her studies in Vermont's snowy mountains, has returned to her family in India, fearing she's haunted by a dark spell cast by an artist she once turned to for intimacy and inspiration. Sunny, a struggling journalist now in New York City, is fleeing his imperious mother and the violence of his warring clan.

Uncertain of their future, Sonia and Sunny embark on a search for happiness together as they confront the alienations of our modern world. This sweeping tale navigates the forces that shape their lives: country, class, race, history, and the complicated bonds linking one generation to the next. A love story, family saga, and rich novel of ideas from one of our most accomplished novelists.
Refined_Short_Summary: Two young people whose fates intersect across continents must navigate love, family expectations, and the pull between tradition and modernity. This sweeping epic from the Booker Prize winner will resonate with fans of Jhumpa Lahiri and Mohsin Hamid.
Refined_Bio: Kiran Desai is the bestselling author of Hullabaloo in the Guava Orchard and The Inheritance of Loss, which won both the Booker Prize and the National Book Critics Circle Award. Born in India, she moved to the US at sixteen and now lives in New York City.
Formatted_Quotes:
"Kiran Desai reveals the breadth and depth of time, how it weighs on families and nations caught within the drama of history. She captures this with a rare and astute sensitivity that, no matter her subject, casts a light on our present."

—Hisham Matar, Pulitzer Prize–winning author of The Return

"Literary love stories are vanishingly rare these days, and The Loneliness of Sonia and Sunny is that even more precious thing: a love story that's also profound, sparkling, funny, exquisitely written, and that teaches us how to live in full-throated exultation for the astonishments of this world. It has so many urgent things to say—about the costs and consolations of art, about power and class and race and freedom—that reading the book feels like a long conversation at night with your most interesting and ardent friend."

—Lauren Groff

"A powerful novel by a writer strong enough to pull back together worlds that are being pulled apart."

—Mohsin Hamid, New York Times bestselling author of Exit West
Short_Summary: A spellbinding story of two young people whose fates intersect and diverge across continents and years—an epic of love and family, India and America, tradition and modernity, by the Booker Prize-winning author of The Inheritance of Loss
Long_Summary:
When Sonia and Sunny first glimpse each other on an overnight train, they are immediately captivated, yet also embarrassed by the fact that their grandparents had once tried to matchmake them, a clumsy meddling that only served to drive Sonia and Sunny apart.

Sonia, an aspiring novelist who recently completed her studies in the snowy mountains of Vermont, has returned to her family in India, fearing she is haunted by a dark spell cast by an artist to whom she had once turned for intimacy and inspiration. Sunny, a struggling journalist resettled in New York City, is attempting to flee his imperious mother and the violence of his warring clan. Uncertain of their future, Sonia and Sunny embark on a search for happiness together as they confront the many alienations of our modern world.

The Loneliness of Sonia and Sunny is the sweeping tale of two young people navigating the many forces that shape their lives: country, class, race, history, and the complicated bonds that link one generation to the next. A love story, a family saga, and a rich novel of ideas, it is the most ambitious and accomplished work yet by one of our greatest novelists.

Title: Evicted
Subtitle: Poverty and Profit in the American City
Summary: Following eight Milwaukee families through eviction court and precarious rentals, Desmond shows how housing instability isn’t just a symptom of poverty—it’s a cause. Riveting narrative meets agenda-setting research.
Refined_Long_Summary:
In Evicted, Princeton sociologist and MacArthur Fellow Matthew Desmond follows eight families in Milwaukee as they struggle to keep roofs over their heads. Through intimate portraits of tenants and landlords, Desmond reveals how eviction has become a routine part of urban poverty—not just a consequence of being poor, but a primary cause of it.

Desmond spent years living in Milwaukee's poorest neighborhoods, documenting how families navigate impossible choices between paying rent and buying food, medicine, or heat. He shows how eviction creates a devastating cycle: families forced to move frequently can't build stability, children change schools constantly, and parents lose jobs due to housing disruptions.

Hailed as "wrenching and revelatory" by The Nation and "vivid and unsettling" by the New York Review of Books, Evicted transforms our understanding of poverty and economic exploitation. Its unforgettable scenes of hope and loss remind us that home is foundational—without stable housing, nothing else is possible. Desmond provides fresh ideas for solving one of America's most devastating problems.
Refined_Short_Summary: Through intimate portraits of eight Milwaukee families facing eviction, Desmond reveals how housing instability creates and perpetuates poverty. Essential reading that will change how you think about inequality in America.
Refined_Bio: Matthew Desmond is the Maurice P. During Professor of Sociology at Princeton University and founding director of the Eviction Lab. His book Evicted: Poverty and Profit in the American City won the Pulitzer Prize, National Book Critics Circle Award, and PEN/John Kenneth Galbraith Award. A MacArthur Fellow, he's also a contributing writer for The New York Times Magazine.
Formatted_Quotes:
"After reading Evicted, you'll realize you cannot have a serious conversation about poverty without talking about housing. . . . The book is that good, and it's that unignorable."

—Jennifer Senior, New York Times

"This book gave me a better sense of what it is like to be very poor in this country than anything else I have read. . . . It is beautifully written, thought-provoking, and unforgettable."

—Bill Gates

"My God, what [Evicted] lays bare about American poverty. It is devastating and infuriating and a necessary read."

—Roxane Gay, author of Bad Feminist and Difficult Women

Title: Trust
Subtitle: A Novel
Summary: At the height of 1920s Wall Street wealth, a tycoon and his wife become the subject of overlapping accounts—novels, memoirs, manuscripts—all telling different versions of their story. Trust is a dazzling metafictional puzzle that unravels themes of money, power, and truth itself. Diaz challenges readers to question who controls narratives and whose voices shape history.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Even through the roar and effervescence of the 1920s, everyone in New York has heard of Benjamin and Helen Rask. He is a legendary Wall Street tycoon; she is the daughter of eccentric aristocrats. Together, they have risen to the very top of a world of seemingly endless wealth—all as a decade of excess and speculation draws to an end.

But at what cost have they acquired their immense fortune? This is the mystery at the center of Bonds, a successful 1937 novel that all of New York seems to have read. Yet there are other versions of this tale of privilege and deceit.

Hernan Diaz's TRUST elegantly puts these competing narratives into conversation with one another—and in tension with the perspective of one woman bent on disentangling fact from fiction. The result is a novel that spans over a century and becomes more exhilarating with each new revelation.

At once an immersive story and a brilliant literary puzzle, TRUST engages readers in a quest for the truth while confronting the deceptions that live at the heart of personal relationships, the reality-warping force of capital, and the ease with which power can manipulate facts.
Refined_Short_Summary: Four different texts tell the story of a 1920s Wall Street power couple, but which version is true? This Pulitzer Prize-winning metafictional masterpiece will have you questioning everything about money, power, and who gets to control the narrative.

Long_Summary:
Even through the roar and effervescence of the 1920s, everyone in New York has heard of Benjamin and Helen Rask. He is a legendary Wall Street tycoon; she is the daughter of eccentric aristocrats. Together, they have risen to the very top of a world of seemingly endless wealth—all as a decade of excess and speculation draws to an end. But at what cost have they acquired their immense fortune? This is the mystery at the center of Bonds, a successful 1937 novel that all of New York seems to have read. Yet there are other versions of this tale of privilege and deceit.
Hernan Diaz’s TRUST elegantly puts these competing narratives into conversation with one another—and in tension with the perspective of one woman bent on disentangling fact from fiction. The result is a novel that spans over a century and becomes more exhilarating with each new revelation.
At once an immersive story and a brilliant literary puzzle, TRUST engages the reader in a quest for the truth while confronting the deceptions that often live at the heart of personal relationships, the reality-warping force of capital, and the ease with which power can manipulate facts.

Title_Subtitle: This Is How You Lose Her
Title: This Is How You Lose Her
Summary: Through linked stories, Díaz portrays the romantic misadventures of Yunior, a Dominican American man whose infidelity and longing expose the complexities of love, masculinity, and diaspora identity. Raw and funny, the collection is both intimate and universal.
Refined_Long_Summary:
On a beach in the Dominican Republic, a doomed relationship flounders. In a New Jersey laundry room, a woman does her lover's washing and thinks about his wife. In Boston, a man buys his love child, his only son, a first baseball bat and glove.

At the heart of these linked stories is the irrepressible, irresistible Yunior, a young hardhead whose longing for love is equaled only by his recklessness—and by the extraordinary women he loves and loses. Through his romantic misadventures, we witness the complexities of masculinity, infidelity, and what it means to navigate between Dominican and American identities.

In prose that is endlessly energetic, inventive, tender, and funny, these stories lay bare the infinite longing and inevitable weakness of the human heart. They remind us that passion always triumphs over experience, and that the half-life of love is forever.
Refined_Short_Summary: Yunior can't stop cheating, but he can't stop loving either. These raw, funny stories about a Dominican American man's romantic disasters will break your heart while making you laugh. Perfect for fans of Ocean Vuong's emotional intensity.
Refined_Bio: Junot Díaz is the author of Drown; The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao, which won the 2008 Pulitzer Prize and the National Book Critics Circle Award; and This Is How You Lose Her, a New York Times bestseller and National Book Award finalist. His first picture book, Islandborn, was a New York Times Bestseller and won the CLASP Américas Award 2019.
Formatted_Quotes:
"Nobody does scrappy, sassy, twice-the-speed of sound dialogue better than Junot Díaz. His exuberant short story collection, called This Is How You Lose Her, charts the lives of Dominican immigrants for whom the promise of America comes down to a minimum-wage paycheck, an occasional walk to a movie in a mall and the momentary escape of a grappling in bed."

—Maureen Corrigan, NPR

"Junot Díaz has one of the most distinctive and magnetic voices in contemporary fiction: limber, streetwise, caffeinated and wonderfully eclectic… The strongest tales are those fueled by the verbal energy and magpie language that made Brief Wondrous Life so memorable and that capture Yunior's efforts to commute between two cultures, Dominican and American, while always remaining an outsider."

—Michiko Kakutani, The New York Times

"Searing, sometimes hilarious, and always disarming… Readers will remember why everyone wants to write like Díaz, bring him home, or both. Raw and honest, these stories pulsate with raspy ghetto hip-hop and the subtler yet more vital echo of the human heart."

—Publishers Weekly

Title: Claire McCardell
Subtitle: The Designer Who Set Women Free
Refined_Long_Summary:
Claire McCardell forever changed fashion—and the lives of women. She shattered cultural norms around women's clothes, and today much of what we wear traces back to her ingenious, rebellious mind.

McCardell invented ballet flats and mix-and-match separates, introducing wrap dresses, hoodies, leggings, and denim into womenswear. She tossed out corsets in favor of comfortable elegance and insisted on pockets, even as male designers didn't see the need. She made zippers easy to reach because a woman "may live alone and like it," McCardell once wrote, "but you may regret it if you wrench your arm trying to zip a back zipper into place."

After World War II, McCardell fought the severe, hyper-feminized silhouette championed by male designers like Christian Dior. While Dior claimed he wanted to "save women from nature," McCardell wanted to set women free. As young journalist Betty Friedan called her in 1955, she became "The Gal Who Defied Dior."

Filled with personal drama and industry secrets, this story reveals how McCardell built an empire when women rarely reached the upper echelons of business. At its core, it's about our right to choose how we dress—and how we live.
Refined_Short_Summary: Meet Claire McCardell, the forgotten fashion revolutionary who invented everything from ballet flats to hoodies while fighting for women's freedom. Perfect for readers fascinated by hidden histories and female pioneers.
Refined_Bio: Elizabeth Evitts Dickinson is an award-winning journalist whose writing has appeared in The New York Times, Harper's Magazine, The New Yorker, The Southern Review, and The Washington Post Magazine. A National Endowment for the Arts Creative Writing Fellow, her work has been recognized in The Best American Essays and earned Maryland's prestigious Mary Sawyers Imboden Prize for literature. She lives in Baltimore with her husband and daughter.
Formatted_Quotes:
"An insightful, beautifully written tribute to a designer who was ahead of her time. In a world where women are still fighting for full agency, this book reminds us that fashion, at its best, is about freedom on our own terms. It's an essential read."

—Susan Magsamen, New York Times bestselling co-author of Your Brain on Art

"In the hands of Dickinson, this is more than just the biography of a fashion revolutionary: It is a story of the fight for women's identity and, incidentally, the birth of an American industry."

—The New York Times

"Dickinson illustrates how fashion served as a mirror for sociopolitical change...Fashion aficionados won't want to miss this."

—Publishers Weekly
Short_Summary: The riveting hidden history of Claire McCardell, the most influential fashion designer you’ve never heard of.
Long_Summary:
Claire McCardell forever changed fashion—and most importantly, the lives of women. She shattered cultural norms around women’s clothes, and today much of what we wear traces back to her ingenious, rebellious mind. McCardell invented ballet flats and mix-and-match separates, and she introduced wrap dresses, hoodies, leggings, denim, and more into womenswear. She tossed out corsets in favor of a comfortably elegant look and insisted on pockets, even as male designers didn’t see a need for them. She made zippers easy to reach because a woman “may live alone and like it,” McCardell once wrote, “but you may regret it if you wrench your arm trying to zip a back zipper into place.”

After World War II, McCardell fought the severe, hyper-feminized silhouette championed by male designers, like Christian Dior. Dior claimed that he wanted to “save women from nature.” McCardell, by contrast, wanted to set women free. Claire McCardell became, as the young journalist Betty Friedan called her in 1955, “The Gal Who Defied Dior.”

Filled with personal drama and industry secrets, this story reveals how Claire McCardell built an empire at a time when women rarely made the upper echelons of business. At its core, hers is a story about our right to choose how we dress—and our right to choose how we live.

A National Endowment for the Arts Creative Writing Fellow, Dickinson’s work has earned recognition in anthologies such as The Best American Essays and been awarded Maryland’s prestigious Mary Sawyers Imboden Prize for literature. Dickinson lives in Baltimore with her husband and daughter.

Title: Blue Nights
Summary: A poignant meditation on memory, illness, and the loss of her daughter, Didion reflects with her signature clarity and elegance on aging and grief.
Refined_Long_Summary:
From one of America's most powerful writers comes a work of stunning frankness about losing a daughter. Joan Didion examines her thoughts, fears, and doubts about parenthood, illness, and aging in this deeply personal meditation.

Blue Nights opens on July 26, 2010, as Didion reflects on what would have been her daughter Quintana's wedding anniversary. This triggers vivid memories of Quintana's childhood in Malibu, Brentwood, and school in Holmby Hills. Reflecting on her role as a parent, Didion asks the candid questions any parent might: How did she fail? What cues did she miss? "How could I have missed what was clearly there to be seen?" Perhaps we all remain fundamentally unknown to each other.

Woven throughout are moments that underscore Didion's own aging—something she finds difficult to acknowledge, much less accept. Blue Nights refers to the long, light evening hours of summer solstice, "the opposite of the dying of the brightness, but also its warning." Like The Year of Magical Thinking, this is an iconic work of incisive honesty, haunting and profoundly moving.
Refined_Short_Summary: Joan Didion's devastating meditation on losing her daughter and confronting her own mortality. If The Year of Magical Thinking moved you, this companion piece will leave you breathless with its unflinching honesty.
Refined_Bio: Joan Didion (1934–2021) was one of America's most distinct literary voices, author of five novels and nine nonfiction books, including Slouching Towards Bethlehem, The White Album, Play It As It Lays, and bestsellers The Year of Magical Thinking, Blue Nights, and South and West. She received numerous awards, including the National Book Award for Nonfiction and the National Book Foundation's Medal for Distinguished Contribution to American Letters.
Formatted_Quotes:
"A haunting memoir . . . Didion is, to my mind, the best living essayist in America . . . What appears on the surface to be an elegantly, intelligently, deeply felt, precisely written story of the loss of a beloved child is actually an elegantly, intelligently, deeply felt, precisely written glimpse into the abyss, a book that forces us to understand, to admit, that there can be no preparation for tragedy, no protection from it, and so, finally, no consolation . . . The book has . . . an incantatory quality: it is a beautiful, soaring, polyphonic eulogy, a beseeching prayer the is sung even as one knows the answer to one's plea, and that answer is: No."

—Cathleen Schine, The New York Times

"Darkly riveting . . . The cumulative effect of watching her finger her recollections like beads on a rosary is unexpectedly instructive. None of us can escape death, but Blue Nights shows how Didion has, with the devastating force of her penetrating mind, learned to simply abide."

—Louisa Kamps, Elle

"Brilliant...Nothing Didion has written since Play It As It Lays seems to me as right and true as Blue Nights. Nothing she has written seems as purposeful and urgent to be told."

—Joe Woodward, The Huffington Post
Short_Summary: A poignant meditation on memory, illness, and the loss of her daughter, Didion reflects with her signature clarity and elegance on aging and grief.
Long_Summary:
From one of our most powerful writers, a work of stunning frankness about losing a daughter. Richly textured with bits of her own childhood and married life with her husband, John Gregory Dunne, and daughter, Quintana Roo, this new book by Joan Didion examines her thoughts, fears, and doubts regarding having children, illness, and growing old.

Blue Nights opens on July 26, 2010, as Didion thinks back to Quintana’s wedding in New York seven years before. Today would be her wedding anniversary. This fact triggers vivid snapshots of Quintana’s childhood—in Malibu, in Brentwood, at school in Holmby Hills. Reflecting on her daughter but also on her role as a parent, Didion asks the candid questions any parent might about how she feels she failed either because cues were not taken or perhaps displaced. “How could I have missed what was clearly there to be seen?” Finally, perhaps we all remain unknown to each other. Seamlessly woven in are incidents Didion sees as underscoring her own age, something she finds hard to acknowledge, much less accept.

Blue Nights—the long, light evening hours that signal the summer solstice, “the opposite of the dying of the brightness, but also its warning”—like The Year of Magical Thinking before it, is an iconic book of incisive and electric honesty, haunting and profoundly moving.

Title_Subtitle: Beyond the Door of No Return
Title: Beyond the Door of No Return
Subtitle: A Novel
Summary: Set in 18th-century Senegal and France, Beyond the Door of No Return follows a French botanist who becomes obsessed with the story of a woman enslaved and lost to history. Diop crafts a haunting narrative about colonialism, memory, and the silenced voices of the past.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Paris, 1806. The renowned botanist Michel Adanson lies on his deathbed, his life's masterwork still incomplete. As he expires, the last word to escape his lips is a woman's name: Maram.

The key to this mysterious woman's identity lies hidden in Adanson's unpublished memoir, concealed in a secret compartment. Within its pages unfolds a story as fantastical as it is tragic: Maram is the fabled revenant, a young woman of noble birth from the kingdom of Waalo who was sold into slavery but escaped from the Island of Gorée to a hidden village in the forest.

As a young man on a research expedition in West Africa, Adanson heard her story and became obsessed with finding her. Accompanied by his guide, he ventured deep into the Senegalese bush on a journey that revealed both the savagery of French colonial occupation and the unlikely transports of the human heart.

Drawing on the richness of Senegal's oral traditions, Diop has constructed a love story like few others—a historical epic that illuminates the silenced voices of the past.
Refined_Short_Summary: When a French botanist becomes obsessed with finding an escaped slave known as the revenant, his search reveals devastating truths about colonialism and love. This stunning historical epic draws from Senegalese oral tradition to illuminate voices erased from history.
Refined_Bio: David Diop is the author of At Night All Blood Is Black, which was awarded the International Booker Prize and the Los Angeles Times Book Prize for Fiction. Born in Paris and raised in Senegal, he is a professor of literature at the University of Pau, where his research encompasses eighteenth-century French literature and European representations of Africa.
Formatted_Quotes:
"[A] mesmerizingly layered work of historical fiction . . . Diop, with remarkable tonal and narrative deftness, evokes and complicates [his character's] cathartic hopes in a way that feels unexpectedly timeless."

—The Atlantic

"A mesmerizing tale . . . Less brutal than Diop's International Booker Prize–winning At Night All Blood is Black (2020) but no less powerful . . . With its sumptuous physical descriptions, shades of language, and smooth overlap of truth and invention, this is masterful storytelling. The ease with which the narratives (including Aglaé's) unfold belies the emotional force they gather."

—Kirkus

"A captivating intergenerational epic influenced by Senegalese oral tradition . . . Told as a series of fast-paced stories within stories, the novel contemplates race, hierarchy, religion, legends . . . Diop writes excellently of historical and regional minutiae, as in his descriptions of the sheer heat and exhaustion his characters face on their travels. This is a novel to devour quickly, but which will leave readers contemplating its story long after."

—Publishers Weekly
Short_Summary: Set in 18th-century Senegal and France, Beyond the Door of No Return follows a French botanist who becomes obsessed with the story of a woman enslaved and lost to history. Diop crafts a haunting narrative about colonialism, memory, and the silenced voices of the past.
Long_Summary:
Paris, 1806. The renowned botanist Michel Adanson lies on his deathbed, the masterwork to which he dedicated his life still incomplete. As he expires, the last word to escape his lips is a woman’s name: Maram.

The key to this mysterious woman’s identity is Adanson’s unpublished memoir of the years he spent in Senegal, concealed in a secret compartment in a chest of drawers. Therein lies a story as fantastical as it is tragic: Maram, it turns out, is none other than the fabled revenant. A young woman of noble birth from the kingdom of Waalo, Maram was sold into slavery but managed to escape from the Island of Gorée—a major embarkation point of the transatlantic slave trade—to a small village hidden in the forest. While on a research expedition in West Africa as a young man, Adanson hears the story of the revenant and becomes obsessed with finding her. Accompanied by his guide, he ventures deep into the Senegalese bush on a journey that reveals not only the savagery of the French colonial occupation but also the unlikely transports of the human heart.

Written with sensitivity and unrivaled narrative flair, David Diop’s Beyond the Door of No Return is a love story like few others. Drawing on the richness and lyricism of Senegal’s oral traditions, Diop has constructed a historical epic of the highest order.

Title: The Copenhagen Trilogy
Subtitle: Childhood; Youth; Dependency
Summary: This rediscovered Danish classic traces Ditlevsen’s life from girlhood to addiction, in prose as piercing as it is lyrical, capturing art, love, and self-destruction.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Tove Ditlevsen is today celebrated as one of the most important voices in twentieth-century Danish literature, and the Copenhagen Trilogy is her rediscovered masterpiece.

Childhood follows a misfit girl's fierce determination to become a poet despite her working-class circumstances. Youth captures her early experiences with sex, work, and hard-won independence. In Dependency, she embarks on the first of four marriages and spirals into drug addiction, enabled by her manipulative doctor-husband.

Throughout, Ditlevsen grapples with the impossible tension between her calling as a writer and her roles as daughter, wife, mother, and addict. Dismissed by critics during her lifetime, the trilogy is now hailed as a literary triumph and spiritual forerunner of today's autofiction. Ditlevsen's work is remarkable for its unflinching intensity and immersive exploration of female friendship, family dynamics, and the brutal reality of a young woman fighting to be taken seriously as an artist.
Refined_Short_Summary: Elena Ferrante fans will be obsessed with this rediscovered Danish masterpiece. Ditlevsen traces her journey from determined young poet to struggling addict with prose that's both piercing and devastatingly honest.
Refined_Bio: Tove Ditlevsen was born in 1917 in a working-class Copenhagen neighborhood. Her first poetry volume was published in her early twenties, followed by many more books, including the three volumes of the Copenhagen Trilogy: Childhood (1967), Youth (1967), and Dependency (1971). She died in 1976.
Formatted_Quotes:
"A particular kind of masterpiece, one that helps fill a particular kind of void. Ditlevsen's voice, diffident and funny, dead-on about her own mistakes, is a welcome addition to that canon of women who showed us their secret faces so that we might wear our own."

—The New York Times

"Ditlevsen's taut, simple prose shines a light on what life and love were like for working-class women in 20th century Copenhagen. Elena Ferrante fans, take note."

—Stylist

"Intense and elegant ... an absolute tour de force."

—Lucy Scholes, The Paris Review
Short_Summary: This rediscovered Danish classic traces Ditlevsen’s life from girlhood to addiction, in prose as piercing as it is lyrical, capturing art, love, and self-destruction.
Long_Summary:
Tove Ditlevsen is today celebrated as one of the most important and unique voices in twentieth-century Danish literature, and the Copenhagen Trilogy (1969–71) is her rediscovered masterpiece. Childhood tells the story of a misfit child’s single-minded determination to become a poet; Youth describes her early experiences of sex, work, and independence. In Dependency, the narrator embarks on the first of her four marriages and descends into drug addiction, enabled by her sinister, gaslighting doctor-husband.

Throughout, the narrator grapples with the tension between her vocation as a writer and her competing roles as daughter, wife, mother, and drug addict. Dismissed by the critical establishment in the author’s lifetime, and currently regarded as a literary triumph and spiritual forerunner of today's autofiction, Ditlevsen’s trilogy is remarkable for its intensity and its immersive exploration of female friendships and family life, the struggles of a young woman to be taken seriously as a writer, and the vicious spiral of substance abuse.
Copy_Bio: Tove Ditlevsen was born in 1917 in a working-class neighborhood in Copenhagen. Her first volume of poetry was published when she was in her early twenties and was followed by many more books, including the three volumes of the Copenhagen Trilogy: Childhood (1967), Youth (1967), and Dependency (1971). She died in 1976.

Title_Subtitle: All the Light We Cannot See
Title: All the Light We Cannot See
Subtitle: A Novel
Summary: In Nazi-occupied France, the paths of a blind French girl and a German boy trained by the Hitler Youth converge. All the Light We Cannot See is a luminous story of resilience, humanity, and the small acts of kindness that endure amid war.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Marie-Laure lives with her father in Paris near the Museum of Natural History, where he works as the master of its thousands of locks. When she goes blind at six, her father builds a perfect miniature of their neighborhood so she can memorize it by touch and navigate her way home.

When she is twelve, the Nazis occupy Paris, and father and daughter flee to the walled citadel of Saint-Malo, where Marie-Laure's reclusive great uncle lives in a tall house by the sea. With them they carry what might be the museum's most valuable and dangerous jewel.

In a mining town in Germany, the orphan Werner grows up with his younger sister, enchanted by a crude radio they find. Werner becomes an expert at building and fixing these crucial instruments, a talent that wins him a place at a brutal academy for Hitler Youth, then a special assignment to track the Resistance. More and more aware of the human cost of his intelligence, Werner travels through the heart of the war and, finally, into Saint-Malo, where his story and Marie-Laure's converge.
Refined_Short_Summary: Two lives intersect in Nazi-occupied France: a blind girl carrying a dangerous jewel and a German boy tracking the Resistance. This Pulitzer Prize winner weaves their stories into an unforgettable tale of survival and humanity during World War II.

Henry Prizes, the Rome Prize, the Young Lions Award, a Guggenheim Fellowship, and the Story Prize. Born in Cleveland, he lives in Boise with his wife and two sons.
