Title: Cloud Cuckoo Land
Subtitle: A Novel
Summary: Spanning centuries and continents, Cloud Cuckoo Land interlaces the stories of children and dreamers—from 15th-century Constantinople to a spaceship traveling the future—united by a single ancient text. Richly imaginative, Doerr’s novel is a celebration of storytelling’s power to endure across time and space.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Among the most celebrated novels of recent times, Cloud Cuckoo Land is a triumph of imagination and compassion—a soaring story about dreamers and outsiders whose lives span centuries, all connected by the power of a single ancient book.

In 15th-century Constantinople, orphaned Anna learns to read within the city's formidable walls. In this ancient center of learning, she discovers what might be the last copy of a centuries-old story about Aethon, who longs to become a bird and fly to a utopian paradise. Outside the walls, village boy Omeir is conscripted with his beloved oxen into the army besieging the city. Their paths will cross in unexpected ways.

In present-day Idaho, octogenarian Zeno rehearses children in a play adaptation of Aethon's story, preserved against all odds through the centuries. Hidden among the library shelves is a bomb, planted by troubled teenager Seymour—creating another kind of siege.

In the not-so-distant future, aboard the interstellar ship Argos, Konstance sits alone in a vault, copying Aethon's story onto scraps of sacking, carrying forward the tale her father once told her.

Doerr's dazzling imagination transports us across worlds so immersive we forget our own, celebrating storytelling's eternal power to connect us across time and space.
Refined_Short_Summary: Five lives across centuries—from besieged Constantinople to a future spaceship—intertwine through one ancient story about a man who dreams of becoming a bird. Doerr weaves magic that'll remind you why The Midnight Library hit so hard.
Refined_Bio: Anthony Doerr is the author of the New York Times bestselling Cloud Cuckoo Land, a National Book Award finalist, and All the Light We Cannot See, winner of the Pulitzer Prize, Carnegie Medal, and Alex Award. He's also written the story collections Memory Wall and The Shell Collector, the novel About Grace, and memoir Four Seasons in Rome. His honors include five O. Henry Prizes, the Rome Prize, a Guggenheim Fellowship, and the Story Prize. Born in Cleveland, he lives in Boise with his wife and two sons.
Formatted_Quotes:
"Of all our contemporary fiction writers, Anthony Doerr is the one whose novels seem to be the purest response to the primal request: tell me a story. . . . [Cloud Cuckoo Land] transports us far above the stars, and down into the mud. It dazzles, and disturbs. And I for one wanted Doerr's vast and overwhelming story to last much, much longer."

—Maureen Corrigan, NPR

"There is a kind of book a seasoned writer produces after a big success: large-hearted, wide in scope and joyous. Following his Pulitzer winner All the Light We Cannot See, Anthony Doerr's Cloud Cuckoo Land is a deep lungful of fresh air–and a gift of a novel."

—Elizabeth Knox, The Guardian

"In a big fiction year . . . Cloud Cuckoo Land stands out. . . . Doerr's characters are astoundingly resilient, suggesting that we may yet save ourselves, with literature an essential tool."

—Hamilton Cain, Boston Globe

Among the most celebrated and beloved novels of recent times, Cloud Cuckoo Land is a triumph of imagination and compassion, a soaring story about children on the cusp of adulthood in worlds in peril, who find resilience, hope, and a book.

In the 15th century, an orphan named Anna lives inside the formidable walls of Constantinople. She learns to read, and in this ancient city, famous for its libraries, she finds what might be the last copy of a centuries-old book, the story of Aethon, who longs to be turned into a bird so that he can fly to a utopian paradise in the sky. Outside the walls is Omeir, a village boy, conscripted with his beloved oxen into the army that will lay siege to the city. His path and Anna’s will cross.

In the present day, in a library in Idaho, octogenarian Zeno rehearses children in a play adaptation of Aethon’s story, preserved against all odds through centuries. Tucked among the library shelves is a bomb, planted by a troubled, idealistic teenager, Seymour. This is another siege.

And in a not-so-distant future, on the interstellar ship Argos, Konstance is alone in a vault, copying on scraps of sacking the story of Aethon, told to her by her father.

Anna, Omeir, Seymour, Zeno, and Konstance are dreamers and outsiders whose lives are gloriously intertwined. Doerr’s dazzling imagination transports us to worlds so dramatic and immersive that we forget, for a time, our own.

Title_Subtitle: All the Frequent Troubles of Our Days
Title: All the Frequent Troubles of Our Days
Subtitle: The True Story of the American Woman at the Heart of the German Resistance to Hitler
Summary: A riveting biography of Mildred Harnack, the only American in the German resistance against Hitler, blending archival research with novelistic storytelling.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Born and raised in Milwaukee, Mildred Harnack was twenty-six when she enrolled in a PhD program in Germany and witnessed the meteoric rise of the Nazi party. In 1932, she began holding secret meetings in her apartment—a small band of political activists that by 1940 had grown into the largest underground resistance group in Berlin.

She recruited working-class Germans into the resistance, helped Jews escape, plotted acts of sabotage, and collaborated in writing leaflets that denounced Hitler and called for revolution. Her coconspirators circulated through Berlin under cover of night, slipping the leaflets into mailboxes, public restrooms, and phone booths. When the first shots of World War II were fired, she became a spy, couriering top-secret intelligence to the Allies.

Historians identify Mildred Harnack as the only American in the leadership of the German resistance, yet her remarkable story has remained almost unknown until now. Harnack's great-great-niece Rebecca Donner draws on extensive archival research across four countries and newly uncovered family documents to produce this astonishing work of narrative nonfiction. Fusing biography, real-life political thriller, and scholarly detective story, Donner brilliantly interweaves letters, diary entries, smuggled prison notes, and declassified intelligence documents into a powerful epic that reconstructs the moral courage of an enigmatic woman nearly erased by history.
Refined_Short_Summary: The untold story of Mildred Harnack, the only American to lead German resistance against Hitler. This masterful biography reads like a thriller while honoring an extraordinary woman history nearly forgot.
Refined_Bio: Rebecca Donner was awarded a Guggenheim Fellowship in 2022 and was a 2018-19 Biography Fellow at the Leon Levy Center for Biography. She's a two-time Yaddo Fellow and has received fellowships from the Ucross Foundation twice. Her essays, reportage, and reviews have appeared in the New York Times, Bookforum, and other publications. All the Frequent Troubles of Our Days is her third book, following two critically acclaimed works of fiction.
Formatted_Quotes:
"At once boldly imagined and lovingly researched, All the Frequent Troubles of Our Days sets the remarkable story of resistance fighter Mildred Harnack against the backdrop of daily life in Germany as Hitler tightened his grip on the nation. Epic in sweep, written with a novelist's attention to detail and a historian's perspective on social and political forces, this book opens up new possibilities for biography."

—Ruth Franklin, winner of the NBCC Award for Biography, author of Shirley Jackson: A Rather Haunted Life

"Extraordinarily intimate… Wilder and more expansive than a standard-issue biography… a real-life thriller with a cruel ending—not to mention an account of Hitler's ascent from attention-seeking buffoon to genocidal Führer."

—Jennifer Szalai, New York Times

"A stunning biography... Donner's research is impeccable, and her fluid prose and vivid character sketches keep the pages turning…This standout history isn't to be missed."

—Publishers Weekly
Short_Summary: A riveting biography of Mildred Harnack, the only American in the German resistance against Hitler, blending archival research with novelistic storytelling.
Long_Summary:
Born and raised in Milwaukee, Mildred Harnack was twenty-six when she enrolled in a PhD program in Germany and witnessed the meteoric rise of the Nazi party. In 1932, she began holding secret meetings in her apartment—a small band of political activists that by 1940 had grown into the largest underground resistance group in Berlin. She recruited working-class Germans into the resistance, helped Jews escape, plotted acts of sabotage, and collaborated in writing leaflets that denounced Hitler and called for revolution. Her coconspirators circulated through Berlin under the cover of night, slipping the leaflets into mailboxes, public restrooms, phone booths. When the first shots of the Second World War were fired, she became a spy, couriering top-secret intelligence to the Allies. On the eve of her escape to Sweden, she was ambushed by the Gestapo. At a Nazi military court, a panel of five judges sentenced her to six years at a prison camp, but Hitler overruled the decision and ordered her execution. On February 16, 1943, she was strapped to a guillotine and beheaded.

Historians identify Mildred Harnack as the only American in the leadership of the German resistance, yet her remarkable story has remained almost unknown until now.

Harnack’s great-great-niece Rebecca Donner draws on her extensive archival research in Germany, Russia, England, and the U.S. as well as newly uncovered documents in her family archive to produce this astonishing work of narrative nonfiction. Fusing elements of biography, real-life political thriller, and scholarly detective story, Donner brilliantly interweaves letters, diary entries, notes smuggled out of a Berlin prison, survivors’ testimony, and a trove of declassified intelligence documents into a powerful, epic story, reconstructing the moral courage of an enigmatic woman nearly erased by history.

Epic in sweep, written with a novelist’s attention to detail and a historian’s perspective on social and political forces, this book opens up new possibilities for biography.”—Ruth Franklin, winner of the NBCC Award for Biography, author of Shirley Jackson: A Rather Haunted Life

“Extraordinarily intimate… Wilder and more expansive than a standard-issue biography… a real-life thriller with a cruel ending—not to mention an account of Hitler’s ascent from attention-seeking buffoon to genocidal Führer.”—Jennifer Szalai, New York Times

"A stunning biography... Donner’s research is impeccable, and her fluid prose and vivid character sketches keep the pages turning…This standout history isn’t to be missed.”—Publishers Weekly

Title: Room
Subtitle: A Novel
Summary: Told through the eyes of a five-year-old boy, Room depicts life in captivity with his mother in a single locked space, and their eventual escape into a wider, terrifying world. Both harrowing and tender, it’s a novel of survival, love, and resilience.
Refined_Long_Summary:
To five-year-old Jack, Room is the entire world. It's where he was born, where he and his Ma eat, sleep, play, and learn together. At night, his Ma tucks him safely in the wardrobe, where he's supposed to be asleep when Old Nick visits.

For Jack, Room is home. But for Ma, it's the prison where she's been held captive for seven years. Through fierce maternal love, she's created a full life for her son within this eleven-by-eleven-foot space, shielding him from the horror of their reality.

As Jack's curiosity grows alongside Ma's mounting desperation, she realizes that Room cannot contain either of them much longer. What follows is a tale both shocking and exhilarating—a story of unconquerable love in the most harrowing circumstances, and the unbreakable bond between mother and child.
Refined_Short_Summary: Told through the eyes of five-year-old Jack, this devastating novel explores captivity, freedom, and the fierce bond between mother and child. Fans of We Need to Talk About Kevin will be mesmerized by this unique perspective.
Refined_Bio: Emma Donoghue is the author of sixteen novels, including the award-winning national bestseller Room, basis for the acclaimed film. Her latest novel is The Paris Express. She has written screenplays for Room and The Wonder, plus nine stage plays. Her next film adaptation is H Is for Hawk. Born in Dublin, she lives in Ontario with her family.
Formatted_Quotes:
"Emma Donoghue's writing is superb alchemy, changing innocence into horror and horror into tenderness. Room is a book to read in one sitting. When it's over you look up: the world looks the same but you are somehow different and that feeling lingers for days."

"Powerful.... Seen entirely through Jack's eyes and childlike perceptions, the developments in this novel--there are enough plot twists to provide a dramatic arc of breathtaking suspense--are astonishing.... Donoghue brilliantly portrays the psyche of a child raised in captivity...will keep readers rapt."

—Publishers Weekly

"one of the most affecting and subtly profound novels of the year"

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

Room is a tale at once shocking, riveting, exhilarating — a story of unconquerable love in harrowing circumstances, and of the diamond-hard bond between a mother and her child.

Title: The Pull of the Stars
Subtitle: A Novel
BISAC_Category_Description: Fiction / Historical / 20th Century / World War I
Summary: In a Dublin hospital during the 1918 flu pandemic, nurse Julia Power tends to expectant mothers quarantined with influenza. Over three intense days, her life intertwines with a volunteer and a rebel doctor. The Pull of the Stars is an intimate, urgent story of resilience, compassion, and hope amid crisis.
Refined_Long_Summary:
In 1918 Dublin, ravaged by war and the deadly flu pandemic, Nurse Julia Power works at an understaffed hospital where expectant mothers infected with the terrible new disease are quarantined together. Her ordered world is disrupted by two unexpected arrivals: Doctor Kathleen Lynn, a rumored rebel fleeing police, and young volunteer Bridie Sweeney.

Over three intense days in this cramped maternity ward, these women's lives become unexpectedly intertwined. They witness heartbreaking losses to the baffling pandemic, but also help shepherd new life into a frightening world. Through tireless care and quiet acts of humanity, these caregivers and mothers somehow manage their impossible work.

Emma Donoghue finds light in the darkness of this historical moment, crafting a story of hope and survival against overwhelming odds.
Refined_Short_Summary: Set during the 1918 flu pandemic, this follows three women in a Dublin maternity ward over three transformative days. Donoghue delivers another intimate masterpiece exploring resilience in crisis—perfect for readers who were moved by The Midnight Library or Station Eleven.

They lose patients to this baffling pandemic, but they also shepherd new life into a fearful world. With tireless tenderness and humanity, carers and mothers alike somehow do their impossible work.

In The Pull of the Stars, Emma Donoghue once again finds the light in the darkness in this new classic of hope and survival against all odds.

Title_Subtitle: There is Power in a Union
Title: There is Power in a Union
Subtitle: The Epic Story of Labor in America
Summary: A sweeping history of the American labor movement, from its nineteenth-century origins to its lasting impact on politics, economics, and civil rights.
Refined_Long_Summary:
From the textile mills of Lowell, Massachusetts—America's first real factories—to the triumph of unions in the twentieth century and their declining influence today, the battle between labor and capital has fundamentally shaped our national experience.

Philip Dray delivers an epic, character-driven narrative that follows this struggle for security and dignity across diverse settings: picket lines and union halls, jails and assembly lines, corporate boardrooms, courtrooms, Congress, and the White House. He demonstrates with visceral drama the urgency of the fight for fairness and economic democracy.

This sweeping history illuminates organized labor's vital accomplishments and central role in America's social, political, economic, and cultural evolution. Dray's ambitious work reveals how the contest for American bounty between workers and owners created the country we know today—making this story especially relevant as ordinary Americans face mounting economic anxiety.
Refined_Short_Summary: This sweeping history traces American labor from factory floors to union halls, revealing how workers' fights for dignity shaped our nation. Essential reading for anyone trying to understand today's economic struggles and workplace battles.
Refined_Bio: Philip Dray is the author of several books of American cultural and political history, including At the Hands of Persons Unknown: The Lynching of Black America, which won the Robert F. Kennedy Book Award and was a Pulitzer Prize finalist; There Is Power in a Union: The Epic Story of Labor in America; and Capitol Men: The Epic Story of Reconstruction Through the Lives of the First Black Congressmen. He is an adjunct professor in the Journalism + Design Department at Eugene Lang College of Liberal Arts and lives in Brooklyn, New York.
Formatted_Quotes:
"Philip Dray's big and bold history of organized labor in America splendidly retells a story - or a multitude of stories - badly in need of retelling. The labor movement's decline in recent decades has accompanied a great national amnesia about all that the movement achieved for the nation. That amnesia threatens those achievements, so Dray's book is timely as well as gripping."

—Sean Wilentz, author of Chants Democratic: New York City and the Rise of the American Working Class & Bob Dylan in America

"The unending struggle between unions and big business has never been more vividly told. Philip Dray is a marvelous story teller who brings history memorably alive, and you will not soon forget the tales of murder and greed, commitment and sacrifice, that fill these pages. But this is more than history; the compelling saga of labor as a crucible for social change should prompt some honest and hard debate about what's happening to working men and women today."

—Bill Moyers

"Any union leader working to define and strengthen the role of organized labor in the 21st century must read There Is Power in a Union, a comprehensive and fascinating history of the American labor movement."

—Michael Winship, President, Writers Guild of America
Short_Summary: From an award-winning historian, a stirring (and timely) narrative history of American labor from the dawn of the industrial age to the present day.

The author demonstrates, viscerally and dramatically, the urgency of the fight for fairness and economic democracy-a struggle that remains especially urgent today, when ordinary Americans are so anxious and beset by eco­nomic woes.

Title: Washington Black
Subtitle: A novel
Summary: George Washington Black, an enslaved boy on a Barbados plantation, becomes the apprentice of an eccentric inventor. Their escape launches a globe-spanning adventure of science, freedom, and self-discovery. Washington Black is both a page-turner and a profound meditation on identity.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Eleven-year-old George Washington Black—known as Wash—is a field slave on a Barbados sugar plantation when he's chosen as manservant to his master's eccentric brother, Christopher Wilde. What begins as terror transforms into wonder as Wash discovers Christopher is a naturalist, explorer, inventor, and abolitionist who introduces him to a world of flying machines and scientific marvels.

For the first time, Wash glimpses a life of dignity and meaning beyond his chains. But when a man is killed and a bounty is placed on Wash's head, he and Christopher must flee together across the globe. Their shared journey becomes one of separation as Wash searches for his true identity and place in the world.

Spanning from the Caribbean to the Arctic, London to Morocco, this is an epic story of self-invention and betrayal, love and redemption. Washington Black explores what it means to be truly free in a world where humanity must be fought for and won.
Refined_Short_Summary: When a young slave becomes assistant to an abolitionist scientist, he discovers a world beyond his chains—until danger forces them to flee across continents. Perfect for readers who were captivated by The Underground Railroad's blend of historical truth and soaring imagination.
Refined_Bio: Esi Edugyan, raised in Calgary and educated at Johns Hopkins University and the University of Victoria, is the internationally bestselling author of Washington Black, Half-Blood Blues, and The Second Life of Samuel Tyne. Her work has won the Scotiabank Giller Prize twice and earned Man Booker Prize and Governor General's Literary Award nominations. She's held fellowships across the U.S., Europe, and Iceland, and lives in Victoria, British Columbia.
Formatted_Quotes:
"A thrilling page-turner . . . also a lyrical contemplation of captivity and freedom, and the scars that stay with us for life."

—Marsha Lederman, Globe & Mail

"Edugyan's magnificent third novel again demonstrates her range and gifts . . . Framing the story with rich evocations of the era's science and the world it studies, Edugyan mines the tensions between individual goodwill and systemic oppression, belonging and exclusion, wonder and terror, and human and natural order . . . Crafted in supple, nuanced prose, Edugyan's novel is both searing and beautiful."

—Publishers Weekly

"High adventure fraught with cliffhanger twists marks this runaway-slave narrative, which leaps, sails, and soars from Caribbean cane fields to the fringes of the frozen Arctic and across a whole ocean . . . One of the most unconventional escapes from slavery ever chronicled . . . Edugyan displays as much ingenuity and resourcefulness as her main characters in spinning this yarn, and the reader's expectations are upended almost as often as her hero's. A thoughtful, boldly imagined ripsnorter that broadens inventive possibilities for the antebellum novel."

—Kirkus
Short_Summary: “A gripping historical narrative exploring both the bounds of slavery and what it means to be truly free.” —Vanity Fair
Long_Summary:
Eleven-year-old George Washington Black—or Wash—a field slave on a Barbados sugar plantation, is initially terrified when he is chosen as the manservant of his master’s brother. To his surprise, however, the eccentric Christopher Wilde turns out to be a naturalist, explorer, inventor, and abolitionist. Soon Wash is initiated into a world where a flying machine can carry a man across the sky, where even a boy born in chains may embrace a life of dignity and meaning, and where two people, separated by an impossible divide, can begin to see each other as human.
 
But when a man is killed and a bounty is placed on Wash’s head, they must abandon everything and flee together. Over the course of their travels, what brings Wash and Christopher together will tear them apart, propelling Wash ever farther across the globe in search of his true self. Spanning the Caribbean to the frozen Far North, London to Morocco, Washington Black is a story of self-invention and betrayal, of love and redemption, and of a world destroyed and made whole again.
Copy_Bio: A graduate of Johns Hopkins University and the University of Victoria, Esi Edugyan was raised in Calgary, Alberta. She is the award-winning and internationally bestselling author of Washington Black, which was a finalist for the Rogers Writers' Trust Fiction Prize and the Man Booker Award and won the Scotiabank Giller Prize; Half-Blood Blues, which was a finalist for the Governor General's Literary Award and the Man Booker Prize and won the Scotiabank Giller Prize; and The Second Life of Samuel Tyne. She is also the author of Dreaming of Elsewhere, which is part of the Kreisel Memorial Lecture Series. She has held fellowships in the U.S., Scotland, Iceland, Germany, Hungary, Finland, Spain, and Belgium. She lives in Victoria, British Columbia.

Title_Subtitle: A Visit from the Goon Squad
Title: A Visit from the Goon Squad
Summary: Linked stories trace the lives of a record executive, his assistant, and their orbit of friends over decades. Blending time shifts and experimental styles, A Visit from the Goon Squad is a dazzling exploration of aging, music, and memory.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Bennie is an aging former punk rocker turned record executive, still chasing the music that once defined him. Sasha is the passionate, troubled young woman he employs, carrying secrets of her own. Jennifer Egan brilliantly weaves together their stories, revealing how their pasts shaped them and exploring the inner lives of a host of other characters whose paths intersect with theirs.

With music pulsing through every page, this startling novel moves through time and perspective, showing how the soundtrack of our lives connects us across decades. It's a story of self-destruction and redemption, of dreams deferred and second chances, featuring characters you'll care deeply about as you watch them make mistakes, find grace, and act gloriously, infuriatingly human.
Refined_Short_Summary: Music, time, and human connection collide in this Pulitzer Prize-winning masterpiece that jumps between decades and perspectives. If you loved the interconnected storytelling of Cloud Atlas or the nostalgic punch of Daisy Jones & The Six, this brilliant novel will stay with you long after the final page.
Refined_Bio: Jennifer Egan is the author of six previous books of fiction: Manhattan Beach, winner of the Andrew Carnegie Medal for Excellence in Fiction; A Visit from the Goon Squad, which won the Pulitzer Prize and the National Book Critics Circle Award; The Keep; the story collection Emerald City; Look at Me, a National Book Award Finalist; and The Invisible Circus. Her work has appeared in The New Yorker, Harper's Magazine, Granta, McSweeney's, and The New York Times Magazine.
Formatted_Quotes:
"A spiky, shape-shifting new book. . . . A display of Egan's extreme virtuosity."

—The New York Times

"Frequently dazzling. . . . Egan's expert flaying of human foibles has the compulsive allure of poking at a sore tooth: excruciating but exhilarating too."

—Entertainment Weekly

"If Egan is our reward for living through the self-conscious gimmicks and ironic claptrap of postmodernism, then it was all worthwhile. . . . [A] triumph of technical bravado and tender sympathy. . . . Turn up the music, skip the college reunion and curl up with The Goon Squad instead."

—The Washington Post

Title: The Candy House
Subtitle: A Novel
Summary: In a near-future world, a revolutionary technology allows people to upload and share their memories. Through interconnected characters, The Candy House explores the allure and dangers of this new collective consciousness. Expansive yet intimate, the novel weaves questions of privacy, authenticity, and connection into a kaleidoscopic portrait of modern life.
Refined_Long_Summary:
The Candy House opens with tech mogul Bix Bouton, whose company Mandala has made him "one of those tech demi-gods with whom we're all on a first name basis." At forty, with four kids and desperate for his next breakthrough, Bix stumbles into a conversation group of Columbia professors. One is experimenting with "externalizing" memory—and within a decade, Bix has transformed this into "Own Your Unconscious," technology that allows access to every memory you've ever had and lets you share memories in exchange for others'.

In Egan's spectacular imagination, there are "counters" who track and exploit desires, and "eluders" who understand the price of taking a bite of the Candy House. She introduces these characters through an astonishing array of narrative styles—omniscient, first person plural, dueling voices, epistolary chapters, and even tweets.

Intellectually dazzling yet deeply human, The Candy House is a moving testament to our tenacity and transcendence in the eternal quest for connection, family, privacy, and love.
Refined_Short_Summary: Tech mogul Bix Bouton creates technology that lets you access and share every memory you've ever had, seducing multitudes in the process. Egan's prismatic storytelling explores the price of connection in our digital age through an astonishing array of narrative styles.
Refined_Bio: Jennifer Egan is the author of six previous books of fiction: Manhattan Beach, winner of the Andrew Carnegie Medal for Excellence in Fiction; A Visit from the Goon Squad, which won the Pulitzer Prize and the National Book Critics Circle Award; The Keep; the story collection Emerald City; Look at Me, a National Book Award Finalist; and The Invisible Circus. Her work has appeared in The New Yorker, Harper's Magazine, Granta, McSweeney's, and The New York Times Magazine.
Formatted_Quotes:
"The novel — with its prismatic plotting and ever-shifting chorus of seekers, kooks, and visionaries — feels less like a house than a honeycomb full of fantastical rooms, each one alive and thrumming with bright, weird humanity."

—Leah Greenblatt, Entertainment Weekly

"This is minimalist maximalism. It's as if Egan compressed a big 19th-century triple-decker novel onto a flash drive… Egan goes all in on the power of storytelling and of fiction."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

"A brilliant demonstration of the unquantifiable pleasures of great fiction."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post
Short_Summary: From one of the most celebrated writers of our time comes an “inventive, effervescent” (Oprah Daily) novel about the memory and quest for authenticity and human connection.
Long_Summary:
The Candy House opens with the staggeringly brilliant Bix Bouton, whose company, Mandala, is so successful that he is “one of those tech demi-gods with whom we’re all on a first name basis.” Bix is forty, with four kids, restless, and desperate for a new idea, when he stumbles into a conversation group, mostly Columbia professors, one of whom is experimenting with downloading or “externalizing” memory. Within a decade, Bix’s new technology, “Own Your Unconscious”—which allows you access to every memory you’ve ever had, and to share your memories in exchange for access to the memories of others—has seduced multitudes.

In the world of Egan’s spectacular imagination, there are “counters” who track and exploit desires and there are “eluders,” those who understand the price of taking a bite of the Candy House. Egan introduces these characters in an astonishing array of narrative styles—from omniscient to first person plural to a duet of voices, an epistolary chapter, and a chapter of tweets. Intellectually dazzling, The Candy House is also a moving testament to the tenacity and transcendence of human longing for connection, family, privacy, and love.

Title: Manhattan Beach
Subtitle: A Novel
Summary: During World War II, Anna Kerrigan works at the Brooklyn Naval Yard while her father disappears into the criminal underworld. Caught between family secrets and new independence, Anna’s journey is one of survival, courage, and reinvention.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Eleven-year-old Anna Kerrigan accompanies her father to visit Dexter Styles, sensing this mysterious man holds the key to her family's survival. She's mesmerized by the sea beyond his house and the charged tension between the two men.

Years later, her father has vanished and America is at war. Anna works at the Brooklyn Naval Yard, where women now fill roles once held by men fighting overseas. She becomes the first female diver—the most dangerous and exclusive occupation—repairing ships crucial to winning the war.

One evening at a nightclub, Anna encounters Dexter Styles again and begins unraveling the complexity of her father's life and the reasons behind his disappearance. With the atmosphere of a noir thriller, Egan plunges readers into a world of gangsters, sailors, divers, and union men. This deft, propulsive exploration captures a transformative moment in the lives of women and men, and in America itself.
Refined_Short_Summary: When Anna's father vanishes into New York's criminal underworld during WWII, she becomes the first female diver at Brooklyn Naval Yard. This atmospheric noir explores family secrets and female resilience with the complexity of Gone Girl.
Refined_Bio: Jennifer Egan is the author of six books of fiction, including Manhattan Beach, winner of the Andrew Carnegie Medal for Excellence in Fiction, and A Visit from the Goon Squad, which won the Pulitzer Prize and National Book Critics Circle Award. Her other works include The Keep, Emerald City, Look at Me (a National Book Award Finalist), and The Invisible Circus. Her work has appeared in The New Yorker, Harper's Magazine, and The New York Times Magazine.
Formatted_Quotes:
"A bounteous miracle that makes you feel that past time, and our time, differently; everything becomes freshly energized, infused with humanity, vital, sad, and full of importance. To see the world through Egan's eyes is to be moved, through language, to new adoration of the world. I don't know a better writer working today. There is a generosity in her prose that is vastly enlivening to its reader and brings about that beautiful effect fiction sometimes causes: more, and better-grounded, fondness for reality, just as it is."

—George Saunders

"Manhattan Beach is ambitiously and deliciously plot-driven."

—NPR

"Egan's first foray into historical fiction makes you forget you're reading historical fiction at all."

—Elle
Short_Summary: During World War II, Anna Kerrigan works at the Brooklyn Naval Yard while her father disappears into the criminal underworld. Caught between family secrets and new independence, Anna’s journey is one of survival, courage, and reinvention.
Long_Summary:
Anna Kerrigan, nearly twelve years old, accompanies her father to visit Dexter Styles, a man who, she gleans, is crucial to the survival of her father and her family. She is mesmerized by the sea beyond the house and by some charged mystery between the two men.

‎Years later, her father has disappeared and the country is at war. Anna works at the Brooklyn Naval Yard, where women are allowed to hold jobs that once belonged to men, now soldiers abroad. She becomes the first female diver, the most dangerous and exclusive of occupations, repairing the ships that will help America win the war. One evening at a nightclub, she meets Dexter Styles again, and begins to understand the complexity of her father’s life, the reasons he might have vanished.

With the atmosphere of a noir thriller, Egan’s first historical novel follows Anna and Styles into a world populated by gangsters, sailors, divers, bankers, and union men. Manhattan Beach is a deft, dazzling, propulsive exploration of a transformative moment in the lives and identities of women and men, of America and the world. It is a magnificent novel by the author of A Visit from the Goon Squad, one of the great writers of our time.

Title: A Hologram for the King
Summary: Alan Clay, a struggling American businessman, travels to Saudi Arabia to pitch a technology deal. In a shifting landscape of globalization and alienation, A Hologram for the King portrays a man confronting obsolescence in a rapidly changing world.
Refined_Long_Summary:
In a rising Saudi Arabian city, far from weary, recession-scarred America, a struggling businessman pursues a last-ditch attempt to stave off foreclosure, pay his daughter's college tuition, and finally do something great.

Dave Eggers takes us around the world to show how one man fights to hold himself and his splintering family together in the face of the global economy's gale-force winds. This taut, richly layered novel captures the disorientation of middle-class America in a newly globalized world, where jobs disappear overseas and dreams feel increasingly out of reach.

What emerges is both a darkly comic portrait of contemporary anxiety and an elegiac meditation on how we arrived at this moment of economic uncertainty and personal fragmentation.
Refined_Short_Summary: When a desperate businessman travels to Saudi Arabia for one final shot at financial salvation, he confronts the brutal realities of globalization. This darkly comic novel captures middle-class American anxiety with the precision of a Cormac McCarthy road trip.
Refined_Bio: Dave Eggers is the author of many books, including The Every, The Circle, Museum of Rain, The Monk of Mokha, and the National Book Award finalist A Hologram for the King, plus numerous books for young readers like Her Right Foot and The Lifters. He founded McSweeney's publishing and ScholarMatch nonprofit, and co-founded 826 Valencia writing center. He's won the Muhammad Ali Humanitarian Award for Education and the Dayton Literary Peace Prize.
Formatted_Quotes:
"Mr. Eggers uses a new, pared down, Hemingwayesque voice to recount his story... he demonstrates in Hologram that he is master of this more old-fashioned approach as much as he was a pioneering innovator with A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius....[This] sad-funny-dreamlike story unfolds to become an allegory about the frustrations of middle-class America, about the woes unemployed workers and sidelined entrepreneurs have experienced in a newly globalized world in which jobs are being outsourced abroad.... A comic but deeply affecting tale about one man's travails that also provides a bright, digital snapshot of our times."

—Michiko Kakutani, The New York Times

"Eerie, suspenseful and tightly controlled? Exciting stuff."

—Cynthia Macdonald, The Globe and Mail

"A potent, well-drawn portrait of one man's discovery of where his personal and professional selves split and connect."

—Kirkus

This taut, richly layered, and elegiac novel is a powerful evocation of our contemporary moment - and a moving story of how we got here.

Title: King
Subtitle: A Life
Summary: A revelatory biography of Martin Luther King Jr., drawing on newly released archives and interviews to present the most intimate portrait yet of the civil rights leader.
Refined_Long_Summary:
The first major biography of Martin Luther King Jr. in decades, Jonathan Eig's King: A Life draws on recently declassified FBI files to reveal an intimate portrait of the civil rights icon. This isn't just another hagiography—Eig shows us the complete man behind the movement.

We see King as a minister wrestling with his own human frailties and dark moods, a citizen hunted by his own government, and a determined fighter for justice who knew it might cost him his life. Following MLK from classroom to pulpit to the streets of Birmingham, Selma, and Memphis, Eig dramatically recreates the journey of the man who recast American race relations and became our only modern-day founding father.

This landmark biography gives us an MLK for our times: a deep thinker, brilliant strategist, complicated husband and father, and committed radical who led one of history's greatest movements. His demands for racial and economic justice remain as urgent today as they were in his lifetime.
Refined_Short_Summary: Using newly declassified FBI files, this definitive biography reveals the complete Martin Luther King Jr.—brilliant strategist, troubled human being, and radical leader whose fight for justice remains urgently relevant today.
Refined_Bio: Jonathan Eig is a former senior writer for The Wall Street Journal and New York Times bestselling author of five books, including Ali: A Life, Luckiest Man: The Life and Death of Lou Gehrig, and Opening Day: The Story of Jackie Robinson's First Season. Ken Burns calls him "a master storyteller," and his books have been named among the best of the year by The Washington Post, Chicago Tribune, Sports Illustrated, and Slate.
Formatted_Quotes:
"Definitive . . . Monumental . . . An extraordinary achievement and an essential life of the iconic warrior for social justice."

―Kirkus

"[A] sweeping biography. Eig gives a rousing recap of King's triumphs as a civil rights leader . . . [A] complex, nuanced portrait . . . Eig's evocative prose ably conveys his bravery, charisma, and spell-binding oratory . . . An enthralling reappraisal that confirms King's relevance to today's debates over racial justice."

―Publishers Weekly

"King: A Life might be described as a deeply reported psychobiography [. . .] infused with the narrative energy of a thriller . . . Eig does a particularly nuanced job of conjuring up the mind-set of Coretta Scott King in the years before she emerged as a forceful activist in her own right . . . The most compelling account of King's life in a generation."

―Mark Whitaker, The Washington Post
Short_Summary: The first full biography in decades, King mixes revelatory and exhaustive new research with brisk and accessible storytelling to forge the definitive life for our times.
Long_Summary:
Vividly written and exhaustively researched, Jonathan Eig’s King: A Life is the first major biography in decades of the civil rights icon Martin Luther King Jr.—and the first to include recently declassified FBI files. In this revelatory new portrait of the preacher and activist who shook the world, the bestselling biographer gives us an intimate view of the courageous and often emotionally troubled human being who demanded peaceful protest for his movement but was rarely at peace with himself. King reveals a minister wrestling with his own human frailties and dark moods, a citizen hunted by his own government, and a man determined to fight for justice even if it proved to be a fight to the death. As he follows MLK from the classroom to the pulpit to the streets of Birmingham, Selma, and Memphis, Eig dramatically re-creates the journey of a man who recast American race relations and became our only modern-day founding father.

In this landmark biography, Eig gives us an MLK for our times: a deep thinker, a brilliant strategist, a perplexing husband and father, and a committed radical who led one of history’s greatest movements, and whose demands for racial and economic justice remain as urgent today as they were in his lifetime.

The most compelling account of King’s life in a generation.”―Mark Whitaker, The Washington Post

Title: Invisible Child
Subtitle: Poverty, Survival & Hope in an American City (Pulitzer Prize Winner)
Summary: An extraordinary portrait of Dasani, a girl growing up homeless in New York City, Elliott’s book exposes systemic inequality through intimate, years-long reporting.
Refined_Long_Summary:
In Invisible Child, Pulitzer Prize winner Andrea Elliott follows eight dramatic years in the life of Dasani, a girl whose imagination soars as high as the skyscrapers near her Brooklyn shelter. Elliott weaves Dasani's childhood story with the history of her ancestors, tracing their passage from slavery to the Great Migration north.

As Dasani comes of age, New York City's homeless crisis explodes, deepening the chasm between rich and poor. She must guide her siblings through a world riddled by hunger, violence, racism, drug addiction, and the constant threat of foster care. On the street, Dasani becomes a fierce fighter "to protect those who I love."

When she finally escapes city life to enroll in boarding school, she faces an impossible question: What if leaving poverty means abandoning your family, and yourself? Written in luminous, riveting prose that reads like a page-turning novel, Invisible Child is an astonishing story about resilience, family, and the true cost of inequality—told through one remarkable girl's journey.
Refined_Short_Summary: Eight years in the life of Dasani, a brilliant girl navigating homelessness in New York City. Elliott's immersive reporting reveals how systemic inequality shapes one family's fight for survival and dignity.
Refined_Bio: Andrea Elliott is an investigative reporter for The New York Times. Her reporting has earned two Pulitzer Prizes, a George Polk Award, the J. Anthony Lukas Book Prize, an Overseas Press Club award, and other honors. She has served as an Emerson fellow at New America and visiting journalist at the Russell Sage Foundation. In 2015, she received Columbia University's Medal for Excellence. Elliott is the first woman to win individual Pulitzer Prizes in both Journalism and Arts & Letters. This is her first book.
Formatted_Quotes:
"From its first indelible pages to its rich and startling conclusion, Invisible Child had me, by turns, stricken, inspired, outraged, illuminated, in tears, and hungering for reimmersion in its Dickensian depths. This book is so many things: a staggering feat of reporting, an act of profound civic love, an extraordinarily moving tale about the fierceness of family love, and above all, a future American classic."

—Ayad Akhtar, author of Homeland Elegies

"A vivid and devastating story of American inequality."

—The New York Times

"A classic to rank with Orwell."

—The Sunday Times

Title: A Marriage at Sea
Subtitle: A True Story of Love, Obsession, and Shipwreck
Refined_Long_Summary:
Maurice and Maralyn make an odd couple. He's a loner, awkward and obsessive; she's charismatic and ambitious. But they share a horror of wasting their lives and dream of running away from it all. What if they quit their jobs, sold their house, bought a boat, and sailed away?

Most of us begin and end with the daydream. But Maurice studied nautical navigation while Maralyn made detailed lists of provisions. In June 1972, they set sail.

For nearly a year all went well, until deep in the Pacific, a breaching whale knocked a hole in their boat and it sank beneath the waves. What follows is a jaw-dropping fight to survive in the wild ocean, with little hope of rescue.

Alone together for months in a tiny rubber raft, starving and exhausted, Maurice and Maralyn must find not only ways to stay alive but ways to get along, as their inner demons emerge and their marriage faces the ultimate test. They could run away from the world, but they can't run away from themselves.

Taut and propulsive, A Marriage at Sea pairs an adrenaline-fueled high seas adventure with a gutting love story about why we love difficult people and who we become under extreme conditions.
Refined_Short_Summary: When a whale destroys their boat in the Pacific, an unlikely couple must survive months adrift in a tiny raft. This harrowing true story explores love, obsession, and endurance under impossible conditions.
Refined_Bio: Sophie Elmhirst is an award-winning journalist who writes regularly for The Guardian Long Read and The Economist. Her work has appeared in The New York Times Magazine, The New Yorker, and Harper's Bazaar. She's won the British Press Award for Feature Writer of the Year and a Foreign Press Award. She lives in London and A Marriage at Sea is her first book.
Formatted_Quotes:
"A beautiful meditation on endurance, codependence, and the power of love. A dazzling book."

—Patrick Radden Keefe

"Stark, elemental, and sure to be a classic."

—Hampton Sides

"An enthralling, engrossing story of survival and the resilience of the human spirit."

—Bill Bryson
Short_Summary: The electrifying true story of a young couple shipwrecked at sea: a mind-blowing tale of obsession, survival, and partnership stretched to its limits.
Long_Summary:
Maurice and Maralyn make an odd couple. He’s a loner, awkward and obsessive; she’s charismatic and ambitious. But they share a horror of wasting their lives. And they dream – as we all dream – of running away from it all. What if they quit their jobs, sold their house, bought a boat, and sailed away?

Most of us begin and end with the daydream. But Maurice began to study nautical navigation. Maralyn made detailed lists of provisions. And in June 1972, they set sail. For nearly a year all went well, until deep in the Pacific, a breaching whale knocked a hole in their boat and it sank beneath the waves.

What ensues is a jaw-dropping fight to survive in the wild ocean, with little hope of rescue. Alone together for months in a tiny rubber raft, starving and exhausted, Maurice and Maralyn have to find not only ways to stay alive but ways to get along, as their inner demons emerge and their marriage is put to the greatest of tests. Although they could run away from the world, they can’t run away from themselves.

Taut, propulsive, and dazzling, A Marriage at Sea pairs an adrenaline-fueled high seas adventure with a gutting love story that asks why we love difficult people, and who we become under the most extreme conditions imaginable.
Copy_Bio: Sophie Elmhirst is an award-winning journalist who writes regularly for The Guardian Long Read and The Economist; her work has also appeared in The New York Times Magazine, The New Yorker, and Harper’s Bazaar, among other places. She’s the winner of the British Press Award for Feature Writer of the Year and a Foreign Press Award. She lives in London and A Marriage at Sea is her first book.

Title: The Beauty and the Sorrow
Subtitle: An Intimate History of the First World War
BISAC_Category_Description: History / Wars & Conflicts / World War I
Summary: Englund tells the First World War through the diaries and letters of twenty individuals from different nations, offering a mosaic of human experience in the midst of catastrophe.
Refined_Long_Summary:
In The Beauty and the Sorrow, Peter Englund offers a masterful and original history of World War I, told through the journals and letters of twenty men and women from across the globe. Their stories span Belgium, France, Germany, Britain, Italy, Russia, the Austro-Hungarian Empire, Australia, New Zealand, Venezuela, and the United States.

Englund captures the war from intimate perspectives—soldiers, nurses, surgeons, pilots, prisoners, civil servants, and children. From the exhilaration of early victories to the collapse of ideals and the devastation of daily life, he presents a brilliant mosaic of voices that reveal not only the tragedy and horror of the Great War, but also its absurdity, moments of resilience, and even fleeting beauty.

Both intimate and expansive, this unforgettable narrative restores humanity to a conflict too often reduced to statistics, allowing forgotten witnesses to speak for themselves and for a generation shaped by the war.
Refined_Short_Summary: World War I through twenty real voices—soldiers, nurses, children—from across the globe. This intimate mosaic captures both the horror and unexpected beauty of the Great War through actual letters and diaries.
Refined_Bio: Peter Englund is a historian, journalist, and member of the Swedish Academy, which chooses Nobel Prize winners. He's received the August Prize for best Swedish book of the year and the Selma Lagerlöf literature prize. Author of ten previous books, Englund lives in Uppsala, Sweden.
Formatted_Quotes:
"Intense and bighearted…The best books about World War I have often been oblique, like Paul Fussell's Great War and Modern Memory, or novels, like Erich Maria Remarque's All Quiet on the Western Front, rather than comprehensive histories. Englund's volume joins an unconventional pantheon…The accounts of [these] lives can be terrifying or stirring, but are most fully alive in Englund's accumulation of small moments, stray details…His book has the most devastating ending I can remember in a piece of nonfiction."

—The New York Times

"A brilliant feat of retrospective journalism…Englund's deft collation provides insights into more than the carnage…This book fleshes out the grim statistics of the Great War…The eloquence of everyday participants will link the reader to the era when the origins of the ensuing century's conflicts became apparent."

—Publishers Weekly

"An exquisite book…There are adventures and battles, of course, but also many moments of quiet contemplation with closely observed details of street scenes, restaurants, railway stations, and deserted battlefields…By turns pithy, lyrical, colorful, poignant, and endlessly absorbing."

—Kirkus

Title: The Wren, the Wren
Subtitle: A Novel
Summary: Three generations of Irish women reckon with the legacy of a famous but flawed poet patriarch. Lyrical and intimate, The Wren, the Wren explores family, art, and inheritance with Enright’s trademark precision.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Nell McDaragh never knew her grandfather Phil, the celebrated Irish poet whose love poems seem to speak directly to her. At twenty-two, restless and wryly self-assured, she leaves her mother Carmel's orderly home to find her own voice as a writer and live a poetical life. As she chases obsessive love, damage, and transcendence in Dublin and beyond, her grandfather's poetry seems to guide her home.

Carmel McDaragh knows the magic of her father's poetry too well—the kind that makes women slip outside for a kiss and then elope, as her mother Terry had done. In his poems, Phil envisions Carmel as a bright-eyed wren escaping from his hand. But it is Phil who departs, abandoning his wife and daughters. Carmel struggles to reconcile "the poet" with the father whose desertion scars her life. To distance herself from this betrayal, she turns inward, raising Nell alone.

The Wren, the Wren brings to life three generations of McDaragh women contending with inheritances of poetic wonder and abandonment. Their stronger inheritance is a sustaining love that is "more than a strand of DNA, but a rope thrown from the past." In crystalline prose, Enright masterfully braids a family story of longing, betrayal, and hope.
Refined_Short_Summary: Three generations of Irish women grapple with the legacy of a celebrated poet who abandoned his family. Enright weaves poetry and betrayal into something luminous—fans of Normal People's complex family dynamics will be captivated.
Refined_Bio: Anne Enright is the author of eight novels, most recently The Wren, the Wren. She has been awarded the Man Booker Prize and the Andrew Carnegie Medal for Excellence in Fiction, and was named the inaugural Laureate for Irish Fiction. In 2022, Enright received a Lifetime Achievement Award from the Irish Book Awards. She lives and works in Dublin.
Formatted_Quotes:
"This is a powerful, thoughtful book by one of the great living writers on the subject of family. Speaking about love in terms both domestic and transcendent, Enright coos through newly connected wires."

—The New York Times

"To call Anne Enright's new novel a moving, nuanced glimpse at three generations of Irish life underplays its thrilling expansiveness: in the end, The Wren, The Wren is an electrifying romp through language itself—its dizzying possibilities and satisfactions—led by one the most gifted writers working in English today."

—Jennifer Egan, author of A Visit From the Goon Squad & The Candy House

"The power of Enright's novel derives not so much from the age-old tale of men behaving badly, but from the beauty and depth of her own style. She's so deft at rendering arresting insights into personality types or situations."

—Maureen Corrigan - NPR
Short_Summary: An incandescent novel from one of our greatest living novelists (The Times) about the inheritance of trauma, wonder, and love across three generations of women.
Long_Summary:
Nell McDaragh never knew her grandfather, the celebrated Irish poet Phil McDaragh. But his love poems seem to speak directly to her. Restless and wryly self-assured, at twenty-two Nell leaves her mother Carmel’s orderly home to find her own voice as a writer (mostly online, ghost-blogging for an influencer) and to live a poetical life. As she chases obsessive love, damage, and transcendence, in Dublin and beyond, her grandfather’s poetry seems to guide her home.

Nell’s mother, Carmel McDaragh, knows the magic of her Daddo’s poetry too well—the kind of magic that makes women in their nighties slip outside for a kiss and then elope, as her mother Terry had done. In his poems to Carmel, Phil envisions his daughter as a bright-eyed wren ascending in escape from his hand. But it is Phil who departs, abandoning his wife and two young daughters. Carmel struggles to reconcile “the poet” with the father whose desertion scars her life, along with that of her fiercely dutiful sister and their gentle, cancer-ridden mother. To distance herself from this betrayal, Carmel turns inward, raising Nell, her daughter, and one trusted love, alone.

The Wren, the Wren brings to life three generations of McDaragh women who must contend with inheritances—of poetic wonder and of abandonment by a man who is lauded in public and carelessly selfish at home. Their other, stronger inheritance is a sustaining love that is “more than a strand of DNA, but a rope thrown from the past, a fat twisted rope, full of blood.” In sharp prose studded with crystalline poetry, Anne Enright masterfully braids a family story of longing, betrayal, and hope.
Copy_Bio: Anne Enright is the author of eight novels, most recently The Wren. She has been awarded the Man Booker Prize and the Andrew Carnegie Medal for Excellence in Fiction, and was named the inaugural Laureate for Irish Fiction. In 2022, Enright was awarded a Lifetime Achievement Award from the Irish Book Awards. She lives and works in Dublin.
Copy_Quotes:
"This is a powerful, thoughtful book by one of the great living writers on the subject of family. Speaking about love in terms both domestic and transcendent, Enright coos through newly connected wires."—The New York Times

"To call Anne Enright’s new novel a moving, nuanced glimpse at three generations of Irish life underplays its thrilling expansiveness: in the end, The Wren, The Wren is an electrifying romp through language itself—its dizzying possibilities and satisfactions—led by one the most gifted writers working in English today."—Jennifer Egan, author of A Visit From the Goon Squad & The Candy House

"The power of Enright's novel derives not so much from the age-old tale of men behaving badly, but from the beauty and depth of her own style. She's so deft at rendering arresting insights into personality types or situations. "—Maureen Corrigan - NPR

Longlisted — Booker Prize (2023)
Named — Publishers Weekly 10 Best Books (2023)

Title: Our Share of Night
Subtitle: A Novel
Summary: In Argentina, a father and son confront a secret occult society seeking immortality through dark rituals. Blending horror with political allegory, Our Share of Night is a sprawling, gothic masterpiece about inheritance, violence, and survival.
Refined_Long_Summary:
A young father and son embark on a devastating road trip following the death of the wife and mother they both loved. United in grief, they travel to her ancestral home, where they must confront a terrifying legacy: a family cult called the Order that commits unspeakable acts in search of immortality.

For Gaspar, the son, this maniacal cult represents his destiny. As the Order tries to pull him into their evil, he and his father take flight, attempting to outrun a powerful clan that will do anything to ensure its own survival. But how far will Gaspar's father go to protect his child? And can anyone escape their fate?

Moving between London in the swinging 1960s and the brutal years of Argentina's military dictatorship, Our Share of Night defies categorization. It's simultaneously a family story, a ghost story, and an exploration of the occult—a book about the complexities of love and longing with queer themes woven throughout. This is the masterwork of one of Latin America's most original novelists.
Refined_Short_Summary: When a father and son flee an occult family cult seeking immortality, their journey becomes a haunting exploration of fate and sacrifice. This gothic Argentine masterpiece will captivate fans of Mexican Gothic and Silvia Moreno-Garcia's dark storytelling.
Refined_Bio: Mariana Enriquez is a Buenos Aires-based writer who has published the novel Our Share of Night and three story collections: A Sunny Place for Shady People, Things We Lost in the Fire, and The Dangers of Smoking in Bed. Her work has been a finalist for the International Booker Prize, the Kirkus Prize, the Ray Bradbury Prize for Science Fiction, Fantasy, & Speculative Fiction, and the Los Angeles Times Book Prize in Fiction.
Formatted_Quotes:
"Reader, beware! Our Share of Night is a novel so disquieting, so unsettling that I could neither put it down nor read it late at night . . . [this] novel is going to haunt me for the rest of my life."

—Kelly Link, author of The Book of Love & White Cat, Black Dog

"A literary achievement, gorgeous and exacting in its execution . . . Our Share of Night is not only a bloody valentine to the bonds between parent and child, but also an inspired evisceration of how the powerful prey on the powerless . . ."

—The Washington Post

"A haunting generational horror story."

—Silvia Moreno-Garcia
Short_Summary: In Argentina, a father and son confront a secret occult society seeking immortality through dark rituals. Blending horror with political allegory, Our Share of Night is a sprawling, gothic masterpiece about inheritance, violence, and survival.
Long_Summary:
A young father and son set out on a road trip, devastated by the death of the wife and mother they both loved. United in grief, the pair travel to her ancestral home, where they must confront the terrifying legacy she has bequeathed: a family called the Order that commits unspeakable acts in search of immortality.

For Gaspar, the son, this maniacal cult is his destiny. As the Order tries to pull him into their evil, he and his father take flight, attempting to outrun a powerful clan that will do anything to ensure its own survival. But how far will Gaspar’s father go to protect his child? And can anyone escape their fate?

Moving back and forth in time, from London in the swinging 1960s to the brutal years of Argentina’s military dictatorship and its turbulent aftermath, Our Share of Night is a novel like no other: a family story, a ghost story, a story of the occult and the supernatural, a book about the complexities of love and longing with queer subplots and themes. This is the masterwork of one of Latin America’s most original novelists, “a mesmerizing writer,” says Dave Eggers, “who demands to be read.”
Copy_Bio: Mariana Enriquez is a writer based in Buenos Aires. She has published in English the novel Our Share of Night and three story collections, A Sunny Place for Shady People, Things We Lost in the Fire, and The Dangers of Smoking in Bed, which was a finalist for the International Booker Prize, the Kirkus Prize, the Ray Bradbury Prize for Science Fiction, Fantasy, & Speculative Fiction, and the Los Angeles Times Book Prize in Fiction.

Title: The Round House
Subtitle: A Novel
Summary: On a North Dakota reservation, a teenage boy seeks justice after his mother is brutally attacked. Combining a coming-of-age story with a legal thriller, The Round House examines family, culture, and the quest for truth.
Refined_Long_Summary:
On a summer Sunday in 1988, an Ojibwe woman living on a reservation in North Dakota is brutally attacked. Traumatized, Geraldine Coutts refuses to share details of what happened with the police, her husband Bazil (a tribal judge), or their thirteen-year-old son Joe.

Overnight, Joe's world crumbles. His strong mother stays in bed, slipping into depression, while his father struggles with anger and grief, trying to maintain normalcy. Feeling increasingly alone, Joe is thrust into an adult world he's not ready for.

With Joe's help, Bazil searches through legal decisions for clues to the attacker's identity and answers to crucial questions: Was the perpetrator Indian or white? Where exactly was the crime committed—on state or tribal land? Who should lead the investigation?

Frustrated by his father's limitations and hungry for justice, Joe sets out with three friends to find the truth. Their quest begins at the Round House, a sacred Ojibwe worship space, leading to a journey filled with unexpected twists that will transform Joe, his family, and friends forever.

Erdrich's remarkable novel illuminates the harsh realities of a community where Ojibwe and white live uneasily together, blending tragedy, comedy, and a spirit world very much present in its all-too-human characters' lives.
Refined_Short_Summary: When his mother is brutally attacked on their North Dakota reservation, thirteen-year-old Joe embarks on a dangerous quest for justice with his friends. Perfect for readers who loved There There's exploration of Native identity and community.

Short_Summary: On a North Dakota reservation, a teenage boy seeks justice after his mother is brutally attacked. Combining a coming-of-age story with a legal thriller, The Round House examines family, culture, and the quest for truth.
Long_Summary:
On a summer Sunday in 1988, an Ojibwe woman living on a reservation in North Dakota is brutally attacked. Traumatized, Geraldine Coutts, a tribal enrollment specialist, refuses to share the details of what happened with the police or her husband Bazil, the tribal judge, and their thirteen-year old son Joe.

In one day, Joe’s home life is upended. His strong, steadfast mother stays in bed, slipping deeper into an abyss of depression while his father, struggling with his own anger and grief, tries to maintain a semblance of normality. Feeling increasingly alone, Joe is thrust prematurely into an adult world for which he is ill prepared.

 With Joe’s help, Bazil pores through previous legal decisions searching for clues to the attacker’s identity and motives, as well as answers to perplexing questions: Was the perpetrator Indian or white? Where, exactly, was the crime committed—on state or tribal land? Who should lead the investigation—the tribal police, the state, or federal law enforcement? Frustrated with the seeming banality and limits of his father’s power, becoming increasingly resistant to adult authority, and eager for justice, Joe sets out with his three friends, Cappy, Zack and Angus, to find the truth, a quest that begins at the Round House, a sacred space and place of worship for the Ojibwe. Filled with unexpected twists and surprises both momentous and devastating, it is a journey of discovery that will leave Joe, his family, and his friends irrevocably transformed.

An indelible portrait of family and memory, injustice and vengeance, friendship and growing up, Louise Erdrich’s remarkable novel illuminates the harsh realities of a community where Ojibwe and white live uneasily together. Written with undeniable urgency, blending tragedy, the comic, and a spirit world very much present in its all-too-human characters’ lives, The Round House is a masterpiece of literary fiction from one of the most distinguished writers of our time.

Title: The Mighty Red
Subtitle: A Novel
Summary: In this imaginative fable, a fire hydrant known as the Mighty Red stands witness to generations of neighborhood life. Blending humor, tenderness, and sly social commentary, Erdrich creates a playful yet profound meditation on community, resilience, and the overlooked objects that shape our days.
Refined_Long_Summary:
In Argus, North Dakota, a collection of people revolve around a fraught wedding that will change everything.

Gary Geist, a terrified young man set to inherit two farms, desperately wants to marry Kismet Poe, an impulsive, lapsed Goth who can't read her future but seems to resolve his. Hugo, a gentle red-haired, home-schooled giant, is also in love with Kismet. He's determined to steal her away and eager to be a home wrecker. Kismet's mother, Crystal, hauls sugar beets for Gary's family, and on her nightly runs, she tunes into the darkness of late-night radio, sees visions of guardian angels, and worries for the future—both her daughter's and her own.

Against the backdrop of deep time and Red River time, the half-life of herbicides and pesticides, and fracking core samples from unimaginable depths, these characters navigate the speed of climate change, depleting natural resources, and the economic meltdown of 2008-2009. How much does a dress cost? A used car? Can you see the shape of your soul in the everchanging clouds?

The Mighty Red is a novel of tender humor and hallucinatory mourning about ordinary people who dream, fall in love, struggle, and endure tragedy in a starkly beautiful prairie community whose members must cope with devastating consequences as powerful forces upend their lives.
Refined_Short_Summary: When a love triangle collides with economic collapse and environmental crisis in small-town North Dakota, ordinary people face extraordinary choices. Erdrich weaves tender humor with devastating beauty in this portrait of community and resilience.

"[Erdrich is] a master, a legend at building stories around community. . . . This is a book about family and community. It is a book about upward mobility and finding our true passions. You will love Kismet."

"In The Mighty Red, humor and sorrow are fused together like twined tree trunks that keep each other standing.... Erdrich is so good at romantic comedy, with her special blend of Austen sense and Ojibwe sensibility. As the funny scenes flow one after another, you may not even notice the stray drops of blood scattered along the novel's margins. . . . As usual when closing a book by Louise Erdrich, I'm left wondering, how can a novel be so funny and so moving? How can life?"

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

"A captivating tale of love and everyday life amid environmental upheaval and the 2008 financial crisis. . . . Erdrich excels at the slow simmer, and once again she delivers a deliciously seductive masterwork."

—Publishers Weekly
Short_Summary: In this stunning novel, Pulitzer Prize and National Book Award–winning author Louise Erdrich tells a story of love, natural forces, spiritual yearnings, and the tragic impact of uncontrollable circumstances on ordinary people’s lives.
Long_Summary:
History is a flood. The mighty red . . .

In Argus, North Dakota, a collection of people revolve around a fraught wedding. 

Gary Geist, a terrified young man set to inherit two farms, is desperate to marry Kismet Poe, an impulsive, lapsed Goth who can't read her future but seems to resolve his. 

Hugo, a gentle red-haired, home-schooled giant, is also in love with Kismet. He’s determined to steal her and is eager to be a home wrecker.  

Kismet's mother, Crystal, hauls sugar beets for Gary's family, and on her nightly runs, tunes into the darkness of late-night radio, sees visions of guardian angels, and worries for the future, her daughter’s and her own.

Human time, deep time, Red River time, the half-life of herbicides and pesticides, and the elegance of time represented in fracking core samples from unimaginable depths, is set against the speed of climate change, the depletion of natural resources, and the sudden economic meltdown of 2008-2009. How much does a dress cost? A used car? A package of cinnamon rolls? Can you see the shape of your soul in the everchanging clouds? Your personal salvation in the giant expanse of sky? These are the questions the people of the Red River Valley of the North wrestle with every day.

The Mighty Red is a novel of tender humor, disturbance, and hallucinatory mourning. It is about on-the-job pains and immeasurable satisfactions, a turbulent landscape, and eating the native weeds growing in your backyard. It is about ordinary people who dream, grow up, fall in love, struggle, endure tragedy, carry bitter secrets; men and women both complicated and contradictory, flawed and decent, lonely and hopeful. It is about a starkly beautiful prairie community whose members must cope with devastating consequences as powerful forces upend them. As with every book this great modern master writes, The Mighty Red is about our tattered bond with the earth, and about love in all of its absurdity and splendor.

Title: If I Survive You
Summary: Linked stories follow a Jamaican immigrant family in Miami as they struggle with belonging, identity, and economic survival. Escoffery captures the humor and heartbreak of diaspora life with sharp insight.
Refined_Long_Summary:
In the 1970s, Topper and Sanya flee political violence in Kingston for Miami, hoping for a better life. But America proves far from the promised land they imagined. Excluded from society as Black immigrants, the family pushes through Hurricane Andrew and the 2008 recession, living in a house so cursed that even the pet fish launches itself out of its tank.

Even as things fall apart, they remain driven by what younger son Trelawny calls "the exquisite, racking compulsion to survive." These linked stories follow Trelawny as he struggles to carve out a place for himself amid financial disaster, racism, and relentless bad luck. After a fight with his father, he claws his way out of homelessness through a series of odd, often hilarious jobs.

Meanwhile, his brother Delano attempts a disastrous cash grab to get his kids back, and cousin Cukie searches for a father who doesn't want to be found. Pulsing with vibrant lyricism and sly humor, Escoffery's debut unravels what it means to be caught between homes and cultures in a world ruled by capitalism and whiteness.
Refined_Short_Summary: When a Jamaican family flees to Miami seeking the American dream, they discover survival requires more than hope. This darkly funny debut captures the immigrant experience with heart and razor-sharp wit that will stay with you.
Refined_Bio: Jonathan Escoffery is the recipient of the 2020 Plimpton Prize for Fiction, a 2020 National Endowment for the Arts Literature Fellowship, and the 2020 ASME Award for Fiction. His fiction has appeared in The Paris Review, American Short Fiction, Prairie Schooner, AGNI, and Electric Literature, and has been anthologized in The Best American Magazine Writing. He's a fellow in USC's PhD in Creative Writing and Literature Program and was awarded a Wallace Stegner Fellowship from Stanford University in 2021. If I Survive You is his first book.
Formatted_Quotes:
"It's truly a feat that a book of short stories tackling such big stuff—family, love, violence, race—could be so damn funny. A welcome reminder of what fiction can do."

—Rumaan Alam, author of Leave the World Behind

"If I Survive You is a collection of brilliant wit, real heart, and electric humor. Jonathan Escoffery masterfully mines from his life and emerges, in this debut, as a talent not to be ignored."

—Nana Kwame Adjei-Brenyah, author of Chain Gang All Stars & Friday Black

"These are superb stories about identity, family, and place. There is a beautiful economy in the telling that never sacrifices the depth, complexity, and richness of the worlds these characters inhabit. Jonathan Escoffery's is a strong, much-needed new voice in our literature."

—Percival Everett, author of James & The Trees
Short_Summary: A major debut, blazing with style and heart, that follows a Jamaican family striving for more in Miami, and introduces a generational storyteller.
Long_Summary:
In the 1970s, Topper and Sanya flee to Miami as political violence consumes their native Kingston. But America, as the couple and their two children learn, is far from the promised land. Excluded from society as Black immigrants, the family pushes on through Hurricane Andrew and later the 2008 recession, living in a house so cursed that the pet fish launches itself out of its own tank rather than stay. But even as things fall apart, the family remains motivated, often to its own detriment, by what the younger son, Trelawny, calls “the exquisite, racking compulsion to survive.”

Masterfully constructed with heart and humor, the linked stories in Jonathan Escoffery’s If I Survive You center on Trelawny as he struggles to carve out a place for himself amid financial disaster, racism, and flat-out bad luck. After a fight with Topper, Trelawny claws his way out of homelessness through a series of odd, often hilarious jobs. Meanwhile, his brother, Delano, attempts a disastrous cash grab to get his kids back, and his cousin Cukie looks for a father who doesn’t want to be found. As each character searches for a foothold, they never forget the profound danger of climbing without a safety net.

Pulsing with vibrant lyricism and inimitable style, sly commentary and contagious laughter, Escoffery’s debut unravels what it means to be in between homes and cultures in a world at the mercy of capitalism and whiteness. With If I Survive You, Escoffery announces himself as a prodigious storyteller in a class of his own, a chronicler of American life at its most gruesome and hopeful.
Copy_Bio: Jonathan Escoffery is the recipient of the 2020 Plimpton Prize for Fiction, a 2020 National Endowment for the Arts Literature Fellowship, and the 2020 ASME Award for Fiction. His fiction has appeared in The Paris Review, American Short Fiction, Prairie Schooner, AGNI, Passages North, Zyzzyva, and Electric Literature, and has been anthologized in The Best American Magazine Writing. He is a fellow in the University of Southern California’s PhD in Creative Writing and Literature Program, and in 2021 he was awarded a Wallace Stegner Fellowship from Stanford University. He was raised in Miami, Florida. If I Survive You is his first book.

“These are superb stories about identity, family, and place. There is a beautiful economy in the telling that never sacrifices the depth, complexity, and richness of the worlds these characters inhabit.
