Title_Subtitle: There Is No Place for Us
Title: There Is No Place for Us
Subtitle: Working and Homeless in America
Refined_Long_Summary:
The phrase "working homeless" should be an oxymoron in America, where hard work supposedly guarantees success. But skyrocketing rents, stagnant wages, and weak tenant protections have created a devastating reality: full-time workers who can't afford housing, especially in booming cities where rapid growth fuels displacement.

Journalist Brian Goldstone takes readers into the lives of five Atlanta families fighting to stay housed in an increasingly unequal city. Maurice and Natalia seek a fresh start in the "Black Mecca" after being priced out of DC. Kara dreams of her own cleaning business while working hospital floors. Britt secures a coveted housing voucher. Michelle studies to become a social worker. Celeste balances her warehouse job with cancer treatment. Each parent aspires to provide stability for their children—yet one by one, they join America's working homeless.

Through intimate portraits, Goldstone reveals families sleeping in cars or squalid motels, then heading to jobs and schools each morning. These hidden homeless don't appear in official statistics, proving that visible encampments represent only a fraction of a much larger crisis. This urgent, heartbreaking investigation shows that America's housing emergency won't end until shelter becomes a fundamental human right.
Refined_Short_Summary: Five Atlanta families with full-time jobs lose their homes in this devastating investigation of America's "working homeless." A paradigm-shifting look at how gentrification creates invisible poverty that Matthew Desmond fans need to read.
Refined_Bio: Brian Goldstone is a journalist whose longform reporting and essays have appeared in The New York Times, Harper's Magazine, The New Republic, The California Sunday Magazine, and Jacobin. He holds a PhD in anthropology from Duke University and was a Mellon Research Fellow at Columbia University. In 2021, he was a National Fellow at New America. He lives in Atlanta with his family.
Formatted_Quotes:
"Deeply reported and written with an empathy that brims from every page . . . [Goldstone] has pulled off a rare and stunning narrative feat."

—Jonathan Blitzer, author of Everyone Who Is Gone Is Here

"A crucial, masterful book that will change the national conversation about homelessness."

—Rachel Aviv, author of Strangers to Ourselves

"Goldstone stitches together a textured and extraordinarily detailed narrative of [five families'] multiyear struggle to keep a roof over their heads. The effect is reminiscent of Random Family. . . . There Is No Place for Us shifts the paradigm on homelessness."

—The Washington Post
Short_Summary: Through the unforgettable stories of five Atlanta families, this landmark work of journalism exposes a new and troubling trend—the dramatic rise of the “working homeless” in cities across America
Long_Summary:
The working homeless. In a country where hard work and determination are supposed to lead to success, there is something scandalous about this phrase. But skyrocketing rents, low wages, and a lack of tenant rights have produced a startling phenomenon: People with full-time jobs cannot keep a roof over their head, especially in America’s booming cities, where rapid growth is leading to catastrophic displacement. These families are being forced into homelessness not by a failing economy but a thriving one.

In this gripping and deeply reported book, Brian Goldstone plunges readers into the lives of five Atlanta families struggling to remain housed in a gentrifying, increasingly unequal city. Maurice and Natalia make a fresh start in the country’s “Black Mecca” after being priced out of DC. Kara dreams of starting her own cleaning business while mopping floors at a public hospital. Britt scores a coveted housing voucher. Michelle is in school to become a social worker. Celeste toils at her warehouse job while undergoing treatment for ovarian cancer. Each of them aspires to provide a decent life for their children—and each of them, one by one, joins the ranks of the nation’s working homeless.

Through intimate, novelistic portraits, Goldstone reveals the human cost of this crisis, following parents and their kids as they go to sleep in cars, or in squalid extended-stay hotel rooms, and head out to their jobs and schools the next morning. These are the nation’s hidden homeless—omitted from official statistics, and proof that overflowing shelters and street encampments are only the most visible manifestation of a far more pervasive problem.

By turns heartbreaking and urgent, There Is No Place for Us illuminates the true magnitude, causes, and consequences of the new American homelessness—and shows that it won’t be solved until housing is treated as a fundamental human right.

He has a PhD in anthropology from Duke University and was a Mellon Research Fellow at Columbia University. In 2021, he was a National Fellow at New America. He lives in Atlanta with his family.

Title: Anita de Monte Laughs Last
Subtitle: Reese's Book Club Pick (A Novel)
Summary: A brilliant art student in 1990s New York stumbles onto the forgotten legacy of Anita de Monte, a rising Latina artist whose death was overshadowed by her famous boyfriend. As timelines braid, the novel skewers gatekeeping in the art world and celebrates women who refuse to be erased—propulsive, stylish, and sharply observant without giving away its turns.
Refined_Long_Summary:
1985. Anita de Monte, a rising star in the art world, is found dead in New York City. Her tragic death is the talk of the town—until it isn't. By 1998, Anita's name has been all but forgotten.

Enter Raquel, a third-year art history student preparing her final thesis. On College Hill, surrounded by privileged students whose futures are already paved, Raquel feels like an outsider. Students of color like her are the minority, and the pressure to work twice as hard for the same opportunities is no secret.

When Raquel becomes romantically involved with a well-connected older art student, she finds herself unexpectedly rising up the social ranks. As she attempts to straddle both worlds, she stumbles upon Anita's story, raising unsettling questions about the dynamics of her own relationship—which eerily mirrors that of the forgotten artist.

Moving between past and present through both women's perspectives, this is a propulsive, witty examination of power, love, and art that dares to ask: who gets to be remembered, and who is left behind in the rarefied world of the elite?
Refined_Short_Summary: Two women, decades apart, navigate love and ambition in the elite art world. When a struggling student discovers a forgotten artist's story, she realizes their lives mirror each other in dangerous ways. Perfect for fans of The Seven Husbands of Evelyn Hugo.
Refined_Bio: Xochitl Gonzalez is the New York Times bestselling author of Anita de Monte Laughs Last, a Reese's Book Club Pick longlisted for the Aspen Words Literary Prize, and the award-winning Olga Dies Dreaming, named a Best of 2022 by The New York Times, TIME, Kirkus, the Washington Post, and NPR. She's a staff writer for the Atlantic and was a 2023 Pulitzer Prize finalist in Commentary. A Brooklyn native and Brown University graduate, she holds an MFA from Iowa Writers' Workshop.
Formatted_Quotes:
"Gonzalez crafts excoriating and whip-smart commentary on the art world's Eurocentric conceptions of beauty and the racism faced by first-generation students of color. This is incandescent."

—Publishers Weekly

"Funny, piercing, and full of moxie, Anita de Monte Laughs Last is unsparing in its assessment of what goes on behind the castle walls, the price people pay to be accepted into those hallowed halls, and what it takes to liberate oneself from the dangers that lurk within. Really, what Xochitl Gonzalez has written is an affirmation for anyone who's ever had to 'work twice as hard to get half as much.' Anita de Monte Laughs Last is rollicking, melodic, tender, and true. And oh so very wise."

—Robert Jones, Jr., author of The Prophets, a finalist for the National Book Award for Fiction

"An uncompromising message, delivered via a gripping story with two engaging heroines."

—Kirkus
Short_Summary: New York Times bestselling author Xochitl Gonzalez delivers a mesmerizing novel about a first-generation Ivy League student who uncovers the genius work of a female artist decades after her suspicious death
Long_Summary:
1985. Anita de Monte, a rising star in the art world, is found dead in New York City; her tragic death is the talk of the town. Until it isn’t. By 1998 Anita’s name has been all but forgotten—certainly by the time Raquel, a third-year art history student is preparing her final thesis. On College Hill, surrounded by privileged students whose futures are already paved out for them, Raquel feels like an outsider. Students of color, like her, are the minority there, and the pressure to work twice as hard for the same opportunities is no secret.

But when Raquel becomes romantically involved with a well-connected older art student, she finds herself unexpectedly rising up the social ranks. As she attempts to straddle both worlds, she stumbles upon Anita’s story, raising questions about the dynamics of her own relationship, which eerily mirrors that of the forgotten artist.

Title: Olga Dies Dreaming
Subtitle: A Novel
Summary: In 2017 New York, a high-powered wedding planner and her congressman brother juggle love, ambition, and a radical mother whose activism upends their carefully curated lives. Funny, tender, and politically alive, this is a story about home, Puerto Rican identity, and what it costs to dream on your own terms.
Refined_Long_Summary:
It's 2017, and Olga and her brother Pedro "Prieto" Acevedo are boldfaced names in New York. Prieto is a popular congressman representing their gentrifying Latinx neighborhood in Brooklyn, while Olga orchestrates lavish weddings for Manhattan's power brokers.

Despite their alluring public lives, behind closed doors things are far less rosy. Olga can craft perfect love stories for the 1 percent, but she can't seem to find her own—until she meets Matteo, who forces her to confront long-held family secrets.

Their mother Blanca, a former Young Lord turned radical, abandoned her children to advance a militant political cause, leaving them to be raised by their grandmother. Now, with the winds of hurricane season, Blanca has come barreling back into their lives.

Set against the backdrop of New York City during the months surrounding Hurricane Maria, Olga Dies Dreaming examines political corruption, familial strife, and the American dream while asking what it really means to weather a storm.

Title: Isola: Reese's Book Club
Subtitle: A Novel
Refined_Long_Summary:
Heir to a fortune, Marguerite is destined for a life of prosperity and gentility. Then she is orphaned, and her guardian—an enigmatic and volatile man—spends her inheritance and insists she accompany him on an expedition to New France. Isolated and afraid, Marguerite befriends her guardian's servant and the two develop an intense attraction.

But when their relationship is discovered, they are brutally punished and abandoned on a small island with no hope for rescue. Once a child of privilege who dressed in gowns and laced pearls in her hair, Marguerite finds herself at the mercy of nature. As the weather turns, blanketing the island in ice, she discovers a faith she'd never before needed.

Inspired by the real life of a sixteenth-century heroine, Isola is the timeless story of a woman fighting for survival.

Her fiction has appeared in The New Yorker and has been anthologized in The O. Henry Awards and Best American Short Stories. She lives with her family in Cambridge, Massachusetts.

Title: The Bully Pulpit
Subtitle: Theodore Roosevelt, William Howard Taft, and the Golden Age of Journalism
Summary: Goodwin captures the dynamic friendship and rivalry between Roosevelt and Taft, while chronicling the rise of investigative journalism in the Progressive Era.
Refined_Long_Summary:
In The Bully Pulpit, Doris Kearns Goodwin brings to life the turbulent first decade of the Progressive Era, when widening inequality, political stalemate, and corporate power threatened to tear the nation apart.

At the center of the story is the friendship—and later bitter rivalry—between Theodore Roosevelt and William Howard Taft, a relationship that shaped the course of reform and ultimately fractured the Republican Party in 1912. Goodwin also captures the rise of the muckraking press, led by Ida Tarbell, Lincoln Steffens, Ray Stannard Baker, and William Allen White, whose fearless reporting galvanized the spirit of change.

Drawing on an extraordinary wealth of letters, diaries, and personal accounts, Goodwin delivers both an intimate portrait of two presidents and a sweeping narrative of an America in upheaval, showing how leadership, journalism, and activism converged to bring the nation closer to its founding ideals.
Refined_Short_Summary: Pulitzer Prize-winning historian Doris Kearns Goodwin chronicles the explosive friendship and rivalry between Theodore Roosevelt and William Howard Taft during the Progressive Era. Political drama meets fearless journalism in this sweeping portrait of America's fight for reform.
Refined_Bio: Doris Kearns Goodwin is a Pulitzer Prize-winning presidential historian and bestselling author. Her books include Lyndon Johnson and the American Dream; No Ordinary Time, winner of the Pulitzer Prize; Team of Rivals, which earned the Lincoln Prize and inspired Steven Spielberg's film Lincoln; The Bully Pulpit, winner of the Carnegie Medal; Leadership: In Turbulent Times; and An Unfinished Love Story: A Personal History of the 1960s.
Formatted_Quotes:
"If you find the grubby spectacle of today's Washington cause for shame and despair—and really, how could you not?—then I suggest you turn off the TV and board Doris Kearns Goodwin's latest time machine. … [Goodwin puts] political intrigues and moral dilemmas and daily lives into rich and elegant language. Imagine 'The West Wing' scripted by Henry James."

—Bill Keller, The New York Times

"Doris Kearns Goodwin tells this tale with her usual literary skill and deep research. … Goodwin not only sheds light on the birth of the modern political world but chronicles a remarkable friendship between two remarkable men."

—The Wall Street Journal

"Goodwin's evocative examination of the Progressive world is smart and engaging. . . . She presents a highly readable and detailed portrait of an era. The Bully Pulpit brings the early 20th century to life and firmly establishes the crucial importance of the press to Progressive politics."

—The Washington Post

Title: On Juneteenth
Summary: Blending history and memoir, Gordon-Reed reflects on the significance of Juneteenth and the complexities of race, memory, and identity in America.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Weaving together American history, dramatic family chronicle, and searing episodes of memoir, Annette Gordon-Reed's On Juneteenth provides a historian's view of the country's long road to Juneteenth. She recounts both its origins in Texas and the enormous hardships that African-Americans have endured in the century since, from Reconstruction through Jim Crow and beyond.

All too aware of the stories of cowboys, ranchers, and oilmen that have long dominated the lore of the Lone Star State, Gordon-Reed—herself a Texas native and the descendant of enslaved people brought to Texas as early as the 1820s—forges a new and profoundly truthful narrative of her home state, with implications for us all.

Combining personal anecdotes with poignant facts gleaned from the annals of American history, Gordon-Reed shows how African-Americans played an integral role in the Texas story, from the earliest presence of Black people in Texas to June 19, 1865, when Major General Gordon Granger announced the end of legalized slavery in Galveston. Reworking the traditional "Alamo" framework, she powerfully demonstrates that the slave- and race-based economy not only defined the fractious era of Texas independence but precipitated the Mexican-American War and the Civil War itself.
Refined_Short_Summary: This Pulitzer Prize-winning historian combines personal memoir with rigorous scholarship to reveal how Juneteenth shaped American history. Gordon-Reed dismantles Texas mythology to uncover the essential role of African-Americans in the state's story, offering vital context as the holiday gains national recognition.
Refined_Bio: Annette Gordon-Reed is the Carl M. Loeb University Professor at Harvard University and author of the Pulitzer Prize-winning The Hemingses of Monticello. She lives in New York and Cambridge, Massachusetts.
Formatted_Quotes:
"The Pulitzer Prize-winning historian interweaves her personal, trailblazing history with that of her home state to pierce many of the false narratives we learned as children about the country's treatment of African Americans.... Gordon-Reed offers a timely history lesson. She does so with beautiful prose, breathtaking stories and painful memories.... Gordon-Reed's literary gift is the ability to research and write about subjects with broadly accepted stories in a convincing way that allows readers to consider other perspectives."

—Daina Ramey Berry, The Washington Post

"Pulitzer-winner Gordon-Reed (The Hemingses of Monticello) interweaves history, politics, and memoir in these immersive and well-informed essays reflecting on the history of Juneteenth.... Despite the thorny racial history, Gordon-Reed expresses a deep fondness for her native state, writing that 'love does not require taking an uncritical stance toward the object of one's affections.' This brisk history lesson entertains and enlightens."

—Publishers Weekly

"A concise personal and scholarly history that avoids academic jargon as it illuminates emotional truths."

—Kirkus
Short_Summary: The essential, sweeping story of Juneteenth’s integral importance to American history, as told by a Pulitzer Prize–winning historian and Texas native.
Long_Summary:
Weaving together American history, dramatic family chronicle, and searing episodes of memoir, Annette Gordon-Reed’s On Juneteenth provides a historian’s view of the country’s long road to Juneteenth, recounting both its origins in Texas and the enormous hardships that African-Americans have endured in the century since, from Reconstruction through Jim Crow and beyond. All too aware of the stories of cowboys, ranchers, and oilmen that have long dominated the lore of the Lone Star State, Gordon-Reed—herself a Texas native and the descendant of enslaved people brought to Texas as early as the 1820s—forges a new and profoundly truthful narrative of her home state, with implications for us all.

Combining personal anecdotes with poignant facts gleaned from the annals of American history, Gordon-Reed shows how, from the earliest presence of Black people in Texas to the day in Galveston on June 19, 1865, when Major General Gordon Granger announced the end of legalized slavery in the state, African-Americans played an integral role in the Texas story.

Reworking the traditional “Alamo” framework, she powerfully demonstrates, among other things, that the slave- and race-based economy not only defined the fractious era of Texas independence but precipitated the Mexican-American War and, indeed, the Civil War itself.

As our nation verges on recognizing June 19 as a national holiday, On Juneteenth is both an essential account and a stark reminder that the fight for equality is exigent and ongoing.

Title: The Good Nurse
Subtitle: A True Story of Medicine, Madness, and Murder
Summary: The chilling true story of Charlie Cullen, a nurse who became one of America’s most prolific serial killers, and the pursuit to bring him to justice.
Refined_Long_Summary:
The Good Nurse tells the horrifying true story of Charlie Cullen, a registered nurse who may be the most prolific serial killer in American history, implicated in as many as 400 patient deaths. Once a beloved father, husband, and celebrated caregiver, Cullen spent sixteen years working across nine hospitals, repeatedly shielded by a medical system more concerned with protecting its reputation than its patients.

Drawing on hundreds of pages of police records, wiretaps, videotapes, and exclusive jailhouse interviews with Cullen himself, Charles Graeber exposes the chilling secrets behind these crimes. But this isn't just the story of a killer—it's also about the detectives and colleagues who risked everything to stop him, especially Amy, a fellow nurse torn between loyalty to her friend and the lives hanging in the balance.

At once a terrifying portrait of madness and a searing indictment of America's for-profit healthcare system, The Good Nurse is ultimately an inspiring account of the quiet heroes who chose courage over silence.
Refined_Short_Summary: This true crime masterpiece follows nurse Charlie Cullen, potentially America's most prolific serial killer with 400 victims. If you devoured I'll Be Gone in the Dark or In Cold Blood, this chilling investigation is essential reading.
Refined_Bio: Charles Graeber has earned an Overseas Press Club award for Outstanding International Journalism, an Edgar nomination, and a British Medical Association citation of merit. His work has appeared in The New Yorker, New York Magazine, GQ, Bloomberg Businessweek, Vogue, MIT Technology Review, and The New York Times. He's been anthologized in The Best American Crime Writing, The Best American Science Writing, and other collections. Born in Iowa, he now lives closer to saltwater.
Formatted_Quotes:
"A stunning book...that should and does bring to mind In Cold Blood....the story appeals to prurient interests, as does any graphic tale of true crime. But THE GOOD NURSE succeeds in being about much more than Mr. Cullen's murderous kinks. The causes of his pathology are not interesting. But the eagerness of ambitious hospital administrators to cover up his misdeeds is revelatory. And the police investigation that brought him down is a thriller in every sense of that word."

—Janet Maslin, The New York Times

"The most terrifying book published this year. It is also one of the most thoughtful.... From a long series of conversations with Cullen, the detectives who solved the case and Amy, a nurse who once was Cullen's best friend and eventually got him to confess, among many other sources, Graeber has crafted a book that is a revelation. THE GOOD NURSE is gripping, sad, suspenseful, rhythmic and beautifully documented (the endnotes to this book are impressive)."

—Kirkus

"Graeber doesn't pull punches... A deeply unsettling addition to the true crime genre."

—Publishers Weekly

Title: Killers of the Flower Moon
Subtitle: The Osage Murders and the Birth of the FBI
Summary: Grann unravels a forgotten chapter of American history: the murder spree targeting the Osage Nation in the 1920s, exposing greed, racism, and the early FBI’s role in the case.
Refined_Long_Summary:
In the 1920s, the Osage Nation in Oklahoma became the richest people per capita in the world after oil was discovered beneath their land. They rode in chauffeured automobiles, built mansions, and sent their children to study in Europe.

Then the murders began. One by one, the Osage were systematically killed off. Mollie Burkhart's family became a prime target—one relative was shot, another poisoned. As the death toll mounted under mysterious circumstances, anyone who dared investigate was murdered too.

The newly created FBI took up the case, with young director J. Edgar Hoover turning to former Texas Ranger Tom White to solve the mystery. White assembled an undercover team, including a Native American agent who infiltrated the region. Working alongside the Osage, they began to expose one of the most chilling conspiracies in American history—a methodical campaign of terror driven by greed and racism that would shake the nation.
Refined_Short_Summary: When oil made the Osage Nation incredibly wealthy in the 1920s, a systematic murder campaign began targeting them. This chilling true crime masterpiece reads like a thriller but exposes horrifying American history.
Refined_Bio: David Grann is the author of #1 New York Times bestsellers Killers of the Flower Moon and The Lost City of Z. Killers of the Flower Moon was a National Book Award finalist and won an Edgar Allan Poe Award. He also wrote The White Darkness and The Devil and Sherlock Holmes. His investigative reporting has earned several honors, including a George Polk Award. He lives with his family in New York.
Formatted_Quotes:
"[C]lose to impeccable. It's confident, fluid in its dynamics, light on its feet.... The crime story it tells is appalling, and stocked with authentic heroes and villains. It will make you cringe at man's inhumanity to man."

—The New York Times

"The best book of the year so far."

—Entertainment Weekly

"Disturbing and riveting.... Grann has proved himself a master of spinning delicious, many-layered mysteries that also happen to be true.... It will sear your soul."

—Dave Eggers, Author of A Hologram for the King
Short_Summary: Grann unravels a forgotten chapter of American history: the murder spree targeting the Osage Nation in the 1920s, exposing greed, racism, and the early FBI’s role in the case.
Long_Summary:
In the 1920s, the richest people per capita in the world were members of the Osage Nation in Oklahoma. After oil was discovered beneath their land, the Osage rode in chauffeured automobiles, built mansions, and sent their children to study in Europe.

Then, one by one, the Osage began to be killed off. The family of an Osage woman, Mollie Burkhart, became a prime target. One of her relatives was shot. Another was poisoned. And it was just the beginning, as more and more Osage were dying under mysterious circumstances, and many of those who dared to investigate the killings were themselves murdered.

As the death toll rose, the newly created FBI took up the case, and the young director, J. Edgar Hoover, turned to a former Texas Ranger named Tom White to try to unravel the mystery. White put together an undercover team, including a Native American agent who infiltrated the region, and together with the Osage began to expose one of the most chilling conspiracies in American history.
Copy_Bio: David Grann is the author of the #1 New York Times bestsellers Killers of the Flower Moon and The Lost City of Z. Killers of the Flower Moon was a finalist for the National Book Award and won an Edgar Allan Poe Award. He is also the author of The White Darkness and the collection The Devil and Sherlock Holmes. Grann’s investigative reporting has garnered several honors, including a George Polk Award. He lives with his wife and children in New York.

“The best book of the year so far.”—Entertainment Weekly

“Disturbing and riveting.... Grann has proved himself a master of spinning delicious, many-layered mysteries that also happen to be true.... It will sear your soul.”—Dave Eggers, Author of A Hologram for the King

Title: The Fault in Our Stars
Summary: Green’s international bestseller tells the story of two teenagers with cancer who fall in love, confronting mortality with humor and heart.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Despite the tumor-shrinking medical miracle that has bought her a few years, Hazel has never been anything but terminal, her final chapter inscribed upon diagnosis. But when a gorgeous plot twist named Augustus Waters suddenly appears at Cancer Kid Support Group, Hazel's story is about to be completely rewritten.

Insightful, bold, irreverent, and raw, The Fault in Our Stars is John Green's most ambitious and heartbreaking work yet, brilliantly exploring the funny, thrilling, and tragic business of being alive and in love.
Refined_Short_Summary: Two teenagers with cancer fall in love and confront mortality with humor and devastating honesty. If you ugly-cried over Everything I Never Told You, prepare your tissues for this one.
Refined_Bio: John Green is the award-winning, #1 bestselling author of Looking for Alaska, The Fault in Our Stars, Turtles All the Way Down, and Everything is Tuberculosis. His books have received a Printz Medal, Printz Honor, and Edgar Award. He's been a two-time Los Angeles Times Book Prize finalist and was named one of TIME's 100 Most Influential People. He hosts the acclaimed podcast The Anthropocene Reviewed and co-created Vlogbrothers and Crash Course with his brother Hank.

Title: The Swerve
Subtitle: How the World Became Modern
Summary: Tracing the rediscovery of Lucretius’s ancient poem On the Nature of Things, Greenblatt shows how its ideas helped ignite the Renaissance and shape the modern world.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Nearly six hundred years ago, a sharp-eyed book hunter made a discovery that would change everything. Pulling an ancient manuscript from a dusty library shelf, he recognized its explosive potential and ordered it copied immediately.

That book was the last surviving copy of Lucretius's On the Nature of Things—a stunning Roman philosophical epic filled with the most dangerous ideas of its time. It argued that the universe operated without gods, that religious fear damaged human life, and that all matter consisted of tiny particles in constant motion, colliding and changing direction in an eternal dance.

Stephen Greenblatt, one of our most celebrated scholars, traces how this single rediscovered text ignited the Renaissance and shaped our modern world. The poem's revolutionary ideas inspired Botticelli's art and Bruno's philosophy, influenced the thinking of Galileo and Darwin, Freud and Einstein, and left their mark on writers from Montaigne to Shakespeare to Thomas Jefferson. This is both masterful history and thrilling detective story—showing how one manuscript, rescued from a millennium of neglect, made possible the world as we know it.
Refined_Short_Summary: When a medieval book hunter discovered the last copy of an ancient Roman poem, he unknowingly sparked the Renaissance. Greenblatt masterfully traces how Lucretius's radical ideas about science and religion transformed Western thought forever.
Refined_Bio: Stephen Greenblatt is Cogan University Professor of the Humanities at Harvard University. He's written extensively on English Renaissance literature and serves as general editor of The Norton Anthology of English Literature and The Norton Shakespeare. Author of fourteen books, including The Swerve, winner of the Pulitzer Prize and National Book Award, and Will in the World, a Pulitzer Prize finalist.
Formatted_Quotes:
"The ideas in The Swerve are tucked, cannily, inside a quest narrative. . . . The details that Mr. Greenblatt supplies throughout The Swerve are tangy and exact. . . . There is abundant evidence here of what is Mr. Greenblatt's great and rare gift as a writer: an ability, to borrow a phrase from The Swerve, to feel fully 'the concentrated force of the buried past."

—The New York Times

"In this gloriously learned page-turner, both biography and intellectual history, Harvard Shakespearean scholar Greenblatt turns his attention to the front end of the Renaissance as the origin of Western culture's foundation: the free questioning of truth."

—Publishers Weekly

"More wonderfully illuminating Renaissance history from a master scholar and historian."

—Kirkus
Short_Summary: Tracing the rediscovery of Lucretius’s ancient poem On the Nature of Things, Greenblatt shows how its ideas helped ignite the Renaissance and shape the modern world.
Long_Summary:
One of the world's most celebrated scholars, Stephen Greenblatt has crafted both an innovative work of history and a thrilling story of discovery, in which one manuscript, plucked from a thousand years of neglect, changed the course of human thought and made possible the world as we know it.

Nearly six hundred years ago, a short, genial, cannily alert man in his late thirties took a very old manuscript off a library shelf, saw with excitement what he had discovered, and ordered that it be copied. That book was the last surviving manuscript of an ancient Roman philosophical epic, On the Nature of Things, by Lucretius—a beautiful poem of the most dangerous ideas: that the universe functioned without the aid of gods, that religious fear was damaging to human life, and that matter was made up of very small particles in eternal motion, colliding and swerving in new directions.

The copying and translation of this ancient book-the greatest discovery of the greatest book-hunter of his age-fueled the Renaissance, inspiring artists such as Botticelli and thinkers such as Giordano Bruno; shaped the thought of Galileo and Freud, Darwin and Einstein; and had a revolutionary influence on writers such as Montaigne and Shakespeare and even Thomas Jefferson.

Title: Small Rain
Subtitle: A Novel
Summary: A poet confined to a hospital room contemplates love, illness, and the body during lockdown. With Greenwell’s luminous sentences and unflinching interiority, Small Rain is a short, ravishing novel about beauty at the edge of fear—intimate, searching, and quietly life-affirming.
Refined_Long_Summary:
A poet's life is turned inside out by sudden, wrenching pain that brings him to his knees and eventually to the ICU. Confined to bed and plunged into the dysfunctional American healthcare system, he struggles to understand what's happening to his body as someone who has lived for years in his mind.

This searching, sweeping novel unfolds at the furthest edges of human experience, where the forces that give life value—art, memory, poetry, music, care—are thrown into sharp relief. Time expands and contracts. Sudden intimacies bloom.

Small Rain surges beyond the hospital to encompass a radiant vision of human life: our shared vulnerability, the limits and possibilities of sympathy, the ideal of art and the fragile dream of America. Above all, this is a love story of the most unexpected kind.
Refined_Short_Summary: When a medical crisis brings a poet to the brink of death, he discovers unexpected intimacy and beauty in the most unlikely place. Greenwell crafts something luminous from pain and vulnerability.
Refined_Bio: Garth Greenwell is the author of Cleanness and What Belongs to You. He's received a Guggenheim Fellowship and the Harold D. Vursell Memorial Award for prose style from the American Academy of Arts and Letters, and is currently Distinguished Writer in Residence at New York University.
Formatted_Quotes:
"There's an unshowy genius to Garth Greenwell's prose that feels genuinely peerless among contemporary American novelists . . . Small Rain is a classic, a dawn serenade, a little miracle of exigent joy. I'll be rereading it the rest of my life."

—Kaveh Akbar, author of Martyr!

"Throughout Small Rain, Greenwell's massing, vascular prose, arranged in paragraphs that span many pages, deftly forces the reader to slow down and concentrate. His sentences are parataxic and branching, as organic and surprising as a network of veins . . . Greenwell's great gift: finding forms for the representation of thought, much as the Impressionist painters, more than a century ago, found new forms for the representation of light . . . The novel [has] blazing universality and grace."

—Sarah Thankam Mathews, author of All This Could Be Different

"I just didn't put it down . . . Very romantic, incredibly moving."

—Miranda July, author of All Fours

Title: Fates and Furies
Subtitle: A Novel
Summary: A marriage told twice: his version and then hers. Groff’s electric novel peels back eros, ambition, and the stories couples spin about themselves—glittering with secrets and structural daring, but grounded in raw, complicated love.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Fates and Furies is a literary masterpiece that defies expectation—a dazzling examination of marriage and creative partnership from one of the best writers of her generation.

Every story has two sides. Every relationship has two perspectives. And sometimes, the key to a great marriage is not its truths but its secrets. At the core of this rich, expansive novel, Lauren Groff presents the story of one such marriage over twenty-four years.

At age twenty-two, Lotto and Mathilde are tall, glamorous, madly in love, and destined for greatness. A decade later, their marriage is still the envy of their friends, but with electric precision we understand that things are far more complicated and remarkable than they seemed.

With stunning revelations and multiple narrative threads, Groff delivers a deeply satisfying exploration of love, art, creativity, and power in prose that is vibrantly alive and original. Profound, surprising, and emotionally riveting, this novel stirs both mind and heart.
Refined_Short_Summary: Marriage has two sides, and this stunning dual narrative reveals both over twenty-four years of secrets, passion, and creative ambition. Perfect for readers who were captivated by the complex relationships in Normal People.
Refined_Bio: Lauren Groff is a three-time National Book Award finalist and New York Times bestselling author of the novels The Monsters of Templeton, Arcadia, Fates and Furies, Matrix, and The Vaster Wilds, plus acclaimed short story collections Delicate Edible Birds and Florida. She has won The Story Prize, the ABA Indies' Choice Award, France's Grand Prix de l'Héroïne, and the Joyce Carol Oates Prize. Her work appears regularly in The New Yorker and The Atlantic, and has been translated into thirty-six languages. She lives in Gainesville, Florida, where she and her husband own the independent bookstore The Lynx.
Formatted_Quotes:
"One of the pleasures of reading Ms. Groff is her sheer unpredictability: She can inject her narrator's voice at any time, turn a sentence into a small hurricane."

—The New York Times

"Even from her impossibly high starting point, Lauren Groff just keeps getting better and better. Fates and Furies is a clear-the-ground triumph."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

"Fates and Furies is a dazzling novel, its people and its prose wondrously alive from page one. At once intimate and sweeping, this is the story of a marriage as parallel myths— flaring with passion and betrayal, with redemption and retribution, with the sort of heart-breaking, head-slapping secrets that make you want to seek out someone else who's read it. Lauren Groff is a powerful and graceful writer, one of the best of her generation."

—Jess Walter, New York Times-bestselling author of Beautiful Ruins
Short_Summary: From the award-winning, New York Times bestselling author of The Monsters of Templeton and Arcadia, an exhilarating novel about marriage, creativity, art, and perception.
Long_Summary:
Fates and Furies is a literary masterpiece that defies expectation. A dazzling examination of a marriage, it is also a portrait of creative partnership written by one of the best writers of her generation.

Every story has two sides. Every relationship has two perspectives. And sometimes, it turns out, the key to a great marriage is not its truths but its secrets. At the core of this rich, expansive, layered novel, Lauren Groff presents the story of one such marriage over the course of twenty-four years.

At age twenty-two, Lotto and Mathilde are tall, glamorous, madly in love, and destined for greatness. A decade later, their marriage is still the envy of their friends, but with an electric thrill we understand that things are even more complicated and remarkable than they have seemed. With stunning revelations and multiple threads, and in prose that is vibrantly alive and original, Groff delivers a deeply satisfying novel about love, art, creativity, and power that is unlike anything that has come before it. Profound, surprising, propulsive, and emotionally riveting, it stirs both the mind and the heart.

Title: Matrix
Subtitle: A Novel
Summary: Cast out from court, a young Marie de France becomes abbess of a struggling 12th-century abbey and transforms it into a thriving feminist stronghold. A visionary historical novel of power, mysticism, and women remaking the world.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Cast out by Eleanor of Aquitaine and deemed too rough for courtly life, seventeen-year-old Marie de France is exiled to England as prioress of a crumbling abbey where nuns face starvation and disease.

Initially overwhelmed by the harsh reality, Marie discovers unexpected purpose in leading her extraordinary sisters. In this demanding environment, she transforms her longing for family and homeland into something powerful: unwavering devotion to her community and faith in her divine visions.

Born into a lineage of women warriors and crusaders, Marie is determined to forge a revolutionary path for the women under her protection. But as the world shifts in frightening ways—one that can never accept her existence—will her fierce vision prove strong enough?

Matrix weaves together violence, sensuality, and religious ecstasy in a mesmerizing portrait of consuming passion and aberrant faith. Groff's first novel since Fates and Furies offers a defiant exploration of female creativity's raw power in a corrupted world.
Refined_Short_Summary: When Marie de France is banished from Eleanor of Aquitaine's court, she transforms a dying 12th-century abbey into a feminist fortress. Groff delivers a mystical powerhouse about women reshaping their world through sheer will and divine vision.
Refined_Bio: Lauren Groff is a three-time National Book Award finalist and New York Times bestselling author of The Monsters of Templeton, Arcadia, Fates and Furies, Matrix, and The Vaster Wilds, plus acclaimed story collections Delicate Edible Birds and Florida. She's won The Story Prize, ABA Indies' Choice Award, France's Grand Prix de l'Héroïne, and the Joyce Carol Oates Prize. Her work appears in The New Yorker and The Atlantic, translated into thirty-six languages. She lives in Gainesville, Florida, where she and her husband own independent bookstore The Lynx.
Formatted_Quotes:
"A radiant novel about the 12th-century poet and mystic Marie de France. . . Groff richly imagines Marie's decades of exile in a royal convent, which she eventually leads. A charged novel about female ambition."

—Maureen Corrigan, NPR's Fresh Air

"An audacious piece of storytelling, full of passion, wisdom and magic."

—Sarah Waters, New York Times bestselling author of The Paying Guests

"A thrillingly vivid, adventurous story about women and power that will blow readers' minds. Left me gasping."

—Emma Donoghue, author of Room
Short_Summary: Cast out from court, a young Marie de France becomes abbess of a struggling 12th-century abbey and transforms it into a thriving feminist stronghold. A visionary historical novel of power, mysticism, and women remaking the world.
Long_Summary:
Cast out of the royal court by Eleanor of Aquitaine, deemed too coarse and rough-hewn for marriage or courtly life, seventeen-year-old Marie de France is sent to England to be the new prioress of an impoverished abbey, its nuns on the brink of starvation and beset by disease.

At first taken aback by the severity of her new life, Marie finds focus and love in collective life with her singular and mercurial sisters. In this crucible, Marie steadily supplants her desire for family, for her homeland, for the passions of her youth with something new to her: devotion to her sisters, and a conviction in her own divine visions. Marie, born the last in a long line of women warriors and crusaders, is determined to chart a bold new course for the women she now leads and protects. But in a world that is shifting and corroding in frightening ways, one that can never reconcile itself with her existence, will the sheer force of Marie’s vision be bulwark enough?

Equally alive to the sacred and the profane, Matrix gathers currents of violence, sensuality, and religious ecstasy in a mesmerizing portrait of consuming passion, aberrant faith, and a woman that history moves both through and around. Lauren Groff’s new novel, her first since Fates and Furies, is a defiant and timely exploration of the raw power of female creativity in a corrupted world.

Title: Arcadia
Summary: A boy grows up in a utopian commune upstate, then must reckon with adulthood after the dream dissolves. Groff’s lyric, time-spanning novel captures the charisma of idealism and the ache of its aftermath—lush, wistful, and deeply humane.
Refined_Long_Summary:
In the fields of western New York State in the 1970s, a few dozen idealists set out to live off the land, founding a commune centered around a decaying mansion called Arcadia House. This is the story of their romantic, rollicking, and tragic utopian dream from its hopeful beginning through its heyday and inevitable decline.

Arcadia's inhabitants include Handy, the group's charismatic musical leader; Astrid, a midwife; Abe, a master carpenter; Hannah, a baker and historian; and their only child, Bit, born soon after the commune's creation. As the protagonist, Bit grows up immersed in this idealistic world, forming deep attachments to its residents—including Handy and Astrid's troubled daughter, Helle.

While Arcadia rises and falls around him, Bit must grapple with fundamental questions: How can he honor his love for the peaceful agrarian life while becoming his own man? How will he navigate the world outside Arcadia's protective boundaries? Groff masterfully weaves together the personal and political, exploring how utopian dreams shape the people who dare to live them.
Refined_Short_Summary: When idealists create a 1970s commune in upstate New York, their utopian dream shapes young Bit's entire world. This gorgeous novel traces how growing up in paradise complicates finding your place beyond its borders.
Refined_Bio: Lauren Groff is a three-time National Book Award finalist and New York Times bestselling author of the novels The Monsters of Templeton, Arcadia, Fates and Furies, Matrix, and The Vaster Wilds, plus acclaimed short story collections Delicate Edible Birds and Florida. She's won The Story Prize, ABA Indies' Choice Award, France's Grand Prix de l'Héroïne, and the Joyce Carol Oates Prize. Her work appears regularly in The New Yorker and The Atlantic, and has been translated into thirty-six languages. She lives in Gainesville, Florida, where she and her husband own independent bookstore The Lynx.
Formatted_Quotes:
"[Lauren Groff] has taken a quaint, easily caricatured community and given it true universality...And a book that might have been small, dated and insular winds up feeling timeless and vast...The raw beauty of Ms. Groff's prose is one of the best things about Arcadia. But it is by no means this book's only kind of splendor."

—Janet Maslin, The New York Times

"I was constantly torn between wanting to gulp down this book or savor its lines. Even the most incidental details vibrate with life... Arcadia wends a harrowing path back to a fragile, lovely place you can believe in."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

"A moving look at the value of human connection in a scary, chaotic world."

—Entertainment Weekly
Short_Summary: A brilliant follow-up to Groff's bestselling first novel, The Monsters of Templeton, Arcadia is the romantic, lush, haunting story of a great American dream-of a back-to-nature commune that succeeds for a time beyond anyone's expectations and about the lasting impact of the Arcadian experience on a gifted young man born into the idealistic community.
Long_Summary:
In the fields of western New York State in the 1970s, a few dozen idealists set out to live off the land, founding what would become a commune centered on the grounds of a decaying mansion called Arcadia House. Arcadia follows this romantic, rollicking, and tragic utopian dream from its hopeful start through its heyday and after.

Arcadia's inhabitants include Handy, a musician and the group's charismatic leader; Astrid, a midwife; Abe, a master carpenter; Hannah, a baker and historian; and Abe and Hannah's only child, the book's protagonist, Bit, who is born soon after the commune is created.

While Arcadia rises and falls, Bit, too, ages and changes. If he remains in love with the peaceful agrarian life in Arcadia and deeply attached to its residents--including Handy and Astrid's lithe and deeply troubled daughter, Helle--how can Bit become his own man? How will he make his way through life and the world outside of Arcadia where he must eventually live?

With Arcadia, her first novel since her lauded debut, The Monsters of Templeton, Lauren Groff establishes herself not only as one of the most gifted young fiction writers at work today but also as one of our most accomplished literary artists.

Title: Florida
Subtitle: Stories
Summary: Eleven fierce stories of mothers, storms, snakes, and heat: a portrait of a state—and a psyche—alive with dread and radiance. Groff distills the instability of climate and family into taut, unforgettable fiction.
Refined_Long_Summary:
In this electrifying collection, Lauren Groff creates a physical world that is simultaneously domestic and wild—where natural hazards lurk alongside deeper emotional and psychological threats. A family retreat might be disrupted by a prowling panther, or shattered by a buried sexual secret.

Navigating this treacherous landscape are unforgettable characters: resourceful abandoned sisters, a lonely boy grown into a complicated man, a restless childless couple, a searching homeless woman, and a recurring figure—a steely, conflicted wife and mother whose presence haunts multiple stories.

These stories span characters, towns, decades, even centuries, but Florida itself becomes the gravitational center—an energy and mood as much as a place. Groff transports readers into this humid world, then jolts us alert with crackling wit, waves of sadness, and flashes of cruelty. She writes about loneliness, rage, family, and time's relentless passage, pinpointing the precise moments behind human pleasure and pain, hope and despair, love and fury—the moments that make us devastatingly alive.

She's won The Story Prize, ABA Indies' Choice Award, France's Grand Prix de l'Héroïne, and the Joyce Carol Oates Prize. Title: The Bright Sword
Subtitle: A Novel of King Arthur
Summary: After King Arthur’s death, a ragtag fellowship—squires, outcasts, and the last believers—try to salvage meaning from a shattered Camelot. Grossman’s Arthurian adventure blends quest thrills with modern melancholy: what comes after the legend ends?
Refined_Long_Summary:
A gifted young knight named Collum arrives at Camelot to compete for a place at the Round Table, only to discover he's two weeks too late. King Arthur has fallen at the Battle of Camlann, and only a handful of knights remain.

The survivors aren't the legendary heroes like Lancelot or Gawain. They're the Round Table's misfits: Sir Palomides, the Saracen Knight; Sir Dagonet, Arthur's fool who was knighted as a joke; and Nimue, Merlin's former apprentice who turned against her master and buried him under a hill.

Now this unlikely fellowship must rebuild Camelot in a world thrown off balance. As God abandons Britain and ancient powers return—led by the vengeful Morgan le Fay—they face an impossible task. They must reclaim Excalibur and restore the broken realm, but first they need to solve the mystery of why their brilliant, lonely king ultimately fell.

Steeped in Arthurian tradition yet thoroughly modern, The Bright Sword delivers classic elements—duels and quests, magic swords and Fisher Kings—while exploring what happens when imperfect, wounded people try to forge meaning from the ruins of legend.
Refined_Short_Summary: What happens after the legend dies? When Collum arrives at Camelot, Arthur is already dead and only the Round Table's misfits remain. This brilliant reimagining asks whether broken people can rebuild a broken world.
Refined_Bio: Lev Grossman is the author of the #1 New York Times bestselling Magicians trilogy—The Magicians, The Magician King, and The Magician's Land—published in thirty countries and adapted as a five-season SYFY series. He's also written two children's books, The Golden Swift and The Silver Arrow, and contributed journalism to Time, Vanity Fair, The Wall Street Journal, and The New York Times. He lives with his family in New York City.

"For anyone who's ever craved a seat at the Round Table. Utterly enchanting."

—Rebecca Yarros, #1 New York Times bestselling author of Fourth Wing and Iron Flame

"If you love King Arthur as much as I do, you'll love Lev Grossman's The Bright Sword, a fresh and engrossing take on the Matter of Britain featuring a colorful cast of Round Table knights who don't often get as much story time as they deserve. The creator of The Magicians has woven another spell."

—George R. R. Martin, #1 New York Times bestselling author of A Game of Thrones

"The story of King Arthur has been told and substantially altered many times over the centuries, and explored by a multitude of contemporary novelists, but the author of the Magicians trilogy makes room for himself here. . . . Very few writers have explored post-Arthurian Britain or focused quite so much on developing the stories of the minor characters in the saga. . . . A fresh take."

—Kirkus
Short_Summary: After King Arthur’s death, a ragtag fellowship—squires, outcasts, and the last believers—try to salvage meaning from a shattered Camelot. Grossman’s Arthurian adventure blends quest thrills with modern melancholy: what comes after the legend ends?
Long_Summary:
A gifted young knight named Collum arrives at Camelot to compete for a place at the Round Table, only to find that he’s too late. King Arthur died two weeks ago at the Battle of Camlann, and only a handful of the knights of the Round Table are left.

The survivors aren’t the heroes of legend like Lancelot or Gawain. They’re the oddballs of the Round Table, like Sir Palomides, the Saracen Knight, and Sir Dagonet, Arthur’s fool, who was knighted as a joke. They’re joined by Nimue, who was Merlin’s apprentice until she turned on him and buried him under a hill. 

But it's up to them to rebuild Camelot in a world that has lost its balance, even as God abandons Britain and the fairies and old gods return, led by Morgan le Fay. They must reclaim Excalibur and make this ruined world whole again—but first they'll have to solve the mystery of why the lonely, brilliant King Arthur fell. 

The first major Arthurian epic of the new millennium, The Bright Sword is steeped in tradition, complete with duels and quests, battles and tournaments, magic swords and Fisher Kings. It's also a story about imperfect men and women, full of strength and pain, trying to reforge a broken land in spite of being broken themselves.

Title_Subtitle: To the End of the Land
Title: To the End of the Land
Summary: Fleeing the dread of a military notification, a mother walks Israel’s landscape with an old friend, recounting her life to ward off fate. Grossman’s antiwar epic is intimate and immense—about love, fear, and the impossible task of keeping our children safe.
Refined_Long_Summary:
In To the End of the Land, David Grossman tells the powerful story of Ora, an Israeli mother whose son Ofer has returned to the front lines just as his military service was ending. Terrified of receiving devastating news, she embarks on a hike through the Galilee with Avram, her estranged family friend and former lover.

Avram was once a brilliant artist but was broken by his capture and torture during the Yom Kippur War. As they walk across hills and valleys, Ora brings Ofer to life through stories of her motherhood, weaving the joys and sorrows of family life into the ever-present shadow of conflict.

At once intimate and sweeping, this profound novel captures the anguish of love in wartime, the bonds of family and friendship, and the heavy toll of violence across generations. It stands as one of the great antiwar novels of our time.
Refined_Short_Summary: When her son returns to military duty, an Israeli mother flees into the wilderness to escape devastating news. This profound exploration of motherhood and war will shatter you completely.
Refined_Bio: David Grossman was born in Jerusalem and is the author of acclaimed works of fiction, nonfiction, and children's literature. His books have been translated into more than forty languages, and his writing has appeared in The New Yorker. A recipient of numerous international awards—including the Chevalier de l'Ordre des Arts et des Lettres, Israel's EMET Prize, the Albatross Prize, the Erasmus Prize, and the Man Booker International Prize—he lives in Jerusalem.
Formatted_Quotes:
"Very rarely, a few times in a lifetime, you open a book and when you close it again nothing can ever be the same. To the End of the Land is a book of this magnitude. David Grossman may be the most gifted writer I've ever read.... Powerful, shattering, and unflinching. To read it is to have yourself taken apart, undone, touched at the place of your own essence."

—Nicole Krauss

"This is a book of overwhelming power and intensity, David Grossman's masterpiece. Flaubert created his Emma, Tolstoy made his Anna, and now we have Grossman's Ora — as fully alive, as fully embodied, as any character in recent fiction. I devoured this long novel in a feverish trance. Wrenching, beautiful, unforgettable."

—Paul Auster

"There are some writers in whose words one recognizes the texture of life. David Grossman is such a writer. His characters don't so much lie on the page as rise before the reader's eyes, in three dimensions, their skin covered in prose that both stabs with insight and shines with compassion."

—Yann Martel

Title: Survival Is a Promise
Subtitle: The Eternal Life of Audre Lorde
Summary: Gumbs offers a profound meditation on the work and legacy of poet Audre Lorde, envisioning survival and resistance through her words and life.
Refined_Long_Summary:
We remember Audre Lorde as an iconic writer, a quotable teacher whose words and face grace T-shirts, nonprofit annual reports, and campus diversity-center walls. But even those inspired by Lorde's teachings on "the creative power of difference" may be missing something fundamental about her life and work.

Lorde's understanding of survival wasn't simply about getting through oppression or being resilient in the face of cancer. It was about the total stakes of what it means to be in relationship with a planet in transformation. The focus on Lorde's quotable essays, to the neglect of her complex poems, has led us to ignore her deep engagement with the natural world—the planetary dynamics of geology, meteorology, and biology. For her, ecological images weren't simply metaphors but literal guides to how to be of earth on earth, and how to survive with the ethics that a Black feminist lesbian warrior poetics demands.

In Survival Is a Promise, Alexis Pauline Gumbs, the first researcher to explore the full depths of Lorde's manuscript archives, illuminates the eternal life of Lorde. Her life and work become more than a sound bite—they become a cosmic force, teaching us the grand contingency of life together on earth.
Refined_Short_Summary: Drawing from Lorde's manuscript archives, this groundbreaking biography reveals how the beloved poet's ecological vision offers radical lessons for survival on a transforming planet. Essential reading for anyone moved by The Prophets or Braiding Sweetgrass.
Refined_Bio: Alexis Pauline Gumbs is the author of several works of poetry and Undrowned: Black Feminist Lessons from Marine Animals, which won a Whiting Writers' Award in 2022. In 2023, she won a Windham Campbell Prize for her poetry. She lives in Durham, North Carolina.
Formatted_Quotes:
"Layered and original . . . Gumbs's book revels in Lorde's lush multiplicity, moving through the ebbs and flows of her life with both precision and lyricism and expanding the limits of what a biography can be and hold and feel like . . . The result is a prismatic work of art."

—Danielle Amir Jackson, The Atlantic

"An endless constellation of everyone who affected and was affected by Lorde . . . Survival is a Promise admirably demonstrates the breadth and depth of Lorde's journey from Harlem to the stars . . . By recounting Lorde's story outside linear chronology, and putting her alongside the rivers, forests, radio waves and obsidian, Gumbs is faithful to her subject's great desire to be something more eternal. But Survival is a Promise finally shows that this cosmic life is achieved through grounded and deep human work."

—Zito Madu, The Washington Post

"An award-winning poet, writer, feminist and activist in her own right, Gumbs is among the first researchers to delve into Lorde's manuscript archives. The resulting book highlights the late author's commitment to interrogating what it means to survive on this planet—and how Lorde's radical understanding of ecology can guide us today."

—Erika Taylor, NPR

Lorde’s understanding of survival was not simply about getting through to the other side of oppression or being resilient in the face of cancer. Title: The Rabbit Hutch
Subtitle: A novel
Summary: In a fading Indiana city, four teenagers in subsidized housing orbit toward a single incandescent night. Weird, tender, and darkly funny, Gunty’s debut is a choral portrait of loneliness and yearning in post-industrial America.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Blandine isn't like the other residents of her building. Ethereally beautiful and formidably intelligent, she shares her apartment with three teenage boys she neither likes nor understands. All four have aged out of the state foster care system that repeatedly failed them, all searching for meaning in their lives.

Their neighbors in the Rabbit Hutch—a low-cost housing complex in the once-bustling industrial center of Vacca Vale, Indiana—include an online obituary writer, a young mother with a dark secret, and a woman waging a solo campaign against rodents. Separated only by thin walls, their lives intersect in unexpected ways.

Set over one sweltering week in July, this savagely beautiful and bitingly funny snapshot of contemporary America explores loneliness and longing, entrapment and freedom, building toward a bizarre act of violence that finally changes everything.
Refined_Short_Summary: Four foster care graduates share a cramped apartment in a crumbling Indiana housing complex, their lives intersecting with eccentric neighbors over one explosive July week. If you loved the ensemble cast dynamics of There There, this haunting debut will captivate you.
Refined_Bio: Tess Gunty earned an MFA in creative writing from NYU, where she was a Lillian Vernon Fellow. Her work has appeared in The Iowa Review, Joyland, Los Angeles Review of Books, No Tokens, Flash, and elsewhere. She was raised in South Bend, Indiana, and lives in Los Angeles.
Formatted_Quotes:
"The Rabbit Hutch aches, bleeds, and even scars but it also forgives with laughter, with insight, and finally, through an act of generational independence that remains this novel's greatest accomplishment, with an act of rescue, rescue of narrative, rescue from ritual, rescue of heart, the rescue of tomorrow."

—Mark Z. Danielewski, author of House of Leaves

"An astonishing portrait . . . Gunty delves into the stories of Blandine's neighbors, brilliantly and achingly charting the range of their experiences. . . . It all ties together, achieving this first novelist's maximalist ambitions and making powerful use of language along the way. Readers will be breathless."

—Publishers Weekly

"Darkly funny, surprising, and mesmerizing . . . A stunning and original debut that is as smart as it is entertaining . . . Gunty pans swiftly from room to room, perspective to perspective, molding a story that . . . is extremely suspenseful and culminates in a finale that will leave readers breathless. With sharp prose and startling imagery, the novel touches on subjects from environmental trauma to rampant consumerism to sexual power dynamics to mysticism to mental illness, all with an astonishing wisdom and imaginativeness. . . . A striking and wise depiction of what it means to be awake and alive in a dying building, city, nation, and world."

—Kirkus

An online obituary writer. A young mother with a dark secret. A woman waging a solo campaign against rodents — neighbors, separated only by the thin walls of a low-cost housing complex in the once bustling industrial center of Vacca Vale, Indiana.

Ethereally beautiful and formidably intelligent, Blandine shares her apartment with three teenage boys she neither likes nor understands, all, like her, now aged out of the state foster care system that has repeatedly failed them, all searching for meaning in their lives.

Set over one sweltering week in July and culminating in a bizarre act of violence that finally changes everything, The Rabbit Hutch is a savagely beautiful and bitingly funny snapshot of contemporary America, a gorgeous and provocative tale of loneliness and longing, entrapment and, ultimately, freedom.

Title: Afterlives
Subtitle: A Novel
BISAC_Category_Description: Fiction / World Literature / Africa / East Africa
Summary: In German East Africa, the fates of three people—stolen as a child soldier, sold into service, left behind by war—intersect across decades. Written with tenderness and historical sweep, Afterlives traces love and repair in the long shadow of empire.
Refined_Long_Summary:
When Ilyas was just a boy, German colonial troops stole him from his parents on the coast of east Africa. After years fighting against his own people, he returns home to discover his parents gone and his sister Afiya abandoned into slavery.

Hamza also comes back from the war, scarred in body and soul with nothing but the clothes on his back—until he meets the beautiful, determined Afiya. As these young people work, love, and build new lives together, their fates become increasingly intertwined.

But the shadow of another war on a distant continent threatens to tear them apart once again. This sweeping story explores how colonialism fractures families and communities, while celebrating the resilience of those who refuse to be broken by history's cruelties.
Refined_Short_Summary: Nobel Prize winner Gurnah crafts an intimate epic about siblings torn apart by German colonization in east Africa. When they reunite years later, love and hope bloom amid the scars of empire. Essential reading for fans of Homegoing.
Refined_Bio: Abdulrazak Gurnah won the 2021 Nobel Prize in Literature. He's authored nine novels, including Paradise (Booker Prize shortlisted), By the Sea (Booker longlisted, LA Times Book Prize finalist), and Desertion. Born in Zanzibar, he's Professor Emeritus of English and Postcolonial Literatures at the University of Kent and lives in Canterbury, England.

Title: Theft (Winner of the Nobel Prize in Literature)
Subtitle: A Novel
BISAC_Category_Description: Fiction / World Literature / Africa / East Africa
Refined_Long_Summary:
At the turn of the twenty-first century, three young people navigate the complexities of modern Tanzania. Karim returns to his sleepy hometown after university in Dar es Salaam, brimming with new swagger and ambition. There he catches the eye of Fauzia, who sees in him a chance to escape her smothering upbringing.

When the two offer refuge to Badar, a poor boy uncertain whether the future holds anything for him at all, they can't imagine how deeply their fates will entwine and diverge. As rapidly accelerating global change reaches even their quiet corner of the world—bringing tourists, technology, and unexpected opportunities alongside new perils—each character arrives at a different understanding of what it means to take control of their destiny.

Gurnah masterfully captures a generation caught between tradition and transformation, exploring how young people forge their identities when everything around them is shifting.
Refined_Short_Summary: Three young Tanzanians navigate love, ambition, and identity as globalization transforms their quiet corner of the world. Gurnah's first novel since winning the Nobel Prize captures a generation caught between tradition and change with stunning intimacy.

Title: Transcendent Kingdom
Subtitle: A novel
Summary: A Ghanaian American neuroscientist studies addiction and reward while caring for her depressed mother, haunted by her brother’s overdose. Spare and piercing, the novel braids science, faith, and the fragile hope of family repair.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Gifty is a sixth-year PhD candidate in neuroscience at the Stanford University School of Medicine studying reward-seeking behavior in mice and the neural circuits of depression and addiction. Her brother, Nana, was a gifted high school athlete who died of a heroin overdose after an ankle injury left him hooked on OxyContin. Her suicidal mother is living in her bed. Gifty is determined to discover the scientific basis for the suffering she sees all around her. But even as she turns to the hard sciences to unlock the mystery of her family's loss, she finds herself hungering for her childhood faith and grappling with the evangelical church in which she was raised, whose promise of salvation remains as tantalizing as it is elusive.

Transcendent Kingdom is a deeply moving portrait of a family of Ghanaian immigrants ravaged by depression and addiction and grief—a novel about faith, science, religion, love. Exquisitely written, emotionally searing, this is an exceptionally powerful follow-up to Gyasi's phenomenal debut.
Refined_Short_Summary: Yaa Gyasi's stunning follow-up to her acclaimed national best seller Homegoing is a powerful, raw, intimate, deeply layered novel about a Ghanaian family in Alabama.
Refined_Bio: Yaa Gyasi was born in Ghana and raised in Huntsville, Alabama. Her debut novel, Homegoing, won her the National Book Critics Circle’s John Leonard Award for best first book, the PEN/Hemingway Award for a first book of fiction, the National Book Foundation’s “5 under 35” honors for 2016, and the American Book Award. She lives in Brooklyn.
Formatted_Quotes:
"I would say that Transcendent Kingdom is a novel for our time (and it is) but it is so much more than that. It is a novel for all times. The splendor and heart and insight and brilliance contained in the pages holds up a light the rest of us can follow."  
—Ann Patchett, author of Tom Lake, Commonwealth & State of Wonder

"Meticulous, psychologically complex...At once a vivid evocation of the immigrant experience and a sharp delineation of an individual’s inner struggle, the novel brilliantly succeeds on both counts."—Publishers Weekly

"Gyasi’s wise second novel pivots toward intimacy... In precise prose, Gyasi creates an ache of recognition, especially for readers knowledgeable about the wreckage of addiction. Still, she leavens this nonlinear novel with sly humor... The author is astute about childhood grandiosity and a pious girl’s deep desire to be good; she conveys in brief strokes the notched, nodding hook of heroin’s oblivion...final chapter that gives readers a taste of hard-won deliverance."—Kirkus

Title: Homegoing
Subtitle: A novel
Summary: Two half-sisters in 18th-century Ghana are separated—one sold into slavery, the other married to a slave trader—launching a lineage that spans continents and centuries. Homegoing is sweeping yet intimate, a mosaic of how history moves through families.
Refined_Long_Summary:
The unforgettable New York Times best seller begins with the story of two half-sisters, separated by forces beyond their control: one sold into slavery, the other married to a British slaver. Written with tremendous sweep and power, Homegoing traces the generations of family who follow, as their destinies lead them through two continents and three hundred years of history, each life indeliably drawn, as the legacy of slavery is fully revealed in light of the present day.
           
Effia and Esi are born into different villages in eighteenth-century Ghana. Effia is married off to an Englishman and lives in comfort in the palatial rooms of Cape Coast Castle. Unbeknownst to Effia, her sister, Esi, is imprisoned beneath her in the castle’s dungeons, sold with thousands of others into the Gold Coast’s booming slave trade, and shipped off to America, where her children and grandchildren will be raised in slavery. One thread of Homegoing follows Effia’s descendants through centuries of warfare in Ghana, as the Fante and Asante nations wrestle with the slave trade and British colonization. The other thread follows Esi and her children into America. From the plantations of the South to the Civil War and the Great Migration, from the coal mines of Pratt City, Alabama, to the jazz clubs and dope houses of twentieth-century Harlem, right up through the present day, Homegoing makes history visceral, and captures, with singular and stunning immediacy, how the memory of captivity came to be inscribed in the soul of a nation.
Refined_Short_Summary: Two half-sisters in 18th-century Ghana are separated—one sold into slavery, the other married to a slave trader—launching a lineage that spans continents and centuries. Homegoing is sweeping yet intimate, a mosaic of how history moves through families.
Refined_Bio: Yaa Gyasi was born in Ghana and raised in Huntsville, Alabama. Her debut novel, Homegoing, won her the National Book Critics Circle’s John Leonard Award for best first book, the PEN/Hemingway Award for a first book of fiction, the National Book Foundation’s “5 under 35” honors for 2016, and the American Book Award. She lives in Brooklyn.
Formatted_Quotes:
“Gyasi’s characters are so fully realized, so elegantly carved—very often I found myself longing to hear more. Craft is essential given the task Gyasi sets for herself—drawing not just a lineage of two sisters, but two related peoples. Gyasi is deeply concerned with the sin of selling humans on Africans, not Europeans. But she does not scold. She does not excuse. And she does not romanticize. The black Americans she follows are not overly virtuous victims.  Sin comes in all forms, from selling people to abandoning children.  I think I needed to read a book like this to remember what is possible.  I think I needed to remember what happens when you pair a gifted literary mind to an epic task. Homegoing is an inspiration.”—Ta-Nehisi Coates, National Book Award-winning author of Between the World and Me

“The hypnotic debut novel by Yaa Gyasi, a stirringly gifted writer . . . magical . . . the great, aching gift of the novel is that it offers, in its own way, the very thing that enslavement denied its descendants: the possibility of imagining the connection between the broken threads of their origins.”—Isabel Wilkerson, The New York Times

"Homegoing is a remarkable feat—a novel at once epic and intimate, capturing the moral weight of history as it bears down on individual struggles, hopes, and fears. A tremendous debut.” —Phil Klay, National Book Award-winning author of Redeployment

Title: After Visiting Friends
Subtitle: A Son's Story
Summary: Investigative memoir meets family mystery as Hainey unravels the story of his father’s mysterious death, blending journalism and personal narrative.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Michael Hainey was six when his uncle knocked on the door with devastating news: his father Bob, a 35-year-old assistant copy desk chief at the Chicago Sun-Times, had been found dead near his car on Chicago's North Side. The cause? An apparent heart attack.

Bob was a rising star in the competitive, hard-living world of 1970s newspapers—a world of booze-soaked nights that bled into dawn. His sudden death left behind a young widow, two sons, and a fractured family haunted by unanswered questions about that mysterious night.

Thirty-five years later, Michael—now roughly his father's age and a seasoned reporter himself—sets out to uncover the truth. The obituaries said Bob died "after visiting friends," but the details were maddeningly inconsistent. What friends? Where? What really happened?

At the heart of his investigation is Michael's all-too-silent mother, a woman of fierce courage and steely determination not to look back. Working through his father's old newspaper buddies—men bound by an honor code of silence and secrecy—Michael must navigate long-held family myths to reconcile the father he'd imagined with the one he discovers, finding unexpected truths about his mother along the way.
Refined_Short_Summary: When journalist Michael Hainey's father died mysteriously in 1970s Chicago, his family never spoke of it. Decades later, Michael embarks on his own investigation to uncover what really happened that night. A gripping blend of family memoir and detective story.
Refined_Bio: Michael Hainey is the deputy editor of GQ. Born in Chicago, he now lives in Manhattan.
Formatted_Quotes:
"After Visiting Friends is full of love for the lost world of nocturnal newspaper work and after-hours boozing."

—Janet Maslin, The New York Times

"Part what next? detective story, part moving family portrait, and part wistful ode to the whiskey-sloshed mid-century Chicago newspaper world…"

—Rob Brunner, Entertainment Weekly

"A book whose heartbreak and humor, in the true Irish tradition, can't be untangled. It's a kind of detective story, but the mystery is the past itself."

—John Jeremiah Sullivan, author of Pulphead
Short_Summary: A decade in the writing, the haunting story of a son’s quest to understand the mystery of his father’s death—a universal memoir about the secrets families keep and the role they play in making us who we are.
Long_Summary:
Michael Hainey had just turned six when his uncle knocked on his family’s back door one morning with the tragic news: Bob Hainey, Michael’s father, was found alone near his car on Chicago’s North Side, dead, of an apparent heart attack. Thirty-five years old, a young assistant copy desk chief at the Chicago Sun-Times, Bob was a bright and shining star in the competitive, hard-living world of newspapers, one that involved booze-soaked nights that bled into dawn. And then suddenly he was gone, leaving behind a young widow, two sons, a fractured family—and questions surrounding the mysterious nature of his death that would obsess Michael throughout adolescence and long into adulthood. Finally, roughly his father’s age when he died, and a seasoned reporter himself, Michael set out to learn what happened that night. Died “after visiting friends,” the obituaries said. But the details beyond that were inconsistent. What friends? Where? At the heart of his quest is Michael’s all-too-silent, opaque mother, a woman of great courage and tenacity—and a steely determination not to look back. Prodding and cajoling his relatives, and working through a network of his father’s buddies who abide by an honor code of silence and secrecy, Michael sees beyond the long-held myths and ultimately reconciles the father he’d imagined with the one he comes to know—and in the journey discovers new truths about his mother.

A stirring portrait of a family and its legacy of secrets, After Visiting Friends is the story of a son who goes in search of the truth and finds not only his father, but a rare window into a world of men and newspapers and fierce loyalties that no longer exists.
Copy_Bio: Michael Hainey is the deputy editor of GQ. He was born in Chicago and now lives in Manhattan.

"A book whose heartbreak and humor, in the true Irish tradition, can't be untangled. It's a kind of detective story, but the mystery is the past itself."—John Jeremiah Sullivan, author of Pulphead
