Title: The Country of the Blind
Subtitle: A Memoir at the End of Sight
Summary: Leland chronicles his gradual loss of sight and explores blindness in history, culture, and community with humor and insight.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Andrew Leland finds himself in an extraordinary liminal space: suspended between sight and blindness. Living with retinitis pigmentosa, a condition that gradually steals vision from the outside in, he's spent decades watching his world slowly shrink. What began as subtle changes in his teenage years has progressed to an inevitable conclusion—soon, he will likely be completely blind.

Rather than simply wait for that moment, Leland embarks on a fascinating journey of discovery. He dives deep into the rich culture, language, and politics of blindness, determined to understand not just the physical reality awaiting him, but the entire world he's about to enter. Along the way, he navigates shifting relationships with his wife and son, and grapples with his evolving sense of identity as he moves from mainstream life to one with disability.

Part memoir, part cultural investigation, this is Leland's refusal to merely survive his transition. Instead, he seeks transformation—hunting for the ways blindness might actually enlighten rather than diminish. Warm, funny, and deeply curious, it's an exhilarating exploration of what it means to discover an entirely new way of being.
Refined_Short_Summary: Living with a degenerative eye condition, Leland chronicles his journey from sight to blindness with humor and curiosity. Rather than mourning what he's losing, he explores blindness as a rich culture with its own language and customs. Perfect for readers who loved Educated's transformative self-discovery.
Refined_Bio: Andrew Leland's writing has appeared in The New York Times Magazine, The New Yorker, McSweeney's, The San Francisco Chronicle, and Art in America. From 2013 to 2019, he hosted and produced The Organist, an arts and culture podcast for KCRW, and has produced pieces for Radiolab and 99% Invisible. He has been an editor at The Believer since 2003. He lives in western Massachusetts with his wife and son.
Formatted_Quotes:
"The Country of the Blind is about seeing—but also about marriage and family and the moral and emotional challenge of accommodating the parts of ourselves that scare us. A warm, profound, and unforgettable meditation on how we adjust to new ways of being in the world."

—Rachel Aviv, author of Strangers to Ourselves

"[Leland's] education in navigating the world without his eyes is an entry point into a fascinating cultural history of blindness. The great strength of this memoir is its voracious, humble curiosity; throughout, Leland treats losing his vision as just as much an opportunity as a foreclosure."

—The Atlantic

"This is such a gorgeous book. Andrew Leland manages to deftly balance the personal, historical and political as he documents—documents is too sterile a word; he gently sings about—his becoming blind. There is a great nonfiction book here about the history of blindness and the pioneers who have built a world of access and empowerment. But crucially, Leland weaves into that larger tapestry the deeply touching story of how he, his wife Lily, and his son Oscar face their myriad new challenges—with open minds and abundant wit, and always fearlessly together."

—Dave Eggers, author of A Hologram for the King, The Circle & A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius
Short_Summary: A witty, winning, and revelatory personal narrative of the author’s transition from sightedness to blindness and his quest to learn about blindness as a rich culture all its own.
Long_Summary:
We meet Andrew Leland as he’s suspended in the liminal state of the soon-to-be blind: he’s midway through his life with retinitis pigmentosa, a condition that ushers those who live with it from sightedness to blindness over years, even decades. He grew up with full vision, but starting in his teenage years, his sight began to degrade from the outside in. Soon— but without knowing exactly when—he will likely have no vision left.

Full of apprehension but also dogged curiosity, Leland embarks on a sweeping exploration of the state of being that awaits him: not only the physical experience of blindness but also its language, politics, and customs. He negotiates his changing relationships with his wife and son, and with his own sense of self, as he moves from his mainstream, “typical” life to one with a disability. Part memoir, part historical and cultural investigation, The Country of the Blind represents Leland’s determination not to merely survive this transition but to grow from it—to seek out and revel in that which makes blindness enlightening. Brimming with warmth and humor, it is an exhilarating tour of a new way of being.

Title: Book of Ages
Subtitle: The Life and Opinions of Jane Franklin
Summary: Lepore brings to life Jane Franklin, sister of Benjamin, in a biography that illuminates women’s overlooked role in early America.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Benjamin Franklin wrote more letters to his sister Jane than to anyone else, yet while he became the original American self-made man, she spent her life caring for her children. They left very different traces behind.

Using an amazing cache of little-studied material—including recently discovered documents, objects, and portraits—Jill Lepore brings Jane Franklin to life in a way that illuminates not only this remarkable woman but an entire world usually lost to history. Like her famous brother, Jane was a passionate reader, gifted writer, and shrewd political commentator. Unlike him, she was a mother of twelve.

Lepore's biography offers a strikingly original perspective on Benjamin Franklin while telling one of the great untold stories of American history: a wholly different account of the founding of the United States, seen through the eyes of a brilliant woman whose voice has been silent for centuries.
Refined_Short_Summary: Jane Franklin was as brilliant as her famous brother Benjamin—a passionate reader, gifted writer, and shrewd political commentator. The difference? She was a mother of twelve whose remarkable story has been lost to history until now.
Refined_Bio: Jill Lepore is the David Woods Kemper '41 Professor of American History at Harvard University and professor of law at Harvard Law School. She is also a staff writer at The New Yorker. Her many books include the international bestseller These Truths: A History of the United States & Book of Ages. She lives in Cambridge, Massachusetts.

Title: The Topeka School
Subtitle: A Novel
Summary: A gifted high school debater in 1990s Kansas wrestles with toxic masculinity, family tensions, and the politics of language. A sharp, formally inventive novel of adolescence and American discontent.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Adam Gordon is a senior at Topeka High School, class of '97. His mother, Jane, is a famous feminist author; his father, Jonathan, is an expert at getting "lost boys" to open up. They both work at a psychiatric clinic that has attracted staff and patients from around the world.

Adam is a renowned debater, expected to win a national championship before he heads to college. He's one of the cool kids, ready to fight or freestyle about fighting if it keeps his peers from thinking of him as weak. Adam is also one of the seniors who bring the loner Darren Eberheart—who is, unbeknownst to Adam, his father's patient—into the social scene, to disastrous effect.

Deftly shifting perspectives and time periods, The Topeka School is the story of a family navigating its struggles and strengths: Jane's reckoning with the legacy of an abusive father, Jonathan's marital transgressions, the challenge of raising a good son in a culture of toxic masculinity. It's also a riveting prehistory of our present moment—the collapse of public speech, the trolls and tyrants of the New Right, and the ongoing crisis of identity among white men.
Refined_Short_Summary: Family drama meets cultural prophecy in this brilliant novel about a teenage debater in 1990s Kansas. Lerner masterfully connects personal trauma to our current political nightmare. If you loved Normal People's psychological insight, this deserves a spot on your shelf.
Refined_Bio: Ben Lerner is the author of eight previous books of poetry and prose, as well as several collaborations with visual artists. The recipient of fellowships from the Fulbright, Guggenheim, and MacArthur Foundations, Lerner has been a finalist for the National Book Award for Poetry and the Pulitzer Prize for Fiction, among many other honors. He is a Distinguished Professor of English at Brooklyn College.
Formatted_Quotes:
"[An] essayistic and engrossing novel . . . Few writers are so deeply engaged as Lerner in how our interior selves are shaped by memory and consequence . . . Increasingly powerful and heartbreaking as the story moves on. Autofiction at its smartest and most effective: self-interested, self-interrogating, but never self-involved."

—Kirkus

"The Topeka School is [Lerner's] most discerning, ambitious, innovative, and timely novel to date. It's a complete pleasure to read Lerner experimenting with other minds and times, to watch his already profound talent blooming into new subjects, landscapes, and capacities. This book is a prehistory of a deeply disturbing national moment, but it's written with the kind of intelligence, insight, and searching that makes one feel well-accompanied and, in the final hour, deeply inspired."

—Maggie Nelson, author of The Argonauts

"Ben Lerner has redefined what it means for a writer to inhabit an American present by showing how a family reckons with its past. Here the personal and political are masterfully interwoven. The Topeka School is brave, furious, and, finally, a work of love."

—Ocean Vuong, author of On Earth We're Briefly Gorgeous

Title: The Rules Do Not Apply
Subtitle: A Memoir
Summary: In this candid memoir, Levy reflects on love, loss, and resilience, offering sharp observations on freedom and self-invention.
Refined_Long_Summary:
All her life, Ariel Levy was told she was too fervent, too forceful, too much. As a young woman, she decided becoming a writer would perfectly channel her strength and desire. She would be a professional explorer—"the kind of woman who is free to do whatever she chooses."

Levy moved to Manhattan to pursue her dream and spent years traveling the world, writing stories about unconventional heroines and following their fearless examples in her own life. But when she experiences unthinkable heartbreak, Levy is forced to surrender her illusion of control.

In telling her story, Levy captures a portrait of our time—the shifting forces in American culture, what has changed and what has remained, and how to begin again when everything falls apart.
Refined_Short_Summary: When heartbreak shatters her carefully constructed life, a fearless journalist must rebuild from scratch. Levy's raw honesty about ambition and loss will resonate with anyone who's ever felt like they were too much for the world.
Refined_Bio: Ariel Levy joined The New Yorker as a staff writer in 2008 and received the National Magazine Award for Essays and Criticism in 2014 for her piece "Thanksgiving in Mongolia." She is the author of Female Chauvinist Pigs and was a contributing editor at New York for twelve years.
Formatted_Quotes:
"Unflinching and intimate, wrenching and revelatory, Ariel Levy's powerful memoir about love, loss, and finding one's way shimmers with truth and heart on every page."

—Cheryl Strayed

"Every deep feeling a human is capable of will be shaken loose by this profound book. Ariel Levy has taken grief and made art out of it."

—David Sedaris

"Levy has the rare gift of seeing herself with fierce, unforgiving clarity. And she deploys prose to match, raw and agile. She plumbs the commotion deep within and takes the measure of her have-it-all generation."

—The Atlantic

Title: The Big Short
Subtitle: Inside the Doomsday Machine
Summary: Lewis tells the gripping story of the 2008 financial crisis through the outsiders who foresaw and profited from the housing market collapse.
Refined_Long_Summary:
When the U.S. stock market crash became public knowledge in fall 2008, it was already old news. The real crash had taken place over the previous year in bizarre feeder markets where the sun doesn't shine and the SEC doesn't dare to tread: bond and real estate derivative markets where geeks invented impenetrable securities to profit from the misery of Americans who couldn't pay their debts.

Michael Lewis turns the inquiry on its head to create a fresh, character-driven narrative brimming with indignation and dark humor. Instead of asking what went wrong, he asks: Who got it right? Who saw the real estate market for the black hole it would become and made billions from that perception? What qualities of character made these few persist when peers dismissed them as delusional?

Out of this handful of unlikely heroes, Lewis fashions a story as compelling as any of his earlier bestsellers, proving yet again that he is the finest and funniest chronicler of our times.
Refined_Short_Summary: Follow the unlikely heroes who saw the 2008 financial crisis coming and bet against the system. Lewis delivers his trademark wit and character-driven storytelling to explain how a few outsiders got rich while Wall Street burned.
Refined_Bio: Michael Lewis is the bestselling author of Liar's Poker, Moneyball, The Blind Side, The Big Short, The Fifth Risk, and Going Infinite. He lives in Berkeley, California, with his family.
Formatted_Quotes:
"No one writes with more narrative panache about money and finance than Mr. Lewis....[he] does a nimble job of using his subjects' stories to explicate the greed, idiocies and hypocrisies of a system notably lacking in grown-up supervision....Writing in faintly Tom Wolfe-ian prose, Mr. Lewis does a colorful job of introducing the lay reader to the Darwinian world of the bond market."

—Michiko Kakutani, The New York Times

"One of the best business books of the past two decades."

—Malcolm Gladwell, The New York Times

"Superb: Michael Lewis doing what he does best, illuminating the idiocy, madness and greed of modern finance. . . . Lewis achieves what I previously imagined impossible: He makes subprime sexy all over again."

—Andrew Leonard, Salon.com
Short_Summary: The #1 New York Times bestseller: a brilliant account—character-rich and darkly humorous—of how the U.S. economy was driven over the cliff.
Long_Summary:
When the crash of the U. S. stock market became public knowledge in the fall of 2008, it was already old news. The real crash, the silent crash, had taken place over the previous year, in bizarre feeder markets where the sun doesn’t shine, and the SEC doesn’t dare, or bother, to tread: the bond and real estate derivative markets where geeks invent impenetrable securities to profit from the misery of lower- and middle-class Americans who can’t pay their debts. The smart people who understood what was or might be happening were paralyzed by hope and fear; in any case, they weren’t talking.

The crucial question is this: Who understood the risk inherent in the assumption of ever-rising real estate prices, a risk compounded daily by the creation of those arcane, artificial securities loosely based on piles of doubtful mortgages? Michael Lewis turns the inquiry on its head to create a fresh, character-driven narrative brimming with indignation and dark humor, a fitting sequel to his #1 best-selling Liar’s Poker. Who got it right? he asks. Who saw the real estate market for the black hole it would become, and eventually made billions of dollars from that perception? And what qualities of character made those few persist when their peers and colleagues dismissed them as Chicken Littles? Out of this handful of unlikely—really unlikely—heroes, Lewis fashions a story as compelling and unusual as any of his earlier bestsellers, proving yet again that he is the finest and funniest chronicler of our times.

Title: Things in Nature Merely Grow
Refined_Long_Summary:
"There is no good way to say this," Yiyun Li writes at the beginning of this devastating memoir. "My husband and I had two children and lost them both: Vincent in 2017, at sixteen, James in 2024, at nineteen. Both chose suicide, and both died not far from home."

Because words fall short, it takes only an instant for death to become fact—"a single point in a timeline." Living now on this single point, Li turns to thinking, reasoning, and searching for words that might hold a place for James. She does what she can: "doing the things that work," including not just writing but gardening, reading Camus and Wittgenstein, learning piano, and living thinkingly alongside death.

This is a book for James, but it is not about grieving or mourning. As Li writes, "The verb that does not die is to be. Vincent was and is and will always be Vincent. James was and is and will always be James... There is no now and then, now and later, only, now and now and now and now." Things in Nature Merely Grow is a testament to Li's indomitable spirit.
Refined_Short_Summary: Yiyun Li confronts unimaginable loss with radical acceptance and fierce love in this profound meditation on living alongside death. Her luminous prose transforms tragedy into testament, creating something both heartbreaking and unexpectedly life-affirming.
Refined_Bio: Yiyun Li is the author of several works of fiction—Wednesday's Child; The Book of Goose; Must I Go; Where Reasons End; Kinder Than Solitude; Gold Boy, Emerald Girl; The Vagrants; and A Thousand Years of Good Prayers—and the memoir Dear Friend, from My Life I Write to You in Your Life. She is the recipient of many awards, including a PEN/Faulkner Award, a PEN/Malamud Award, a PEN/Hemingway Award, a PEN/Jean Stein Book Award, a MacArthur Fellowship, and a Windham-Campbell Prize, and was a finalist for the Pulitzer Prize. She teaches at Princeton University.

"A memoir unlike others, strange and profound and fiercely determined not to look away."

—Publishers Weekly

"To be in Li's head is a rare privilege—she is a writer of elegance and clarity and is a deeply interesting thinker. And the book, surprisingly, is not sad. It is moving and even funny in places as she writes about her wonderful friends, a few awful strangers, but most of all her extraordinary sons. You may find yourself transformed after reading it. I did."

—NPR

“There is no good way to say this,” Yiyun Li writes at the beginning of this book.

“There is no good way to state these facts, which must be acknowledged. My husband and I had two children and lost them both: Vincent in 2017, at sixteen, James in 2024, at nineteen. Both chose suicide, and both died not far from home.”

There is no good way to say this—because words fall short. It takes only an instant for death to become fact, “a single point in a timeline.” Living now on this single point, Li turns to thinking and reasoning and searching for words that might hold a place for James. Li does what she can: “doing the things that work,” including not just writing but gardening, reading Camus and Wittgenstein, learning the piano, and living thinkingly alongside death.

This is a book for James, but it is not a book about grieving or mourning. As Li writes, “The verb that does not die is to be. Vincent was and is and will always be Vincent. James was and is and will always be James. We were and are and will always be their parents. There is no now and then, now and later, only, now and now and now and now.” Things in Nature Merely Grow is a testament to Li’s indomitable spirit.

Title: Wednesday's Child
Subtitle: Stories
Summary: A collection of stories exploring grief, resilience, and the complex bonds between parents and children. With quiet intensity and emotional depth, Li illuminates the human capacity for endurance and love.
Refined_Long_Summary:
A grieving mother makes a spreadsheet of everyone she's lost. A professor develops a troubled intimacy with her hairdresser. Every year, a restless woman receives an email from a strange man twice her age and several states away.

In Yiyun Li's stories, people strive for ordinary existence until doing so becomes unsustainable—until the surface cracks and the grand mysterious forces of death, violence, and estrangement come to light. Even everyday life is laden with meaning, studded with indelible details: a filched jar of honey, a mound of wounded ants, a photograph kept hidden for years until it must be seen.

Li is a truly original writer, an alchemist of opposites: tender yet unsentimental, metaphysical yet blunt, funny and horrifying. Written over a decade and gathering pieces from The New Yorker and Zoetrope, these stories articulate the cost—both material and emotional—of living through exile, assimilation, loss, and love with her trademark unnerving beauty and wisdom.
Refined_Short_Summary: Devastating stories about grief, connection, and survival from the MacArthur Fellow behind The Book of Goose. If you loved Ocean Vuong's tender brutality or the quiet intensity of Normal People, these perfectly crafted tales will stay with you.
Refined_Bio: Yiyun Li is the author of Wednesday's Child; The Book of Goose; Must I Go; Where Reasons End; Kinder Than Solitude; Gold Boy, Emerald Girl; The Vagrants; A Thousand Years of Good Prayers; and the memoir Dear Friend, from My Life I Write to You in Your Life. She's received a PEN/Faulkner Award, PEN/Malamud Award, PEN/Hemingway Award, PEN/Jean Stein Book Award, MacArthur Fellowship, and Windham-Campbell Prize, and was a Pulitzer Prize finalist. She teaches at Princeton University.

"Li is a master at understanding human emotion, but her tenderness never gives way to sentimentality . . . Gorgeous prose and painstaking attention to detail . . . makes these stories so beautiful, so accomplished. This is a perfect collection by a writer at the top of her game, and a heart-wrenching look at how loss changes not only the bereaved, but their entire existence."

—Michael Schaub, NPR

"Splendid and elegantly observed . . . Distinguished by their fully realized characters, nuanced narration, and striking portraits of everyday struggles, these stories find Li at the top of her game."

And even everyday life is laden with meaning, studded with indelible details: a filched jar of honey, a mound of wounded ants, a photograph kept hidden for many years, until it must be seen.

Beloved for her novels and memoirs, she returns here to her earliest form, gathering pieces that have appeared in The New Yorker, Zoetrope, and elsewhere. Taken together, the stories in Wednesday's Child, written over the span of a decade, articulate the cost, both material and emotional, of living—exile, assimilation, loss, love—with her trademark unnerving beauty and wisdom.

Title: The Book of Goose
Subtitle: A Novel
Summary: In postwar rural France, two girls craft a story that catapults one to literary fame while the other recedes into obscurity. A haunting novel of friendship, ambition, and storytelling.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Fabienne is dead. Her childhood best friend, Agnès, receives the news in America, far from the French countryside where the two girls were raised—the place that Fabienne helped Agnès escape ten years ago. Now Agnès is free to tell her story.

As children in a war-ravaged backwater town, they built a private world, invisible to everyone but themselves—until Fabienne hatched the plan that would change everything, launching Agnès on an epic trajectory through fame, fortune, and terrible loss.

A magnificent, beguiling tale winding from the postwar rural provinces to Paris, from an English boarding school to the quiet Pennsylvania home where a woman can live without her past, The Book of Goose explores disturbing intimacy and obsession, exploitation and strength of will, by the celebrated author Yiyun Li.
Refined_Short_Summary: When childhood best friend Fabienne dies, Agnès finally tells the story of their twisted bond and the plan that changed everything. Dark, gorgeous fiction exploring toxic friendship and its lasting damage.
Refined_Bio: Yiyun Li is the author of several works of fiction—Wednesday's Child; The Book of Goose; Must I Go; Where Reasons End; Kinder Than Solitude; Gold Boy, Emerald Girl; The Vagrants; and A Thousand Years of Good Prayers—and the memoir Dear Friend, from My Life I Write to You in Your Life. She is the recipient of many awards, including a PEN/Faulkner Award, a MacArthur Fellowship, and a Windham-Campbell Prize, and was a Pulitzer Prize finalist. She teaches at Princeton University.
Formatted_Quotes:
"A compulsively readable meditation on how our closest friendships harbor both love and hate—and how we can fail each other over and over again . . . Li's crystalline, insightful prose adds incredible depth to the drama, yet the dynamic between the girls remains the complex heart of The Book of Goose."

—Sarah Rose Etter, BOMB

"Li, of course, has never been the kind of writer who tells you what you want to hear, and this is surely part of why she has become, while still in her 40s, one of our finest living authors: Her elegant metaphysics never elide the blood and maggots."

Title: Deep House
Subtitle: The Gayest Love Story Ever Told
Refined_Long_Summary:
It's 1996, and Jeremy Atherton Lin has met the boy of his dreams — a mumbling, starry-eyed Brit — just as Congress prepares the Defense of Marriage Act, denying same-sex couples federal rights including immigration. The pair steals away to remote forests and vast deserts, London fashion shows and Berlin sex clubs, dinner parties, back alleys, East Village hotel rooms, and San Francisco dives. Finding no other way to stay together, they shack up illicitly among unlikely allies in a "city of refuge."

With Atherton Lin's inimitable blend of tenderness and wicked humor, Deep House moves through the couple's string of rented apartments while unlocking doors to a lineage of gay men who have come before — smuggling foreign partners through national checkpoints or going public to stand up for the right to get down in the privacy of their own homes. They include hapless criminals, sexpot bartenders, friars, pirates, government workers who subverted the system, activists who went all the way to the Supreme Court, and the celebrated artist Felix Gonzalez-Torres.

Deep House juxtaposes whispered disclosures of undocumented domesticity with courtroom drama and political stunts to explore myriad forms of intimacy while questioning the mechanisms that legitimize love.
Refined_Short_Summary: When immigration laws threaten to tear apart a queer couple in 1996, they create an underground home while marriage equality battles rage. A genre-defying blend of memoir, legal history, and love story that's both politically urgent and deeply intimate.
Refined_Bio: Jeremy Atherton Lin is the author of Gay Bar, a New York Times Top Book of 2021 and winner of the National Book Critics Circle Award. His essays appear in the Paris Review, the Times Literary Supplement and the Yale Review, for which he was a National Magazine Award finalist. He has reviewed fiction for the Guardian and the Washington Post, and his sound programs have been broadcast on NTS Radio. He is based in Los Angeles and East Sussex, England.
Formatted_Quotes:
"Deep House goes from the pensoroso of the best history of marriage equality we have to the allegro of a very hot gay love story told in the funniest, most tender way."

—Edmund White

"A strong cocktail of memoir, legal history and sociology...Atherton Lin beautifully captures the Bay Area at the turn of the millennium: the creeping gentrification, the tech bros, the video shops, the aging hippies. He's also not shy in his descriptions of sex of many kinds and configurations, with all the attendant sensations. (At times you can almost smell it.)"

—The Washington Post

"Deep House is that rare and beautiful book—equally illuminating and pleasurable. I loved its luminous transcription of queer life, its incisive and intimate legal history of gay marriage in the U.S., its transcendently sexy and propulsive love story, and its portrait of social change that promises not the fantasy of permanent liberty, but that more ephemeral reward: joy. It is exactly the book we need right now."

—Melissa Febos, author of The Dry Season and Girlhood
Short_Summary: From the National Book Critics Circle Award-winning author of Gay Bar comes a rule-breaking, sweat-soaked, genre-busting story of outlaw love.
Long_Summary:
It’s 1996, and Jeremy Atherton Lin has met the boy of his dreams — a mumbling, starry-eyed Brit — just as, amid a media frenzy, US Congress prepares the Defense of Marriage Act, denying same-sex couples federal rights including immigration. The pair steals away to remote forests and vast deserts, London fashion shows and Berlin sex clubs, dinner parties, back alleys, East Village hotel rooms, and San Francisco dives. Finding no other way to stay together, they shack up illicitly among unlikely allies in a “city of refuge.”

With Atherton Lin’s inimitable blend of tenderness and wicked humor, Deep House moves through the couple’s string of rented apartments while unlocking doors to a lineage of gay men who have come before — smuggling a foreign partner through national checkpoints or going public to stand up for the right to get down in the privacy of their own homes. They include hapless criminals, sexpot bartenders, friars, pirates, government workers who subverted the system, activists who went all the way to the Supreme Court, and the celebrated artist Felix Gonzalez-Torres.

Following Gay Bar — called “a rich tapestry” by Vanity Fair and “an absolute tour de force” by Maggie Nelson — Deep House juxtaposes whispered disclosures of undocumented domesticity with courtroom drama and political stunts to explore myriad forms of intimacy while questioning the mechanisms that legitimize love. Deep House is at once a historical kaleidoscope and the innermost tale of two boyfriends who made a home in the shadows of a turbulent civil rights battle.

Title: Here After
Subtitle: A Memoir
Summary: Lin’s debut memoir is a searing portrait of grief and love after the sudden loss of her fiancé, written with clarity and emotional depth.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Amy Lin never expected to find a love like the one she shares with her husband, Kurtis, a gifted young architect who pulls her toward joy, adventure, and greater self-acceptance. On a sweltering August morning, only a few months shy of the newlyweds' move to Vancouver, thirty-two-year-old Kurtis heads out to run a half-marathon with Amy's family. It is the last time she sees her husband alive.

What follows is a rich and unflinchingly honest account of her life with Kurtis and the vortex created by his death. Here After is an intimate story of deep love followed by dizzying loss—a memoir so finely etched that its power will remain with you long after the final page.
Refined_Short_Summary: When Amy Lin's architect husband dies suddenly during a half-marathon, she must navigate the devastating aftermath. This raw, poetic memoir captures both profound love and crushing grief with unflinching honesty.
Refined_Bio: Amy Lin is a writer and educator living in Calgary, Canada. Her work has been published in Ploughshares and she has received residencies from Yaddo and Casa Comala. Here After is her first book.
Formatted_Quotes:
"It has been years since I have been so rocked, so moved, by any book, as I have been by Here After by the earthquaking new talent Amy Lin. Lin invites us into this place of exquisite pain and beauty; what a great gift she has given us."

—Lauren Groff, author of Fates and Furies

"How gorgeously Here After tackles the twin specters of grief and survival; a steely, symphonic memoir of unexpected loss—and what (necessarily, unbearably) comes next."

—Carmen Machado, author of In the Dream House

"Here After is a searing account of a young couple's lost future and a writer's descent into the soul-ravaging, shape-shifting wilderness of grief. Amy Lin writes with devastating clarity about the wounds that do not heal, the stories that remain forever fractured, and love's enduring force. This is a profound and essential memoir."

—Laura van den Berg, author of The Third Hotel

Title: The Book of Love
Subtitle: A Novel
Summary: When three teenagers are returned from the dead to a small New England town, they must unravel mysteries of magic, love, and their own unfinished stories. A genre-bending, whimsical, and darkly enchanting novel.
Refined_Long_Summary:
The Book of Love showcases Kelly Link at the height of her powers, channeling potent magic and exploring all varieties of love—from friendship to romance to family bonds—with her trademark compassion, wit, and literary brilliance.

Late one night, Laura, Daniel, and Mo find themselves beneath the fluorescent lights of a high school classroom, almost a year after disappearing from their hometown of Lovesend, Massachusetts, having long been presumed dead. Which, in fact, they are.

With them is their previously unremarkable high school music teacher, who seems to know something about their disappearance—and what has brought them back. Desperate to reclaim their lives, the three agree to his bargain: complete a series of magical tasks, and they may return to their families and friends. But they can tell no one where they've been.

Their resurrection attracts other supernatural figures with their own agendas. As the teens grapple with the pieces of their former lives, and Laura's sister Susannah struggles to reconcile memory with fear, mysterious forces begin arriving in Lovesend. The community becomes engulfed in danger and chaos, making it imperative that the teens solve the mystery of their deaths to avert looming disaster.

Welcome to Kelly Link's incomparable Lovesend, where you'll encounter love and loss, laughter and dread, magic and karaoke, and some really good pizza.
Refined_Short_Summary: Three dead teenagers return to their small Massachusetts town with a supernatural bargain to complete. If you loved the eerie small-town magic of Midnight Girls, this haunting debut novel will captivate you completely.
Refined_Bio: Kelly Link is the author of White Cat, Black Dog; Get in Trouble, a Pulitzer Prize finalist; Magic for Beginners; Stranger Things Happen; and Pretty Monsters. Her stories appear in The Best American Short Stories and Prize Stories: The O. Henry Awards. A MacArthur fellow and NEA grant recipient, she co-founded Small Beer Press, co-edits Lady Churchill's Rosebud Wristlet, and co-owns Book Moon bookstore in Easthampton, Massachusetts.
Formatted_Quotes:
"A luxurious, bewitching novel of exceptional beauty and power."

—Carmen Maria Machado, author of In the Dream House

"A dizzying dream ride you will never forget."

—Leigh Bardugo, author of Ninth House

"By turns playful and harrowing, surreal and sagacious, replete with gods and other monsters, The Book of Love is an astonishing, gorgeous novel written with Link's unique wit, warmth and ability to get under your skin."

—Holly Black, author of Book of Night
Short_Summary: In the acclaimed first novel from short story virtuoso and Pulitzer Prize finalist Kelly Link, three teenagers become pawns in a supernatural power struggle.
Long_Summary:
The Book of Love showcases Kelly Link at the height of her powers, channeling potent magic and attuned to all varieties of love—from friendship to romance to abiding family ties—with her trademark compassion, wit, and literary derring-do. Readers will find joy (and a little terror) and an affirmation that love goes on, even when we cannot.

Late one night, Laura, Daniel, and Mo find themselves beneath the fluorescent lights of a high school classroom, almost a year after disappearing from their hometown, the small seaside community of Lovesend, Massachusetts, having long been presumed dead. Which, in fact, they are.

With them in the room is their previously unremarkable high school music teacher, who seems to know something about their disappearance—and what has brought them back again. Desperate to reclaim their lives, the three agree to the terms of the bargain their music teacher proposes. They will be given a series of magical tasks; while they undertake them, they may return to their families and friends, but they can tell no one where they’ve been. In the end, there will be winners and there will be losers.

But their resurrection has attracted the notice of other supernatural figures, all with their own agendas. As Laura, Daniel, and Mo grapple with the pieces of the lives they left behind, and Laura’s sister, Susannah, attempts to reconcile what she remembers with what she fears, these mysterious others begin to arrive, engulfing their community in danger and chaos, and it becomes imperative that the teens solve the mystery of their deaths to avert a looming disaster.

Welcome to Kelly Link’s incomparable Lovesend, where you’ll encounter love and loss, laughter and dread, magic and karaoke, and some really good pizza.
Copy_Bio: Kelly Link is the author of White Cat, Black Dog; Get in Trouble, a finalist for the Pulitzer Prize in fiction; Magic for Beginners; Stranger Things Happen; and Pretty Monsters. Her short stories have been published in The Best American Short Stories and Prize Stories: The O. Henry Awards. She is a MacArthur “Genius” fellow and has received a grant from the National Endowment for the Arts. She is the co-founder of Small Beer Press and co-edits the occasional zine Lady Churchill’s Rosebud Wristlet. She is also the co-owner of Book Moon, an independent bookstore in Easthampton, Massachusetts.

“A dizzying dream ride you will never forget.”—Leigh Bardugo, author of Ninth House

“By turns playful and harrowing, surreal and sagacious, replete with gods and other monsters, The Book of Love is an astonishing, gorgeous novel written with Link’s unique wit, warmth and ability to get under your skin.”—Holly Black, author of Book of Night

Title: The War for Gloria
Subtitle: A novel
Summary: A boy comes of age caring for his mother, who is dying of ALS, while contending with an absent father. A raw, urgent, and tender novel of love, masculinity, and resilience.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Corey Goltz grows up in working-class Boston as the only child of Gloria, whose early ambitions were derailed but who has always given her son everything she can. Restless and dreaming of adventure, Corey's world crashes down when he's fifteen and Gloria is diagnosed with ALS.

Too late, his estranged father Leonard—a man of great charisma but dubious moral character—reenters their lives. Determined to be his mother's hero at any cost, Corey begins shouldering responsibility for her expensive medical care, pushing himself to physical and emotional limits as her disease cruelly progresses.

As Leonard's influence over Corey grows, the teenager must dismantle the myth of his father's genius and confront the darkness beneath it. Gritty and profoundly stirring, this is the story of a young man straddling childhood and adulthood, whose yearning to protect his mother requires him to risk destroying his father.
Refined_Short_Summary: When fifteen-year-old Corey's mother is diagnosed with ALS, his charismatic but dangerous father returns to their lives. A devastating portrait of family loyalty and toxic masculinity that will gut you like A Little Life.
Refined_Bio: Atticus Lish is the author of The War for Gloria and Preparation for the Next Life, which won the 2015 PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction and the 2016 Grand Prix de Littérature Américaine. He lives in California.
Formatted_Quotes:
"Solemn, punishing, kinetic, in easy contact with dark areas of the psyche, and yet heartbreaking in its portrait of a mother and son facing her mortal illness . . . Lish's novel is powerful, intelligent, brooding and most of all convincing; it earns its emotions . . . It more than pays off on the promise of his first novel, Preparation for the Next Life, which won the 2015 PEN/Faulkner award . . . You never sense [Lish] is merely writing "quality fiction"; he seems to draw instead from a deep well of experience, especially when it comes to the tastes and textures of life on the economic margins . . . The War for Gloria works because the details are so casually drilled home . . . Gloria is this novel's great, glowing presence. Lish is exacting in his portraiture."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

"The War For Gloria is an ambitious book with a lot to say about family loyalty and love . . . Lish is a sensational literary craftsman, using the words in his toolbelt to construct narrative that is at once coolly dispassionate and red hot with emotion . . . I will be thinking about The War For Gloria for a long time."

—Martha Anne Toll, NPR

"Unflinching and heartbreaking . . . Lish imbues the male characters' varied pitches of toxic masculinity with great sadness, smoothing the edges off their macho posturing, and he writes with devastating empathy of Gloria's highs and lows. This is a tremendous achievement."

—Publishers Weekly
Short_Summary: From the author of the PEN/Faulkner Award–winning debut novel Preparation for the Next Life, a gripping, tender, unforgettable story about fathers and sons, regret and redemption
Long_Summary:
Corey Goltz grows up in the working-class outskirts of Boston as the only child of Gloria, whose ambitions were derailed early but who has always given her son everything she can. Corey, restless, dreams of leaving home for a great adventure.
 
Instead, when he is fifteen, the world comes crashing down upon him, when Gloria is diagnosed with ALS and, too late, his estranged father, Leonard—a man of great charisma but dubious moral character—reenters the picture. Determined to be his mother’s hero at any cost, Corey begins shouldering responsibility for her expensive medical care, pushing himself to his physical and emotional limits as her disease cruelly progresses. And as Leonard’s influence over Corey grows, Corey must dismantle the myth of his father’s genius and confront the evil that lurks beneath it.
 
Gritty, visceral, and profoundly stirring, The War for Gloria tells the story of a young man, straddling childhood and adulthood, whose yearning to protect his mother requires him to risk destroying his father. An indelible work from a strikingly original voice in American fiction.

Title_Subtitle: No One Is Talking About This
Title: No One Is Talking About This
Subtitle: A Novel
Summary: A social media celebrity’s hyper-online life collides with a family crisis, forcing her to reckon with love and mortality. Surreal, hilarious, and deeply moving.
Refined_Long_Summary:
A woman catapulted to internet fame through her viral social media posts embarks on a world tour to meet her adoring fans. But navigating what she calls "the portal" becomes increasingly disorienting as she grapples with the unsettling feeling that a vast chorus of online voices is dictating her very thoughts.

As existential threats mount—climate change, economic instability, the rise of an unnamed dictator, an epidemic of loneliness—she posts deeper into the portal's void. Images, details, and references accumulate into a landscape that is post-sense, post-irony, post-everything. "Are we in hell?" the people of the portal ask themselves. "Are we all just going to keep doing this until we die?"

Then two urgent texts from her mother shatter the digital noise: "Something has gone wrong," and "How soon can you get here?" As real life collides with the portal's absurd antics, she confronts a world containing both overwhelming proof of goodness, empathy, and justice, and a deluge of evidence to the contrary.

Fragmentary and omniscient, incisive and sincere, this novel serves as both a love letter to the endless scroll and a profound meditation on love, language, and human connection.
Refined_Short_Summary: When a viral social media star's hyper-online existence crashes into a devastating family emergency, she must navigate between digital absurdity and profound human connection. Perfect for fans of Sally Rooney's exploration of modern communication and isolation.
Refined_Bio: Patricia Lockwood is the bestselling author of the Booker Prize finalist and Dylan Thomas Prize-winning novel No One Is Talking About This, named one of the 10 Best Books of 2021 by The New York Times Book Review and one of The Atlantic's Great American Novels of the past 100 years. Her other books include the memoir Priestdaddy, named one of the 10 Best Books of 2017 by The New York Times Book Review, and two poetry collections. She's a contributing editor at the London Review of Books.
Formatted_Quotes:
"[Lockwood is] a master of startling concision when highlighting the absurdities we've grown too lazy to notice . . . It's a vertiginous experience, gorgeously rendered but utterly devastating. I rattled around the house for days afterwards, shattered but grateful for the reminder that the ephemeral world we've constructed online is a shadow compared to the pain and affection we're blessed to experience in real life."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

"I really admire and love this book. Patricia Lockwood is a completely singular talent and this is her best, funniest, weirdest, most affecting work yet."

—Sally Rooney, author of Normal People and Conversations with Friends

"Reading Patricia Lockwood feels like looking through a kaleidoscope built by a mischievous sorcerer—the world is suddenly rearranged in fragments that are cosmic, wondrous, humiliating, and profane. No One Is Talking About This is a furiously original novel, alive and unstable; the book builds to a reminder of how devastation and connection produce each other, endlessly and surprisingly, both on the internet and in human places that our shared digital consciousness can never reach."

—Jia Tolentino, author of Trick Mirror
Short_Summary: A social media celebrity’s hyper-online life collides with a family crisis, forcing her to reckon with love and mortality. Surreal, hilarious, and deeply moving.
Long_Summary:
As this urgent, genre-defying book opens, a woman who has recently been elevated to prominence for her social media posts travels around the world to meet her adoring fans. She is overwhelmed by navigating the new language and etiquette of what she terms "the portal," where she grapples with an unshakable conviction that a vast chorus of voices is now dictating her thoughts. When existential threats--from climate change and economic precariousness to the rise of an unnamed dictator and an epidemic of loneliness--begin to loom, she posts her way deeper into the portal's void. An avalanche of images, details, and references accumulate to form a landscape that is post-sense, post-irony, post-everything. "Are we in hell?" the people of the portal ask themselves. "Are we all just going to keep doing this until we die?"

Suddenly, two texts from her mother pierce the fray: "Something has gone wrong," and "How soon can you get here?" As real life and its stakes collide with the increasingly absurd antics of the portal, the woman confronts a world that seems to contain both an abundance of proof that there is goodness, empathy, and justice in the universe, and a deluge of evidence to the contrary.

Fragmentary and omniscient, incisive and sincere, No One Is Talking About This is at once a love letter to the endless scroll and a profound, modern meditation on love, language, and human connection from a singular voice in American literature.

Her writing has appeared in The New York Times, The New Yorker, The New Republic, and the London Review of Books, where she is a contributing editor.

Title: Priestdaddy
Subtitle: A Memoir
Summary: With biting humor and lyricism, Lockwood recounts her eccentric childhood with a Catholic priest father in this acclaimed memoir.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Father Greg Lockwood is unlike any Catholic priest you've ever met—a man who lounges in boxer shorts, loves action movies, and whose constant guitar jamming reverberates "like a whole band dying in a plane crash in 1972." His daughter is an irreverent poet who long ago left the Church behind.

When an unexpected crisis forces her and her husband to move back into her parents' rectory, their two worlds collide spectacularly. Lockwood interweaves emblematic moments from her childhood and adolescence—from an ill-fated family hunting trip and an abortion clinic sit-in where her father was arrested to her involvement in a cultlike Catholic youth group—with scenes from the eight-month adventure she and her husband had living in her parents' household after a decade on their own.

Lockwood details her education of a seminarian also living at the rectory, tries to explain Catholicism to her mystified husband, and encounters mysterious substances on hotel beds with her mother. Pivoting from the raunchy to the sublime, from comic to deeply serious, she explores issues of belief, belonging, and personhood in this unforgettable portrait of a deeply odd religious upbringing.
Refined_Short_Summary: What happens when an irreverent poet moves back into her guitar-obsessed Catholic priest father's rectory? Pure comedic gold with surprising depth. Perfect for anyone who loved Educated's family dysfunction with David Sedaris-level wit.

Her memoir Priestdaddy was named one of the 10 Best Books of 2017 by The New York Times Book Review. She's also published two poetry collections and is a contributing editor at the London Review of Books.

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

Father Greg Lockwood is unlike any Catholic priest you have ever met—a man who lounges in boxer shorts, loves action movies, and whose constant jamming on the guitar reverberates “like a whole band dying in a plane crash in 1972.” His daughter is an irreverent poet who long ago left the Church’s country. When an unexpected crisis leads her and her husband to move back into her parents’ rectory, their two worlds collide.

Title: Lost Children Archive
Subtitle: A novel
Summary: A family road trip across America becomes a meditation on migration, storytelling, and belonging. Inventive and urgent, Luiselli’s novel fuses documentary and fiction with lyrical power.
Refined_Long_Summary:
A mother and father set out with their two children, driving from New York to Arizona in the heat of summer. Their destination: Apacheria, the place the Apaches once called home. Why Apaches? asks the ten-year-old son. Because they were the last of something, answers his father.

In their car, they play games and sing along to music. But on the radio, there's news about an "immigration crisis": thousands of kids trying to cross the southwestern border into the United States, getting detained—or lost in the desert along the way.

As the family drives through Virginia to Tennessee, across Oklahoma and Texas, we sense they're on the brink of their own crisis. A fissure grows between the parents, one the children can almost feel beneath their feet. They're led, inexorably, to a grand, harrowing adventure—both in the desert landscape and within their own imaginations.

Told through compelling voices and blending texts, sounds, and images, Lost Children Archive is an astonishing feat of literary virtuosity. With urgency and empathy, it probes how we document our experiences and remember what matters most, taking us deep into one remarkable family's story while examining justice and equality today.
Refined_Short_Summary: When a family's road trip collides with America's immigration crisis, their journey becomes something extraordinary. Luiselli crafts a stunning blend of family drama and social commentary that feels both intimate and urgent.
Refined_Bio: Valeria Luiselli was born in Mexico City and grew up in South Korea, South Africa, and India. She's the author of Sidewalks, Faces in the Crowd, The Story of My Teeth, and Tell Me How It Ends: An Essay in Forty Questions. She's a MacArthur "Genius Grant" recipient, winner of two Los Angeles Times Book Prizes, an American Book Award, and the 2021 Dublin Literary Award. She's been nominated twice for the National Book Critics Circle Award and three times for the Kirkus Prize, and was a National Book Foundation "5 Under 35" honoree. Her work appears in The New York Times, Granta, and McSweeney's, and has been translated into over twenty languages.
Formatted_Quotes:
"Lost Children Archive is political . . . but Luiselli doesn't let this obscure her story about family: about a marriage coming apart and the bond between a sister and brother. She paints beautiful scenes of family and wonderful portraits of the children. It's a road trip: there are fights, there are meltdowns, there is singing, there are pit stops; most of all, there are stories. Luiselli's stories are special, the result of a towering intellect and a remarkable imagination."

—David Ebner, The Globe and Mail

"Impossibly smart, full of beauty, heart and insight. Everyone should read this book."

—Tommy Orange, author of There There

"The novel truly becomes novel again in Luiselli's hands—electric, elastic, alluring, new . . . She is a superb chronicler of children: the daughter and son feel piercingly real—perceptive, irreplaceable, wonderfully odd. The book [is] an archive of curiosities, yearnings, animated by the narrator's restless energy . . . It breaks out of the rhythms of the road trip, into a heart-stopping climax."

—Parul Sehgal, The New York Times
Short_Summary: A fiercely imaginative new novel about a family whose road trip across America collides with an immigration crisis at the southwestern border--an indelible journey told with breathtaking imagery, spare lyricism, and profound humanity.
Long_Summary:
A mother and father set out with their two children, a boy and a girl, driving from New York to Arizona in the heat of summer. Their destination: Apacheria, the place the Apaches once called home.

Why Apaches? asks the ten-year-old son. Because they were the last of something, answers his father.

In their car, they play games and sing along to music. But on the radio, there is news about an "immigration crisis": thousands of kids trying to cross the southwestern border into the United States, but getting detained--or lost in the desert along the way.

As the family drives--through Virginia to Tennessee, across Oklahoma and Texas--we sense they are on the brink of a crisis of their own. A fissure is growing between the parents, one the children can almost feel beneath their feet. They are led, inexorably, to a grand, harrowing adventure--both in the desert landscape and within the chambers of their own imaginations.

Told through several compelling voices, blending texts, sounds, and images, Lost Children Archive is an astonishing feat of literary virtuosity. It is a richly engaging story of how we document our experiences, and how we remember the things that matter to us the most. With urgency and empathy, it takes us deep into the lives of one remarkable family as it probes the nature of justice and equality today.

Title: The Story of My Teeth
Summary: A playful, experimental novel about an auctioneer who sells his teeth as art objects. Surreal, witty, and slyly profound.
Refined_Long_Summary:
I was born in Pachuca, the Beautiful Windy City, with four premature teeth and my body completely covered in a very fine coat of fuzz. But I'm grateful for that inauspicious start because ugliness, as my other uncle, Eurípides López Sánchez, was given to saying, is character forming.

Highway is a late-in-life world traveler, yarn spinner, collector, and legendary auctioneer. His most precious possessions are the teeth of the "notorious infamous" like Plato, Petrarch, and Virginia Woolf.

Written in collaboration with workers at a Jumex juice factory, Teeth is an elegant, witty romp through the industrial suburbs of Mexico City and Luiselli's own literary influences. This exhilarating novel explores how possessions acquire value through the stories we tell about them, blending philosophical musings with playful storytelling.
Refined_Short_Summary: Meet Highway, a legendary auctioneer obsessed with collecting teeth from famous figures like Virginia Woolf and Marilyn Monroe. This wildly inventive collaboration with juice factory workers creates pure literary magic.

She's the author of Sidewalks, Faces in the Crowd, The Story of My Teeth, and Tell Me How It Ends: An Essay in Forty Questions. She's a MacArthur "Genius Grant" recipient, winner of two Los Angeles Times Book Prizes, an American Book Award, and the 2021 Dublin Literary Award. Her work appears in The New York Times, Granta, and McSweeney's, and has been translated into over twenty languages.

"One of the most unforgettable images in any book this year is that of Gustavo "Highway" Sánchez Sánchez, the protagonist of Luiselli's delightfully unclassifiable novel, walking around the streets of Mexico City, smiling at people with the teeth of Marilyn Monroe installed in his mouth . . . surprising and charming . . . It's difficult not to follow wherever it takes you."

—Publishers Weekly

"This boggling and enchanting collaborative novel about a man who believes he has had Marilyn Monroe's literal teeth implanted into his mouth began as a bit of art gallery catalog copy sponsored by a large juice company."

"A lively, loopy experimental novel rich with musings on language, art, and, yes, teeth. . .the whole book is a kind of extended commentary on how possessions acquire value largely through the stories we tell about them. . . A clever philosophical novel that, as the author puts it, has "less to do with lying than surpassing the truth.""

—Kirkus

Title: Strangers in the Land
Subtitle: Exclusion, Belonging, and the Epic Story of the Chinese in America
Refined_Long_Summary:
Strangers in the Land tells the story of Chinese migrants who began arriving in America by the tens of thousands in the mid-nineteenth century, seeking fortune in what they called Gum Shan—Gold Mountain. Initially welcomed, these immigrants soon faced horrific racial terror as their numbers grew and economic downturns left white workers unemployed.

What followed was a series of increasingly harsh federal laws targeting Chinese laborers—marking the first time the United States banned people based solely on race. Michael Luo follows this community from these brutal early years to modern times, revealing how they persisted despite systematic persecution.

Luo chronicles early victims like Gene Tong, a Los Angeles herbalist lynched by a mob, and demagogues like Denis Kearney, who led the anti-Chinese movement. He also highlights pioneering activists like Wong Chin Foo, who fought for their community's rights. At the book's heart lies a shameful chapter: the violent expulsion of Chinese residents from towns across the American West, creating America's first undocumented immigrants—hounded, counted, and surveilled.

Only in 1965 did America's gates reopen to Asian immigrants like Luo's own parents. Drawing on extensive archives and written with a New Yorker writer's precision, this revelatory history examines how the "stranger" label persists even as over twenty-two million Asian Americans call this country home.
Refined_Short_Summary: This sweeping history traces Chinese Americans' 150-year struggle against exclusion and violence, from Gold Rush persecution to modern-day belonging. New Yorker writer Michael Luo uncovers how America's first race-based immigration bans shaped our democracy—and why this story matters now.
Refined_Bio: Michael Luo is an executive editor at The New Yorker, writing on politics, religion, and Asian American issues. He joined the magazine in 2016 after thirteen years at the New York Times as metro reporter, national correspondent, and investigative reporter and editor. He's received a George Polk Award and a Livingston Award for Young Journalists.
Formatted_Quotes:
"Strangers in the Land is what history should be--richly detailed, authoritative, and compelling. Luo pieces together the stunning and shocking story of a people's journey to this country, and in the process reveals an essential part of the story of America."

—David Grann, New York Times-bestselling author of The Wager and Killers of the Flower Moon

"An epic of both the best and worst aspects of the American experiment, Strangers in the Land is a work of history that is deeply researched, deftly written, and highly relevant today. In the vivid, often heartbreaking, and ultimately inspiring experiences of Chinese immigrants and Chinese Americans, Luo finds a deeper story about aspiration and belonging that is as universal as it is profound."

—Patrick Radden Keefe, New York Times-bestselling author of Say Nothing

"Tracing echoes of today's debates around immigration and exclusion to the past, Luo's vividly told, carefully researched, and deeply compassionate book is an essential contribution to the continually unfolding story of the Chinese in America."

—Hua Hsu, Pulitzer Prize-winning author of Stay True
Short_Summary: From New Yorker writer Michael Luo comes a masterful narrative history of the Chinese in America that traces the sorrowful theme of exclusion and documents their more than century-long struggle to belong.
Long_Summary:
Strangers in the Land tells the story of a people who, beginning in the middle of the nineteenth century, migrated by the tens of thousands to a distant land they called Gum Shan­––Gold Mountain. Americans initially welcomed these Chinese arrivals, but, as their numbers grew, horrific episodes of racial terror erupted on the Pacific coast. A prolonged economic downturn that idled legions of white workingmen helped create the conditions for what came next: a series of progressively more onerous federal laws aimed at excluding Chinese laborers from the country, marking the first time the United States barred a people based on their race. In a captivating debut, Michael Luo follows the Chinese from these early years to modern times, as they persisted in the face of bigotry and persecution, revealing anew the complications of our multiracial democracy.

    Luo writes of early victims of anti-Asian violence, like Gene Tong, a Los Angeles herbalist who was dragged from his apartment and hanged by a mob during one of the worst mass lynchings in the country’s history; of demagogues like Denis Kearney, a sandlot orator who became the face of the anti-Chinese movement in the late-1870s; of the pioneering activist Wong Chin Foo and other leaders of the Chinese community, who pressed their new homeland to live up to its stated ideals.  At the book’s heart is a shameful chapter of American history: the brutal driving out of Chinese residents from towns across the American West. The Chinese became the country’s first undocumented immigrants: hounded, counted, suspected, surveilled.

    In 1889, while upholding Chinese exclusion, Supreme Court Justice Stephen J. Field characterized them as “strangers in the land.” Only in 1965 did America’s gates swing open to people like Luo’s parents, immigrants from Taiwan. Today there are more than twenty-two million people of Asian descent in the United States and yet the “stranger” label, Luo writes, remains. Drawing on archives from across the country and written with a New Yorker writer’s style and sweep, Strangers in the Land is revelatory and unforgettable, an essential American story.

Before that, he spent thirteen years at the New York Times, as a metro reporter, national correspondent, and investigative reporter and editor. He is a recipient of a George Polk Award and a Livingston Award for Young Journalists.

Title: H Is for Hawk
Summary: Macdonald’s bestselling memoir follows her training of a goshawk after her father’s death, blending nature writing with personal grief and reflection.
Refined_Long_Summary:
When Helen Macdonald's father dies suddenly, she makes an extraordinary decision: to train one of nature's most fierce and unpredictable predators, a northern goshawk she names Mabel. What follows is a raw, transformative journey through grief that defies easy categorization.

This isn't just a nature memoir—it's a profound meditation on loss, wildness, and what it means to be human. As Macdonald struggles to train her volatile raptor, she discovers that Mabel's feral temperament mirrors her own fractured emotional state. Together, woman and bird navigate the complex terrain of healing, revealing both the pain and startling beauty of being alive.

Macdonald's prose soars between intimate personal reflection and stunning observations of the natural world, creating something entirely unique. H Is for Hawk became an instant sensation for good reason: it captures the messy, complicated process of grief with unflinching honesty while celebrating the wild creatures that share our world.
Refined_Short_Summary: When her father dies, Macdonald decides to train a notoriously difficult goshawk named Mabel. This stunning memoir weaves together grief, nature writing, and the complex bond between human and raptor. Perfect for readers who loved Lab Girl or The Midnight Library.
Refined_Bio: Helen Macdonald is a writer, poet, illustrator and naturalist, and an affiliated research scholar at the Department of History and Philosophy of Science at the University of Cambridge. She's the author of the bestselling H Is for Hawk, the cultural history Falcon, and three poetry collections including Shaler's Fish. A former Research Fellow at Jesus College, Cambridge, she has worked as a professional falconer and assisted with raptor research and conservation projects across Eurasia. She now writes for the New York Times Magazine.
Formatted_Quotes:
"Beautiful and nearly feral...H Is for Hawk reminds us that excellent nature writing can lay bare some of the intimacies of the wild world as well."

—The New York Times

"One of the loveliest things you'll read this year . . . You'll never see a bird overhead the same way again."

—Entertainment Weekly

"An elegantly written amalgam of nature writing, personal memoir, literary portrait and an examination of bereavement. . . . It illuminates unexpected things in unexpected ways."

—The Washington Post
Short_Summary: Macdonald’s bestselling memoir follows her training of a goshawk after her father’s death, blending nature writing with personal grief and reflection.

Fierce and feral, her goshawk Mabel's temperament mirrors Helen's own state of grief after her father's death, and together raptor and human "discover the pain and beauty of being alive" (People). Macdonald was a Research Fellow at Jesus College, Cambridge, has worked as a professional falconer, and has assisted with the management of raptor research and conservation projects across Eurasia. She now writes for the New York Times Magazine.

Title: Is a River Alive?
Refined_Long_Summary:
Hailed in the New York Times as "a naturalist who can unfurl a sentence with the breathless ease of a master angler," Robert Macfarlane brings his glittering style to a profound work exploring an ancient, urgent idea: that rivers are living beings who should be recognized as such in imagination and law.

Macfarlane takes readers on three unforgettable journeys to the miraculous cloud-forests and mountain streams of Ecuador, the wounded creeks and lagoons of India, and the spectacular wild rivers of Canada—imperiled respectively by mining, pollution, and dams. Braiding these travels is the life story of a fragile chalk stream near his home, flowing through his own years and days.

Powered by dazzling prose and illuminated by diverse voices, this joyful, mind-expanding exploration will open hearts, challenge perspectives, and remind us that our fate flows with that of rivers—and always has.
Refined_Short_Summary: What if rivers are actually living beings deserving legal rights? Macfarlane journeys from Ecuador's cloud-forests to India's polluted waterways, weaving science with lyrical prose. Perfect for readers who loved The Overstory or Braiding Sweetgrass.
Refined_Bio: Robert Macfarlane's best-selling books include Is a River Alive? and Underland. His work has been translated into more than thirty languages and has won many prizes worldwide. He is a Fellow of Emmanuel College, Cambridge.

Title: Underland
Subtitle: A Deep Time Journey
Summary: A profound exploration of the world beneath our feet, Macfarlane travels through caves, catacombs, and ice cores to illuminate deep time and human connection.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Hailed as "the great nature writer of this generation" by the Wall Street Journal, Robert Macfarlane embarks on an epic journey into Earth's hidden realms in his masterpiece Underland—a book that's mythic, literary, and geological all at once.

A sequel to his international bestseller The Old Ways, Underland travels through "deep time," spanning from the birth of the universe to a post-human future. Macfarlane takes readers from prehistoric cave art in Norway to the depths of the Greenland ice cap, from Bronze Age tombs to the catacombs of Paris, from fungal networks that allow trees to communicate to vast repositories where nuclear waste will lie for 100,000 years.

Along the way, he interweaves stories of explorers, mourners, artists, and dreamers who have descended into the underworld seeking meaning, survival, or revelation. Global in scope and lyrical in style, Underland poses a profound, urgent question: "Are we being good ancestors to the future Earth?" At once ancient and contemporary, this transformative book will change how you see the world beneath your feet.
Refined_Short_Summary: Journey through deep time and hidden worlds with Britain's master nature writer. From prehistoric caves to nuclear waste sites, this lyrical exploration will change how you see what lies beneath our feet.
Refined_Bio: Robert Macfarlane is the internationally bestselling author of Underland, The Old Ways, The Wild Places, and other award-winning books translated into more than thirty languages. His collaborations include The Lost Words and The Lost Spells with Jackie Morris, plus films and stage works. A recipient of the E. M. Forster and Henry David Thoreau prizes, he is a fellow of Emmanuel College, Cambridge.

Title: In the Dream House
Subtitle: A Memoir
Summary: Machado reinvents the memoir form to tell a harrowing story of an abusive relationship, blending genres in a groundbreaking narrative.
Refined_Long_Summary:
In the Dream House is Carmen Maria Machado's engrossing and wildly innovative account of a relationship gone bad—a bold dissection of psychological abuse and its cultural representations. Tracing the full arc of a harrowing relationship with a charismatic but volatile woman, Machado struggles to make sense of how these experiences shaped who she was becoming.

That struggle drives the book's original structure: each chapter operates through a different narrative trope—the haunted house, erotica, the bildungsroman—allowing Machado to examine events from multiple angles. She reflects on her religious adolescence, unpacks stereotypes of lesbian relationships as inherently safe and utopian, and widens the lens with essayistic explorations of abuse in queer relationships.

Machado's devastating narrative is balanced by her characteristic wit, playfulness, and intellectual curiosity. She casts a critical eye over legal proceedings, fairy tales, Star Trek, Disney villains, and iconic works of film and fiction. The result is a wrenching, riveting book that explodes our ideas about what memoir can accomplish.
Refined_Short_Summary: Machado shatters memoir conventions to examine an abusive relationship through multiple narrative lenses—from horror tropes to fairy tales. Essential reading for fans of Crying in H Mart and Know My Name.
Refined_Bio: Carmen Maria Machado is the author of the bestselling memoir In the Dream House, the graphic novel The Low, Low Woods, and the award-winning short story collection Her Body and Other Parties. She has been a National Book Award finalist and winner of the Bard Fiction Prize, Lambda Literary Awards for both Lesbian Fiction and LGBTQ Nonfiction, the Brooklyn Public Library Literature Prize, the Shirley Jackson Award, and the National Book Critics Circle's John Leonard Prize. In 2018, the New York Times named Her Body and Other Parties as part of "The New Vanguard."
Formatted_Quotes:
"Machado's writing is full of repressed physical energy and the raw juice of annihilating female fury."

—Louise Erdrich, The Millions

"[Machado's] use of a vivid experimental lens to show women struggling for agency is startling."

—The New Yorker

"With Machado, everything feels razed and built anew."

—Star Tribune (Minneapolis)
Short_Summary: Machado reinvents the memoir form to tell a harrowing story of an abusive relationship, blending genres in a groundbreaking narrative.
Long_Summary:
In the Dream House is Carmen Maria Machado’s engrossing and wildly innovative account of a relationship gone bad, and a bold dissection of the mechanisms and cultural representations of psychological abuse. Tracing the full arc of a harrowing relationship with a charismatic but volatile woman, Machado struggles to make sense of how what happened to her shaped the person she was becoming.

And it’s that struggle that gives the book its original structure: each chapter is driven by its own narrative trope—the haunted house, erotica, the bildungsroman—through which Machado holds the events up to the light, examining them from different angles. She looks back at her religious adolescence, unpacks the stereotype of lesbian relationships as safe and utopian, and widens the view with essayistic explorations of the history and reality of abuse in queer relationships.

Machado’s dire narrative is leavened with her characteristic wit, playfulness, and openness to inquiry. She casts a critical eye over legal proceedings, fairy tales, Star Trek, and Disney villains, as well as iconic works of film and fiction. The result is a wrenching, riveting book that explodes our ideas about what a memoir can do and be.

Title: Rogue Heroes
Subtitle: The History of the SAS, Britain's Secret Special Forces Unit That Sabotaged the Nazis and Changed the Nature of War
BISAC_Category_Description: History / Wars & Conflicts / World War II
Summary: Macintyre tells the riveting history of the SAS during World War II, a tale of daring raids, eccentric characters, and lasting military innovation.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Britain’s Special Air Service—or SAS—was the brainchild of David Stirling, a young, gadabout aristocrat whose aimlessness in early life belied a remarkable strategic mind. Where most of his colleagues looked at a battlefield map of World War II’s African theater and saw a protracted struggle with Rommel’s desert forces, Stirling saw an opportunity: given a small number of elite, well-trained men, he could parachute behind enemy lines and sabotage their airplanes and war material. Paired with his constitutional opposite, the disciplined martinet Jock Lewes, Stirling assembled a revolutionary fighting force that would upend not just the balance of the war, but the nature of combat itself. He faced no little resistance from those who found his tactics ungentlemanly or beyond the pale, but in the SAS’s remarkable exploits facing the Nazis in the Africa and then on the Continent can be found the seeds of nearly all special forces units that would follow.

Bringing his keen eye for psychological detail to a riveting wartime narrative, Ben Macintyre uses his unprecedented access to SAS archives to shine a light inside a legendary unit long shrouded in secrecy. The result is not just a tremendous war story, but a fascinating group portrait of men of whom history and country asked the most.
Refined_Short_Summary: The incredible untold story of WWII’s greatest secret fighting force, as told by our great modern master of wartime intrigue
Refined_Bio: Ben Macintyre is a writer-at-large for The Times (U.K.) and the bestselling author of Agent Sonya, The Spy and the Traitor, A Spy Among Friends, Double Cross, Operation Mincemeat, Agent Zigzag, and Rogue Heroes, among other books. Macintyre has also written and presented BBC documentaries of his work.
Formatted_Quotes:
“Ben Macintyre’s suspenseful new book, Rogue Heroes, about the founding of Britain’s S.A.S. during World War II, reads like a mashup of 'The Dirty Dozen' and 'The Great Escape,' with a sprinkling of “Ocean’s 11” thrown in for good measure… Mr. Macintyre draws sharp, Dickensian portraits of these men, and he displays his usual gifts here for creating a cinematic narrative that races along… Mr. Macintyre is masterly in using details to illustrate his heroes’ bravery, élan and dogged perseverance…a gripping account of the early days of S.A.S.”—Michiko Kakutani, The New York Times

"Rogue Heroes is a terrific story of human enterprise, endurance and achievement and vividly brings to life an extraordinary cast of characters…. An absorbing story of derring-do, told with skill and flair.”—The Wall Street Journal

“[A] riveting new history… Macintyre has produced yet another wonderful book… even minor characters bristle with life.... This is the spot in the book review where I’m supposed to find some point to quibble with, some omission, some historical inaccuracy, some flaw. Sorry to disappoint. The fact is Macintyre has produced yet another wonderful book. As Captain What What might have put it, this is a ripping good read.”—The Washington Post

Title: These Summer Storms
Subtitle: A Novel
Refined_Long_Summary:
Alice Storm hasn't been welcome at her family's magnificent private island off the Rhode Island coast in five years—not since she was cast out and built her life beyond the Storm name, influence, and untold billions. But the shocking death of her larger-than-life father changes everything.

Alice plans to keep her head down, pay her final respects, and leave the minute the funeral is over. Unfortunately, her father had other plans. The eccentric, manipulative patriarch left his family a final challenge—an inheritance game designed to upend their world. The rules are clear: spend one week on the island, complete their assigned tasks, and receive the inheritance.

But a whole week on Storm Island is no easy task for Alice. Every corner of the sprawling old house is bursting with chaos: her older sister's secret love affair, her brother's unyielding arrogance, her younger sister's constant analysis of the vibes, and her mother's cold judgment. All under the stern, watchful gaze of Jack Dean, her father's intriguing and too-handsome second-in-command.

A smart and tender story about the transformative power of grief, love, and family, this luscious novel explores past secrets, present truths, and futures forged in the wake of wild summer storms.
Refined_Short_Summary: When Alice Storm returns to her wealthy family's private island for her father's funeral, she discovers he's left them all an inheritance game. One week, impossible tasks, and family secrets everywhere—plus her father's devastatingly handsome second-in-command watching her every move.
Refined_Bio: Sarah MacLean is the author of bestselling novels translated into more than twenty-five languages. The co-host of the weekly romance podcast Fated Mates, she is a leading voice in the romance genre. A product of Rhode Island summers and New England storms, Sarah now lives in New York City.
Formatted_Quotes:
