"Poignant overtures of grief, deliciously complicated family dynamics, and forbidden love thread together in a perfect tapestry of mystery and romance."

—Ashley Poston, New York Times bestselling author of The Seven Year Slip

"From the first rumbles of thunder to the final torrential downpour, MacLean takes readers for a wild ride!"

—Abby Jimenez, New York Times bestselling author of Just for the Summer

Title_Subtitle: A Guardian and a Thief: Oprah's Book Club
Title: A Guardian and a Thief: Oprah's Book Club
Subtitle: A Novel
Refined_Long_Summary:
In a near-future Kolkata, Ma, her two-year-old daughter, and her elderly father are just days from leaving the collapsing city behind to join Ma's husband in Ann Arbor, Michigan. After procuring long-awaited visas from the consulate, they pack their bags for the flight to America. But in the morning they awaken to discover that Ma's purse, containing their treasured immigration documents, has been stolen.

Set over the course of one week, A Guardian and a Thief tells two intertwining stories: Ma's frantic search for the thief while keeping hunger at bay during a worsening food shortage, and the story of Boomba, the thief, whose desperation to care for his family drives him to commit escalating crimes whose consequences he cannot fathom.

With stunning control, Megha Majumdar paints a kaleidoscopic portrait of two families, each operating from a place of ferocious love and undefeated hope, each discovering how far they will go to secure their children's future as catastrophe closes in.
Refined_Short_Summary: Two families fight for survival in a collapsing Kolkata when stolen immigration documents spark a desperate chase. Majumdar delivers a gut-wrenching moral thriller that's perfect for readers who loved Station Eleven's apocalyptic tension.
Refined_Bio: Megha Majumdar is the author of the New York Times bestselling novel A Burning, which was nominated for the National Book Award, the National Book Critics Circle's John Leonard Prize, and the American Library Association's Andrew Carnegie Medal. It was named one of the best books of the year by The Washington Post, The New York Times, NPR, The Atlantic, Vogue, and TIME Magazine. A 2022 Whiting Award winner, she was born and raised in Kolkata, India, and holds degrees in anthropology from Harvard and Johns Hopkins. She is the former editor in chief of Catapult books, and lives in New York.
Formatted_Quotes:
"Wondering if there's a novel out there that gives Cormac McCarthy's The Road a run for its money? Here you go."

—Stacy Schiff, author of Cleopatra: A Life

"[A Guardian and a Thief] is a perfect novel: 200 pages of tightly honed panic about life in a collapsing society. . . . The book's simple structure feels reminiscent of a fairy tale, which helps account for the deep, visceral terror the story generates."

—The Washington Post

"A mesmerizing morality play that demonstrates how categories like 'victim' and 'thief' collapse under conditions of scarcity."

—The Atlantic

Summary: In Kolkata, a Muslim girl’s Facebook post implicates her in a terrorist attack, while others seize on her plight for ambition and survival. A searing, propulsive debut of class, justice, and fate.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Jivan is a Muslim girl from the slums, determined to move up in life, who finds herself accused of executing a terrorist attack on a train because of a careless comment on Facebook.

PT Sir is an opportunistic gym teacher who hitches his aspirations to a right-wing political party and discovers that his own ascent becomes inextricably linked to Jivan's fall.

Lovely—an irresistible outcast whose exuberant voice and dreams of movie stardom fill the novel with warmth, hope, and humor—holds the alibi that can set Jivan free, but using it will cost her everything she holds dear.

Taut, symphonic, and propulsive, A Burning is an electrifying debut that weaves together three unforgettable characters seeking to rise in contemporary India—to the middle class, to political power, to fame—only to find their fates catastrophically intertwined.
Refined_Short_Summary: Three lives collide in contemporary India when a Muslim girl faces terrorism charges over a Facebook post. Think The Kite Runner meets current social media paranoia—devastating and impossible to put down.
Refined_Bio: Megha Majumdar is the author of the New York Times bestselling novel A Burning, which was nominated for the National Book Award, the National Book Critics Circle's John Leonard Prize, and the American Library Association's Andrew Carnegie Medal. Named one of the best books of the year by The Washington Post, The New York Times, NPR, The Atlantic, Vogue, and TIME Magazine. A 2022 Whiting Award winner, she was born and raised in Kolkata, India, and holds degrees in anthropology from Harvard and Johns Hopkins. She is the former editor in chief of Catapult books, and lives in New York.

"Majumdar demonstrates an uncanny ability to capture the vast scope of a tumultuous society by attending to the hopes and fears of people living on the margins. The effect is transporting."

Title: The Great Believers
Summary: Alternating between 1980s Chicago during the AIDS crisis and present-day Paris, Makkai’s novel follows a group of friends whose lives are forever changed. Heartbreaking, sweeping, and unforgettable.
Refined_Long_Summary:
In 1985 Chicago, Yale Tishman is riding high as development director for an art gallery, on the verge of securing an extraordinary collection of 1920s paintings. But as his career flourishes, the AIDS epidemic devastates his community. One by one, his friends are dying, and after his friend Nico's funeral, the virus circles closer to Yale himself. Soon the only person he has left is Fiona, Nico's little sister.

Thirty years later, Fiona travels to Paris to track down her estranged daughter, who has disappeared into a cult. While staying with an old friend—a famous photographer who documented the Chicago crisis—she finally confronts how AIDS shaped her life and fractured her relationship with her daughter. These two intertwining stories span decades of heartbreak and resilience, following Yale and Fiona as they search for hope and connection amid devastating loss.
Refined_Short_Summary: Two interconnected stories of love and loss during the AIDS crisis. Following a gallery director in 1980s Chicago and a woman searching for her daughter in modern Paris, this devastating novel will resonate with anyone who loved The Midnight Library's exploration of grief and connection.
Refined_Bio: Rebecca Makkai's The Great Believers was a Pulitzer Prize and National Book Award finalist, winning the ALA Carnegie Medal, Stonewall Book Award, Clark Prize, and Los Angeles Times Book Prize. The New York Times named it one of 2018's Ten Best Books. Her other works include The Borrower, The Hundred-Year House, and Music for Wartime. A 2022 Guggenheim Fellow, she teaches at University of Nevada, Reno and Northwestern University, and serves as Artistic Director of StoryStudio Chicago.
Formatted_Quotes:
"Tearjerker… The Great Believers asks big questions about redemption, tragedy, and connection. Makkai has written her most ambitious novel yet."

—Entertainment Weekly

"Stirring, spellbinding and full of life."

—Téa Obreht, New York Times bestselling author of The Tiger's Wife

"The Great Believers kept me up reading late into the night, and I'd wake up thinking about Makkai's vibrant, complex, and deeply human characters. This is an immersive, heartbreaking novel—I loved it."

—Maggie Shipstead, author of The Great Circle & Astonish Me
Short_Summary: A dazzling novel of friendship and redemption in the face of tragedy and loss set in 1980s Chicago and contemporary Paris
Long_Summary:
In 1985, Yale Tishman, the development director for an art gallery in Chicago, is about to pull off an amazing coup, bringing in an extraordinary collection of 1920s paintings as a gift to the gallery. Yet as his career begins to flourish, the carnage of the AIDS epidemic grows around him. One by one, his friends are dying and after his friend Nico’s funeral, the virus circles closer and closer to Yale himself. Soon the only person he has left is Fiona, Nico’s little sister.

Thirty years later, Fiona is in Paris tracking down her estranged daughter who disappeared into a cult. While staying with an old friend, a famous photographer who documented the Chicago crisis, she finds herself finally grappling with the devastating ways AIDS affected her life and her relationship with her daughter. The two intertwining stories take us through the heartbreak of the eighties and the chaos of the modern world, as both Yale and Fiona struggle to find goodness in the midst of disaster.
Copy_Bio: Rebecca Makkai’s last novel, The Great Believers, was a finalist for both the Pulitzer Prize and the National Book Award; it was the winner of the ALA Carnegie Medal, the Stonewall Book Award, the Clark Prize, and the Los Angeles Times Book Prize; and it was chosen as one of the Ten Best Books of 2018 by The New York Times. Her other books are the novels The Borrower and The Hundred-Year House, and the collection Music for Wartime—four stories from which appeared in The Best American Short Stories. A 2022 Guggenheim Fellow, Rebecca is on the MFA faculties of the University of Nevada, Reno at Lake Tahoe and Northwestern University, and is Artistic Director of StoryStudio Chicago.

Title: Station Eleven
Subtitle: A novel
Summary: After a flu pandemic collapses civilization, a troupe of actors and musicians travels the Great Lakes, preserving art in the ruins. A haunting, luminous novel of survival and memory.
Refined_Long_Summary:
An audacious, darkly glittering novel set in the eerie days following civilization's collapse, Station Eleven tells the spellbinding story of a nomadic group of actors roaming the scattered outposts of the Great Lakes region, risking everything for art and humanity.

Fifteen years after a flu pandemic wiped out most of the world's population, Kirsten performs with the Traveling Symphony, a small troupe moving across the gutted landscape, bringing Shakespeare and music to scattered communities of survivors.

But when they arrive in the outpost of St. Deborah by the Water, they encounter a violent prophet who digs graves for anyone who dares to leave. Spanning decades and moving back and forth in time, this suspenseful, elegiac novel vividly depicts life before and after the disaster, creating a story rife with beauty about the relationships that sustain us.
Refined_Short_Summary: Fifteen years after a pandemic ends civilization, traveling actors bring Shakespeare to survivors across the wasteland. This haunting masterpiece weaves between past and present, exploring how art and human connection endure. Perfect for fans of The Road or The Leftovers.
Refined_Bio: Emily St. John Mandel's five previous novels include The Glass Hotel and Station Eleven, which was a finalist for a National Book Award and the PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction and has been translated into thirty-five languages. She lives in New York City.
Formatted_Quotes:
"A novel that carries a magnificent depth . . . We get to see something that is so difficult to show or feel – how small moments in time link together. And how these moments add up to a life . . . Her best yet. It feels as though she took the experience earned from her previous writing and braided it together to make one gleaming strand . . . An epic book."

—Claire Cameron, The Globe and Mail

"Deeply melancholy, but beautifully written, and wonderfully elegiac . . . A book that I will long remember, and return to."

—George R. R. Martin

"Station Eleven is so compelling, so fearlessly imagined, that I wouldn't have put it down for anything."

—Ann Patchett, author of Tom Lake, The Dutch House, Commonweath & State of Wonder

Title: Sea of Tranquility
Subtitle: A novel
Summary: From Vancouver Island in 1912 to a lunar colony five centuries later, Sea of Tranquility weaves together characters linked by a mysterious anomaly in time. Moving fluidly across eras, Mandel crafts a haunting meditation on art, survival, and the possibility of time travel. Beautifully written, the novel explores how lives intersect across centuries and how humanity searches for meaning amid uncertainty.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Edwin St. Andrew is eighteen when he crosses the Atlantic by steamship, exiled from polite society following an ill-conceived dinner party outburst. Wandering through the Canadian wilderness, he's suddenly shocked by an impossible sound: violin notes echoing as if in an airship terminal.

Two centuries later, famous writer Olive Llewellyn tours Earth promoting her latest book, though her home is now the second moon colony with its white stone towers and artificial beauty. Within her bestselling pandemic novel lies a haunting passage: a man playing violin in an airship terminal's echoing corridor as forest trees rise around him.

When detective Gaspery-Jacques Roberts investigates an anomaly in the North American wilderness, he uncovers connected lives across time: an exiled earl's son, a writer trapped during a pandemic, and a childhood friend who glimpsed something extraordinary that could disrupt the universe's timeline.

A virtuoso performance both intellectually playful and deeply human, Sea of Tranquility weaves together art, time travel, and love while capturing the precise reality of our current moment.
Refined_Short_Summary: Time travel meets pandemic fiction in this stunning journey from 1912 Vancouver Island to a lunar colony five centuries later. Perfect for readers who were captivated by The Midnight Library's exploration of interconnected lives across time and space.
Refined_Bio: Emily St. John Mandel's five previous novels include The Glass Hotel and Station Eleven, which was a finalist for a National Book Award and the PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction and has been translated into thirty-five languages. She lives in New York City.
Formatted_Quotes:
"In Sea of Tranquility, Mandel offers one of her finest novels and one of her most satisfying forays into the arena of speculative fiction yet, but it is her ability to convincingly inhabit the ordinary, and…project a sustaining acknowledgment of beauty, that sets the novel apart…Born of…empathy and hard-won understanding, beautifully built into language, for all of us who inhabit this 'green-and-blue world' and who one day might live well beyond."

—Laird Hunt, The New York Times

"Mandel delivers...with an impish blend of wit and dread. The paradoxes of Gaspery's adventure will be familiar to anyone who's studied Jean Baudrillard or seen "Back to the Future." But Mandel has the stylistic elegance and emotional sympathy to make this more than merely an undergraduate bull session. Absent your own time portal to the 1990s, it's a chance to... wrestle with the mind-blowing possibility that what is may be entirely different from what we see."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

"I didn't just read Station Eleven, The Glass Hotel, or Mandel's latest, Sea of Tranquility. I lived in those novels and felt the remnants of their weird, chill atmosphere long after I had to move on…World builder is a phrase that's rightly used to describe Mandel's immersive powers as a novelist…Sea Of Tranquility is a poignant, ingeniously constructed and deeply absorbing novel that surveys big questions about the cruel inevitability of time passing, loss, the nature of what we consider reality and, in the end, what finally matters…Mandel is an important novelist of our moment, but doesn't settle for merely replicating our moment. She inhabits it even as she sees beyond it."

—Maureen Corrigan, NPR
Short_Summary: The award-winning, best-selling author of Station Eleven and The Glass Hotel returns with a novel of art, time travel, love, and plague that takes the reader from Vancouver Island in 1912 to a dark colony on the moon five hundred years later, unfurling a story of humanity across centuries and space.
Long_Summary:
Edwin St. Andrew is eighteen years old when he crosses the Atlantic by steamship, exiled from polite society following an ill-conceived diatribe at a dinner party. He enters the forest, spellbound by the beauty of the Canadian wilderness, and suddenly hears the notes of a violin echoing in an airship terminal—an experience that shocks him to his core. 

Two centuries later a famous writer named Olive Llewellyn is on a book tour. She’s traveling all over Earth, but her home is the second moon colony, a place of white stone, spired towers, and artificial beauty. Within the text of Olive’s best-selling pandemic novel lies a strange passage: a man plays his violin for change in the echoing corridor of an airship terminal as the trees of a forest rise around him. 

When Gaspery-Jacques Roberts, a detective in the black-skied Night City, is hired to investigate an anomaly in the North American wilderness, he uncovers a series of lives upended: The exiled son of an earl driven to madness, a writer trapped far from home as a pandemic ravages Earth, and a childhood friend from the Night City who, like Gaspery himself, has glimpsed the chance to do something extraordinary that will disrupt the timeline of the universe.

A virtuoso performance that is as human and tender as it is intellectually playful, Sea of Tranquility is a novel of time travel and metaphysics that precisely captures the reality of our current moment.

Subtitle: Uncovering the New World Columbus Created
BISAC_Category_Description: History / Americas (North, Central, South, West Indies)
Summary: Mann explores the ecological and cultural consequences of the Columbian Exchange, showing how 1493 reshaped the modern world.
Refined_Long_Summary:
More than 200 million years ago, the continents split apart, evolving in isolation until Columbus's arrival in the Americas ended that separation forever. His voyages unleashed the "Columbian Exchange"—a vast transfer of plants, animals, and microbes that transformed diets, landscapes, and lives across the planet. Tomatoes reached Italy, chili peppers reached Asia, earthworms and rats spread everywhere.

Decades later, the Spanish established global trade through Manila, linking American silver, Asian silk, and European markets in the first true world economy. Biologically and economically, these exchanges reshaped history.

Drawing on cutting-edge research, Mann reveals how this worldwide network fostered Europe's rise, convulsed Africa, weakened China, and for two centuries made Mexico City the hub of global interaction. He shows how the ecological and economic revolutions set in motion by Columbus still reverberate in today's fiercest debates over immigration, trade, and culture.
Refined_Short_Summary: The sequel to the bestselling 1491 explores how Columbus's voyages created the first global economy and changed everything from what we eat to how we live. Think Sapiens meets world history—fascinating and essential.
Refined_Bio: Charles C. Mann writes for The Atlantic, Science, and Wired, and has contributed to Fortune, The New York Times, Smithsonian, Technology Review, Vanity Fair, The Washington Post, HBO, and Law & Order. A three-time National Magazine Award finalist, he's received writing awards from the American Bar Association, American Institute of Physics, Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, and Lannan Foundation.
Formatted_Quotes:
"Revelatory."

—Lev Grossman, Time

"Compelling and eye-opening."

—Publishers Weekly

"In the wake of his groundbreaking book 1491 Charles Mann has once again produced a brilliant and riveting work that will forever change the way we see the world. Mann shows how the ecological collision of Europe and the Americas transformed virtually every aspect of human history. Beautifully written, and packed with startling research, 1493 is a monumental achievement."

—David Grann, author of Killers of the Flower Moon, The Lost City of Z
Short_Summary: From the author of 1491—the best-selling study of the pre-Columbian Americas—a deeply engaging new history of the most momentous biological event since the death of the dinosaurs.

Tomatoes reached Italy, chili peppers reached Asia, earthworms and rats spread everywhere.

In 1493, Charles C. Mann reveals how this worldwide network fostered Europe’s rise, convulsed Africa, weakened China, and for two centuries made Mexico City the hub of global interaction. Drawing on cutting-edge research, Mann shows how the ecological and economic revolutions set in motion by Columbus and Legazpi still reverberate in today’s fiercest debates over immigration, trade, and culture.

Title: Bring Up the Bodies
Subtitle: A Novel
Summary: The sequel to Wolf Hall follows Thomas Cromwell as he engineers Anne Boleyn’s downfall. A masterful, gripping portrayal of power, betrayal, and ambition in Tudor England.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Though he battled for seven years to marry her, Henry VIII is now disenchanted with Anne Boleyn. She has failed to give him a son, and her sharp intelligence and audacious will alienate his old friends and the noble families of England. When the discarded Katherine dies in exile from the court, Anne stands starkly exposed, the focus of gossip and malice.

At a word from Henry, Thomas Cromwell is ready to bring her down. Over three terrifying weeks, Anne is ensnared in a web of conspiracy, while the demure Jane Seymore waits her turn for the poisoned wedding ring. But Anne and her powerful family will not yield without a ferocious struggle.

Hilary Mantel's Bring Up the Bodies follows the dramatic trial of the queen and her suitors for adultery and treason. To defeat the Boleyns, Cromwell must ally with his natural enemies, the papist aristocracy. What price will he pay for Anne's head?
Refined_Short_Summary: Thomas Cromwell orchestrates Anne Boleyn's downfall in this masterful sequel to Wolf Hall. Mantel transforms familiar Tudor history into a gripping political thriller that rivals The Crown for royal intrigue.
Refined_Bio: Hilary Mantel was a renowned English writer who twice won the Booker Prize for Wolf Hall and Bring Up the Bodies. The final novel of the trilogy, The Mirror & the Light, debuted at #1 on the New York Times bestseller list. She wrote seventeen celebrated books, including the memoir Giving Up the Ghost, and won the National Book Critics Circle Award, Walter Scott Prize, Costa Book Award, and Hawthornden Prize. In 2014, she was appointed Dame Commander of the Order of the British Empire. She died in 2022 at age seventy.
Formatted_Quotes:
"Two years ago something astonishingly fair happened in the world of prestigious prizes: the Man Booker Prize and the National Book Critics Circle Award for fiction for 2009 both went to the right winner. The book was Hilary Mantel's Wolf Hall, and it would have dwarfed the competition any year…It was a hard act to follow. But the follow-up is equally sublime…That ironic ending will be no cliffhanger for anyone even remotely familiar with Henry VIII's trail of carnage. But in Bring Up the Bodies it works as one. The wonder of Ms. Mantel's retelling is that she makes these events fresh and terrifying all over again."

—The New York Times

"the finest works of historical fiction in contemporary literature."

—The Washington Post

"In Mantel's hands, Cromwell's cunning, morally complicated orchestration of that historic slice through the royal neck is as exciting as any thriller."

—Entertainment Weekly

Title: The Mirror & the Light
Subtitle: A Novel
Summary: The final volume in Mantel’s Cromwell trilogy traces his rise to unparalleled power and his brutal fall. Majestic and immersive, it completes one of the great achievements of modern historical fiction.
Refined_Long_Summary:
England, May 1536. Anne Boleyn is dead, executed by a French swordsman in a single stroke. As her body is hastily buried, Thomas Cromwell breakfasts with the victors, the blacksmith's son from Putney emerging from the bloodbath to continue his relentless climb to power.

His master, Henry VIII, has already moved on to his third queen, Jane Seymore, who will die giving him the male heir he desperately craves. Cromwell has only his wits to rely on—no noble family, no private army. Yet despite rebellion at home, traitors abroad, and threats of invasion testing Henry's regime, Cromwell's imagination envisions a transformed England.

But can a nation shed its past like old skin? Do the dead refuse to stay buried? The Spanish ambassador poses a chilling question: What will you do when the king inevitably turns on you, as he does everyone who gets too close?

Mantel brings her magnificent trilogy to a triumphant close, tracing Cromwell's final years as he reaches the pinnacle of power. This is a defining portrait of predator and prey, a ferocious contest between past and present, royal will and common vision—of a modern nation forging itself through conflict and courage.
Refined_Short_Summary: Thomas Cromwell reaches the height of his power in Henry VIII's court, but his meteoric rise makes his fall inevitable. Mantel's masterful conclusion to her trilogy delivers a devastating portrait of ambition and mortality.
Refined_Bio: Hilary Mantel authored the bestselling Wolf Hall and its sequel Bring Up the Bodies, both Booker Prize winners. The trilogy's final volume, The Mirror & the Light, debuted at #1 on the New York Times bestseller list. She wrote seventeen celebrated books, including the memoir Giving Up the Ghost, earning the National Book Critics Circle Award, Walter Scott Prize, Costa Book Award, and Hawthornden Prize. Appointed Dame Commander of the Order of the British Empire in 2014, she died in 2022 at age seventy.
Formatted_Quotes:
"Two years ago something astonishingly fair happened in the world of prestigious prizes: the Man Booker Prize and the National Book Critics Circle Award for fiction for 2009 both went to the right winner. The book was Hilary Mantel's Wolf Hall, and it would have dwarfed the competition any year…It was a hard act to follow. But the follow-up is equally sublime…That ironic ending will be no cliffhanger for anyone even remotely familiar with Henry VIII's trail of carnage. But in Bring Up the Bodies it works as one. The wonder of Ms. Mantel's retelling is that she makes these events fresh and terrifying all over again."

—The New York Times

"Bring Up the Bodies isn't just her boldest book; it's also her best -- and it reaffirms Mantel's reputation as one of England's greatest living novelists."

—NPR

"the finest works of historical fiction in contemporary literature."

—The Washington Post
Short_Summary: The final volume in Mantel’s Cromwell trilogy traces his rise to unparalleled power and his brutal fall. Majestic and immersive, it completes one of the great achievements of modern historical fiction.
Long_Summary:
England, May 1536. Anne Boleyn is dead, decapitated in the space of a heartbeat by a hired French executioner. As her remains are bundled into oblivion, Thomas Cromwell breakfasts with the victors. The blacksmith’s son from Putney emerges from the spring’s bloodbath to continue his climb to power and wealth, while his formidable master, Henry VIII, settles to short-lived happiness with his third queen before Jane dies giving birth to the male heir he most craves.

Cromwell is a man with only his wits to rely on; he has no great family to back him, no private army. Despite rebellion at home, traitors plotting abroad and the threat of invasion testing Henry’s regime to the breaking point, Cromwell’s robust imagination sees a new country in the mirror of the future. But can a nation, or a person, shed the past like a skin? Do the dead continually unbury themselves? What will you do, the Spanish ambassador asks Cromwell, when the king turns on you, as sooner or later he turns on everyone close to him?

With The Mirror & the Light, Hilary Mantel brings to a triumphant close the trilogy she began with Wolf Hall and Bring Up the Bodies. She traces the final years of Thomas Cromwell, the boy from nowhere who climbs to the heights of power, offering a defining portrait of predator and prey, of a ferocious contest between present and past, between royal will and a common man’s vision: of a modern nation making itself through conflict, passion, and courage.

Title: Malcolm X
Subtitle: A Life of Reinvention
Summary: Marable’s landmark biography of Malcolm X draws on new sources to present a fuller, more complex portrait of the revolutionary leader.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Of the great figures in twentieth-century American history, perhaps none is more complex and controversial than Malcolm X. Constantly rewriting his own story, he became a criminal, a minister, a leader, and an icon, all before being felled by assassins' bullets at age thirty-nine. Through his tireless work and countless speeches, he empowered hundreds of thousands of black Americans to create better lives and stronger communities while establishing the template for the self-actualized, independent African American man.

Manning Marable's biography is a stunning achievement filled with new information and shocking revelations that go beyond the Autobiography. Malcolm X unfolds a sweeping story of race and class in America, from the rise of Marcus Garvey and the Ku Klux Klan to the struggles of the civil rights movement in the fifties and sixties.

Reaching into Malcolm's troubled youth, it traces a path from his parents' activism through his own engagement with the Nation of Islam, charting his astronomical rise in the world of Black Nationalism and culminating in the never-before-told true story of his assassination. This definitive work captures with revelatory clarity a man who constantly strove to remake himself anew.
Refined_Short_Summary: Drawing on groundbreaking research, this biography reveals shocking new details about Malcolm X's life and assassination. Essential reading for anyone captivated by figures who transformed America through sheer force of will.
Refined_Bio: Manning Marable (1950–2011) was Professor of African-American Studies and of Public Affairs, History and Political Science at Columbia University. His books include Black American Politics, Black Leadership, Living Black History, Beyond Black and White: From Civil Rights to Barack Obama, and Malcolm X: A Life of Reinvention.
Formatted_Quotes:
"It will be difficult for anyone to better this book. It goes deeper and richer than a mere homage to Malcolm X. It is a work of art, a feast that combines genres skillfully: biography, true-crime, political commentary. It gives us Malcolm X in full gallop, a man who died for his belief in freedom, a man whom Marable calls the 'fountainhead' of the black power movement in America."

—The Washington Post

"In his revealing and prodigiously researched new biography, Malcolm X: A Life of Reinvention, Manning Marable - a professor at Columbia University and the director of its Center for Contemporary Black History, who died just last week - vividly chronicles these many incarnations of his subject. . . Mr. Marable artfully strips away the layers and layers of myth that have been lacquered onto his subject's life - first by Malcolm himself in that famous memoir, and later by both supporters and opponents after his assassination in 1965 at the age of 39."

—Michiko Kakutani, The New York Times

"Unlike Bruce Perry's 1991 biography, Malcolm, which entertained the most outlandish stories in an attempt to present a comprehensive portrait, Marable's biography judiciously sifts fact from myth."

—The Atlantic

Long_Summary:

Manning Marable's new biography of Malcolm is a stunning achievement. Title: The Infatuations
Summary: A Madrid woman becomes obsessed with a couple she sees daily at a café—until the man is murdered, pulling her into a web of intrigue and desire. Stylish, cerebral, and suspenseful.
Refined_Long_Summary:
At her usual Madrid café, María Dolz becomes fascinated by a couple she observes each morning before work. Their seemingly perfect life provides an escape from her own mundane existence—until the man is brutally murdered in the street.

When María approaches the widow to offer condolences, she enters their world and meets another man who casts the crime in a disturbing new light. As she falls in love with him, the boundaries between observation and obsession blur dangerously.

Through María's narration, what begins as a murder mystery transforms into something far more complex—a metaphysical exploration of love and death, guilt and chance, and how we're haunted by loss. Marías crafts a brilliant meditation on the slippery nature of truth and the stories we tell ourselves to make sense of tragedy.
Refined_Short_Summary: When the man María secretly observes at her local café is murdered, her fascination with his perfect life spirals into dangerous obsession. Fans of psychological thrillers like The Silent Patient will be captivated by this haunting exploration of truth and desire.
Refined_Bio: Javier Marías was born in Madrid in 1951. He published fifteen novels, including The Infatuations and A Heart So White, plus three short story collections and essay volumes. His work has been translated into forty-four languages, sold over eight million copies worldwide, and won numerous international awards, including the International IMPAC Dublin Literary Award and Prix Femina Étranger. He died in 2022.
Formatted_Quotes:
"Whatever else we may think is going on when we read, we are choosing to spend time in an author's company. In Javier Marías's case this is a good decision; his mind is insightful, witty, sometimes startling, sometimes hilarious, and always intelligent . . . The masterly Spanish novelist [has] a penetrating empathy."

—Edward St. Aubyn, The New York Times

"The Infatuations is mysterious and seductive; it's got deception, it's got love affairs, it's got murder—the book is the most sheerly addictive thing Marías has ever written . . . Marías is a star writer in Europe, where his best-sellers collect prizes the way Kardashians collect paparazzi. He's been hailed in America, too, yet he's never broken through like Haruki Murakami or Roberto Bolaño. This should change with his new novel, The Infatuations, which is the ideal introduction to his work."

—NPR

"Blindingly intelligent, engagingly accessible—it seems there's nothing Marías can't make fiction do . . . Marías's rare gift is his ability to make intellectual jousting as suspenseful as the chase scenes in a commercial thriller."

—Kirkus
Short_Summary: From the award-winning Spanish writer Javier Marías comes an extraordinary new book that has been a literary sensation around the world: an immersive, provocative novel propelled by a seemingly random murder that we come to understand—or do we?—through one woman’s ever-unfurling imagination and infatuations.
Long_Summary: At the Madrid café where she stops for breakfast each day before work, María Dolz finds herself drawn to a couple who is also there every morning. Though she can hardly explain it, observing what she imagines to be their “unblemished” life lifts her out of the doldrums of her own existence. But what begins as mere observation turns into an increasingly complicated entanglement when the man is fatally stabbed in the street. María approaches the widow to offer her condolences, and at the couple’s home she meets—and falls in love with—another man who sheds disturbing new light on the crime. As María recounts this story, we are given a murder mystery brilliantly reimagined as metaphysical enquiry, a novel that grapples with questions of love and death, guilt and obsession, chance and coincidence, how we are haunted by our losses, and above all, the slippery essence of the truth and how it is told.

He has published fifteen novels, including The Infatuations and A Heart So White, as well as three collections of short stories and several volumes of essays. His work has been translated into forty-four languages, has sold more than eight and a half million copies worldwide, and has won a dazzling array of international literary awards, including the prestigious International IMPAC Dublin Literary Award and the Prix Femina Étranger. He died in 2022.

Title: Matterhorn
Subtitle: A Novel of the Vietnam War
Summary: A young Marine lieutenant leads his company through brutal combat in Vietnam, confronting the futility and brotherhood of war. An epic war novel, visceral and unforgettable.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Intense, powerful, and compelling, Matterhorn is an epic Vietnam War novel in the tradition of Norman Mailer's The Naked and the Dead and James Jones's The Thin Red Line. It follows young Marine lieutenant Waino Mellas and his comrades in Bravo Company, dropped into the mountain jungles of Vietnam as boys and forced to fight their way into manhood.

Battling not only the North Vietnamese but also monsoon rains, disease, hunger, and the wilderness itself, they must confront divisions within their own ranks—racial tension, clashing ambitions, and the failures of their commanders. When Bravo Company is surrounded and outnumbered by a massive enemy force, the Marines are plunged into the raw terror of combat in an ordeal that will change them forever.

Written over thirty years by a decorated Marine veteran, Matterhorn is a spellbinding, unforgettable novel destined to stand as a modern classic of war literature.
Refined_Short_Summary: Vietnam through the eyes of young Marines facing impossible odds in the jungle. This devastating war epic captures both the horror and brotherhood of combat with unflinching honesty.
Refined_Bio: Karl Marlantes graduated from Yale University and was a Rhodes Scholar at Oxford University, before serving as a Marine in Vietnam, where he was awarded the Navy Cross, the Bronze Star, two Navy Commendation Medals for valor, two Purple Hearts, and ten air medals. He is the bestselling author of Matterhorn and What It Is Like to Go to War. He lives in rural Washington.
Formatted_Quotes:
"I've laughed at Catch-22 and wept at The Thin Red Line, but I've never encountered a war novel as stark, honest and wrenching as Matterhorn. . . . By turns, this book horrified me, crushed me and beat me up, but I found it nearly impossible to stop reading. More than any living American novelist I've read, Marlantes made me feel what I already must have known: that war is worse than hell."

—NPR

"Never have we seen the particular horrors and challenges of Vietnam so richly explored, and never have we felt the tactile experience of the war depicted with such mesmerizing force. We see the big picture, but as with all great novels, it's the tiny details—the mud, the leeches, the adrenaline-drenched dread of combat, and the tender joy of comradeship—that linger with the reader long after the story is over."

—Hampton Sides, author of Ghost Soldiers and Hellhound on His Trail

"These are the words I wrote down while reading Matterhorn: authentic, funny, heartbreaking, infuriating, devastating. This great book crawled under my skin on the first page, and I suspect it will remain there for a very long time."

—David Finkel, author of The Good Soldiers

Title: Western Lane
Subtitle: A Novel
Summary: Amid the silent grief of their mother’s loss, eleven-year-old Gopi finds solace and purpose on the squash court—her father’s training regime becomes a language of survival, sisterhood, and self-discovery in Chetna Maroo’s achingly beautiful debut novel.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Eleven-year-old Gopi has been playing squash since she was old enough to hold a racket. When her mother dies, her father enlists her in a quietly brutal training regimen, and the game becomes her world. Slowly, she grows apart from her sisters. Her life is reduced to the sport, guided by its rhythms: the serve, the volley, the drive, the shot and its echo.

But on the court, she is not alone. She is with her pa. She is with Ged, a thirteen-year-old boy with his own formidable talent. She is with the players who have come before her. She is in awe.

Chetna Maroo's debut novel captures the ordinary and transforms it with devastating beauty. Western Lane is both a valentine and an elegy for innocence—for the closeness of sisterhood, for the strange ways we come to know ourselves and each other, for the force of obsession and its consequences.
Refined_Short_Summary: Grief transforms a young squash player's world in this luminous debut. When training becomes obsession, family bonds fracture in unexpected ways. Perfect for readers who were moved by Tomorrow and Tomorrow and Tomorrow.
Refined_Bio: Chetna Maroo lives in London. Her stories have been published in The Paris Review, the Stinging Fly, and the Dublin Review, and she was the recipient of the 2022 Plimpton Prize for Fiction.
Formatted_Quotes:
"Western Lane moved me in a way that is rare. It is limpid, crystalline, holding strange depths."

—C Pam Zhang, author of Land of Milk and Honey

"Compact and powerful . . . This will invigorate readers."

—Publishers Weekly

"Subtle and elegant . . . Gopi's retrospective narration accumulates slow layers of heartbreak as the story proceeds, patiently building up an entire landscape of emotion through gestures, silences, and overheard murmurings in the dark. A debut novel of immense poise and promise."

—Kirkus
Short_Summary: A taut, enthralling first novel about grief, sisterhood, and a young athlete's struggle to transcend herself.

Title: A Constellation of Vital Phenomena
Subtitle: A Novel
Summary: Set inside a small Chechen village during the Second Chechen War in 2004, this haunting debut threads together the lives of three central figures—a retreating neighbor-turned-doctor Akhmed, an eight-year-old girl named Havaa, and a lone surgeon named Sonja—over five days, weaving a “constellation” of resilience, trauma, and unexpected connection.
Refined_Long_Summary:
On the morning after the Feds burned down her house and took her father, eight-year-old Havaa wakes from dreams of sea anemones. Hidden in the woods, she watches the blaze until her neighbor Akhmed discovers her sitting in the snow.

Akhmed knows getting involved means risking his life. In a village where informers will do anything for a loaf of bread, there's no safe place to hide a child. But for reasons of his own, he sneaks her through the forest to an abandoned hospital where the sole remaining doctor, Sonja Rabina, treats the wounded.

Though Sonja protests that her hospital is not an orphanage, Akhmed convinces her to keep Havaa for a trial. Over five extraordinary days, Sonja's world shifts on its axis, revealing the intricate pattern of connections that weaves together the pasts of these three unlikely companions and unexpectedly decides their fate.

This is a majestic debut about love, loss, and the unexpected ties that bind us together in the most impossible circumstances.
Refined_Short_Summary: When eight-year-old Havaa's father is taken and her house burned, a neighbor risks everything to hide her with a doctor in an abandoned hospital. Over five days, their lives intertwine in this stunning debut about love surviving in wartime.
Refined_Bio: Anthony Marra is the New York Times bestselling author of The Tsar of Love and Techno and A Constellation of Vital Phenomena, winner of the National Book Critics Circle's John Leonard Prize and the Anisfield-Wolf Book Award, and longlisted for the National Book Award.
Formatted_Quotes:
"My favorite book of the year....Many people can write beautifully, but few manage to create a whole that is more valuable than the sum of its parts. Marra does this in spades. It is a brilliant book."

—Ann Patchett, New York Times bestselling author of Tom Lake, The Dutch House, Commonwealth & State of Wonder

"A Constellation of Vital Phenomena is ambitious and intellectually restless....[Marra is] a lover not a fighter, a prose writer who resembles the Joseph Heller of Catch-22 and the Jonathan Safran Foer of Everything Is Illuminated."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

"A flash in the heavens that makes you look up and believe in miracles....Here, in fresh, graceful prose, is a profound story that dares to be as tender as it is ghastly, a story about desperate lives in a remote land that will quickly seem impossibly close and important....I haven't been so overwhelmed by a novel in years. At the risk of raising your expectations too high, I have to say you simply must read this book."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post
Short_Summary: A story of the transcendent power of love in wartime, A Constellation of Vital Phenomena is a work of sweeping breadth, profound compassion, and lasting significance.
Long_Summary: Two doctors risk everything to save the life of a hunted child in this majestic debut about love, loss, and the unexpected ties that bind us together. “On the morning after the Feds burned down her house and took her father, Havaa woke from dreams of sea anemones.” Havaa, eight years old, hides in the woods and watches the blaze until her neighbor, Akhmed, discovers her sitting in the snow. Akhmed knows getting involved means risking his life, and there is no safe place to hide a child in a village where informers will do anything for a loaf of bread, but for reasons of his own, he sneaks her through the forest to the one place he thinks she might be safe: an abandoned hospital where the sole remaining doctor, Sonja Rabina, treats the wounded. Though Sonja protests that her hospital is not an orphanage, Akhmed convinces her to keep Havaa for a trial, and over the course of five extraordinary days, Sonja’s world will shift on its axis and reveal the intricate pattern of connections that weaves together the pasts of these three unlikely companions and unexpectedly decides their fate.
Copy_Bio: Anthony Marra is the New York Times bestselling author of The Tsar of Love and Techno and A Constellation of Vital Phenomena, winner of the National Book Critics Circle’s John Leonard Prize and the Anisfield-Wolf Book Award, and longlisted for the National Book Award.

Title: North Woods
Subtitle: A Novel
Summary: This genre-defying historical novel traces the centuries-spanning history of a single house nestled in New England’s north woods—from its founding by Puritan lovers to a shifting array of inhabitants, including soldiers, twins, reporters, and even wildlife—melding archival forms, natural history, and supernatural whispers into a richly interwoven meditation on memory and place
Refined_Long_Summary:
When two young lovers flee a Puritan colony, their humble cabin in the woods becomes home to an extraordinary succession of inhabitants across centuries. An English soldier abandons battlefield glory to devote himself to growing apples. Spinster twins navigate war, famine, envy, and desire. A crime reporter unearths an ancient mass grave, only to discover the earth refuses to give up its secrets.

A lovelorn painter, a sinister con man, a stalking panther, a lusty beetle—as each inhabitant confronts the wonder and mystery around them, they begin to realize the dark, raucous, beautiful past is very much alive. This inventive novel from Pulitzer Prize finalist Daniel Mason brims with love and madness, humor and hope.

Following the cycles of history, nature, and language itself, North Woods reveals the magical ways we're connected to our environment, to history, and to one another. More than an unforgettable story about secrets and destinies, it asks the timeless question: How do we live on, even after we're gone?
Refined_Short_Summary: Centuries of inhabitants—from Puritan lovers to modern crime reporters—call one New England house home in this genre-bending masterpiece. Mason weaves together their stories with breathtaking skill, creating something truly magical about connection and legacy.
Refined_Bio: Daniel Mason is the author of The Piano Tuner, A Far Country, The Winter Soldier, and A Registry of My Passage Upon the Earth, which was a Pulitzer Prize finalist. His work has been translated into twenty-eight languages and adapted for opera and stage. He's received a Guggenheim Fellowship, the Joyce Carol Oates Prize, a California Book Award, an O. Henry Prize, and a National Endowment for the Arts Fellowship. He's an assistant professor in Stanford University's psychiatry department.
Formatted_Quotes:
"North Woods is a monumental achievement of polyphony and humanity . . . I loved it."

—Maggie O'Farrell, New York Times bestselling author of Hamnet

"North Woods is the most original and spellbinding novel I've read in ages. Mason makes bramble, brush, and orchard come alive with the spirits of their unforgettable former inhabitants. Their lives . . . had me glued to my seat."

—Abraham Verghese, New York Times bestselling author of The Covenant of Water

"Each arc is beautifully, heartbreakingly conveyed, stitching together subtle connections across time. This astonishes."

—Publishers Weekly
Short_Summary: A sweeping novel about a single house in the woods of New England, told through the lives of those who inhabit it across the centuries—“a time-spanning, genre-blurring work of storytelling magic” (The Washington Post) from the Pulitzer Prize finalist and author of The Piano Tuner and The Winter Soldier.
Long_Summary:
When two young lovers abscond from a Puritan colony, little do they know that their humble cabin in the woods will become the home of an extraordinary succession of human and nonhuman characters alike. An English soldier, destined for glory, abandons the battlefields of the New World to devote himself to growing apples. A pair of spinster twins navigate war and famine, envy and desire. A crime reporter unearths an ancient mass grave—only to discover that the earth refuse to give up their secrets. A lovelorn painter, a sinister con man, a stalking panther, a lusty beetle: As the inhabitants confront the wonder and mystery around them, they begin to realize that the dark, raucous, beautiful past is very much alive.

This magisterial and highly inventive novel from Pulitzer Prize finalist Daniel Mason brims with love and madness, humor and hope. Following the cycles of history, nature, and even language, North Woods shows the myriad, magical ways in which we’re connected to our environment, to history, and to one another. It is not just an unforgettable novel about secrets and destinies, but a way of looking at the world that asks the timeless question: How do we live on, even after we’re gone?

Title: My Friends
Subtitle: A Novel
Summary: In London, a Libyan exile reflects on his youth and the friendships that shaped him, haunted by love, loss, and the weight of political violence. Matar’s prose is spare yet deeply moving, an elegiac exploration of intimacy, memory, and the search for belonging.
Refined_Long_Summary:
One evening in Benghazi, young Khaled hears a bizarre short story on the radio about a man being eaten alive by a cat. The words change him forever, sparking an obsession with their enigmatic author, Hosam Zowa, that will reshape his entire life.

This obsession leads Khaled far from Libya to pursue his education at the University of Edinburgh. Thrust into an open society vastly different from his homeland, he begins to transform. But when he attends a protest against the Qaddafi regime in London, tragedy strikes. In a flash, Khaled finds himself injured, clinging to life, unable to leave Britain or return home. Even telling his parents what he's done would expose them to danger on Libya's tapped phone lines.

A chance hotel encounter brings Khaled face-to-face with Hosam Zowa himself, leading to the deepest friendship of his life. This bond sustains him through years of exile, but as the Arab Spring erupts, it forces him to confront agonizing choices between revolution and safety, family and exile, and how to define himself against those he loves most.
Refined_Short_Summary: When a radio story changes young Khaled's life forever, his literary obsession leads him from Libya to exile in Britain. A devastating meditation on friendship and belonging that captures the impossible choices of displacement.
Refined_Bio: Hisham Matar was born in New York City to Libyan parents, spent his childhood in Tripoli and Cairo, and has lived most of his life in London. His memoir The Return won the 2017 Pulitzer Prize, the PEN/Jean Stein Book Award, and the Rathbones Folio Prize. His novel In the Country of Men was shortlisted for the Booker Prize. He's also the author of Anatomy of a Disappearance and A Month in Siena. Matar is a professor at Barnard College and Columbia University, a fellow of the Royal Society of Literature, and an honorary fellow of the Royal Academy of Arts.
Formatted_Quotes:
"Dazzling . . . a personal, deeply felt work . . . tightly structured and controlled, looping back and forth through time and memory, building on itself in a process of gradual expansion and revelation."

—Toronto Star

"Matar channels Roberto Bolaño's theme of literary obsession in this sublime novel of a Libyan exile in London whose two friends return to Libya in 2011 to take part in the overthrow of Gadhafi. As the narrator describes his quest to understand life through literature, the novel's sense of truthfulness and urgency restores the reader's belief in what fiction can do."

—Publishers Weekly

"Riveting and humane . . . At the core of My Friends is a powerful juxtaposition of loneliness and camaraderie, self-reliance and dependence, which defines the outline of exile. . . ."

—The Atlantic
Short_Summary: A “masterly” (The New York Times, Editors’ Choice), “riveting” (The Atlantic) novel of friendship, family, and the unthinkable realities of exile, from the Pulitzer Prize–winning author of The Return
Long_Summary:
One evening, as a young boy growing up in Benghazi, Khaled hears a bizarre short story read aloud on the radio, about a man being eaten alive by a cat, and has the sense that his life has been changed forever. Obsessed by the power of those words—and by their enigmatic author, Hosam Zowa—Khaled eventually embarks on a journey that will take him far from home, to pursue a life of the mind at the University of Edinburgh.

There, thrust into an open society that is miles away from the world he knew in Libya, Khaled begins to change. He attends a protest against the Qaddafi regime in London, only to watch it explode into tragedy. In a flash, Khaled finds himself injured, clinging to life, unable to leave Britain, much less return to the country of his birth. To even tell his mother and father back home what he has done, on tapped phone lines, would expose them to danger.

When a chance encounter in a hotel brings Khaled face-to-face with Hosam Zowa, the author of the fateful short story, he is subsumed into the deepest friendship of his life. It is a friendship that not only sustains him but eventually forces him, as the Arab Spring erupts, to confront agonizing tensions between revolution and safety, family and exile, and how to define his own sense of self against those closest to him.

A devastating meditation on friendship and family, and the ways in which time tests—and frays—those bonds, My Friends is an achingly beautiful work of literature by an author working at the peak of his powers.

Title: The Return
Subtitle: Fathers, Sons and the Land in Between
Summary: Matar’s memoir of searching for his disappeared father in Libya is a moving meditation on family, exile, and political violence.
Refined_Long_Summary:
In 2012, after Qaddafi's overthrow, acclaimed novelist Hisham Matar returns to his native Libya after thirty years in exile. His journey is both a homecoming and a search for answers about his father's fate.

When Matar was eight, his family fled Libya for political reasons. Eight years later, his father—a former diplomat turned dissident—was kidnapped from Cairo's streets by Libyan agents and disappeared into the regime's most notorious prison.

Now the prisons stand empty, and little hope remains that Jaballah Matar survived. Yet as his son discovers, hope proves "persistent and cunning." What emerges is a deeply moving family memoir that captures both personal loss and a nation's trauma. Matar paints a brilliant portrait of Libya and its people at a moment of profound transformation, while exploring the devastating legacy of absolute power and the enduring bonds between father and son.
Refined_Short_Summary: When Libya's prisons opened after Qaddafi's fall, Hisham Matar returned home after thirty years to search for his disappeared father. A devastating memoir about family, loss, and hope that reads like a thriller while breaking your heart.
Refined_Bio: Hisham Matar was born in New York City to Libyan parents and spent his childhood in Tripoli and Cairo. His memoir The Return won the 2017 Pulitzer Prize, the PEN/Jean Stein Book Award, and the Rathbones Folio Prize, and was shortlisted for the Booker Prize. His novels include In the Country of Men and Anatomy of a Disappearance. He teaches at Barnard College and Columbia University and is a fellow of the Royal Society of Literature.
Formatted_Quotes:
"[Hisham Matar] writes with both a novelist's eye for physical and emotional detail, and a reporter's tactile sense of place and time. The prose is precise, economical, chiseled; the narrative elliptical, almost musical…. The Return is, at once, a suspenseful detective story about a writer investigating his father's fate at the hands of a brutal dictatorship, and a son's efforts to come to terms with his father's ghost, who has haunted more than half his life by his absence."

—Michiko Kakutani, The New York Times

"A moving, unflinching memoir of a family torn apart by the savage realities of today's Middle East. The crushing of hopes raised by the Arab spring—at both the personal and national levels—is conveyed all the more powerfully because Matar's anger remains controlled, his belief in humanity undimmed."

—Kazuo Ishiguro, "The Best Summer Books," The Guardian

"What a brilliant book. Hisham Matar has the quality all historians—of the world and the self—most need: He knows how to stand back and let the past speak. In chronicling his quest for his father, his manner is fastidious, even detached, but his anger is raw and unreconciled; through his narrative art he bodies out the shape of loss and gives a universality to his very particular experience of desolation. The Return reads as easily as a thriller, but is a story that will stick: A person is lost, but gravity and resonance remain."

—Hilary Mantel, author of Wolf Hall & Bring Up the Bodies
Short_Summary: From Man Booker Prize and National Book Critics Circle Award finalist Hisham Matar, a memoir of his journey home to his native Libya in search of answers to his father’s disappearance.
Long_Summary:
In 2012, after the overthrow of Qaddafi, the acclaimed novelist Hisham Matar journeys to his native Libya after an absence of thirty years.

When he was eight, Matar and his family went into political exile. Eight years later Matar’s father, a former diplomat and military man turned brave dissident, was kidnapped from the streets of Cairo by the Libyan government and is believed to have been held in the regime’s most notorious prison.

Now, the prisons are empty and little hope remains that Jaballah Matar will be found alive. Yet, as the author writes, hope is “persistent and cunning.”

This book is a profoundly moving family memoir, a brilliant and affecting portrait of a country and a people on the cusp of immense change, and a disturbing and timeless depiction of the monstrous nature of absolute power.

Title: Dark Money
Subtitle: The Hidden History of the Billionaires Behind the Rise of the Radical Right
BISAC_Category_Description: Political Science / Political Process / Campaigns & Elections
Summary: Mayer investigates the powerful network of wealthy conservatives shaping American politics, exposing the influence of dark money in democracy.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Dark Money exposes how a network of ultra-wealthy libertarian donors—led by Charles and David Koch—secretly reshaped American politics through billions in strategic funding. Jane Mayer reveals how this shadow network bankrolled think tanks, academic programs, legal cases, and political movements to block environmental reforms, weaken labor protections, and tilt tax laws in their favor.

Through five years of meticulous reporting and hundreds of interviews, Mayer uncovers how this hidden web of influence transformed fringe libertarian ideas into mainstream political power, ultimately creating a new American oligarchy that operates largely in the shadows.

Urgent and gripping, Dark Money reads like a political thriller while delivering the hard-hitting journalism essential for understanding modern American democracy. This is must-read reporting for anyone concerned about inequality, the erosion of democratic norms, and the future of the United States.
Refined_Short_Summary: Follow the money trail behind America's political transformation. Mayer's explosive investigation reveals how billionaire donors secretly built a shadow network to reshape democracy. Essential reading for anyone who loved Democracy in Chains or wants to understand modern politics.
Refined_Bio: Jane Mayer is a staff writer for The New Yorker and author of four acclaimed works of narrative nonfiction. She co-authored Landslide: The Unmaking of the President, 1984–1988 and Strange Justice: The Selling of Clarence Thomas, a National Book Award finalist. The Dark Side was named one of The New York Times's Top 10 Books and won the J. Anthony Lukas Book Prize and Goldsmith Book Prize. Dark Money, a New York Times bestseller, also earned Top 10 recognition and the New York Public Library's Helen Bernstein Book Award.
Formatted_Quotes:
"Jane Mayer's Dark Money is utterly brilliant and chilling — no matter how much you think you already know. . . . Read it!"

—Naomi Klein, bestselling author of Doppelganger: A Trip into the Mirror World, The Shock Doctrine: The Rise of Disaster Capitalism & This Changes Everything: Capitalism vs the Climate

"Revelatory. . .persuasive, timely and necessary. . . . Only the most thoroughly documented, compendious account could do justice to the Kochs' bizarre and Byzantine family history and the scale and scope of their influence."

—The New York Times

"Mayer is. . . a writer whose reporting can leave a reader breathless. . . . I urge you to read Dark Money."

—Bill Moyers

Title: How Beautiful We Were
Subtitle: A Novel
Summary: In a small African village under the shadow of foreign oil companies, one community’s decision to resist environmental destruction sets off a sweeping confrontation with power. Mbue’s bold novel is at once intimate and epic, charting the costs of survival and the resilience of those who dare to fight.
Refined_Long_Summary:
In the fictional African village of Kosawa, an American oil company's environmental devastation has poisoned the land and water, killing children and destroying livelihoods. Pipeline spills render farmlands barren while corporate promises of cleanup and reparations go unfulfilled. The country's corrupt government serves only its own interests, leaving the villagers with no choice but to fight back.

Told through the eyes of a generation of children, particularly following Thula as she grows from a young girl into a revolutionary leader, this sweeping novel chronicles decades of resistance. The community's struggle against corporate greed and colonial legacies comes at an enormous cost, testing their determination to protect their ancestral home.

Mbue masterfully explores what happens when the reckless pursuit of profit collides with a community's fierce resolve to survive. This is a story of environmental justice, the weight of history, and one woman's willingness to sacrifice everything for her people's freedom.
Refined_Short_Summary: Environmental disaster meets fierce resistance in this sweeping tale of a young woman who becomes a revolutionary fighting an American oil company destroying her African village. Fans of Homegoing and Americanah will be captivated by this powerful story of community and courage.
Refined_Bio: Imbolo Mbue is the author of the New York Times bestseller Behold the Dreamers, which won the PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction and the Blue Metropolis Words to Change Prize and was an Oprah's Book Club selection. The novel was named a notable book by The New York Times and The Washington Post, translated into eleven languages, and adapted into an opera and stage play. A native of Limbe, Cameroon, and graduate of Rutgers and Columbia Universities, she lives in New York City.
Formatted_Quotes:
"Sweeping and quietly devastating . . . How Beautiful We Were charts the ways repression, be it at the hands of a government or a corporation or a society, can turn the most basic human needs into radical and radicalizing acts. . . . Profoundly affecting."

—The New York Times

"Among the many virtues of Mbue's novel is the way it uses an ecological nightmare to frame a vivid and stirring picture of human beings' asserting their value to the world, whether the world cares about them or not. One can both grieve for Kosawa and be inspired by its determined fight for life."

—Kirkus

"Imbolo Mbue has given us a novel with the richness and power of a great contemporary fable, and a heroine for our time."

—Sigrid Nunez, author of The Friend, winner of the National Book Award
Short_Summary: A fearless young woman from a small African village starts a revolution against an American oil company in this sweeping, inspiring novel from the New York Times bestselling author of Behold the Dreamers.
Long_Summary:
We should have known the end was near. So begins Imbolo Mbue’s powerful second novel, How Beautiful We Were. Set in the fictional African village of Kosawa, it tells of a people living in fear amid environmental degradation wrought by an American oil company. Pipeline spills have rendered farmlands infertile. Children are dying from drinking toxic water. Promises of cleanup and financial reparations to the villagers are made—and ignored. The country’s government, led by a brazen dictator, exists to serve its own interests. Left with few choices, the people of Kosawa decide to fight back. Their struggle will last for decades and come at a steep price.
 
Told from the perspective of a generation of children and the family of a girl named Thula who grows up to become a revolutionary, How Beautiful We Were is a masterful exploration of what happens when the reckless drive for profit, coupled with the ghost of colonialism, comes up against one community’s determination to hold on to its ancestral land and a young woman’s willingness to sacrifice everything for the sake of her people’s freedom.
Copy_Bio: Imbolo Mbue is the author of the New York Times bestseller Behold the Dreamers, which won the PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction and the Blue Metropolis Words to Change Prize and was an Oprah’s Book Club selection. A native of Limbe, Cameroon, and a graduate of Rutgers and Columbia Universities, Mbue lives in New York City.

Title: Deacon King Kong
Subtitle: A Novel
Summary: In 1969 Brooklyn, a boisterous church congregation finds its fate bound up with a mysterious old man who sells homemade moonshine. McBride delivers a raucous, big-hearted portrait of community, faith, and forgiveness, bursting with humor and soul.
Refined_Long_Summary:
In September 1969, a fumbling, cranky old church deacon known as Sportcoat shuffles into the courtyard of the Cause Houses housing project in south Brooklyn, pulls a .38 from his pocket, and shoots the project's drug dealer at point-blank range in front of everybody.

This desperate burst of violence sets off a chain reaction that ripples through the community in James McBride's funny, moving follow-up to his National Book Award-winning The Good Lord Bird. McBride brings to vivid life everyone affected by the shooting: the victim, the African-American and Latinx residents who witnessed it, the white neighbors, the local cops investigating, the members of Five Ends Baptist Church where Sportcoat served as deacon, the neighborhood's Italian mobsters, and the enigmatic Sportcoat himself.

As the story unfolds, the lives of these characters—caught in the tumultuous swirl of 1960s New York—overlap in unexpected ways. When truth finally emerges, McBride reveals that not all secrets are meant to stay hidden, that growth comes from facing change without fear, and that love's seeds lie in hope and compassion. Told with masterful insight and wit, this novel demonstrates that faith and humanity live in all of us.
Refined_Short_Summary: When a church deacon shoots a drug dealer in 1969 Brooklyn, the incident unleashes secrets that bind together an entire community. McBride's latest is a sprawling, soulful ensemble piece perfect for fans of Colson Whitehead.

A National Humanities Medal recipient and accomplished musician, McBride is distinguished writer in residence at New York University.

Title_Subtitle: The Good Lord Bird (National Book Award Winner)
Title: The Good Lord Bird
Subtitle: A Novel
Summary: This daring historical picaresque reimagines the life of John Brown’s young companion, a formerly enslaved boy named Henry “Onion” Shackleford. Both irreverent and profound, the novel reckons with race, freedom, and faith while galloping through one of the most turbulent eras in American history.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Henry Shackleford is a young slave living in the Kansas Territory in 1856—a battleground between anti- and pro-slavery forces—when legendary abolitionist John Brown arrives. When an argument between Brown and Henry's master turns violent, Henry is forced to leave town along with Brown, who believes Henry to be a girl and his good luck charm.

Over the ensuing months, Henry, whom Brown nicknames Little Onion, conceals his true identity to stay alive. Eventually Brown sweeps him into the historic raid on Harpers Ferry in 1859—one of the great catalysts for the Civil War.

An absorbing mixture of history and imagination, told with McBride's meticulous eye for detail and character, The Good Lord Bird is both a rousing adventure and a moving exploration of identity and survival.
Refined_Short_Summary: When a young enslaved boy gets swept up in John Brown's antislavery crusade, he must disguise himself as a girl to survive. This National Book Award winner brilliantly reimagines the events leading to Harpers Ferry with humor and heart.

A National Humanities Medal recipient and accomplished musician, he's a distinguished writer in residence at New York University.

Title: The Heaven & Earth Grocery Store
Subtitle: A Novel
Summary: In 1970s Pottstown, Pennsylvania, a dilapidated grocery store becomes the unlikely heart of a neighborhood, binding together Black, Jewish, and immigrant communities. McBride blends humor, suspense, and compassion in this sweeping story of love, survival, and justice.
Refined_Long_Summary:
In 1972, construction workers in Pottstown, Pennsylvania, make a grisly discovery: a skeleton at the bottom of a well. The truth behind this mystery lies buried in the secrets of Chicken Hill, a struggling neighborhood where immigrant Jews and African Americans lived side by side, sharing dreams and hardships.

At the heart of this community are Moshe and Chona Ludlow—he runs an integrated theater, she operates the Heaven & Earth Grocery Store. When the state threatens to institutionalize a deaf boy, Chona teams up with Nate Timblin, the Black janitor at Moshe's theater and unofficial leader of the Black community, to protect him.

As their interconnected stories unfold, McBride reveals the daily struggles of those living on society's margins and what they'll do to survive. When the devastating truth about Chicken Hill emerges—and the role the white establishment played—we see how love and community become lifelines in the darkest times.
Refined_Short_Summary: When a skeleton is discovered in small-town Pennsylvania, the mystery unravels decades of secrets from Chicken Hill, where Jewish immigrants and African Americans built an unlikely community. McBride delivers another masterpiece about resilience and hope.
Refined_Bio: James McBride is the author of the New York Times–bestselling The Heaven & Earth Grocery Store, Oprah's Book Club selection Deacon King Kong, National Book Award–winning The Good Lord Bird, the classic The Color of Water, novels Song Yet Sung and Miracle at St. Anna, story collection Five-Carat Soul, and Kill 'Em and Leave, a James Brown biography. A National Humanities Medal recipient and accomplished musician, McBride is distinguished writer in residence at New York University.
Formatted_Quotes:
"I keep thinking every time I read one of his books, 'That's his best book.' No. THIS is his best book."

—Ann Patchett, author of Tom Lake, Commonwealth & State of Wonder

"Classic McBride: He doesn't shy away from bold statements about the national catastrophes of race and xenophobia, and he always gives us a spoonful of sugar to help the medicine go down. The sugar is McBride's spitfire dialogue and murder-mystery-worthy plot machinations; his characters' big personalities and bigger storylines; his wisecracking, fast-talking humor; and prose so agile and exuberant that reading him is like being at a jazz jam session. . . . Reading McBride just feels good—we are comforted and entertained, and braced for the hard lessons he also delivers."

—The Atlantic

"The Heaven & Earth Grocery Store is one of the best novels I've read this year. It pulls off the singular magic trick of being simultaneously flattening and uplifting."

—NPR
Short_Summary: From James McBride, author of the bestselling Oprah’s Book Club pick Deacon King Kong and the National Book Award–winning The Good Lord Bird, a novel about small-town secrets and the people who keep them
Long_Summary:
In 1972, when workers in Pottstown, Pennsylvania, were digging the foundations for a new development, the last thing they expected to find was a skeleton at the bottom of a well. Who the skeleton was and how it got there were two of the long-held secrets kept by the residents of Chicken Hill, the dilapidated neighborhood where immigrant Jews and African Americans lived side by side and shared ambitions and sorrows. Chicken Hill was where Moshe and Chona Ludlow lived when Moshe integrated his theater and where Chona ran the Heaven & Earth Grocery Store. When the state came looking for a deaf boy to institutionalize him, it was Chona and Nate Timblin, the Black janitor at Moshe’s theater and the unofficial leader of the Black community on Chicken Hill, who worked together to keep the boy safe.

As these characters’ stories overlap and deepen, it becomes clear how much the people who live on the margins of white, Christian America struggle and what they must do to survive. When the truth is finally revealed about what happened on Chicken Hill and the part the town’s white establishment played in it, McBride shows us that even in dark times, it is love and community—heaven and earth—that sustain us.

Bringing his masterly storytelling skills and his deep faith in humanity to The Heaven & Earth Grocery Store, James McBride has written a novel as compassionate as Deacon King Kong and as inventive as The Good Lord Bird.
