Title_Subtitle: I Heard Her Call My Name
Title: I Heard Her Call My Name
Subtitle: A Memoir of Transition
Summary: Sante reflects on her gender transition and artistic life, offering a candid, lyrical memoir of identity and self-discovery.
Refined_Long_Summary:
For a long time, Lucy Sante felt unsure of her place. Born in Belgium to conservative working-class Catholic parents who transplanted their family to the United States, she only felt at home when she moved to New York City in the early 1970s and found her people among fellow bohemians. Some would die young from drugs and AIDS, others would become jarringly famous. Sante flirted with both fates while building an estimable career as a writer.

But she still felt like her life was a performance, presenting a facade even to herself.

Sante's memoir braids together two threads: the arc of her life and her recent step-by-step transition to a place of inner and outer alignment. She brings loving irony to her unsteady first steps—there was much she needed to learn about being a woman after sixty years cloaked in a man's identity, in a man's world. A marvel of grace and empathy, I Heard Her Call My Name parses with great sensitivity the complex issues of gender identity and far beyond.
Refined_Short_Summary: After decades as an acclaimed writer in New York's bohemian scene, Lucy Sante finally confronts the truth she'd been avoiding: her gender identity. A graceful, witty memoir about finding yourself later in life.
Refined_Bio: Lucy Sante is the author of Low Life, Evidence, The Factory of Facts, Kill All Your Darlings, Folk Photography, The Other Paris, Maybe the People Would Be the Times, and Nineteen Reservoirs. Her awards include a Whiting Writers Award, an Award in Literature from the American Academy of Arts and Letters, a Grammy Award, an Infinity Award from the International Center of Photography, and Guggenheim and Cullman Center fellowships. She recently retired after twenty-four years teaching at Bard College.
Formatted_Quotes:
"Reading this book is a joy. Sante is funny and warm . . . I Heard Her Call My Name has much to say about the trans journey and will undoubtedly become a standard for those in need of guidance. But the book speaks to a wider audience, too: for anyone who needs to break out of their self-imposed 'prison of denial,' as Sante puts it, or to stop punishing themselves for wanting what they want."

—The Washington Post

"Miraculous . . . With piercing insight and a formidable command of language, Sante molds the material into a trenchant self-portrait that's equal parts humorous (she wryly gives her coming-out email the subject line 'A Bombshell') and hard-nosed. This is a major achievement."

—Publishers Weekly

"I've admired the utter clarity and authority of Lucy Sante's work for years, and I was deeply moved by how she tunneled through the specificity of her experiences to create this vivid, encompassing, and compassionate book."

—Catherine Lacey, author of Biography of X
Short_Summary: An iconic writer’s lapidary memoir of a life spent pursuing a dream of artistic truth while evading the truth of her own gender identity until, finally, she turned to face who she really was
Long_Summary:
For a long time, Lucy Sante felt unsure of her place. Born in Belgium, the only child of conservative working-class Catholic parents who transplanted their little family to the United States, she felt at home only when she moved to New York City in the early 1970s and found her people among a band of fellow bohemians. Some would die young, from drugs and AIDS, and some would become jarringly famous. Sante flirted with both fates on her way to building an estimable career as a writer. But she still felt like her life was a performance. She was presenting a facade, even to herself.

Sante’s memoir braids together two threads of personal narrative: the arc of her life, and her recent step-by-step transition to a place of inner and outer alignment. Sante brings a loving irony to her account of her unsteady first steps; there was much she found she still needed to learn about being a woman after some sixty years cloaked in a man’s identity, in a man’s world. A marvel of grace and empathy, I Heard Her Call My Name parses with great sensitivity many issues that touch our lives deeply, of gender identity and far beyond.

Title: Tenth of December
Subtitle: Stories
Summary: A story collection that blends satire, surrealism, and deep empathy, portraying characters on the edge of despair and grace. Saunders balances wit and humanity in tales that are darkly comic and moving.
Refined_Long_Summary:
George Saunders returns with a masterful collection that showcases his literary powers at their peak. These stories demonstrate his core philosophy: "To me, the writer's main job is to make the story unscroll in such a way that the reader is snared—she's right there, seeing things happen and caring about them."

The title story delivers an exquisite, moving account of an unlikely intersection at a frozen lake—where a young misfit encounters a middle-aged cancer patient contemplating suicide, leading to an unexpected act of salvation. "Home" offers a tragicomic portrait of a soldier's return from war, while "Victory Lap" presents a taut, inventive thriller about an attempted abduction.

Throughout the collection, Saunders captures characters on the margins with his signature blend of humor and heartbreak. Each story pulses with humanity, revealing profound truths about connection, survival, and the strange beauty of ordinary American lives. This is Saunders at his absolute best—stories that add up to something deep, irreducible, and unforgettably moving.
Refined_Short_Summary: Saunders crafts unforgettable stories about misfits and survivors navigating modern American life with his signature blend of dark humor and profound heart. If you loved the emotional depth of A Swim in a Pond in the Rain, this collection is essential reading.
Refined_Bio: George Saunders is the author of thirteen books, including the novel Lincoln in the Bardo, which won the Man Booker Prize, and five story collections, including Tenth of December, a National Book Award finalist, and Liberation Day (selected by former President Obama as one of his ten favorite books of 2022). Three of his books—Pastoralia, Tenth of December, and Lincoln in the Bardo—were chosen for The New York Times's list of the 100 Best Books of the 21st Century. He hosts the popular Story Club on Substack and was named one of Time's 100 Most Influential People in 2013. He teaches creative writing at Syracuse University.
Formatted_Quotes:
"A visceral and moving act of storytelling…No one writes more powerfully than George Saunders about the lost, the unlucky, the disenfranchised."

—Michiko Kakutani, The New York Times

"Tenth of December shows George Saunders at his most subversive, hilarious, and emotionally piercing. Few writers can encompass that range of adjectives, but Saunders is a true original—restlessly inventive, yet deeply humane."

—Jennifer Egan, Pulitzer Prize–winning author of A Visit from the Goon Squad

"George Saunders is a complete original, unlike anyone else, thank god—and yet still he manages to be the rightful heir to three other complete American originals—Barthelme (the lyricism, the playfulness), Vonnegut (the outrage, the wit, the scope), and Twain (the common sense, the exasperation). There is no author I recommend to people more often—for ten years I've urged George Saunders onto everyone and everyone. You want funny? Saunders is your man. You want emotional heft? Saunders again. You want stories that are actually about something—stories that again and again get to the meat of matters of life and death and justice and country? Saunders. There is no one better, no one more essential to our national sense of self and sanity."

—Dave Eggers, author of A Hologram for the King

Long_Summary: George Saunders, one of our most important writers, is back with a masterful, deeply felt collection that takes his literary powers to a new level. In a recent interview, when asked how he saw the role of the writer, Saunders said: “To me, the writer’s main job is to make the story unscroll in such a way that the reader is snared—she’s right there, seeing things happen and caring about them. And if you dedicate yourself to this job, the meanings more or less take care of themselves.” In Tenth of December, the reader is always right there, and the meanings are beautiful and profound and abundant. The title story is an exquisite, moving account of the intersection, at a frozen lake in the woods, of a young misfit and a middle-aged cancer patient who goes there to commit suicide, only to end up saving the boy’s life. “Home” is the often funny, often poignant account of a soldier returning from the war. And “Victory Lap” is a taut, inventive story about the attempted abduction of a teenage girl. In all, Tenth of December is George Saunders at his absolute best, a collection of stories and characters that add up to something deep, irreducible, and uniquely American.

Title: Lincoln in the Bardo
Subtitle: A Novel
Summary: After the death of his young son, Abraham Lincoln visits his grave, where spirits linger in a liminal space. Saunders’ inventive novel blends history and the supernatural in a moving meditation on grief and compassion.
Refined_Long_Summary:
February 1862. President Lincoln's beloved eleven-year-old son Willie lies gravely ill in the White House. Despite predictions of recovery, Willie dies within days and is laid to rest in a Georgetown cemetery. Newspapers report that a grief-stricken Lincoln returns alone to the crypt to hold his boy's body.

From this seed of historical truth, George Saunders spins an unforgettable supernatural tale. Willie Lincoln finds himself in a strange purgatory where ghosts mingle, gripe, and enact bizarre acts of penance. Within this transitional state—called, in the Tibetan tradition, the bardo—a monumental struggle erupts over young Willie's soul.

Lincoln in the Bardo is a bold step forward from one of our most important writers. Formally daring and deeply concerned with matters of the heart, Saunders has invented a thrilling new form that deploys a kaleidoscopic, theatrical panorama of voices to ask a timeless question: How do we live and love when we know that everything we love must end?
Refined_Short_Summary: George Saunders reimagines Abraham Lincoln's grief after his son's death in this supernatural masterpiece set in a ghostly purgatory. Think The Midnight Library meets historical fiction, with Saunders's signature dark humor illuminating profound questions about love and loss.

Long_Summary:
February 1862. The Civil War is less than one year old. The fighting has begun in earnest, and the nation has begun to realize it is in for a long, bloody struggle. Meanwhile, President Lincoln’s beloved eleven-year-old son, Willie, lies upstairs in the White House, gravely ill. In a matter of days, despite predictions of a recovery, Willie dies and is laid to rest in a Georgetown cemetery. “My poor boy, he was too good for this earth,” the president says at the time. “God has called him home.” Newspapers report that a grief-stricken Lincoln returns, alone, to the crypt several times to hold his boy’s body.

From that seed of historical truth, George Saunders spins an unforgettable story of familial love and loss that breaks free of its realistic, historical framework into a supernatural realm both hilarious and terrifying. Willie Lincoln finds himself in a strange purgatory where ghosts mingle, gripe, commiserate, quarrel, and enact bizarre acts of penance. Within this transitional state—called, in the Tibetan tradition, the bardo—a monumental struggle erupts over young Willie’s soul.

Lincoln in the Bardo is an astonishing feat of imagination and a bold step forward from one of the most important and influential writers of his generation. Formally daring, generous in spirit, deeply concerned with matters of the heart, it is a testament to fiction’s ability to speak honestly and powerfully to the things that really matter to us. Saunders has invented a thrilling new form that deploys a kaleidoscopic, theatrical panorama of voices to ask a timeless, profound question: How do we live and love when we know that everything we love must end?

Title: Liberation Day
Subtitle: Stories
Summary: In this collection, Saunders turns his sharp eye to dystopian scenarios, office absurdities, and timeless questions of morality. With humor and pathos, he probes what it means to be human in fractured times.
Refined_Long_Summary:
The "best short-story writer in English" (Time) returns with a masterful collection that explores power, ethics, and justice, cutting to the heart of what it means to live in community with our fellow humans. With his trademark prose—wickedly funny, unsentimental, and exquisitely tuned—Saunders continues to challenge and surprise with stories that encompass joy and despair, oppression and revolution, bizarre fantasy and brutal reality.

"Love Letter" offers a tender missive from grandfather to grandson amid a dystopian future, reminding us of our obligations to our ideals and one another. "Ghoul" follows a lonely, morally complex character in a Hell-themed underground amusement park who questions everything about his reality. In "Mother's Day," two women who loved the same man reach an existential reckoning during a hailstorm.

Meanwhile, "Elliott Spencer" presents an eighty-nine-year-old victim of memory "scraping"—reprogrammed as a political protester in a scheme targeting the vulnerable. And "My House" confronts the haunting nature of unfulfilled dreams in just seven pages.

Together, these nine subversive, profound stories make a case for viewing the world with the same generosity and clear-eyed attention Saunders brings to even the most absurd circumstances.
Refined_Short_Summary: Nine brilliant stories that blend dystopian futures, moral complexity, and deep humanity from the Booker Prize winner. Perfect for fans of Jennifer Egan and readers who loved Lincoln in the Bardo's innovative storytelling.

He hosts the popular Story Club on Substack and teaches at Syracuse University.

—The San Francisco Chronicle

This, his first book of short fiction in nearly a decade, only cements the validity of such a point of view. The nine pieces here are smart and funny, speculative yet at the same time written on a human scale, narratives full of love and loss and longing and the necessity of trying to connect."

—Kirkus

Long_Summary:
The “best short-story writer in English” (Time) is back with a masterful collection that explores ideas of power, ethics, and justice and cuts to the very heart of what it means to live in community with our fellow humans. With his trademark prose—wickedly funny, unsentimental, and exquisitely tuned—Saunders continues to challenge and surprise: Here is a collection of prismatic, resonant stories that encompass joy and despair, oppression and revolution, bizarre fantasy and brutal reality.

“Love Letter” is a tender missive from grandfather to grandson, in the midst of a dystopian political situation in the (not too distant, all too believable) future, that reminds us of our obligations to our ideals, ourselves, and one another. “Ghoul” is set in a Hell-themed section of an underground amusement park in Colorado and follows the exploits of a lonely, morally complex character named Brian, who comes to question everything he takes for granted about his reality. In “Mother’s Day,” two women who loved the same man come to an existential reckoning in the middle of a hailstorm. In “Elliott Spencer,” our eighty-nine-year-old protagonist finds himself brainwashed, his memory “scraped”—a victim of a scheme in which poor, vulnerable people are reprogrammed and deployed as political protesters. And “My House”—in a mere seven pages—comes to terms with the haunting nature of unfulfilled dreams and the inevitability of decay.

Together, these nine subversive, profound, and essential stories coalesce into a case for viewing the world with the same generosity and clear-eyed attention Saunders does, even in the most absurd of circumstances.

Title: Unworthy Republic
Subtitle: The Dispossession of Native Americans and the Road to Indian Territory
Summary: Saunt examines the forced removal of Native Americans in the 19th century, showing how it reshaped the nation’s history and democracy.
Refined_Long_Summary:
In May 1830, the United States formally launched a policy to expel Native Americans from the East to territories west of the Mississippi River. Justified as a humanitarian enterprise, the undertaking was to be systematic and rational, overseen by Washington's small but growing bureaucracy. But as the policy unfolded over the next decade, thousands of Native Americans died under the federal government's auspices, and thousands of others lost their possessions and homelands in an orgy of fraud, intimidation, and violence.

Drawing on firsthand accounts and voluminous federal records, Saunt's deeply researched book reveals how Indian Removal became national policy and describes the chaotic, deadly results of deporting 80,000 men, women, and children. This was not an inevitable chapter in U.S. expansion—it was a fiercely contested political act designed to secure new lands for slavery's expansion and consolidate southern power.

Indigenous peoples fought relentlessly against the policy, while many U.S. citizens insisted it betrayed the nation's values. When Congress passed the act by a razor-thin margin, it authorized one of the first state-sponsored mass deportations in the modern era. Saunt shows how white supremacy, corruption, and administrative incompetence created this debacle—and how its consequences still resonate today.
Refined_Short_Summary: This unflinching examination of Indian Removal in the 1830s exposes how 80,000 Native Americans were forcibly deported in what became one of history's first state-sponsored mass deportations. Essential reading for understanding America's brutal foundations.
Refined_Bio: Claudio Saunt is the Richard B. Russell Professor in American History at the University of Georgia and author of award-winning books including A New Order of Things, Black, White, and Indian, and West of the Revolution. He lives in Athens, Georgia.
Formatted_Quotes:
"Unworthy Republic" is a powerful and lucid account, weaving together events with the people who experienced them up close.…Saunt has written an unflinching book that reckons with this history and its legacy."

—Jennifer Szalai, The New York Times

"Saunt presents a stark and well-documented case that Native American expulsion was a political choice rather than an inevitable tragedy. This searing account forces a new reckoning with American history."

—Publishers Weekly

"A significant, well-rendered study of a disturbing period in American history."

—Kirkus
Short_Summary: A masterful and unsettling history of “Indian Removal,” the forced migration of Native Americans across the Mississippi River in the 1830s and the state-sponsored theft of their lands.
Long_Summary:
In May 1830, the United States formally launched a policy to expel Native Americans from the East to territories west of the Mississippi River. Justified as a humanitarian enterprise, the undertaking was to be systematic and rational, overseen by Washington’s small but growing bureaucracy. But as the policy unfolded over the next decade, thousands of Native Americans died under the federal government’s auspices, and thousands of others lost their possessions and homelands in an orgy of fraud, intimidation, and violence. Unworthy Republic reveals how expulsion became national policy and describes the chaotic and deadly results of the operation to deport 80,000 men, women, and children.

Drawing on firsthand accounts and the voluminous records produced by the federal government, Saunt’s deeply researched book argues that Indian Removal, as advocates of the policy called it, was not an inevitable chapter in U.S. expansion across the continent. Rather, it was a fiercely contested political act designed to secure new lands for the expansion of slavery and to consolidate the power of the southern states. Indigenous peoples fought relentlessly against the policy, while many U.S. citizens insisted that it was a betrayal of the nation’s values. When Congress passed the act by a razor-thin margin, it authorized one of the first state-sponsored mass deportations in the modern era, marking a turning point for native peoples and for the United States.

In telling this gripping story, Saunt shows how the politics and economics of white supremacy lay at the heart of the expulsion of Native Americans; how corruption, greed, and administrative indifference and incompetence contributed to the debacle of its implementation; and how the consequences still resonate today.

Title: The Slip
Subtitle: A Novel
Refined_Long_Summary:
Austin, Texas, summer of 1998: Sixteen-year-old Nathaniel Rothstein has never felt comfortable in his own skin until he discovers Terry Tucker's Boxing Gym. Under the guidance of David Dalice, a swaggering Haitian-born ex-fighter, Nathaniel begins to transform. Even his slightly stoned uncle Bob, who's supposed to be watching him for the summer, notices the change—Nathaniel is happier, more confident, even tanner. Then one night, he vanishes without a trace.

Across the city, Charles Rex, now going by "X," undergoes his own teenage transformation. He trolls the phone sex hotline where his mother works, seeking an outlet for everything that feels wrong about his body, searching for intimacy and acceptance in a culture that denies him both. When an unlikely romance blooms, X glimpses the safety he's been desperately seeking.

More than a decade later, Bob receives a shocking tip that propels him to investigate his nephew's disappearance. His search pulls in gymgoers past and present, including down-on-their-luck twins, a rookie cop determined to prove herself, and Alexis Cepeda, a promising lightweight who crossed the US-Mexico border at fourteen carrying a license with the wrong name and face.

Bobbing and weaving across America's ever-shifting landscape, The Slip delivers an audacious examination of sex, race, and identity that builds to an unforgettable collision.
Refined_Short_Summary: When a teenage boxer vanishes from an Austin gym in 1998, his uncle's investigation a decade later uncovers a web of fluid identities and hidden lives. This ambitious debut tackles sex, race, and transformation with the scope of Franzen and the heart of Friday Night Lights.
Refined_Bio: Lucas Schaefer lives with his family in Austin. The Slip is his first novel.
Formatted_Quotes:
"Schaefer's narration is wildly, transgressively hilarious, reminiscent of Philip Roth's early novels...This is a high-wire act, but the breadth of Schaefer's affection feels as wide as the depth of his comedy."

—The Washington Post

"Quite simply, The Slip is everything an epic novel should be, everything you want an epic novel to be: symphonic, expansive, irresistibly engrossing, utterly unpredictable. It is immense in ambition, bursting with language, dauntless in scope and imagination; an ode to the infinite crossroads of life that lead each soul to its present moment. That this is a debut staggers me."

—Téa Obreht, New York Times bestselling author of The Tiger's Wife

"Wildly ambitious and immensely rewarding...Schaefer grants depths of vulnerability to even the novel's least sympathetic characters...Suffice it to say, you're unlikely to read a more impressive first novel this year."

—The New York Times
Short_Summary: For readers of Jonathan Franzen and Nathan Hill comes a haymaker of an American novel about a missing teenage boy, cases of fluid and mistaken identity, and the transformative power of boxing.
Long_Summary:
Austin, Texas: It’s the summer of 1998, and there’s a new face on the scene at Terry Tucker’s Boxing Gym. Sixteen-year-old Nathaniel Rothstein has never felt comfortable in his own skin, but under the tutelage of a swaggering, Haitian-born ex-fighter named David Dalice, he begins to come into his own. Even the boy’s slightly stoned uncle, Bob Alexander, who is supposed to be watching him for the summer, notices the change. Nathaniel is happier, more confident—tanner, even. Then one night he vanishes, leaving little trace behind.

Across the city, Charles Rex, now going simply by “X,” has been undergoing a teenage transformation of his own, trolling the phone sex hotline that his mother works, seeking an outlet for everything that feels wrong about his body, looking for intimacy and acceptance in a culture that denies him both. As a surprising and unlikely romance blooms, X feels, for a moment, like he might have found the safety he’s been searching for. But it's never that simple.

More than a decade later, Nathaniel’s uncle Bob receives a shocking tip, propelling him to open his own investigation into his nephew’s disappearance. The resulting search involves gymgoers past and present, including a down-on-his-luck twin and his opportunistic brother; a rookie cop determined to prove herself; and Alexis Cepeda, a promising lightweight, who crossed the US-Mexico border when he was only fourteen, carrying with him a license bearing the wrong name and face.

Bobbing and weaving across the ever-shifting canvas of a changing country, The Slip is an audacious, daring look at sex and race in America that builds to an unforgettable collision in the center of the ring.

Title: Cleopatra
Subtitle: A Life
Summary: Schiff reclaims Cleopatra from centuries of myth, presenting a portrait of the brilliant, politically savvy, and charismatic queen of Egypt.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Her palace shimmered with onyx, garnets, and gold, but was richer still in political and sexual intrigue. Above all else, Cleopatra was a shrewd strategist and an ingenious negotiator.

Though her life spanned fewer than forty years, it reshaped the contours of the ancient world. She was married twice, each time to a brother. She waged a brutal civil war against the first when both were teenagers. She poisoned the second. Ultimately she dispensed with an ambitious sister as well; incest and assassination were family specialties.

Cleopatra appears to have had relationships with only two men—but they happened to be Julius Caesar and Mark Antony, among the most prominent Romans of the day. Both were married to other women. She had a child with Caesar and three more with his protégé after Caesar's murder. Already the wealthiest ruler in the Mediterranean, her alliance with Antony confirmed her status as the most influential woman of the age.

Famous long before she was notorious, Cleopatra has gone down in history for all the wrong reasons. In a masterly return to classical sources, Stacy Schiff boldly separates fact from fiction to rescue the magnetic queen whose death ushered in a new world order.
Refined_Short_Summary: Pulitzer Prize-winning Stacy Schiff strips away centuries of myth to reveal the real Cleopatra—brilliant strategist, shrewd negotiator, and history's most misunderstood ruler. Perfect for readers who devoured Madeline Miller's Circe.
Refined_Bio: Stacy Schiff is the author of Véra (Mrs. Vladimir Nabokov), winner of the Pulitzer Prize; Saint-Exupéry, a Pulitzer Prize finalist; A Great Improvisation: Franklin, France, and the Birth of America, winner of the George Washington Book Prize; Cleopatra: A Life, winner of the PEN/Jacqueline Bograd Weld Award; and The Witches: Salem, 1692. She has received fellowships from the Guggenheim Foundation and the National Endowment for the Humanities, and is a member of the American Academy of Arts and Letters.
Formatted_Quotes:
"Stacy Schiff does a rare thing: She gives us a book we'd miss if it didn't exist."

—Wall Street Journal

"A masterpiece."

—Daily Beast
Short_Summary: The Pulitzer Prize-winning biographer brings to life the most intriguing woman in the history of the world: Cleopatra, the last queen of Egypt.
Long_Summary:
Her palace shimmered with onyx, garnets, and gold, but was richer still in political and sexual intrigue. Above all else, Cleopatra was a shrewd strategist and an ingenious negotiator.

Though her life spanned fewer than forty years, it reshaped the contours of the ancient world. She was married twice, each time to a brother. She waged a brutal civil war against the first when both were teenagers. She poisoned the second. Ultimately she dispensed with an ambitious sister as well; incest and assassination were family specialties. Cleopatra appears to have had sex with only two men. They happen, however, to have been Julius Caesar and Mark Antony, among the most prominent Romans of the day. Both were married to other women. Cleopatra had a child with Caesar and -- after his murder -- three more with his protégé. Already she was the wealthiest ruler in the Mediterranean; the relationship with Antony confirmed her status as the most influential woman of the age. The two would together attempt to forge a new empire, in an alliance that spelled their ends. Cleopatra has lodged herself in our imaginations ever since.

Famous long before she was notorious, Cleopatra has gone down in history for all the wrong reasons. Shakespeare and Shaw put words in her mouth. Michelangelo, Tiepolo, and Elizabeth Taylor put a face to her name. Along the way, Cleopatra's supple personality and the drama of her circumstances have been lost. In a masterly return to the classical sources, Stacy Schiff here boldly separates fact from fiction to rescue the magnetic queen whose death ushered in a new world order. Rich in detail, epic in scope, Schiff 's is a luminous, deeply original reconstruction of a dazzling life.
Copy_Bio: Stacy Schiff is the author of Véra (Mrs. Vladimir Nabokov), winner of the Pulitzer Prize; Saint-Exupéry, a Pulitzer Prize finalist; A Great Improvisation: Franklin, France, and the Birth of America, winner of the George Washington Book Prize and the Ambassador Book Award; Cleopatra: A Life, winner of the PEN/Jacqueline Bograd Weld Award for biography; and most recently, The Witches:Salem, 1692. Schiff has received fellowships from the Guggenheim Foundation, the National Endowment for the Humanities, the American Academy of Arts and Letters, and the Center for Scholars and Writers at the New York Public Library. A member of the American Academy of Arts and Letters, she lives in New York City.

Title: Command and Control
Subtitle: Nuclear Weapons, the Damascus Accident, and the Illusion of Safety
Summary: Schlosser investigates the history and danger of America’s nuclear arsenal, weaving gripping narrative with chilling detail.
Refined_Long_Summary:
In Command and Control, acclaimed journalist Eric Schlosser uncovers the hidden history of America's nuclear arsenal—its accidents, near-misses, technological breakthroughs, and moments of extraordinary heroism. At the heart of the book is the dramatic story of a missile silo accident in rural Arkansas, interwoven with a gripping account of how, for more than fifty years, scientists, policymakers, and servicemen have struggled to prevent nuclear catastrophe.

Drawing on declassified documents and first-hand interviews, Schlosser reveals how human error and technological complexity continue to make nuclear weapons both indispensable and terrifyingly uncontrollable. Audacious and unforgettable, Command and Control reads like a thriller even as it lays bare the gravest risk of the nuclear age.
Refined_Short_Summary: Declassified documents and gripping interviews reveal the terrifying reality behind America's nuclear arsenal. This investigation into near-misses and accidents reads like a thriller while exposing our most dangerous secrets.
Refined_Bio: Eric Schlosser is a correspondent for The Atlantic. His work has appeared in Rolling Stone, Vanity Fair, The Nation, and The New Yorker. He has received a National Magazine Award and a Sidney Hillman Foundation Award for reporting.
Formatted_Quotes:
"Schlosser's book reads like a thriller, but it's masterfully even-handed, well researched, and well organised. Either he's a natural genius at integrating massive amounts of complex information, or he worked like a dog to write this book. You wouldn't think the prospect of nuclear apocalypse would make for a reading treat, but in Schlosser's hands it does."

—Jonathan Franzen, The Guardian

"Nail-biting... thrilling... Mixing expert commentary with hair-raising details of a variety of mishaps, [Eric Schlosser] makes the convincing case that our best control systems are no match for human error, bad luck, and ever-increasing technological complexity."

—Publishers Weekly

"Vivid and unsettling... An exhaustive, unnerving examination of the illusory safety of atomic arms."

—Kirkus

Title_Subtitle: The End of Your Life Book Club
Title: The End of Your Life Book Club
Summary: Schwalbe’s moving memoir recounts the books he shared with his mother as she faced terminal cancer, celebrating reading, love, and family.
Refined_Long_Summary:
In The End of Your Life Book Club, Will Schwalbe tells the inspiring true story of how he and his mother, Mary Anne, created a "book club" as she faced a terminal cancer diagnosis.

Over two years of reading together, their conversations moved from classics to mysteries to poetry, touching on questions of faith, courage, gratitude, and the meaning of life. Through their shared love of literature, they discovered new ways to connect and communicate during an impossibly difficult time.

More than a memoir of illness, this is a moving celebration of books, family, and the power of stories to comfort, connect, and illuminate even in the face of loss. Schwalbe shows how reading together became both refuge and revelation, proving that books can be our greatest companions when we need them most.
Refined_Short_Summary: Through books ranging from classics to mysteries, a son and his dying mother forge deeper connections during her final years. This tender memoir proves literature's power to heal and unite us when everything else falls apart.
Refined_Bio: Will Schwalbe has worked in book publishing as an editor at Macmillan, in digital media, and as a journalist for The New York Times and South China Morning Post. He's the author of Books for Living, The End of Your Life Book Club, and coauthor of Send with David Shipley. He lives in New York.
Formatted_Quotes:
"With a refreshing forthrightness, and an excellent list of books included, this is an astonishing, pertinent, and wonderfully welcome work."

—Publishers Weekly

"Will Schwalbe gives us two love stories in one: that of his relationship with his dynamo of a mother as her horizons shrink, and that of their mutual devotion to the printed word, infinitely and insistently engaging. Tender and touching and beautifully done."

—Stacy Schiff, author of Cleopatra

"In a heartfelt tribute to his mother, Schwalbe illustrates the power of the written word to expand our knowledge of ourselves and others."

—Kirkus

Title: One of Us
Subtitle: The Story of Anders Breivik and the Massacre in Norway
Summary: Seierstad investigates the life of Anders Breivik and the 2011 Norway massacre, blending reportage and narrative in a chilling account.
Refined_Long_Summary:
On July 22, 2011, Anders Behring Breivik detonated a bomb outside government buildings in central Oslo, killing eight people. He then proceeded to a youth camp on the island of Utøya, where he killed sixty-nine more, most of them teenage members of Norway's governing Labour Party.

In One of Us, journalist Åsne Seierstad tells the story of this terrible day and what led up to it. What made Breivik, a gifted child from an affluent Oslo neighborhood, become a terrorist? Seierstad excels at vivid portraiture of lives under stress, delving deep into Breivik's troubled childhood and showing how a hip-hop and graffiti aficionado became a right-wing activist and Internet game addict, then an entrepreneur, Freemason, and self-styled master warrior who sought to "save Norway" from Islam and multiculturalism.

She writes with equal intimacy about Breivik's victims, tracing their political awakenings, aspirations to improve their country, and ill-fated journeys to the island. By the time Seierstad reaches Utøya, we know both the killer and those he will kill—and an entire country, famously peaceful and prosperous, utterly incapable of protecting its youth.
Refined_Short_Summary: This devastating true crime investigation examines the 2011 Norway attacks through both the killer's radicalization and his victims' stories. Essential reading for anyone trying to understand how extremism takes root in modern society.
Refined_Bio: Åsne Seierstad has worked as a correspondent since 1993, writing seven books and receiving numerous journalism awards. The Bookseller of Kabul was translated into over 40 languages. One of Us was selected as one of the ten best books of 2015 by the New York Times and awarded the 2018 Leipzig Book Award for European Understanding. Her latest work, Two Sisters, received the Brage Prize in Norway.
Formatted_Quotes:
"Asne Seierstad's One of Us is almost unbearable to read and absolutely impossible to turn away from: its account of an unthinkable tragedy is reported with staggering rigor and recounted with grace. It's hard to leave this book without feeling incredible grief, without feeling shaken to the core, without feeling urged toward essential questions about what we call evil and how it comes to pass."

―Leslie Jamison, author of The Empathy Exams

"Engrossing, important . . . There are many, many indelible images in Seierstad's account . . . As hard as it is to read about the attack, as frustrating as it is to learn how many delaying mistakes the first responders made and as monstrous as Breivik is, [his victims] on that island that day were beautiful in their idealism. They deserve to be witnessed, which is the ultimate reason to read One of Us."

―Maureen Corrigan, NPR

"The roughly 70 pages Ms. Seierstad devotes to [the attacks] are harrowing in their forensic exactitude . . . These scenes are balanced by moments of tremendous heroism, and I'd be lying if I said I didn't read the final half of One of Us with perpetually moist cheeks . . . The nonfiction horror story told in One of Us moves slowly, inexorably and with tremendous authority."

―Dwight Garner, The New York Times

She writes with equal intimacy about Breivik's victims, tracing their political awakenings, aspirations to improve their country, and ill-fated journeys to the island. By the time Seierstad reaches Utøya, we know both the killer and those he will kill. We have also gotten to know an entire country-famously peaceful and prosperous, and utterly incapable of protecting its youth.

Title: Where'd You Go, Bernadette?
Subtitle: A Novel
Summary: When eccentric architect Bernadette Fox disappears from Seattle, her teenage daughter pieces together emails, documents, and letters to uncover the truth. Semple’s comic novel is a sharp satire of modern life and family bonds.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Bernadette Fox is notorious. To her Microsoft-guru husband, she's a fearlessly opinionated partner; to fellow private-school mothers in Seattle, she's a disgrace; to design mavens, she's a revolutionary architect; and to 15-year-old Bee, she is her best friend and, simply, Mom.

Then Bernadette vanishes. It all began when Bee aced her report card and claimed her promised reward: a family trip to Antarctica. But Bernadette's intensifying allergy to Seattle—and people in general—has made her so agoraphobic that a virtual assistant in India now runs her most basic errands. A trip to the end of the earth is problematic.

To find her mother, Bee compiles email messages, official documents, and secret correspondence—creating a compulsively readable and surprisingly touching novel about misplaced genius and a mother and daughter's role in an absurd world.

Short_Summary: A misanthropic matriarch leaves her eccentric family in crisis when she mysteriously disappears in this "whip-smart and divinely funny" novel,
Long_Summary:
Bernadette Fox is notorious. To her Microsoft-guru husband, she's a fearlessly opinionated partner; to fellow private-school mothers in Seattle, she's a disgrace; to design mavens, she's a revolutionary architect; and to 15-year-old Bee, she is her best friend and, simply, Mom.

Then Bernadette vanishes. It all began when Bee aced her report card and claimed her promised reward: a family trip to Antarctica. But Bernadette's intensifying allergy to Seattle -- and people in general -- has made her so agoraphobic that a virtual assistant in India now runs her most basic errands. A trip to the end of the earth is problematic.

To find her mother, Bee compiles email messages, official documents, and secret correspondence -- creating a compulsively readable and surprisingly touching novel about misplaced genius and a mother and daughter's role in an absurd world.

Title: Colored Television
Subtitle: A Novel
Summary: Senna’s latest novel delves into family secrets, racial identity, and the complexities of American life, told with her trademark wit and incisiveness. A GMA Book Club selection, it blends social commentary with intimate drama.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Jane has high hopes her life is about to turn around. After years of living precariously, she, her painter husband Lenny, and their two kids have landed a house-sitting gig in a luxurious home high in the hills above Los Angeles. The timing feels magical—it coincides perfectly with Jane's sabbatical. If she can just finish her latest novel, Nusu Nusu, the centuries-spanning epic Lenny calls her "mulatto War and Peace," she'll have tenure and finally grasp some semblance of stability and success.

But things don't work out as hoped. In search of a plan B, Jane turns her desperate gaze to Hollywood like countless writers before her. When she finaggles a meeting with a hot young producer who has a seven-figure deal to create "diverse content" for a streaming network, he seems excited to work with a "real writer." He envisions creating the greatest biracial comedy ever to hit the small screen.

Things finally seem to be going right for Jane—until they go terribly wrong. Funny, piercing, and page-turning, this is Senna's most razor-sharp novel yet.
Refined_Short_Summary: When a struggling writer's academic dreams crumble, she pivots to Hollywood's diversity machine with disastrous results. Sharp, hilarious, and painfully relatable—perfect for fans of The Other Black Girl and Yellowface.
Refined_Bio: Danzy Senna is the bestselling author of six books, including Caucasia, New People, and Colored Television. The recipient of numerous awards and honors, she teaches writing at the University of Southern California.
Formatted_Quotes:
"There is no one else who writes like Senna. In all her books she tackles so many different subjects, all the while telling a story with characters so real and compelling you never think about how many ideas are being developed, and discussed, only that you want to find out what happens next, and how the ideas and the characters and the story will coalesce, all the way up until the last page, when you won't want it to have to end."

—Tommy Orange, The Guardian

"I couldn't stop turning the pages, and only when it was all over did I realize what Senna had done. Addictive, hilarious and relatable, yes, but Colored Television is after something larger and more elusive, a very modern reckoning with the ambiguities triangulated by race, class, creativity and love. She nails it."

—Miranda July, author of All Fours and The First Bad Man

"If you thought California was burning before, wait until you read how literary arsonist Danzy Senna gleefully incinerates its values through the eyes of Jane Gibson—a heroine whose insecurity, mistakes, and lies will keep you riveted from start to finish."

—James Hannaham, author of Delicious Foods and Nobody Gives a Shit What Happened to Carlotta

Title: The Furrows
Subtitle: A Novel
Summary: Haunted by the death of her brother, Cassandra grows up caught between memory, grief, and shifting identities. Serpell’s formally daring novel explores the fractures of trauma and the unreliability of narrative.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Cassandra Williams is twelve; her little brother Wayne is seven. One day, when they're alone together, there is an accident and Wayne is lost forever. His body is never recovered.

The missing boy cleaves the family with doubt. Their father leaves, starts another family elsewhere. But their mother can't give up hope and launches an organization dedicated to missing children.

As C grows older, she sees her brother everywhere: in bistros, airplane aisles, subway cars. Here is her brother's older face, the light in his eyes, the way he seems to recognize her, too. But it can't be, of course. Or can it?

Then one day, in another accident, C meets a man both mysterious and familiar, a man who is also searching for someone and for his own place in the world. His name is Wayne.

Serpell's remarkable novel captures the uncanny experience of grief, the way the past breaks over the present like waves in the sea. The Furrows is a bold exploration of memory and mourning that twists unexpectedly into a story of mistaken identity, double consciousness, and the wishful longing for reunion with those we've lost.
Refined_Short_Summary: When a family tragedy leaves a brother missing, grief becomes a lifelong haunting. This inventive exploration of loss and memory will remind you why Serpell is one of our most essential voices.
Refined_Bio: Namwali Serpell was born in Lusaka and lives in New York. She received a 2020 Windham-Campbell Prize, the 2015 Caine Prize for African Writing, and a 2011 Rona Jaffe Foundation Writers' Award. Her debut novel, The Old Drift, won the Anisfield-Wolf Book Award, the Arthur C. Clarke Award, and the Los Angeles Times' Art Seidenbaum Award for First Fiction. Her nonfiction book, Stranger Faces, was a National Book Critics Circle Award finalist. She is a professor of English at Harvard.

"Stylistically refreshing and emotionally intense, cementing Serpell's place among the best writers going."

—Kirkus

"With warmth and dexterity, Serpell has crafted a narrative that underscores how loss can show us the depths of our love."

—Time

"A genuine tour de force."

—Jonathan Lethem

Title_Subtitle: The Woman Who Lost Her Soul
Title: The Woman Who Lost Her Soul
Summary: A sweeping political thriller that spans five decades and multiple continents, this novel examines espionage, war, and moral compromise through the story of a woman entangled in global conflicts.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Renowned for his award-winning portraits of the Caribbean, Bob Shacochis delivers a sweeping epic of love, espionage, and betrayal. Beginning in occupied Haiti in the 1990s, humanitarian lawyer Tom Harrington investigates the murder of photojournalist Jackie Scott, a woman with a mysterious past and dangerous ties. His search pulls him into a world of corruption, guerrilla warfare, and haunting memories of his own connection to Jackie and Special Forces officer Eville Burnette.

Spanning fifty years and four countries—from World War II Dubrovnik to Istanbul in the 1980s—Jackie's shadowy family history unfolds, shaped by her Cold War-era father and her own desperate attempts to escape his grip. Shacochis masterfully entwines personal drama with global conflict to create a magnum opus that traces the tangled roots of America's pre-9/11 identity and the forces that shaped the world we live in today.
Refined_Short_Summary: When a photojournalist is murdered in Haiti, a lawyer's investigation uncovers decades of espionage and family secrets spanning four countries. Perfect for readers who devoured The Seven Husbands of Evelyn Hugo's sweeping timeline and complex characters.
Refined_Bio: Bob Shacochis's debut story collection Easy in the Islands won the National Book Award, and his second, The Next New World, received the Prix de Rome from the American Academy of Arts and Letters. He's the author of Swimming in the Volcano, a National Book Award finalist; The Immaculate Invasion, a finalist for The New Yorker Book Award; and The Woman Who Lost Her Soul, winner of the Dayton Peace Prize and a Pulitzer Prize finalist. A contributing editor at Outside and former GQ columnist, he's written for Harper's, The New York Times, The Washington Post, and The Wall Street Journal.
Formatted_Quotes:
"Engrossing...a soaring literary epic about the ­forces that have driven us to the 9/11 age....Shacochis darts around the globe over the span of five decades like a sorcerer of world history: Locations shift, time swirls, characters reappear in new disguises with new names. He's always so relentlessly captivating that you don't dare fall behind."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

"National Book Award—winning novelist Shacochis makes a long-awaited—indeed, much-anticipated—return to fiction with this stunning novel of love, innocence and honor lost... The wait was worth it... Shacochis has delivered a work that belongs alongside Joseph Conrad and Graham Greene... [The Woman Who Lost Her Soul] moves like a fast-flowing river, and it is memorably, smartly written... An often depressing, cautionary and thoroughly excellent tale of the excesses of empire, ambition and the too easily fragmented human soul."

—Kirkus

"This big beauty of a book was worth the wait. It's tinglingly ambitious, vast in scope, and magnificently written. I could unerringly pick a Bob Shacochis sentence out of a police line-up of sentences, which is just about the highest praise I can offer to any writer."

—Michael Cunningham

Title: House of Stone
Subtitle: A Memoir of Home, Family, and a Lost Middle East
Summary: Pulitzer Prize–winning journalist Shadid reflects on rebuilding his ancestral home in Lebanon while chronicling the region’s turbulent history.
Refined_Long_Summary:
In spring 2011, Anthony Shadid was one of four New York Times reporters captured in Libya, cuffed and beaten, as that country was seized by revolution. When he was freed, he didn't go home to Boston or Beirut—where he lived—or to Oklahoma City, where his Lebanese-American family had settled. Instead, he returned to his great-grandfather's estate, a house he had begun rebuilding three years earlier.

House of Stone chronicles both a battle-scarred home and a war correspondent's jostled spirit, revealing how reconstructing one came to fortify the other. In this poignant memoir, the author of the award-winning Night Draws Near creates a mosaic of past and present, tracing the house's renewal alongside his family's flight from Lebanon and resettlement in America.

Shadid memorializes a lost world while documenting the shifting Middle East, providing profound insights into this volatile landscape. House of Stone becomes an unforgettable meditation on war, exile, rebirth, and the universal yearning for home.
Refined_Short_Summary: After being held captive in Libya, war correspondent Anthony Shadid returns to rebuild his great-grandfather's house in Lebanon. This powerful memoir weaves together family history, Middle Eastern politics, and the healing power of reconstruction.
Refined_Bio: Anthony Shadid (1968-2012), author of Night Draws Near, was an unparalleled chronicler of the human stories behind the news. He won the Pulitzer Prize for his front-page reports from Iraq in the Washington Post, then earned his second Pulitzer in 2010 as Middle East correspondent for the New York Times, covering the Arab Spring from Egypt to Libya to Syria. Tragically, he died while on assignment in Syria on February 16, 2012.
Formatted_Quotes:
"An honest-to-god, hands-down, undeniable and instant classic . . . written with levity and candor and lyricism that makes the book, improbably, both a compulsive read and one you don't want to end."

—Dave Eggers, author of A Hologram for the King

"This is not just the Arab world's Year in Provence. It is as if Shadid has combined the breakthrough effects of Amy Tan's The Joy Luck Club, William Faulkner's As I Lay Dying,and Frances Fitzgerald's Fire in the Lake into one enormously likeable book. It is a masterpiece."

—John Freeman, Boston Globe

"Elegiac, heartbreaking . . . A book conceived as an introspective project of personal recovery — as well as a meditation on politics, identity, craft, and beauty in the Levant — now stands as a memorial. It is a fitting one because of the writing skill and deep feeling [Shadid] unobtrusively displays."

—Steve Coll, The New York Times

"House of Stone is a haunting, beautifully realized piece of writing."

—Nick Flynn, author of The Ticking Is the Bomb

"What a beautiful introduction to a world that I knew so little about. House of Stone is engaging, poignant, and funny."

—Abraham Verghese, author of The Covenant of Water & Cutting for Stone
Short_Summary: A compelling saga of redemption and renewal from two-time Pulitzer Prize-winner Anthony Shadid tells the story of rebuilding his family's ancestral home in Lebanon amid political strife, and his eventual understanding of the emotions behind the turbulence in the Middle East.
Long_Summary:
In spring 2011, Anthony Shadid was one of four New York Times reporters captured in Libya, cuffed and beaten, as that country was seized by revolution. When he was freed, he went home. Not to Boston or Beirut—where he lives— or to Oklahoma City, where his Lebanese-American family had settled and where he was raised. Instead, he returned to his great-grandfather’s estate, a house that, over three years earlier, Shadid had begun to rebuild.

House of Stone is the story of a battle-scarred home and a war correspondent’s jostled spirit, and of how reconstructing the one came to fortify the other. In this poignant and resonant memoir, the author of the award-winning Night Draws Near creates a mosaic of past and present, tracing the house’s renewal alongside his family’s flight from Lebanon and resettlement in America. In the process, Shadid memorializes a lost world, documents the shifting Middle East, and provides profound insights into this volatile landscape. Title: Ordinary Notes
BISAC_Category_Description: Social Science / Cultural & Ethnic Studies / American / African American & Black Studies
Summary: Sharpe offers a mosaic of essays and reflections on Black life, history, and art, written with lyrical precision and depth.
Refined_Long_Summary:
A singular achievement, Ordinary Notes explores profound questions about loss and the shapes of Black life that emerge in the wake. In a series of 248 notes that gather meaning as we read them, Christina Sharpe skillfully weaves artifacts from the past—public ones alongside others that are poignantly personal—with present realities and possible futures.

At the heart of this work is the indelible presence of the author's mother, Ida Wright Sharpe. "I learned to see in my mother's house," writes Sharpe. "My mother gifted me a love of beauty, a love of words." Using these gifts, Sharpe steadily summons a chorus of voices and experiences to the page.

She practices an aesthetic of "beauty as a method," collects entries from a community of thinkers toward a "Dictionary of Untranslatable Blackness," and rigorously examines sites of memory and memorial. In the process, she forges a brilliant new literary form, as multivalent as the ways of Black being it traces.
Refined_Short_Summary: Through 248 interconnected notes, Sharpe weaves personal artifacts and memories into a profound meditation on Black existence and beauty. Perfect for readers who found meaning in The Fire Next Time or Beloved.
Refined_Bio: Christina Sharpe is the author of In the Wake: On Blackness and Being—named by The Guardian as one of the best books of 2016—and Monstrous Intimacies: Making Post-Slavery Subjects. She is the Canada Research Chair in Black Studies in the Humanities at York University in Toronto, where she lives.
Formatted_Quotes:
"A deft blend of memoir, theory, archival documents and lyrical reflections. . . . [Ordinary Notes] build[s] into a mosaic that holds the relentless terror of Black life as well as its undeniable beauty. . . . By turning her gaze inward, Sharpe offers a framework for understanding how to move forward, even when burdened by all the knowledge of the world's cruelty. . . . [Sharpe's] most liberating and poetic experiment yet."

—The New York Times

"A genre-defying, impressionistic series of meditations on history, identity, and the way we live now."

—Toronto Star

"Ordinary Notes is like an intellectual ice climb—you move along a careful series of handholds to cross a terrain that might otherwise seem impassable, and afterward, you are amazed at the passage. At once an act of careful attention and a juxtaposition of observations and questions, the result is a powerful vision of American life, drawn from the Black intellectual history and aesthetics that Sharpe has cultivated as the means to her own liberation, so that she might offer it to others."

—Alexander Chee, author of How to Write An Autobiographical Novel
Short_Summary: The critically acclaimed author of In the Wake, "Christina Sharpe is a brilliant thinker who attends unflinchingly to the brutality of our current arrangements . . . and yet always finds a way to beauty and possibility" (Saidiya Hartman).
Long_Summary:
A singular achievement, Ordinary Notes explores profound questions about loss and the shapes of Black life that emerge in the wake. In a series of 248 notes that gather meaning as we read them, Christina Sharpe skillfully weaves artifacts from the past—public ones alongside others that are poignantly personal—with present realities and possible futures, intricately constructing an immersive portrait of everyday Black existence. The themes and tones that echo through these pages, sometimes about language, beauty, memory; sometimes about history, art, photography, and literature—always attend, with exquisite care, to the ordinary-extraordinary dimensions of Black life.

At the heart of Ordinary Notes is the indelible presence of the author’s mother, Ida Wright Sharpe. “I learned to see in my mother’s house,” writes Sharpe. “I learned how not to see in my mother’s house . . . My mother gifted me a love of beauty, a love of words.” Using these gifts and other ways of seeing, Sharpe steadily summons a chorus of voices and experiences to the page. She practices an aesthetic of "beauty as a method,” collects entries from a community of thinkers toward a “Dictionary of Untranslatable Blackness,” and rigorously examines sites of memory and memorial. And in the process, she forges a brilliant new literary form, as multivalent as the ways of Black being it traces.

She is currently the Canada Research Chair in Black Studies in the Humanities at York University, in Toronto, Canada, where she lives.

Title: The History of Sound
Subtitle: Stories
Summary: Set in World War I–era New England, these linked stories trace lives shaped by love, art, and memory. Shattuck’s prose is lyrical and elegiac, suffused with the ache of time passing.
Refined_Long_Summary:
In twelve luminous stories spanning three centuries, The History of Sound examines the unexpected ways the past returns to us and how love and loss transform across generations. Ben Shattuck's ingenious collection pairs each story with a companion that reveals hidden truths about its predecessor—mysteries and murders surface, history refracts, and deep emotional connections weave through characters and families.

The haunting title story follows two men who meet around a piano in a smoky bar, then spend a summer walking the Maine woods collecting folk songs in the shadow of World War I, forever marked by their odyssey. Decades later, a woman discovers their wax cylinders while cleaning out her new Maine house.

Shattuck's inventive stories transport readers from 1700s Nantucket to contemporary New Hampshire forests. Memories, artifacts, paintings, and journals resurface in surprising ways among evocative beaches and orchards, revealing secrets, misunderstandings, and enduring love that echo across centuries. Written with breathtaking humanity and humor, this collection serves as both a love letter to New England and a moving meditation on our abiding search for home.
Refined_Short_Summary: Twelve interconnected stories spanning three centuries reveal how the past echoes through generations in unexpected ways. Perfect for readers who loved The Midnight Library's exploration of connection across time.
Refined_Bio: Ben Shattuck is the author of Six Walks: In the Footsteps of Henry David Thoreau, a New Yorker Best Book of 2022, Wall Street Journal Best Book of Spring, New York Times Best Book of Summer, New England Indie Bestseller, and Massachusetts Book Award nominee. An Iowa Writers' Workshop graduate, he's won the PEN/Robert J. Dau Short Story Prize for Emerging Writers and a Pushcart Prize. He lives with his wife and daughter on the Massachusetts coast, where he owns and runs America's oldest general store, built in 1793, and directs the Cuttyhunk Island Writers' Residency.
Formatted_Quotes:
"A magnificent collection about love, longing, and New England history. . . . Shattuck shines especially in his depiction of nature. . . . Deeply felt and impeccably researched, these exquisite stories capture the spirit of the Northeast."

—Publishers Weekly

"Exquisitely crafted, deeply imagined, exhilaratingly diverse, The History of Sound places Ben Shattuck firmly among the very finest of our storytellers."

—Geraldine Brooks, New York Times bestselling author of Horse

"In braiding themselves together, The History of Sound's stories generate the most ingenious and pleasing and moving evocation of New England, in all its seasonal and geographic variety. Over time—from 1696 to Radiolab—mysteries posed in one story are off-handedly addressed years later in another, protagonists become someone else's minor character, and fates are meted out as each new narrative throws a crucial contextualizing light upon the other. Ben Shattuck is a devoted magpie: these stories celebrate the earth's music and bounty, and remind us how diminished we are when severed from who and what we loved."

—Jim Shepard, author of The Book of Aron and Like You'd Understand, Anyway
Short_Summary: A stunning collection of interconnected stories set in New England, exploring how the past is often misunderstood and how history, family, heartache, and desire can echo over centuries
Long_Summary:
In twelve luminous stories set across three centuries, The History of Sound examines the unexpected ways the past returns to us and how love and loss are entwined and transformed over generations. In Ben Shattuck's ingenious collection, each story has a companion story, which contains a revelation about the previous, paired story. Mysteries and murders are revealed, history is refracted, and deep emotional connections are woven through characters and families.

The haunting title story recalls the journey of two men who meet around a piano in a smoky, dim bar, only to spend a summer walking the Maine woods collecting folk songs in the shadow of the First World War, forever marked by the odyssey. Decades later, in another story, a woman discovers the wax cylinders recorded that fateful summer while cleaning out her new house in Maine. Shattuck’s inventive, exquisite stories transport readers from 1700s Nantucket to the contemporary woods of New Hampshire and beyond—into landscapes both enduring and unmistakably modern. Memories, artifacts, paintings, and journals resurface in surprising and poignant ways among evocative beaches, forests, and orchards, revealing the secrets, misunderstandings, and love that linger across centuries.

Written with breathtaking humanity and humor, The History of Sound is a love letter to New England, a radiant conversation between past and present, and a moving meditation on the abiding search for home.

Title: The Book of Aron
Subtitle: A novel
Summary: Told from the perspective of a young boy in the Warsaw Ghetto, this novel captures innocence amidst horror. Shepard balances stark tragedy with piercing humanity in a story of resilience.
Refined_Long_Summary:
Aron is an engaging but troubled young boy whose family flees the German invasion from the Polish countryside into Warsaw, where they face mounting deprivation, disease, and persecution. To keep their families alive, Aron and a small group of children risk everything by smuggling contraband through the ghetto's quarantine walls, constantly hunted by blackmailers and Jewish, Polish, and German police—not to mention the Gestapo.

When Aron's family is finally torn away, he finds refuge with Janusz Korczak, a doctor celebrated throughout prewar Europe as a champion of children's rights who now runs the Warsaw orphanage under Nazi rule. Though Treblinka awaits them all, the question remains: can Aron escape as his mentor believes possible, and live to bear witness to these atrocities?

Jim Shepard masterfully crafts this child's-eye view of humanity's darkest chapter into something mesmerizing—sometimes unexpectedly comic, truly heartbreaking, and ultimately inspiring. Aron's unforgettable voice will stay with readers long after the final page.
Refined_Short_Summary: When young Aron's family is torn apart in the Warsaw ghetto, he's taken in by the renowned Dr. Janusz Korczak at his orphanage. This devastating yet beautiful novel captures the Holocaust through a child's eyes with unexpected humor and hope.
Refined_Bio: Jim Shepard is the author of seven novels, including The Book of Aron (winner of the PEN New England Award, the Sophie Brody Medal, the Ribalow Prize, and the Clark Fiction Prize, and a finalist for the National Jewish Book Award), and five story collections, including Like You'd Understand, Anyway, a National Book Award finalist and winner of The Story Prize. His fiction appears in The New Yorker, Harper's Magazine, The Paris Review, and The Atlantic, and has been anthologized in The Best American Short Stories and The PEN/O. Henry Prize Stories. He teaches at Williams College.
Formatted_Quotes:
"Shepard has created a stark masterpiece. His brilliant, iconic book ranks with the best literature that explores the dark side of the human soul."

—Linda Diebel, The Toronto Star

"An immensely rewarding, shocking and beautiful book. . . . Shepard, who for years has been one of this country's greatest fiction writers, is as original here as he has ever been. . . . Aron himself becomes an unforgettable character almost instantly."

—Michael Schaub, NPR

"A masterpiece. . . a remarkable novel destined to join the shelf of essential Holocaust literature. . . . a story of such startling candor about the complexity of heroism that it challenges each of us to greater courage. . . . Shepard has created something transcendent and timeless."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post
Short_Summary: The acclaimed National Book Award finalist—“one of the United States’ finest writers,” according to Joshua Ferris, “full of wit, humanity, and fearless curiosity”—now gives us a novel that will join the short list of classics about children caught up in the Holocaust.
Long_Summary:
Aron, the narrator, is an engaging if peculiar and unhappy young boy whose family is driven by the German onslaught from the Polish countryside into Warsaw and slowly battered by deprivation, disease, and persecution. He and a handful of boys and girls risk their lives by scuttling around the ghetto to smuggle and trade contraband through the quarantine walls in hopes of keeping their fathers, mothers, brothers, and sisters alive, hunted all the while by blackmailers and by Jewish, Polish, and German police, not to mention the Gestapo.

When his family is finally stripped away from him, Aron is rescued by Janusz Korczak, a doctor renowned throughout prewar Europe as an advocate of children’s rights who, once the Nazis swept in, was put in charge of the Warsaw orphanage. Treblinka awaits them all, but does Aron manage to escape—as his mentor suspected he could—to spread word about the atrocities?
Jim Shepard has masterfully made this child’s-eye view of the darkest history mesmerizing, sometimes comic despite all odds, truly heartbreaking, and even inspiring. Anyone who hears Aron’s voice will remember it forever.

His fiction has appeared in The New Yorker, Harper’s Magazine, The Paris Review, The Atlantic, and many others, and has been anthologized in The Best American Short Stories and The PEN/O. Title: Great Circle
Subtitle: A novel
Summary: An ambitious aviatrix disappears during a 1950s polar flight, her life later rediscovered by a scandal-plagued Hollywood actress. Shipstead’s sweeping novel spans continents and eras in a dazzling tale of freedom and reinvention.
Refined_Long_Summary:
After being rescued as infants from a sinking ocean liner in 1914, Marian and Jamie Graves are raised by their dissolute uncle in Missoula, Montana. When a pair of barnstorming pilots pass through town in beat-up biplanes, Marian begins her lifelong love affair with flight.

At fourteen she drops out of school and finds an unexpected patron in a wealthy bootlegger who provides a plane and subsidizes her lessons—an arrangement that will haunt her for the rest of her life, even as it allows her to fulfill her destiny: circumnavigating the globe by flying over the North and South Poles.

A century later, Hadley Baxter is cast to play Marian in a film centered on the aviator's mysterious disappearance in Antarctica. Vibrant and disgusted with Hollywood's claustrophobia, Hadley is eager to redefine herself after a romantic film franchise imprisoned her in cult celebrity. Her immersion into Marian's character unfolds alongside the aviator's own story, as two women's fates—and their hunger for self-determination across vastly different times and places—collide in this epic, meticulously researched novel.
Refined_Short_Summary: Spanning a century, this follows daredevil aviator Marian Graves and modern actress Hadley Baxter as their stories intertwine. Think The Seven Husbands of Evelyn Hugo meets early aviation history—ambitious, sweeping, and utterly captivating.
Refined_Bio: Maggie Shipstead is the New York Times-bestselling author of three novels and a short story collection. Her novel Great Circle was shortlisted for the Booker Prize and is a finalist for the Women's Prize. A graduate of the Iowa Writers' Workshop, she's received a fellowship from the National Endowment for the Arts and won the Dylan Thomas Prize and the L.A. Times Book Prize for First Fiction. She lives in Los Angeles.
Formatted_Quotes:
"A soaring work of historical fiction . . . So convincingly does Shipstead stitch her fictional heroine into the daring flight paths of early aviators that you'll be convinced that you remember the tragic day her plane disappeared. Great Circle is a relentlessly exciting story about a woman maneuvering her way between tradition and prejudice to get what she wants. It's also a culturally rich story that takes full advantage of its extended length to explore the changing landscape of the 20th century. My top recommendation for this summer."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

"A feat of a story in every sense."

—Entertainment Weekly

"The destinies of [Shipstead's] unforgettable characters intersect in ways that reverberate through a hundred years of story. Whether Shipstead is creating scenes in the Prohibition-era American West, in wartime London, or on a Hollywood movie set, her research is as invisible as it should be, allowing a fully immersive experience. Ingeniously structured and so damn entertaining; this novel is as ambitious as its heroines—but it never falls from the sky."

—Kirkus
Short_Summary: The unforgettable story of a daredevil female aviator determined to chart her own course in life, at any cost
Long_Summary:
After being rescued as infants from a sinking ocean liner in 1914, Marian and Jamie Graves are raised by their dissolute uncle in Missoula, Montana. There--after encountering a pair of barnstorming pilots passing through town in beat-up biplanes--Marian commences her lifelong love affair with flight. At fourteen she drops out of school and finds an unexpected and dangerous patron in a wealthy bootlegger who provides a plane and subsidizes her lessons, an arrangement that will haunt her for the rest of her life, even as it allows her to fulfill her destiny: circumnavigating the globe by flying over the North and South Poles.

A century later, Hadley Baxter is cast to play Marian in a film that centers on Marian's disappearance in Antarctica. Vibrant, canny, disgusted with the claustrophobia of Hollywood, Hadley is eager to redefine herself after a romantic film franchise has imprisoned her in the grip of cult celebrity. Her immersion into the character of Marian unfolds, thrillingly, alongside Marian's own story, as the two women's fates--and their hunger for self-determination in vastly different geographies and times--collide. Epic and emotional, meticulously researched and gloriously told, Great Circle is a monumental work of art, and a tremendous leap forward for the prodigiously gifted Maggie Shipstead.

Title: Super Sad True Love Story
Subtitle: A Novel
Summary: In a near-future America on the brink of collapse, a middle-aged man falls for a young woman obsessed with youth and technology. Shteyngart delivers a biting satire of love, consumerism, and political decay.
Refined_Long_Summary:
In a very near future—oh, let's say next Tuesday—a functionally illiterate America is about to collapse. But don't tell that to poor Lenny Abramov, the thirty-nine-year-old son of an angry Russian immigrant janitor, proud author of what may well be the world's last diary, and less-proud owner of a bald spot shaped like the great state of Ohio.

Despite his job at Post-Human Services, which attempts to provide immortality for its super-rich clientele, death is clearly stalking this cholesterol-rich morsel of a man. Lenny's from a different century—he totally loves books (or "printed, bound media artifacts," as they're now known), even though most of his peers find them smelly and annoying. But even more than books, Lenny loves Eunice Park, an impossibly cute and impossibly cruel twenty-four-year-old Korean American woman who just graduated from Elderbird College with a major in Images and a minor in Assertiveness.

After meeting on an extended Roman holiday, blistering Eunice puts that Assertiveness minor to work, teaching our "ancient dork" effective new ways to brush his teeth and making him buy a cottony nonflammable wardrobe. But America proves less flame-resistant than Lenny's new threads. The country is crushed by a credit crisis, riots break out in Central Park, National Guard tanks line the city's streets, and our patient Chinese creditors may just be ready to foreclose on the whole mess.

Undeterred, Lenny vows to love both Eunice and his homeland, determined to prove there's still value in being a real human being.
Refined_Short_Summary: When a book-obsessed thirty-nine-year-old falls for a cruel twenty-four-year-old in a collapsing America, hilarity and heartbreak ensue. Black Mirror meets romantic comedy in this prescient satire about technology, love, and what makes us human.
Refined_Bio: Gary Shteyngart was born in Leningrad in 1972 and came to the United States seven years later. His debut novel, The Russian Debutante's Handbook, won the Stephen Crane Award for First Fiction and the National Jewish Book Award for Fiction. Absurdistan was named one of the 10 Best Books of the Year by The New York Times Book Review. Super Sad True Love Story won the Bollinger Everyman Wodehouse Prize, while his memoir Little Failure was a National Book Critics Circle Award finalist. His most recent novel is the New York Times bestseller Our Country Friends.
Formatted_Quotes:
"[A] smart send-up of our info-overload age… Love Story is funny, on-target, and ultimately sad as it captures the absurdity and anxiety of navigating an increasingly out-of-control world."

—Entertainment Weekly

"This cyber-apocalyptic vision of an American future seems eerily like the present, in a bleak comedy that is even more frightening than funny. Though Shteyngart received rave reviews for his first two novels (The Russian Debutante's Daughter, 2001; Absurdistan, 2006), those appear in retrospect to be trial runs for his third and darkest to date."

—Kirkus

"[A] profane and dizzying satire, a dystopic vision of the future as convincing-and, in its way, as frightening as Cormac McCarthy's The Road. It's also a pointedly old-fashioned May-December love story. . . . a heartbreaker worthy of its title, this is Shteyngart's best yet."

—Publishers Weekly

Title: Our Country Friends
Subtitle: A Novel
Summary: During the early months of the pandemic, a group of friends gathers at a country house, where love, envy, and betrayal unfold. Shteyngart’s comic yet tender novel captures a world on the edge of crisis.
Refined_Long_Summary:
It's March 2020 and a calamity is unfolding. A group of friends and friends-of-friends gathers in a country house to wait out the pandemic. Over the next six months, new friendships and romances will take hold while old betrayals emerge, forcing each character to reevaluate whom they love and what matters most.

The unlikely cast includes a Russian-born novelist; his Russian-born psychiatrist wife; their precocious child obsessed with K-pop; a struggling Indian American writer; a wildly successful Korean American app developer; a global dandy with three passports; a young flame-thrower of an essayist from the Carolinas; and a movie star whose arrival upsets the equilibrium of this chosen family.

In a remarkable literary feat, Gary Shteyngart has documented through fiction the emotional toll of our recent times. Both elegiac and very funny, Our Country Friends reads like a great Russian novel set in upstate New York—the most ambitious book yet by the author of the beloved bestseller Super Sad True Love Story.
Refined_Short_Summary: When the pandemic hits, eight friends retreat to a country house where romance blooms and old secrets surface. Shteyngart delivers Chekhov-level drama with his signature humor—perfect for readers who loved The Midnight Library's exploration of connection.
Refined_Bio: Gary Shteyngart was born in Leningrad in 1972 and came to the United States seven years later.
